description:
Thank you Wayz for getting us lost and no where near where we were trying to get to but luckily as we stepped out of the car, and everything around us didn't seem too appetizing. So we yelped Ramen and this place popped up within walking distance. As we arrived, there were only two tables...it was after 10pm. So I am not sure if we beat the crowd or that no one knows yet how tastey this place is. 
The one waitress was really nice and friendly, greeted us with a smile, answered all my questions. They even have a Japanese bar and tap as well, which is pretty cool.
There is a free Yelp check in offer, but what it says, might not be, as it changes, depending on the night and what they have left. That night they were giving out the wakame.
I got the Chicken Karaage, and man was it yummy! I loved how they brought the karaage on a separate plate, keeps it nicely crispy. The broth was super tastey and so hot. It stayed hot the whole time...which is how to do it..."ahem *cough* kopan in fullerton" can learn a tip or two. 
I loved the corn in my soup. So much that every bite had a good amount. I really enjoyed my ramen. I don't know if it was because I was hungry or it was that good...but I was singing to myself...I have ramen...I got ramen..hey hey hey hey...hehehe...
I will def come back...this place will now be on my yummy list!!!
author: An N.

description:
Synopsis: 

Loungey spot off Geary for decent ramen.

Purpose:

Was in the area and opted not to have Chinese food off Clement Street.

Time:

6:00 pm on a Thursday

Service:

Friendly but not overbearing.

Food: 

*Beef and Green Onion -  green onion wrapped in sliced sirloin with soy sauce. Came with two skewers. This was just okay, probably would not get it again.

*Garlic Rib Ramen - Sliced roasted garlic, pork soft bone, half boiled egg and spinach in tonkotsu base. The broth was rich and slightly oily. The braised rib was fall off the bone tender.  The egg was not soft boiled, but hard boiled which was a tad disappointing. Ramen had a nice chew factor.  It wasn't the best ramen I've had, but it wasn't bad.

*Hamachi Kama - grilled kamachi with citrus ponzu sauce. This item took a good 20-25 minutes to arrive to the point where most of us at the table had finished with their food before this item came out.  They weren't super busy, actually there were only 3 other tables besides us, so it was surprising it took so long as the grill wasn't that busy.

Price/Value:

Average price for ramen these days $9-11.

Ambiance: 

Loungey feel. Some of the seats were a bit ripped. I can see this place being popular later in the night.

Parking:

Street metered parking.

Return:

Not likely if I'm craving ramen, there are other places to choose from.
author: Drea L.

description: Ordered #411 and it was alright. Meat tasted a bit over cooked and egg wasn't runny at all. However the service was good and attentive and they give you Hi Chews at the end as the bill mint. It's a good venue for large groups and they do have a big variety of options. Yelp checkin is for seaweed salad and only one per group...even if you have 10+ people...
author: Jonathan C.

description: The ramen is very flavorful, presentation is also nice.  I've been here a couple times and it never disappoint. My companies said the portions are smaller than other ramen places, but I thought it's fine with me. It's perfect for my appetite. And I don't want leftover to bring home. Overall, the ramen is worth trying and it's delicious.
author: Sandy S.

description:
I'll admit-- I kinda just tried out this spot to round out my sampling of Japanese restaurants across all the delivery platforms. C'est la vie of non-hobby hobbies when you're inside 80 hours a week....

I had the tonkotsu ramen with cha shu (pork) and a ribeye skewer. The broth flavor wasn't as "piggy" as some of the other spots I've had, but was also a bit more salty and not as complex / creamy as some of those other spots. The noodles themselves were pretty al dente and had conformed to the shape of the box by the time they arrived on delivery (totally understandable). The cha shu was a bit on the dry side of things, but they provided four pieces, which is pretty generous vs. some of the other ramen spots, though the pieces were sliced medium-thinly. Whoa the middle of their soy sauce egg was super salty. Eek. The soy sauce egg (half) was fully cooked through. 2.5/5. 

The ribeye skewer could have benefited from some pre-marination and was generally pretty tough. The meat itself seemed of good quality though, and I enjoyed the flavor of the fatty piece that they added in between the meater bits. 3/5.

As much as I'm trying to adopt a genki (enthusiastic / lively) mindset these days, I'll have to not be super genki on this spot for now.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Pretty interesting spot, a lot of open seating for 10 pm on a Saturday night! Came in with a group of 4, and two of our friends recommended either the garlic tenderous ramen or the mapo tofu ramen. 

Both very unusual takes on ramen, but the Mapo Tofu ramen definitely doesn't disappoint! It's spicy mapo tofu, but it's mild not as spicy as it seems. Super flavorful in each bite and the ramen noodles are soft, just the way I like it! There's also pork bits with green onions, and the soup is thicker and on the runny side, but it's not a weird texture. 

We also ordered the chicken karage and there was a soy oyster type of sauce on top! Ordered during one of the Happy Hour times (9-closing I think). Very crunchy, and well seasoned karage! 

The large hot sake was pretty yummy for a cold night. For four people you are getting two shots each which is perfect! 

Great service, very courteous and polite!
author: Erica E.

description:
The food here won't knock your socks off, but you can definitely get a large quantity of pretty good tasting food especially during happy hour.

I came here at 5:30 on a Sunday, and there were only like 3 groups here, so there was no wait, which I really appreciate; one of my pet peeves about San Francisco is having to wait for everything. Happy hour runs from 3-6 PM at after 10 PM 7 days a week (including weekends), so it's actually pretty accessible. The appetizers are $4 during happy hour, so I ordered some chicken karaage along with my chashu ramen, which was $10.95. Just FYI, lunch is served until 5 PM according to their menu.

My food all came out within 5 minutes of ordering, so it was super fast. I got a complimentary wakame salad for checking-in (they didn't have edamame or the cold tofu), which apparently is a seafood salad. It was really clean tasting, without a strong seaweed flavor, and just lightly dressed. It was definitely a good start to my meal.

Then came my chashu ramen, which was overall pretty good. Mainly, there's probably around 6 slices of sliced pork, a good handful of bamboo shoots, and noodles all in a slightly cloudy tonkotsu broth. The pork didn't really have a strong BBQ flavor, but it actually tasted pretty clean, like pork shoulder just roasted in the oven. It was actually pretty good, but didn't have that distinctive chashu taste that I was expecting. I wasn't a huge fan of the bamboo shoots, they were just kind of there and stayed out of the way. The noodles are nice and bouncy and didn't get too soaked in the broth, so no complaints there. And the broth had good substance to it and had a rich pork flavor throughout, so you could tell that they had boiled the bones well for this broth. It's not a complex flavor, but it hits the notes that it needs to.

The chicken karaage came out piping hot, but was probably the most disappointing of the 3. It was a lot of chicken, probably about 12 pieces, but the outside was a bit too heavily coated, and the inside was a bit overcooked. It wasn't dry yet, but it was headed that way. But I can't really complain because for $4, it's still a good amount of food and a good value. Plus, it was still tasty, just not the best I've had. For that same amount of chicken karaage elsewhere, you could definitely be paying up to $9-10 bucks.

The pictures can be deceiving, as I actually got a lot of food. I walked away from this restaurant full, which is really a rarity. It's a pretty unassuming place, and people aren't tripping over their feet to get here, but it is solid quality food with some very reasonable prices. The food probably won't wow you, but it gets all the basic things right for a good meal. This place is definitely worth a visit, especially if you can make it during happy hour.
author: Eric Y.

description: Genki Ramen.  Even though from its name this place sounds like it specializes in ramen, it does not.  It has a wide variety of Japanese food, such as donburi, yakisoba, and even okonomiyaki.  The menu within the ramen category is super eclectic; they have unusual (aka inauthentic) kinds such as sparerib ramen etc.  Therefore, I refused to try their ramen.  Instead, I opted for their okonomiyaki.  But I had doubted it that their okonomiyaki was authentic either.  First all, one option that came with their okonomiyaki was to "add ramen for $2", but in Japan, people put "soba" onto okonomiyaki, not "ramen".  So just from that, I knew it wasn't gonna get real okonomiyaki.  But the beef okonomiyaki with ramen that I ordered turned out to be pretty tasty.  The beef slices were too thick making them tough to chew.  The noodles were incorporated within the batter which is totally unusual since they're usually served on top of or below the okonomiyaki.  But overall it was okay.  We also ordered chicken karaage which was not good at all.  They used the wrong type of breading so they tasted more like American style chicken fingers than actual karaage, and they drizzled tonkatsu sauce over them rather than serving it on the side in case customers don't like it.  The takoyaki was delicious but hella small.
author: Kev H.

description: My husband and I LOVE Genki Ramen! We get take out or delivery almost weekly! I also enjoy eating there! They have a lot of T.V.s. Gyoza and Chicken Katsu Curry Ramen are our favorites!
author: Elise R.

description:
Genki Ramen really hit the spot. We popped in on a Friday night seeking a casual ramen and dumpling dinner. There were only three other parties besides us, so we were a little confused and unsure at first.

Our service was quick! We immediately ordered sake and beer for the table and our server promptly returned to our table with the goods. We then ordered appetizers and main dishes. 

The kimchi and dumplings came first. They were delicious bites to keep us occupied before our noodle dishes arrived. The veggie yakisoba arrived first, hot and sizzling. Next, our table received steaming, flavorful ramen. The broth was delicious! The breaded pork and chicken was tender in the inside and crunchy on the outside-- even after laying in broth. The gyoza was homemade and awesome. We enjoyed both veggie and pork, pork was a bit more notable than veggie.

By the time we left a larger crowd had slowly filtered in. I also observed a few takeout orders. Seeing an uptick in business made me feel good, since our table sincerely enjoyed our meal and I want this place to thrive so that we can come back!
author: Andrea H.

description:
My girl friend and I were around the area and we were craving ramen. We found this place on Yelp. This restaurant is pretty affordable.   

We ordered their pancakes and seafood ramen! Never had anything like their pancake but it was delicious to me. Interesting texture but very flavorful. Ramen was A-OK. It wasn't salty so that's always good news. We got our orders quick and this was during dinner time on a Saturday. 

A  quick tip, check in on Yelp and get a bowl of edamame. You're welcome :)
author: Dianna O.

description: Honestly it is a really cheap restaurant, and it has really delicious food! So much flavor! Truly amazing! I love it so much! Definitely recommend!
author: Maymo S.

description: Genki is pretty good for the price. They are open until late and perfect for a later dinner if you want ramen, but you're on a budget. The service is good. They also serve rice dishes, so there's also choices for non ramen lovers. The soup is not a thick broth. It is just a standard soupy broth. Below is the Mabo Tofu. It's not too spicy, but still has a lot of flavor. I hope to try their drinks next time because they have an interesting selection. I would definitely go to Genki again if I can't splurge on the higher quality stuff. And to be honest, a lot of those places aren't worth it!
author: Caitlyn S.

description:
A solid if somewhat unremarkable place for homemade Japanese Ramen, Genki Ramen is just one of many places where you can get you can get Japanese noodles on Geary Boulevard in San Francisco's Inner Richmond neighborhood. I came to Genki Ramen because my dining mates had been here before and wanted to take me here plus the fact that this was an affordable mom and pop place for some down home Ramen didn't hurt at all.

We came on a Saturday evening at about 7pm and the place wasn't busy at all, as I was able to get a table in the back of the restaurant. You'll notice the rich wood on all of the walls and tables that combined with all of the multitude of flat-screen televisions turned to sports programming provided a homey almost bar-like atmosphere. Since I was sitting back of the restaurant cell phone service is limited in that corner and when I asked if there was a WiFi password to their WiFi option I was immediately rebuked by a server. I must admit despite having the name of the restaurant being named Genki Ramen, the menu has much more than that including Robata grilled items, sizzling rice plates, and even Japanese pancakes!

But let's face it I was here for their signature dish, their Ramen noodles, the only problem I had was in deciding which one I was supposed to choose on their menu, as I counted no fewer than 19 noodles and soup and three cold Ramen noodle dishes. Decisions, decisions,sometimes it's worth noting that less is more when it comes to menu items. But after a long deliberation, I went with number 412 on the menu, Beef Stew Ramen made with tender, braised beef brisket, spinach, red ginger, served in a tonkatsu base. My dining mate went with a more ambitious meal option with number 703 the beef Okonomiyaki, which is a sizzling deep dish pancake served with shredded cabbage, carrot, onion, and topped with seaweed flakes, pancake sauce, mayo and bonito fish flakes. My noodles were a nicely prepared dish with beef that was nicely sliced and prepared as it were pork belly the only drawback is that I wish there were more noodles in my dish to go with all of that excess beef broth. My dining mates' pancake looked unique enough almost like a Japanese pizza, but here too I thought the quantity of food here was lacking. Thankfully Genki Ramen does have a check-in deal via the Yelp app and between a choice between the Edamame or Cold Tofu, we went with the tofu which was an amuse bouche which came topped with dipping sauce and green onions.     

All in all, we had a decent time at Genki, we were able to sit at our table and enjoy ones company as we dined on our noodles as there wasn't too much business going on to move us out. I would consider coming back for lunch perhaps, as they seemed to have some affordable options. Unique ramen dishes with a flair? Count me in all of the time for that!
author: Jason F.

description:
I needed some comfort food and ramen is one of my go-tos. We came here for a warm dinner and I got the curry ramen. To my surprise, it was actually pretty good. The ramen was good, the broth was flavorful and the katsu was tender and not dry. The service was kind of hit or miss as we kept having to search for our waitress.

Overall, not a bad ramen place.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Went here on a whim around 12:30am on a Friday night (or should I say Saturday morning) with my boyfriend, his sister, and her boyfriend. They had a long night of drinking, and her boyfriend kept insisting we go eat here after 3910. The way he was explaining it... he seemed to really like going here late nights for a simple bowl of ramen. 

I don't know of many ramen places that open late, so this is a plus for them to attract late out goers who are seeking for a warm bowl of noodles to comfort them before heading home. I was a bit skeptical at first because I figured that it was his drunk taste buds talking, but it wasn't as bad as I thought it was going to be.

The place looks a little run down. I think they can use a little update because the leather on the booths are all cracked. There's also a sour smell the second you walk in, kind of like a old mop that needs to be replaced, but its just sitting there. 

The workers were really nice! We were seated right away. They were very attentive. Our water was always filled, an someone would consistently come over to see if we needed anything.

We ordered:
Edamame (free w/ yelp check-in)- Good. The usual you would get anywhere else.

Hamachi kama- Surprisingly very good. Perfectly cooked, so it was very moist and juicy.

Minced pork ramen- The overall flavor was good, but it was very salty. My boyfriends sister couldn't even eat half of it because it was too salty.

Chasu ramen- The broth and ramen noodles were good. The pork was over cooked, so it was chewy. The egg was hard boiled and not soft boiled like you would find at most authentic ramen places. I always add corn to my ramen, but that was just a mistake here. The corn was abnormally big and kind of hard.

Would I return? Probably if I had no other options, but at least I know what I can order for next time.
author: Lily T.

description:
I would do 3.5 stars if I could. Genki ramen is an easy spot because they always have tables open and the food is solid. The ramen is tasty and really qualifies as comfort food; great for a cold day or when you're feeling a little under the weather. It's not the best ramen I"ve ever had, but it really hits the spot when you have a random ramen craving.

All of the menu options are solid choices, and I have a sweet spot in particular for the Chicken Karaage ramen. The chicken is really crispy and well seasoned. 

The service is friendly and the atmosphere is casual.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Great lunch deal! Order any ramen and get either chicken karage, fried rice or 2 piece gyoza for $1! I opted for the fried rice and it was seasoned well and not oily.
One of my pet peeves is not receiving my broth hot. Not a problem here it was piping hot and the pork was fork tender. Only thing was the egg in my ramen was hard boiled and not soft boiled ;(
author: Liz N.

description:
I'm a fan of Genki Crepes but I've never been here.  And I was not impressed with their ramen.

Food = okay. Generous portions but I'm underwhelmed by the seasoning and ramen quality.

Shrimp Tempura = Hearty portion. Good batter--not too heavy. Shrimp tempura also had sweet potato and onion.  8.50

Shrimp Tempura Ramen = She enjoyed it. $10.50.

Curry Tonkastu Ramen = Soggy ramen, and flavorless broth.  Generous pork cutlet with good curry.  Perhaps, I should've gotten a rice plate instead? $10.50 x2

Kimchi Ramen = Okay.  Kimchi helped the broth but still had soggy noodles. $10.95

Coke = $2.50

Service = friendly.

Prices = reasonable to moderate.  Dinner for four came out to $60.71.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Great delivery experience!

We got the teriyaki chicken, katsu chicken curry and grilled onigiri.
Order came in less than 45 minutes! And everything was there, labeled and well packaged so nothing had spilled.

Food was good, nothing crazy but it was just what I wanted.
I asked for the curry on the side and they did it. Katsu was crunchy and tasty. Curry was a little too salty and a bit spicy, but Japanese curry usually tastes like this.
The onigiri was really good, a little sweet and crunchy on the outside! Probably my favorite thing we ordered.
author: Coralie S.

description:
Came here on a Sunday around noon for lunch. The restaurant was pretty empty, but it still took our waitress a while to take our orders. There were several other waitresses just standing around not helping us. I haven't been to Genki Ramen in awhile and was surprised by their large selection of different ramens. There is also a daily ramen lunch special (before 5pm) that includes a side of gyoza, chicken karaage, or pork fried rice for just an additional $1!
I got the Negi Beef Ramen and felt that it was just average. The broth itself was too bland. Even the oily/saucy stir fried beef and onions on top couldn't give the broth the flavor that it needed. The noodles were too soft and thin. It wasn't terrible, but I felt like I could've just threw in random ingredients and made this at home. Overall, I wouldn't come here for authentic ramen.
author: Nancy C.

description:
I've heard of Genki before just just decided to try it for the first time. I arrived a little bit after they opened so the servers tended to us right away. It was a nice quiet atmosphere. The first thing I ordered was a watermelon juice. 

I found it hard to drink just because it was icy and in a smoothie form. My bf order the mango salad but we didn't know that was just going to be mangoes with crab on top. We thought it was going to be more like salad but it was mostly just a bowl of mangoes.

I ordered the Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen, it was pretty good but I feel like there was a lack in broth. One of the things I love about ramen is the broth. Once you loosen the noodles, it seems like a lot of the broth disappeared. I was also disappointed in the egg, definitely not soft boiled like most other ramen places. It just doesn't taste the same without a soft boiled egg. The hard boiled egg was just a little dry.
author: Ada N.

description: They have really good ramen! We went in close to the end, but they are really nice and food are really good. Must try takoyaki there!
author: Yujia L.

description: Came here with my bf one late afternoon after our bike ride in golden gate park. We were hungry and stumbled upon Genki ramen. Noticed that they still had their lunch special even though it was like almost 4. We both ordered the chasu ramen with karaage chicken side plus the edamame (free with yelp check in). It was a good portion and came out quick, but I felt that the broth was a little too salty, and nothing stood out to me. It's a good place if you want a quick cheap meal, but not on the top of my list.
author: Wendy L.

description: This is a basic ramen place, where you can get a bang for your buck during lunch. Came on a Saturday at noon and there was no one in the restaurant. My friend and I were served immediately, and were attended to in a timely manner. Unfortunately, we had another event to attend to and I didn't get to finish. I packed the rest of it home, and it fed me for another 2 meals with some other side dishes I made. Amazed at the amount of noodles here!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
If you want to get ramen in the city with no wait, then look no further, come to Genki! Came here on a Friday night because all the other ramen and restuarant joints around the area were packed with 1-2 hour waits and I just wanted to eat ASAP. Here's the breakdown...

Food: Portions were decent. Taste was okay... I got the chicken karaage ramen. I liked how they automatically had the chicken on the side instead of having the chicken soaked in my broth. The chicken overall was nicely fried and flavorful. The ramen itself was just okay.. broth wasn't very rich or flavorful and was a little too oily to my liking. 

Drinks: Extra plus for them having a bar! They have mixed drinks with soju/sake and they were actually pretty good drinks.

Service: The service was good. Our waitress gave us suggestion on what drinks to get, didn't have to constantly ask for water or anything. 

Overall this place would be a solid 3-3.5 stars.  


TLDR; Little to nothing wait, food is okay, they have drinks!
author: Jenny N.

description: Taste is very good, and i really enjoy eating in this restaurant. The KO ramen is my favorate one. Everyone should have tried
author: Xiao M.

description: When you sort of feel like curry.. but also are in a soupy mood.. or it's a bit of a chilly day.. this place hits the spot. Nice little hearty meal with the curry ramens that hit both needs at the same time. :)
author: D W.

description: Amazing, fast, crispy, hot, delicious. I've never been disappointed. And I'm only talking take out.
author: Heather B.

description:
This review is strictly for the garlic tenderous rib ramen. This was everything I thought and more and hit the spot. Taste was on point and meat was tender and flavorful. 

It is now my goal to try all the ramen bowls on their menu! Definitely check it out :)
author: Hello E.

description: There was the smell of cleaning fluids in the midst of the eating area so strong my girlfriend almost wanted to leave when we stepped in the door. We decided to give it a try regardless since there wasn't a line. And it was just $10.95 for the tempura shrimp ramen. While I enjoyed my meal as a decent, but unremarkable ramen, my girlfriend had the curry ramen and became violently ill shortly thereafter. So we won't be returning.
author: David A R.

description: I feel like this place is almost a 4. I was torn whether to rate it 3.5 or 4, but the server who was with us tonight was super helpful and nice so I bumped it up. Came in around 9:30 on a Sunday and was initially not going to come because of the less than stellar reviews, but came anyways because other places were closing soon. Ordered the chashu ramen and mushroom ramen and checked in for the free cold tofu. I was honestly expecting the food to be considerably worse, but was pleasantly surprised. The mushroom ramen comes with about 4 different types of mushrooms and it lended the broth a slightly different taste in a good way. The only other toppings it comes with are green onions and some ginger, while the chashu ramen comes with corn, ginger, and a hard-boiled egg. The portions aren't the biggest and all the broths seem to all be tonkotsu based, with some other options on the menu for non-ramen items. The tofu was decent, but to be fair, you can't really go wrong with tofu. I think this place is a lot better than another certain ramen restaurant on Geary that has a Godzilla theme going on (if you know what I mean).
author: Sandy K.

description:
You get what you would expect from a standard ramen joint (and I mean a non-hipster, non-crafty, non-authentic ramen house).  The late night happy hour (10pm to close) is reliable to try various snack/appetizer options in addition to your bowl of ramen. Try the takoyaki!

My roommate got a watermelon juice type drink (non-alcoholic) which was really refreshing so I'll be ordering that next time!
author: Elisha Y.

description:
popular place in the past, but much better locations around richmond now.

okonomiyaki took 35 mins! and the batter was still running and wasnt crispy.
when asked why it took so long, the wait staff couldnt explain why. just told us it was "hard".

charsui was tender, but the broth in all of our ramen did not have much depth of flavor. it just tasted like salty water with msg. tonkotsu was not creamy at all.

it seems like the staff here no longer cares. the menus were old, the signs outside were faded.  their crepe store is amazing, but even that store is a little dumpy. part of the allure of japanese restaurants is their polished service and storefront even if the food is cheap. this place is not that.
author: Jason C.

description:
Does not take samsing pay so thats misleading. 

The yakisoba was like a fajita and chowmein thrown together. It was plated on a sizzling plate so that was cool.

The ramen was ok. Noodles were more on a dense side. The broth was decent. The egg was   a standard boiled egg. The meat was plentiful and thick but a little tough. My bamboo shoots were a little undercooked but was edible. 

The watermelon drink was pretty awesome. Wished there was refills bit sadly no. Only $4 during happy hours. 

The staff was friendly, attentive and fast. 

Overall a decent place
author: Grence A.

description:
My boyfriend and I arrived around 9:15 PM and there were only 2 tables occupied. Genki Ramen lost a star right when I entered the restaurant. There was a huge faulty smell as if they were leaving the trash out in the open at the back. I wanted to leave right away but decided to give it a try anyway. I suppose someone decided to finally take the trash out because the smell was gone in 10 minutes. 

It was our first time here so we spent time looking at the menu. They have a variety of ramen, rice, appetizers, and beverages. The waiter seemed a little impatient and approached us twice for our order. Luckily I caught that tea is $2.50 so we both opted for iced water. 

I went for chashu ramen while my boyfriend chose a garlic flavor. There wasn't even broth and way too much ramen. It seems like their 'garlic' flavor was literally minced garlic added to the broth because the meat was dry. 
Their menu incorrectly advertises soft boiled egg because ours were clearly boiled tea eggs.

I would recommend Saiwaii Ramen on Irving Street for friendlier service, flavorful broth, and more importantly ramen that isn't falsely advertised.
author: Danae L.

description: The miso broth lacked flavor, and the noodles were just ok. The seasoned egg was hard boiled. Wings had good flavor, but were clearly very poor quality chicken. Edamame was cooked well but flavorless without salt. All in all, pretty disappointing and we won't be ordering again. Extra star for prompt delivery.
author: Bailey D.

description: Mediocre ramen place. I had the karaage ramen and added an egg. I appreciated the fresh corn and ample seaweed but the noodles were too soft, broth was greasy yet not rich enough (missing depth of flavor) and the egg was a rip off! Only half an egg and it was hard boiled, not soft boiled. Overall, I think this place is quick and convenient and really reasonable in price so I wouldn't rule it out in the future but it's not a must-eat. Lots of better ramen places in the city.
author: Lauren S.

description:
$14--after tax + tip + healthy SF fee (i.e. SF tax-tip #2)--could get me one Genki Ramen or two Genki Crepes. Personally I would rather take the 2 crepes :3

The ramen here is okay. The broth is saltier than usual, the noodles are QQ'er than usual noodles, and the menu has more options than usual. However I suggest sticking to the basic chashu ramen, because most of the gimmicks essentially just dumps a curry or stir-fry on top of ramen. 

(-) Shoga Niku Ramen ($10.95 stir-fried pork with ginger in tonkotsu base): I thought it would be based on Japanese ginger pork (shogayaki), but this turned out more like kung pao pork with slices of ginger over ramen. There was no synergism, and the heavy soy sauce and chili were an odd mix with the tonkotsu.

(+) Chashu ramen ($10.95): Decent and will satisfy ramen cravings, but pricey for what it's worth. No magical broth, no magical soft-boiled egg, no magical melt-in-your-mouth chashu. On the plus side, there's good amount of chashu (could be considered extra meat at more pretentious ramen joints), and it's lean cuts. 

(+/-) Chicken karaage side ($1 extra): $1 sounds like a deal, but the plate tiny--the size of a soy sauce & wasabi saucer! At least the karaage was solid and tasted like zesty popcorn chicken, drizzled with the delicious sweet sauce that typically accompanies croquettes.

I'm very close to giving this 3 stars because you dine comfortably here. The ambiance is modern and spacious, featuring lime green and dark wooden chairs each branded with the restaurant name and Kanji character--maybe the ramen here is on the pricey side in order to cover the cost of the custom chairs.

The service unfortunately bumps it down. The attitude was very robotic and RBF, which I usually don't mind, but it led to a lot of small inconveniences. Even though it wasn't too busy at 2pm lunchtime, it took awhile to get seated, it took awhile to get menus after we were seated, and it took awhile for us to get the check. They also only gave 2 Hi-Chews for 3 people and ignored us when we asked for the third one :( If we were snarky, we would've used some tip $ to buy own Hi-Chew at Genki Mart :3
author: Edna C.

description:
if you like asparagus and you like bacon, order the asparagus bacon. If you like ramen and fried chicken, order chicken karaage ramen (and if you like egg, order half egg). Enjoy life completely and immensely.

Keep in mind, for veggie friends, all ramen can be ordered with vegetarian soup base! No more "can't go to ramen cause I'm veggie..."
author: Nathan W.

description:
Genki Ramen has some pretty interesting and tasty combinations. It's not exactly traditional and I wouldn't say all their ramen options are winners, like the Kimchi & the Chashu - meh, a little bland.

The ones I DO like...

Spicy Mabo Tofu - stir fried spicy tofu and minced pork in tonkotsu base:
Lots of spicy tofu cubes & savory minced pork throughout. The broth is very savory and oily, probably from the mapo tofu oils embedded in the soup.

Tan Tan - stir fried minced pork with chili and pepper flakes in vegetarian base:
Tastes like dan dan mian in soup form. Spicy broth with lots of chili pepper flakes. Tons of spicy, savory minced pork throughout the bowl with thick, chewy noodles. 

I guess I like Sichuan dishes in noodle soup form.

The menu is pretty hefty with a bunch of other Japanese-style comfort food options, like okonomiyaki, robatayaki, takoyaki, curry, etc. They are not bad for the price point, but the dishes that stand out to me are definitely the Spicy Mabo Tofu & Tan Tan ramen (~$10). 

The restaurant itself has a good amount of seats. There are tables on one side, and a small bar on the other, as well as a couple of high tables. Towards the back, there is a semi-exposed kitchen.
Also, I recall their happy hour specials are pretty good. Plus, they give out Hi-Chew candies with the bill. Not too shabby, Genki.
author: Joy W.

description: My friend and I were literally yelled at and chased out the door because the waitress thought we didn't tip when we did. Apparently it still wasn't enough to satisfy her, so we caved and tipped more just so we could leave since everyone was staring at us after the scene she made. Safe to say we will never be back here!
author: Harley G.

description: We thought the ramen here was very good.  Stopped in on a whim--would have gone to higher rated places if they were open.  But the ramen was surprisingly good, particularly the beef negi ramen.  Delicious cuts of steak, grilled green onions, and the broth was excellent.  It was a surprise to find ramen this good in a run-of-the-mill place on Geary, but those make the best surprises.  Will come here again if we are in the area...
author: Dave L.

description:
This is my go to place for Ramen when I have a craving, mainly because it is easy to get to in the Richmond district and usually not a very long wait to be seated and start eating. Sure there are better places in SF but often times I find myself waiting 30+ mins at other places due to the crowds or smaller establishments.  

If you're looking for a quick bite, check this place out. I recommend the Chicken Karaage Ramen or if you're not looking for Ramen, try the Salmon fried rice.
author: Brian H.

description:
I'll keep this short because I don't invest time making negative reviews however, I'd like to save you some time, money and disappointment: worst ramen ever. 

A packet of instant ramen is better. Slow and poor quality, no taste. Over a year and I haven't understood how this place stays in business... then I realized they are open later at night (serving people who get out of the bars next to them on Geary)... ahh, now I get it.

Avoid if you like Ramen.
author: Steve B.

description: Growing up in Northern Japan, I know good ramen.  This place is good! Butter ramen was authentic and just as i remembered as a kid.  5 stars!
author: Tony L.

description:
Genki Ramen has always been a reliable spot in the hood, especially as of late with all the rain and the cold of winter now upon us. It's during these days that few things are more satisfying than a piping hot bowl of salty brothy goodness. 

To be honest I've only eaten at the restaurant a couple of times - both of which were on a weekend (I usually just walk to pick it up since I live a couple of blocks away). The restaurant itself looks a little dated and isn't the cleanest place.  I will say service was not an issue like many other yelpers have mentioned.

My go-to Ramen is the Spicy Mabo Tofu Ramen. I always add stir fried veggies, spicy miso and an egg when I'm feeling wild. I've had a handful of appetizers on the menu including the pork and veggie gyoza and the potato cakes. The pork dumplings were the best -- the others were not memorable.

I wish half stars existed because I'd like to boost this place up a bit but have to dock it for lack of "all around amazing" food due to the so/so side dishes to round out the meal. The shining star is definitely the Ramen and worth going for.
author: Christine M.

description: I get their Kimchi ramen everytime I go and I am never disappointed. Very tasty and great prices. I always come in for the kimchii ramen and it's so delightful and yummy. My friends usually get the curry ramen and they also love it. Usually with ramen places either the broth or the noodles are good but never both. Over here, I thoroughly enjoy both equally.
author: Oceana M.

description:
Whenever I'm in San Francisco and craving ramen, this is my place to go! I enjoy coming here since they have a big variety and you never have to endure a long like like at Orenchi's. This place deserves more stars in my book!

My favorite dish here is the Pork Katsu Curry Ramen. The Pork Katsu is cooked to perfection and tastes amazing dipped in the curry ramen broth. YUM. They also offer a lunch menu and you can pay a dollar more for a side dish like pork fried rice or pot stickers. How can one complain? Make sure you also check in on yelp to redeem your free appetizer! 

I would recommend anyone giving this a place a try, especially if you're in the inner richmond area. The food is affordable, plenty of parking, and it's opened late! :)
author: MyTien P.

description: Extremely tasty and a great selection of ramen super extravagant environment but sometimes the hostess/waitress forgets orders or request and I would have to remind her a couple of times. Even if it was not bus waitress or host is very forgetful. Everything is fabulous just her service and her forgetfulness.
author: Rosemarie C.

description:
The San Francisco resident in me returned from Lake Tahoe deprived of Asian food cooked by Asian people. Not trying to get racial, or imply Tahoe lacks legit Asian food - I just didn't come home on a globally balanced diet.  

Genki Ramen is my neighborhood ramen spot, two blocks away from home. It is consistently just average. I've only tried vegetarian options here, and my go-to is mushroom ramen, a savory broth with mushrooms of varied size and shape, ginger, and chewy but thin noodles. Broth is vegetarian on request.  As ramen goes, it was not stellar but it did hit the Asian-deprived spot. Veggie gyoza comes pan-friend, flattened. In my experience it is only tasty with dipping sauce. 

The food may be serviceable, but Genki as a restaurant is commendable: open late, quick, staff consistently nice.  On balance, A-OK.
author: Evan M.

description:
Ordered delivery through Uber Eats and here are my scores!

DELIVERY TIME - 5/5: Food was delivered very fast. Got everything in under 30 min.
TAKEOUT QUALITY - 5/5: Everything was packed up well. They even separated the ramen noodles from the broth so that it wouldn't get super soggy and I was able to mix it all together at home. Portion sizes were also generous.
CROQUETTE - 4/5: The croquette's (which are fried potato cakes) were simple but tasty. Great as an appetizer or side dish. The dish comes with 2 croquette's and a side of hoisin sauce for dipping. Only complaint is that the croquette's could have been more crispy on the outside.
TAN TAN RAMEN - 3/5: Unfortunately this was my least favorite dish. The noodles were cooked very well and it came with a generous amount of minced pork, however the ramen broth lacked in flavor. Tan Tan Ramen normally has a sesame flavor to it with a kick of spice, but this had zero sesame flavor in it. I also asked for an extra side of chili sauce since I love spicy and they forgot to include the side of chili sauce to my order.

Overall this place wasn't bad, but it wasn't the best either. It was pretty simple. They have a lot of variety on their menu though which I liked so I will most likely give it another shot.
author: Chisholm T.

description:
It can be hard to find a ramen place open on a Tuesday or mid-day. The husband and I stopped by around 3pm. We're both feeling under the weather and we're hoping for a pick me up. 

He chose the curry tonkatsu ramen and I got the charshu ramen. We both got a side for an extra $1 - chicken kaarage for me and pork fried rice for him. My husband enjoyed the curry tonkatsu but my charshu was just okay. The noodles weren't too think and were cooked well. The broth was pretty good; creamy and not too salty. The pork, on the other hand, could have been better quality. 

Not my first choice when it comes to ramen but it does hit the spot when you need a ramen fix.
author: Rose A.

description: This is my go to ramen place in SF.  I always enjoy the butter and corn ramen with extra pork and an egg.  When we came here this weekend, it took 15 minutes to get our orders in despite trying to make eye contact with and flag down any servers.  There weren't even that many people in the place.  I'll still come back, but the two stars will stay until service gets better.
author: Richard T.

description: Wow this place is kinda bad to eat at... the interior is kinda dirty and the seats are ripped. The food is "eh". This place seems like a take out restaurant instead of dine in.
author: Jackie T.

description:
We wanted ramen and this was the closest place we could find near where we were at in Golden Gate Park. I kind of was disappointed in the foods, we barely go into the city and should've opted for something more tasty.

For all you ramen snobs, do NOT compare this to Ramen Dojo or Orenchi or straight up ramen from Japan. The ramen here does not specialize in delicious broth, instead it seems more of a place to quickly get mediocre ramen. AKA get your fix without waiting hours for a bowl.

I got the garlic rib pork ramen with spicy miso for an addition dollar something (ugh). Total price of my ramen was disappointingly more than what I pay for at a delicious ramen joint in south bay/san mateo. The broth was salty and okay, the spicy miso barely added any spice to it. The flavors eventually got too salty and bland I didn't finish the broth. The pork was very salty and tasted too much of soy sauce. The bf got chicken kastu curry ramen, he said it was ok. 

We had karange chicken via happy hour deal. I wouldn't get it for regular price since it tastes not as good as other places prepare it. 

Overall I felt like the ramen didn't satisfy my ramen craving. Since the place was nearly empty for a Saturday dinner, service was attentive.
author: Rita K.

description:
**COMPLAINT**

I have eaten here a few times. The food is not the best and it is also not the worst, but this review is not about the food.

I chose to eat here 50 minutes or so before work. I figured that would be enough time to enjoy my dinner with company even if it meant speeding it up at the end. 

It took a few minutes to be seated and we only took five minutes or so to decide what to order but after another five minutes, we were left wondering where our server was. 

Our server was the same person who seated us. We saw her walking around back and forth to bus one or two tables. It took another five or so minutes of us trying to make eye contact/wave someone over, but nobody tried to approach us. 

In another five or so minutes, another couple was seated beside us. After another couple of minutes, our server decided that they would help the other couples first. We were put off by this, but we waited. And then the server LEFT without looking at us even though she had seated us long before and we had been clearly been waiting. WHY? 

Maybe on a different day, I wouldn't be so pissed off but 20+ minutes of my time was wasted and I had even LESS time to grab something to eat before starting a night shift. After another couple of minutes, I was so fed up I got up and left to get a slice of pizza from Nizario's down the block. 

Call this petty as much as you want, but I don't appreciate service that will choose to be inattentive. I don't expect to be groveled to, but if they don't want to see me as a customer worth serving then I will take my business elsewhere. 

I will remember this experience every time I pass by. I'll never want to eat here again, but there's honestly other great food choices all around the area so whatever.
author: Sofia R.

description: Seafood ramen was pretty good. Delivery ramen was separated into two containers. Broth and box with everything else. Easiest if you have a large soup bowl at home.
author: Alex C.

description:
There are not a whole lot of places in the Richmond District that open late (past 10pm) so on that fact alone this place gets two thumbs up in my book. Sometimes people work late and need a place to grub and nothing says "late night comfort" like a hot bowl of soup noodles. 

FOOD: The first time I tried this place I ordered the Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen ($9.75). It was very savory and I was pleased with how tender and flavorful the beef was. On that alone I would have rated this place with 4-stars. However, my most recent visit has brought my ratings for this place down to 3 stars. I ordered the Tan Tan which is their ramen prepared with spicy minced pork in a vegetarian broth. I have one word--Salty. The pork tasted much more like it was sauteed in black bean sauce rather than spicy oil. There was an excessive amount of minced pork in the bowl too, making it difficult to enjoy the ramen noodles. The karaage that I ordered had more of a "KFC"-textured batter on it and did not have much flavor other than the two sauces drizzled on top. 

OVERALL: Still, you can't beat a ramen shop that will serve you even 20 minutes before they close. I will be coming here again to try something else, perhaps their Yakisoba or mixed mushroom ramen!
author: Greg Y.

description: Food was absolutely delicious! I ordered the bbq ribs ramen and i thought it was going to have a weird taste. However to my contradictions, it actually complimented each other well. I do wish they more broth. Halfway through the my broth shrunk\was absorbed from food/noodles and it's cost $3 for an extra small serving for broth. Service was friendly enough. The service was also very fast!
author: Emily V.

description: i like coming to genki when i want a quick and fast ramen meal! i like the thicker noodles and that's what genki has! i have never had to wait in line for this place before which is why i enjoy coming here. i always get the butter and corn ramen and it's just enough for me! sometimes i feel guilty because there's butter in there but honestly it tastes so good!! for lunch, they have a good lunch combo and it's so worth it!! you get a small side with it and i think it's gyoza and chicken karaage. i've been coming here since high school so that means something! haha nothing has really changed since like 7 years ago.
author: diane d.

description:
MSG ATTACK!  Was thirsty, sweaty, dizzy all night .  All signs the broth was loaded with it.  It tasted like it too... had that slightly sweet/salty taste finish to it..  Was delicious, but wow paid for it !  

This the first time I finished the broth because it was addictive.. I never finished the broth anywhere I get ramen.  

Don't want to go through that again.
author: Demanding T.

description:
Solid 3 stars. We popped in here as a group of 6 during a typically chilly SF Saturday evening. We were seated immediately. 

There seems to only be one veg ramen option which is a curry based ramen. I did see a * saying you can replace stuff with a veggie broth but I assume their veggie broth is just this curry one? And I don't love curry broths - prefer the normal one. Twas $10. 

We also got a pink drink for $6.50 which is reasonably priced but it had 1/10 of a shot of soju and probably 500 calories. 

Checked in and got the edamame 4 free! 

Not rushing back, but if someone insisted on this place, i'd go.
author: Aria S.

description:
Came at 10:30, instead of welcoming us and giving us the seat, they just discussed in other language and said that the kitchen's last order is in 5 minutes. Not long after we were looking at the menu, the waitress came and asked if we are ready. My friend wasn't ready to order so I told her to come back in a few mins. She looked unhappy and told us that the kitchen will be closed in 5 minutes. Not even 2 minutes later, another waiter came and rushed us about the order again, saying exactly the same thing that the kitchen's last order is in 5 minutes. I mean, they wrote their working hours is until 11pm, and at that time it was 10:38pm. Its not even 5 minutes before its closed!

After we ordered, the ramen came so fast (which is a good thing), and at 10:45 or so they gave us the check when we haven't done eating. Geez if they really wants us to get off from the restaurant then its better if they just close the whole restaurant at 10:30pm!
author: Rosita O.

description:
PLEASE DO NOT MESSAGE ME THAT VEGGIE RAMEN IS NOT REAL RAMEN. 
I KNOW THAT. 
EVERYBODY KNOWS THAT. 
BE COOL, MAN. BE COOL.

Harry Potter isn't real either but thousands upon thousands of people spend actual money to go to faux Hogwarts and buy a faux wand that is essentially just a fancy stick and everyone seems to be just hunky dory with that cray cray scenario so don't even start in on the veggie ramen convo. 

So I don't want to hear it about the not real ramen.  
The menu said ramen, I got ramen. Vegetarian soup base or what have you, I'm calling it ramen. 

And I liked it.
A lot. 

So much so that after my first visit on Saturday, I came back again today, only 3 days later. 

A special one-time thank you will go out to my roomie for bringing me here because our experience on Saturday was pretty rad and the Yasai (#110) ramen with veggie base was so good that we had to come back for round 2 today.

The watermelon drink is my two-time go-to. It's just blended watermelon and ice but it's so refreshing and sometimes it's good to lay off the alkie. 

Our visit today wasn't as perfect as over the weekend, but to be fair, my roomie was being kind of a poopy pants so it dampened the mood a little in between noodle slurps, but I also think the ramen was a just a little less stellar than our visit before (which I totally would have considered 5-stars). 

I feel like the ramen wasn't as flavorful this time around and also it wasn't super warm, which would have done the bowl some favors. 

Service is pretty on it and they'll help guide you to one of 3 of their vegetarian-friendly ramen choices. 

Obviously I wouldn't hesitate to come back since I already did. A very solid 4-stars in my book, as far as "not real" ramen is concerned.
author: Candice G.

description:
Yummy in my tummy! 

I ordered the chasu ramen and happy hour takoyaki. The ramen was delicious. I added corn for an extra dollar. The portion was a healthy amount and each kernel was very sweet. (Honestly, it's nothing special. I just really like corn and the stuff from cans taste great to me. #basic) I like that you have options at this place. You can specially request your noodles' firmness and your broth's richness. I just got the default and I really liked it. The number one thing I never understood about ramen noodles was why it was so salty!?! I think that's why I enjoyed this place so much. The broth is perfectly flavored and doesn't leave my mouth tingly dry from sodium. I wish it was hotter temperature wise. It was served luke warm :/ For their chasu, I thought it was dry and slightly low quality but I'm really in it for the noodles. I just left the meat aside, nbd. 

Happy hour takoyaki. It was meh. Really soft, almost like it wasn't cooked through. The octopus was a very small piece and the sauce was skimpy. I had to use my takoyaki to scrap the sauces off the side of the place but for three dollars, it was fine. 

Service is quick and nothing special. Though the waitress did drop a piece of karage chicken from the plate for my boyfriend's ramen and he was short a piece. The chunks are large so it made a slight difference to his portion size. I wouldn't have said anything about the service but the waitresses didn't seem very responsive. Maybe it was because it was ten pm and they were tired? The waitress was on her phone at the bar and forgot my yelp check in deal. I was supposed to receive free edamame for paying with card and checking in, but no dice :( not a huge deal but a bummer because there weren't too many tables to attend to. All the little negatives added up to losing a star in my review. They're not big deals separately but all together, they kind of dilute the experience. I'll definitely come again and share this place with friends. 

Note, they also offer vegetarian options which is rare in my books. This place is a good choice that can accommodate the different people in your party. 

Another note, for a place with 1000+ reviews, I'm surprised it's not super crowded and packed all the time.
author: Tina Y.

description: I got chicken katsu curry delivered, but it was 90% rice 10% curry. Incredibly disappointing.
author: Ashley S.

description:
I wanted to try Japanese ramen during my visit in San Francisco since it is impossible to get it in New England (where I'm from). Ordered a Chashu Ramen and honestly, it didn't wow me. The broth didn't have much flavor and it was not warm. The noodles were somewhat tough for me. I could be wrong, but Japanese ramen noodles are supposed to have structure in the ramen to avoid absorbing moisture. I eat a lot of noodle soups and I generally prefer to have softer noodles.

Service was mediocre. The dining room is nice and modern, except for the music; they were playing popular modern American music which is strange for a Japanese restaurant.

Other food my family and I ordered: Seafood Okonomiyaki, Cold Chicken Ramen, and Seafood Yakisoba. Again, nothing wowed me.

At least, Genki Ramen gave me the first opportunity to eat Japanese ramen and I am thankful.
author: David T.

description:
I'm so torn with this rating that I messaged T. "Tell me, between 3 and 4, which one?" He messages right back, "Of course 4." Well, that settles it.

That, and apparently my girlfriend who has been trading emails on evenings with me, who lives just down a few streets in Inner Richmond. 

I was so not into planning for a week night evening. This is because I don't live in New York. Everyone knows San Franciscans go home and sleep early. No one goes out on week days. T wants to take me for ramen. Great. Just great. I want to sleep. Reluctantly said yes a few days before the actual evening, I told my gf in the known (of Inner Richmond) that I'd be heading to her direction, for some ramen place on 4th and Geary. She immediately responded, "You mean Genki." I replied, "I don't know. I just know that it's on 4th and Geary." Apparently she has heard about it from her friends who have children like she. And apparently this is a kids friendly place (which sums up the Avenues). Thank goodness that evening no kids on sight, only youngish people who are, I guess, kids in the eyes of people who are of certain age, present company included.

Allegedly the chicken wings are good. I ordered only 1 stick, seeing that I was not enthusiastic about eating out twice in a roll. The previous night I was also out and I was beginning to feel the effect of staying out late. It was very good, surprisingly so.

Ramen: that's a toughie. I have a few of my favorites: Ippudo in lower east side, naturally; Izakaya Sozai in Inner Sunset; Halu, also in Inner Richmond, Santa Ramen and Ramen Dojo in San Mateo; Jimbo sushi in Alameda (of all places). Men Oh Tokushima has been a good long standing place for me whenever I felt adventurous, a couple of years back. 

Genki is not among them.

Thus the coin toss brain surgery earlier on that resulted me messaging T, because clearly I have nothing more important to do on this evening but to write reviews.

But this is very much a people's food place. You can show up without a reservation, which is always a plus if you are not in the mood of shuffling among a crowded restaurant. You can watch sports because there are countless TVs on the wall. Your companion tolerates your bitchy attitude once again and is so accommodating of your mood. Your girlfriend endorses this neighborhood restaurant and proudly and quickly identifies the place. Did I mention that I was with a friend who's practically a saint when it comes to dealing with my mood? And he likes this place. 

There you have it. I may be back, dragged and kicking. But I may be back. Next time I'll try their odds and ends and avoid ramen.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Let me get absolutely real o'clock with you if you're considering being a patron of this establishment. 

They are completely UNPROFESSIONAL and are unapologetic about their lack of customer service, flat out do not care if the mistakes are on their end, and would rather lose your business and be done with you instead of admitting they made a mistake. In THIS market, that is unacceptable to me. If you value how hard you work for your money and care about quality and customer service than you can not be okay with giving this establishment business.

If you value your money and worth please consider Miki's or Yu Zen in the Richmond. 

Really wishing zero stars was a thing.
author: Licette M.

description:
This is a very average ramen spot - nearby are much better options like Kaiju eats just a few minutes down the road. 

The ramen here is okay but nothing special. Service is also average at best.
author: Eric S.

description:
This rating is for their customer service...or lack there of. 
Me and my wife arrived at this restaurant at 10:34pm, they close at 11:00pm. The server came to us and went on to say that we can no longer be seated as last call is at 10:30, but it was ok to order to go. I explained that I came all the way from out of town and that it was only a few minutes after 10:30. They did not care as all I got was a smirk. Since we drove all the way from out of town, we ordered and I  am now writing this review as we eat in the car. Although I enjoy the food here, I can honestly say that I will no longer bring my business here. I have never experienced a situation like this. If they close at 11pm, they should accommodate customers until 11pm! At the least, there should be a note that the dining area closes at a different time!
author: Carlos M.

description:
I was in the mood for soup. Since the roommate had a 30% off code for delivery dot com, I decided to order from Genki.

Croquettes (2 pcs) - deep fried potato cakes served with deep fried sauce ($4.95)
The roommate's pick. He liked it dipped in the tonkatsu sauce.

Chicken karaage - chicken nuggets ($4.95)
Good. The outside was nicely fried and crispy.

Gyoza (5 pcs) - pan fried pork dumplings ($5)
Okay. Kinda oily and all the dumplings stuck together.

Beef & enoki roll: shredded kimchi and enoki mushroom wrapped in sliced beef, seasoned with spicy miso sauce ($7.50)
I think there was too much sauce and it was too one note. I love enoki mushrooms and beef, but the tastes and texture were just mushy.

Chashu ramen: house made boiled pork served with half boiled egg, bamboo shoot, green onion and red ginger in tonkotsu base ($9.95) +Boiled spinach ($1.75) +Spicy miso (+$1)
They forgot my spicy miso! Arg! This is the second time this has happened so I was annoyed. It was only $1 and if they had come by again with the miso, it would have been too late. The broth is very light, both in consistency and flavor. I was expecting it to be richer. Chashu and toppings were okay. Some slices of the chashu were a little dry. I did like the boiled spinach though.

Ox tongue robatayaki: with salt ($2.75)
Pork neck: with soy sauce ($2.95)
Ika yaki robatayaki: giant squid with soy sauce ($8.50)
Chicken gizzard: seasoned with salt ($2.50)
Shishito: japanese green pepper with salt ($2.50)
All the robatayaki skewers were pretty good. The squid was a little too sweet for my liking. And the gizzard was super rubbery.

Curry tonkatsu rice - deep fried pork chop with curry sauce ($8.95)
The roommate's. I wish they put the curry on the side so the tonkatsu breading wouldn't get soggy en route during delivery. 

Chahan rice - fried rice with chashu ($9.25)
I didn't like this at all. It had a nutty flavor. Almost like there were peanuts in there. Maybe it was some kind of nut oil? Anyways, the roommate liked it. Since I'm not a huge fan of nuts, I didn't care for this dish.

In all, I would give the food 3 stars. But -1 star for forgetting my spicy miso again! What a waste of a $1!
author: Elena N.

description:
I don't have a really hard time giving this place 4 stars.
The food is legit and the menu boasts way more than just ramen. 
The place is clean and well lit. It's is got a chill vibe thats good for groups, one side of the restaurant had a long booth and the tables can be moved together.
There are 5 screens around the place,  the games always on but there's music playing most of the times I have been there.

The menu has more than most ramen places and they a have happy hour discounted appetizer specials and drinks. 

The Broth is good, but not as flavorful as other places. The noodles are not overly chewy, just a little bit. The amount of veggies and meat in the ramen bowls is ample.
The egg is done properly and the bamboo is delicious. 
The chicken karaage is great, very tender and juicy. The chicken teriyaki was a little too grilled and the teriyaki sauce was is little too thick.
The barbecue skewers are a nice add on. I like the Shishito pepper's and the asparagus bacon.

Not many places will do to go orders with ramen and that makes this place special.
author: Ben M.

description: I love the appetizers and seafood ramen here. The staff is usually attentive, and we have never had to wait. I would be here more often if it weren't for the lack of parking in this area.
author: WeiWei H.

description:
i brought my friend here for her birthday lunch since her original choice was closed for the weekend due to a private event and her second choice was actually not yet opened (even though we arrived after the official opening time).  poor girl was starving and hangry for ramen by the time we arrived!

since i didn't want to pay for metered parking (right in front of the restaurant on geary blvd), i actually parked a few blocks away, in laurel heights, where i found free, untimed parking.  no worrying about having the feed to meter or move the car after a couple of hours....just enjoy the day!

we walked in a little before noon on saturday and there were quite a few open tables, much to our delight.  we sat at a spacious table for 4, right in the middle of the restaurant.  the interior wasn't that big, but i think the staff did well in fitting as many tables as they could.  sf rent ain't cheap after all!

restrooms are in the rear, opposite the kitchen, with one unisex room for the gents and one for the ladies.  they were reasonably clean, but then again, i'd expect that since we arrived only a little after they opened for their first meal of the day.

upon checking in on my trusty yelp app, i saw that we were entitled to either a free wakame salad or daruma tofu appetizer.  both were good choices, so we had to ponder a little, but eventually went with the daruma tofu, which was a cold tofu with green onions and a savory brown sauce on top (i forgot to ask what that was but it was very good!)

they also brought us a small dish of pickled cabbage, and a single carrot on top, prior to any of our orders arriving.  i like carrots, but i'm not a fan of pickled cabbage, and neither was my friend, so we just left that plate alone.

i wasn't that hungry, so i just ordered two appetizers as my main: the edamame ($3.00) and nasu gomaae ($5.50), a bowl of japanese beans inside the pod, and a plate of seasoned, sauteed eggplant.  i loved the edamame with a sprinkling of sea salt, as this filled me up pretty fast....beans are high in carbs and fiber after all!  the eggplant was surprisingly delicious with the blend of savory sauce.  i received many more pieces than i expected for an appetizer portion, and before i knew it, i was full!  tummy was very happy though.

now, i was halfway thru my appetizers when i started to wonder why my friend's chashu ramen combo ($9.95) had not yet arrived...it had been at least 15-20 minutes and they weren't super busy, yet.  we asked the waitress who checked on the order and informed us that it would be brought out shortly, which it was.  a piping hot bowl of ramen with small side of pork fried rice was placed in front of the birthday girl, who lit up as soon as she saw her food.

she took her time eating it, and said that she really enjoyed this bowl of ramen b/c the noodles were thinner than other ramen shoppes which she liked.  some like thick noodles, some like thin, some are indifferent, but my friend is definitely a thin noodle kinda gal.  i saw that they gave her a lot of chashu, moreso than most ramen restaurants, and she appreciated the extra slices of meat...although she tried, she couldn't finish it all as it was just too much food!  but that's always better than finishing your food and still having room in your tummy.

after our dishes were cleared, we actually took our time finishing our water and chatting and were glad that no one was waiting for a table, nor did the staff try to hurry us out.  we even got one of the waiters to take a photo of us and they did a nice job getting the right angle and ensuring that it wasn't too dark.

overall, a very pleasant and scrumptious lunch experience, with a final bill that didn't hurt the wallet at all, and the best part was that my friend, the birthday girl, enjoyed her bowl of ramen.

i'd recommend this restaurant for groups of 2-4, maybe 6, but not much bigger b/c it is difficult for this restaurant to seat larger groups.
author: Ellen L.

description:
Problem in San Francisco...doesn't it seem like all good restaurants close at around 9 or 10pm? 

When you are faced with late night hunger on a week night, Genki is the answer. Not only are their doors open past 10pm, but there is also a pretty sweet happy hour past 10pm as well! Cheap appitizers and drinks! 

With a large selection of japanese appitizers and ramen, this clean little geary street restaurant always delivers. In particular, the gyoza, and curry ramen are excellent. 

Bottom Line: Great late night Japanese eats!
author: Jaime W.

description:
I love this place for the huge variety of their menu, especially their ramen menu and all the possible choices! Service was nothing spectacular, but never short of expectations in any way. They open pretty late too (1am on Friday and Saturdays, 11pm the rest of the week), which can be very convenient for those late nights.

There's three ramen dishes that I usually go for, depending on my mood and what I'm craving. I would actually love to venture out and try the other ramen options, buuuuut I always stick to choosing one of these three! Mhmm.. maybe one day..

- Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen
- Spicy Mabo Tofu Ramen
- Curry Chicken Katsu Ramen
author: Kris C.

description: I eat like a normal average persons portion, and I ordered the black pepper beef yakisoba on the sizzling plate. It was a good-sized portion and also quite delicious. I wish I can say the same about the ramen bowls though. When I looked at my friend's sad tiny bowl of noodles, I was relieved that I ordered a yakisoba instead. Though the order was small, the beef slices in the beef stew was indeed very soft and delicious! Also there was a Yelp check in deal for a free order of edamame or tofu thing so that was cool.
author: Sara T.

description: Great delivery experience! We ordered the shrimp tempura, seafood ramen and garlic tenderous rib ramen. The delivery was prompt. The tempura arrived crisp. The seafood ramen and rib ramen were very good, both broths solid, and ingredients fresh. A very solid ramen choice off Geary!
author: Joel A.

description:
I love ramen. I'd like to think I've had some pretty delicious and legit bowls of ramen. So when my cousin brought me here for a catch up, she mentioned this place doesn't have the **best ramen** but it's a local area with no wait. Meh, figured why not. We went around 5ish on a weekday and she was right --- no wait. We were seated right away and saw that it was happy hour. We ordered the gyoza (potstickers $4.75-5pieces) and Takoyaki
(octopus balls with aonori, okonomi sauce, mayonnaise, dried bonito flakes and red ginger- $4.75). 

I ordered the Butter & Corn Ramen (house made boiled pork, fish cake, corn, butter and green onion in miso base $8.25). It was OK. I've definitely had better ramen, in terms of the broth and bite of the noodles, something was just lacking. Also, I didn't think they'd actually put slabs of butter in it. I mean, what's gluttony if you can actually see the bad stuff you're eating! My cousin I believe had the Chashu Ramen (house made boiled pork, half boiled egg, bamboo shoot, green onion and red ginger in tonkatsu base $8.95). The bowls and portions are pretty big for the price of less than $10 for ramen. 

If you're in the area and absolutely need ramen to help you get through SFs cold weather, then yeah go for it, but I'd rather drive down the peninsula and really fulfill my cravings at my favorite ramen spot.
author: Kathleene E.

description: I've been wanting to try this place and today was the day. I had to wait for my car to get done at Firestone and decided to stop by here and I'm so happy I did. Free croquettes if you check in with Yelp. I ordered the garlic ribs and added corn. It was really good and fast service.
author: Anna V.

description: I used to order delivery from here a lot but I just had a horrible experience with them. Got my order in 30mins, was super excited and about to eat it. I ordered a curry chicken katsu ramen but all I got was my ramen and soup. NO chicken nor garnish at all. Tried to call them and tell them that they forgot part of my order but their phone won't work. Good thing that I ordered extra deep fried tofu. At least I can pretend they are fake chicken and finish my meal with it. I was having a bad day and was hoping that Genki Ramen can cheer me up. But all I got was an extra disappointment. Not sure if I'm getting a refund or a new order. Anyway, food was still good tho.
author: Ted C.

description: One of my go-to ramen restaurants anytime I'm in the area. Fast, delicious and pretty decent prices. Happy hour 7 days a week from 3-6 pm too.
author: Caroline C.

description:
This is my 2nd visit to Genki Ramen. Seems like there are a lot more tables than the previous visit. The wait staff seem to be floating around; not in any particular hurry. I had to wait for a table for two although there was one near the door that was empty(??why? I don't know).
When I was seated (after 8 minutes), I only had 2 minutes before someone came to ask me for my order. I really didn't have time to look at the menu much.
In the end I ordered a beef tenderloin ramen in tonkatsu broth & checking in with Yelp(!!) I scored a free wakame salad. My friend had some simple miso ramen with corn.
I gotta say that the tonkatsu broth was very salty and concentrated. There wasn't a lot of it. There were 4 finely cut slices of beef tenderloin. Add to that a small round of spinach and a bit of ginger.
This ramen was okay in size for me; but I'm petite. If I were a guy, I'd probably be hungry still.

Best bet: fried chicken ramen which I saw on another table. A small mound of the chicken!

So, I'd recommend Japantown for your ramen fix. Because this ramen house isn't good.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Ramen is top notch and food is delivered quickly!

I have to dock one star because we had to wait a considerable amount of time to receive our bill. It was Sunday night and there was only one person running the front of the restaurant so this might not be typical.
author: Mike M.

description: My favorite ramen shop.  We come here whenever we are in the area.  Good food, good prices, good service.  Very neighborhoody.  We've never had a bad meal here.  Is it fancy? No.  The foods better than the expensive trendy ramen restaurants  springing up, and you don't get an attitude with your meal.  Just yummy food and good service.  You should try Genki Ramen out.
author: Carolyn K.

description: Continually 5 stars for vegetarians. ..5 stars for veggie mabo tofu no meat/ no pork -veggie base   Nicest servers. Vegan- I'm sure. It's awesome.  Checkin for a free appetizer-ish.
author: Me M.

description: Great fast take out. Pork base option and all the normal ramen goodies. Pleasant staff, lost one point for cleanliness.
author: Becky M.

description:
I like to think I am an expert when it comes to Ramen,
I spent a majority of my youth in Japan and Loving Japanese culture.
This Place is okay, for your Ramen fix. The broth on the super wasn't as flavorful, and the noodles fell apart as if they were over boiled. The location is convenient... if you can find parking, the only perks are the check ins for free salad and tofu. Other than that, I would try anything else but the Ramen. With Solo many Japanese places available in the city at your disposal. this one is okay, for its convenience... but don't be ashamed to try anything closer to Japantown in the Fillmore.
author: Michael R.

description:
Craving ramen on a windy day because that's the thing to do. Especially in SF, where it's windy pretty much 350 days out of the year. 

Four waiters/waitresses and the service was still so slow! Took about 5 minutes to get seated even though the restaurant was about 1/3 full and another 10 minutes to order, even though I made eye contact several times. About another 15-20 minutes to get the food out. 

SESAME WINGS
Okay, I see you, you hot lil thang. This dish came out piping hot, but was still very savory. The flavors blended together nicely, but I'm just overall glad the sheer temperature of the wings didn't kill off my tongue or my taste buds would've been shot.

CRISPY DAIMARU
Yum! Spinach, cheese, and fish cake fried to perfection. Wish there was more of the spinach, cheese, and fish cake, though. Too much of the crisps. I could hardly taste the fish cake.

SPICY MABO TOFU RAMEN
Spicy! Felt a bit powdery, but it was easy to look past that. Tasted almost curry-like, which was definitely a nice touch.

GARLIC TENDEROUS RIB RAMEN
They got my order wrong the first time. Apparently the kitchen made it wrong? Whatever the case, hmph...I'm glad I had appetizers to munch on in the meanwhile. Didn't taste the garlic much, but the ribs were heavenly! Dear gawsh. So tender. Wish there was more spinach to balance it all. I felt like the dish was lacking something, maybe some corn?

FLAVORED SOJU
Loved this! Wish there was more soju, but overall, a great addition to my meal.

Strawberry Smoothie
Meh.

I'm not sure I would come here again based on their service, but the food was good, so MAYBE if I'm feeling nice :).

TIP: 3-6pm and 10-close happy hour daily!
TIP 2: Free delivery after 5pm.
author: Vee B.

description: Everything looked so good but there was a terrible sewer-y smell and the group just couldn't bring ourselves to eat there. Perhaps we'll try again in a few months.
author: Elena N.

description: Very mediocre ramen. Probably the worst I've had in a restaurant setting. It's not that it was gross, it was just bland and unimpressive. It's almost like they used instant ramen as the base and tried to brighten it up by adding their own ingredients.  I did like the fried chicken, but that's about it.
author: Mike T.

description: I've been here twice. The first time was fine, I told myself I'd go some place else just because it wasn't anything special. The second time I wanted Ramen or something and we just decided this place because it was the closest to where we were. The Ramen was fine, it just doesn't satisfy my cravings really. Boyfriend had the fried rice I think and liked it, but it's just fried rice. It's nothing special, but if you want something and you're around then sure. The hi-chew candy they give was good though hahah
author: Maggie W.

description:
The bf and I frequent this place a lot, mostly during their late night HH...

The bf always gets chicken karaage, gyoza, and steamed rice. I usually get the chicken karaage as well, which is pretty good. We've also shared the croquette on occasion, which is basically something like an oval hashbrown. Really yummy! The sesame chicken wings have been pretty tasty too. 

I've also had the chicken salad before and it was alright. I've had the curry chicken katsu ramen twice. I didn't like it the first time, but decided to give it another go recently and it tasted a whole lot better. The broth was good and the katsu wasn't fatty or heavily breaded. I definitely recommend it!

Service could be better. You have to really flag down your waiter/waitress to get your water refilled and even for more napkins. 

Overall, I would skip the daruma tofu, which I only had once for free with a check-in. There was nothing special about it. The shrimp tempura ramen wasn't good either. It gave me an upset stomach.

FYI, on Fridays & Saturdays, make sure to get there before 12:30AM even though it says they close at 1AM because they will turn you away and say that the kitchen is closed.
author: Fallon P.

description:
Alright ramen spot. Nothing extraordinary or something that I have to come back for.

I did not want any meat in my ramen, so the only veggie options were the Nori and the Veggie Curry Ramen. I got the Nori Ramen. The soup base was good and not too salty. The noodles were alright. They were slightly chewy and soft. I noticed that the noodles were not too long, so putting the noodles, nori, corn, and soup in my spoon was pretty easy. And I had a little bit of everything in one spoon =) You all know when noodles are hella long, it takes work to put a little bit of everything into your spoon! 

I like how we can get a free item after we check-in on Yelp. The Daruma tofu is like the Korean side dish, rectangle of tofu with some hot pepper paste. It's simple and I liked it.

Other than the food, the service was good. Seated and served quickly. They checked in with us during our meal and refilled our glasses with water when needed. It's a pretty comfortable restaurant with their set up. The bathrooms are clean and organized as well =)
author: Shirley M.

description:
