Came by here after a concert at bar in the neighborhood. I was craving ramen, and I was stoked they were open late! I ordered the curry veggie ramen, and added boiled egg and fried tofu to it. My friend got the chicken karaage ramen and added kimichi to it. As appetizers, we got the hamachi kama and shishitos to share. The food came out fairly quickly, but not as fast as some other ramen places I have been to, oh well! 

Overall, the food was good. It was probably too much food, but we enjoyed it. My friend did say that the chicken was okay on the ramen, not too impressive though as per the other Yelp reviews. But, hey it's kinda what you get for a divvy-ish ramen place....but I will take it, it was open late for my ramen craving;) 

I summary, I plan to come back one day and get my ramen fix. It's not the best I had, but it is definitely up there, AND it is open late! Must try if you are a ramen aficionado.
author: Sonia A.

description:
The place is nice and somewhat cozy with dim light.  They have a small bar also. We came here to try their Ramen even though they have early and late happy hour.  

I had the Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen plus I asked for corn and shiitake mushroom for additional charged. 2 pieces of small mushroom for $2! The broth is tonkatsu  base..it wasn't flavorful.  You need to add other spices that was on the table to get a good flavor :/.  It came out lukewarm.  Ugh! Although the ribs were good and the noodles were just ok nothing special. Its just ok. 

My fiancé ordered Chashu Ramen with spicy miso.  It had pork cutlets, bamboo shoot and half a boiled egg.  It came out lukewarm also!  not good!

This is not the best ramen place.  It's just ok. Nothing special.  I'd go back to Sawai Ramen anyday.  


Would I come back? Most likely not because there are better ramen house that I've been to.
author: Junaline G.

description:
AND THEN SOME!!!

Just an update. 

Rolled deep with 11 people and were easily accommodated. Fast service. All those who checked in got their karage-chicken. And we had yet another satisfying experience.

I didn't get the ramen because their ramen here is, typical. Tried new stuff because they have a huge menu.

HEFER STATS.

WATERMELON SHAVE ICE ($4) - this beverage was SO refreshing. Wish the garnish was a small slice of watermelon instead of the skin of the watermelon. 

SHISHITO PEPPER ($2.50) - the skewer had about six pieces. Eating them is like playing Russian Rullet; 3 of 6 were hot. 

SHITAKE MUSHEROOM ($2.50) - there were 3 on a stick. They added way too much sauce in the mushrooms but it was still good. 

BACON WRAPPED ASPARAGUS ($3.50) - why would you add sauce all over this, bacon already has a lot of flavor. The sauce is unnecessary and ruins it. There were 4 pieces on a skewer which really equates to one full asparagus and one bacon slice. 

KARAGE-CHICKEN ($free) - when you check in you get free chicken. Nice bite size pieces, nice out layer crunch, and perfect pour of very little drizzle of sauce on top. 

Will I be back? We always do. 

Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
I've put off coming here because I have yet to find a decent Raman joint in this city and have all but given up. Last Thursday however it was the day to go.

I Ordered Online with Yelp and it couldn't have been any easier. It's great not having to open my wallet or talk to other humans every time I want to buy something. I don't like to deal with miscommunication over the phone but I digress.

I ordered the #411: Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen. Unfortunately, because we live in a small town I was forced to wait until 5:00pm when they started accepting internet orders. I ordered at 5:01 and waited patiently for an entire ten minutes. When I walked in I was immediately greeted so I pointed to my food waiting for me by the register. The friendly woman walked me over to her register and I was in and out in less than five minutes.

The Raman wasn't excellent but I'll give it a pass. If you really like Raman like I do this place will do but don't expect the stars. I'll probably be back sometime but I'm in no rush.
author: Justin S.

description: Not good ramen. The noodles tasted like they were from a Maruchan instant soup cup. Seriously! The strips of chicken in my bowl were also dry, rough and extra chewy ... freshness factor = 0. Won't be back and cannot recommend.
author: D S.

description: I came her with my family for dinner and checked into Yelp for the free Cold Tofu or Edamame and ordered our food. Few minutes later the waitress came back and said they don't have free edamame or cold tofu today. They could only give us seaweed salad for the free check-in. The reason they said was it wasn't free today. Moments later we asked if they were out of Edamame. They said no they still have it in stock but you can buy it. Ok WTF? What's the point of offering it free on Yelp check-in if they don't offer it free and made us buy it $3.50. instant 1 star. I'll give them zero for poor customer service if I could. They forgot to bring us the edamame and charged us for it. Had to send the bill back and get them to remove it. Sigh
author: D Y.

description:
I visit this ramen place regularly and I'm a big fan of their menu. Personal favorites include curry veggie ramen (very convenient for vegetarians as they have an option to make any ramen in a vegetarian base.

Also really like the yakisoba noodles here. Worth mentioning that if you are in SF, they have free delivery between 5-10 PM
author: Nitish S.

description:
Finally got to try this place out with my siblings.

The wait is pretty long in the night. The place is pretty HOT and it's dimly lit. They do need some sort of ventilation though, it was so hot inside. 

Service is alright. The woman who was telling us where to sit wanted us to sit at the bar when there was already an available table that could easily fit 5 of us. We asked politely if we could be seated there instead and all she did was give us a pretty smug look before attending to another group and seating them in the bar .___. 

The menu consists of many options, from ramen, to cold ramen, to rice plates, appetizers, and even skewers. Many of the dishes range from a price of $7-$10, especially if you're going for their ramens. I ordered their Chicken Karaage Ramen ($7.50) and was exceptionally okay with it. It contained corn, green onions, and wakame in a tonkatsu base. The portion seemed smaller than what I would get at other places that serve ramen, but I guess it's alright since I also had chicken karaage. The soup was nice and warm, although it was a bit bland in my opinion. I added a dash of red pepper for more flavors, but it's definitely up to you on how you like your soup :-).

Chicken karaage was served in a separate plate. Crunchy exterior, chewy interior. Deep fried, but no sauce or nothin'. Sorta bland, but given in huge chunks lol. 

Overall, this place decent. If you're super hungry, i wouldn't quite recommend it though, not only because of the wait, but just because you could probably find another place with similar food faster. But I'd come back to try something new though. You're good Genki, with a little improvement, you'd be great :-) .
author: Jerianne G.

description:
I've been consistently coming here for 6 years! I love the Mapo Tofu ramen! It's pretty much the only thing I get. My boyfriend and I made the mistake of ordering the Tonkatsu and curry ramen one time, and we were disappointed. Get the Mapo!! You won't be disappointed. During the lunch special, I usually get the Mapo and the cha han (pork fried rice). The cha han is so good! It's such a simple dish but the flavors are great. And for $1 extra you seriously can't go wrong. 

Oh and if you check in on yelp you can get chicken karaage for freeeee! It usually costs $5 alone or $3 during happy hour! I'm not sure why, but if you use this check-in offer, you have to pay with credit card. Honestly, I would not buy the chicken karaage. It just tasted like fried chicken with some sauce drizzled over it :(. But since it was free, I'm not complaining.

The service here is good! The BF wanted to watch the NBA playoffs, and the waitress was able to switch the channels just for him :) 

They also give Hi-chews with your bill! The cherry on top!!
author: Fanny H.

description:
This is definitely a usual for many of my friends due to the convenience of the location. I've tried a good amount of ramen shops and I'd say that the food is reasonable priced and has ok flavor. 

This place is perfect for late night comfort food or a quick grab & go. The ramen is nothing too special or out of the ordinary. If you are in the area and are looking for something convenient to eat, I would recommend. 

*if you check in on yelp- you get a free side of edamame*
author: Grace Z.

description:
This place is not fooling anyone, it's not authentic Japanese. The service is inattentive and rude. The waitress rushed our order, barely let us speak, and rushed away before we could even ask to add on appetizers. 

The Ma Po Tofu ramen was very bland and plain. The Tan Tan was so extremely salty that it was unbearable and had only 1/3 soup in the bowl.  

The Gyozas were undercooked, the pork inside was fleshy pink.

The Chicken Karaage had no flavor or seasoning, only a slight drizzle of sauce. 

With such a prime location, you'd think they would put some effort into the quality of their food, but it's worse than a fast food joint.
author: Briget P.

description: Not bad. Not good. The quite dim lighting threw me off. Got the nori ramen. yay for it being open late since i get off work late.
author: Josie W.

description:
This place is good for people that like to experience something aside from the traditional ramen. There's a few different types of options that are to die for. My number one choice whenever I come to Genki is the Spicy mapo tofu ramen. Be warned it's a bit spicy and its really oily, but it's sooo good. 

Another good one is the Curry Tonkatsu or Curry Chicken Katsu ramen. For side dishes, try their Croquettes, Tonkatsu, and Chicken Karaage.

Wash it down with their watermelon juice or mango smoothie. 

Parking can be kind of a pain here during the weekend, but definitely worth driving around the block a few times.
author: Milton F.

description:
Really enjoyable! Not much to speak of on the outside but once inside its comfortable. Staff was pleasant and answered any questions I had with an added personal likes on the menu. 

My order:
Daimaru yelp special 2 Stars
Okay, but felt like they thought just frying cheese would do it. Wouldn't order it again. 

Gyoza Pot stickers 4 Stars
A tasty plate. I'd get this again. Stand alone good. 

Beef pepper stir fry 4 Stars 
Enjoyed this plate. Smoking hot when it came out so give it time to eat. Beef was good along with noodles. I'd get this again. 

Overall happy with my experience here and enjoyed my lunch. I'll come back definitely.
author: Kyle G.

description:
Probably the worst ramen I've ever had since I came to the US.
First, I ordered and then the ramen came out like cold. Uh hello? Its ramen. You're supposed to serve it hot. Like steaming hot. Also, the soup tasted like water. Gross. I'm Japanese, and I've ate Ramen from Japan, but I don't know what to call this... TBH. 
And what's funny is that when I had a taste of my boyfriends soup, it tasted like salt water. More like sea water.
I only came here to give a generous one star, because I liked the gyouza. If not, it really deserves 0. The staff is unattentive, there were like plates lying around and they weren't cleaning until few customers left.

Maybe one other good thing was that there was free Hi-chew at the end. 

Not a place for me to go back. Sorry!
author: Aya H.

description: Wish the chasu was more tender, but for a quick eat open for late lunch in my mom's neighborhood, it was decent.  Side of chicken karaage was tasty.  Broth was a good flavor.  Noodles were the right chewiness.  Then again, we were pretty hungry close to 2pm.
author: B C.

description: Okay honestly this place is overpriced but tasty. The chashu yakisoba is almost $10 but it feels like $8. To go box is small... But it's really good and the chashu is so tender. The onigiri is $4/2 but I can get bigger onigiri in japantown and it's more worth the price.
author: Bianca M.

description:
Fast service, good food, and affordable prices. 
It's simple, casual and reliable. No wait on a Saturday evening, friendly staff.
author: Pauline T.

description: Wow, this place is amazing it been a long time since I've had some good ramen. We just ordered for delivery. I can't wait to eat here if the food is this good at home it's probably bomb there. Looking forward to trying something new on the menu.
author: Sasha M.

description:
Everything about this place is so average. I've tried their mapo tofu, tan tan, chashu, and butter corn ramens and they are just so EH. The noodles are nothing special, they're thin with no bite. The broth is boring and very plain as well. 
I give it 3 stars because the waitresses are very nice and the food comes out pretty fast. I've tried some of their appetizers and skewers which were pretty good. But if you're looking for good ramen don't come here.
author: Christine L.

description:
Came here on a usual cold and gloomy SF day to catch up with some friends I hadn't seen in a while.

FOOD:
We started out with some appetizers: edamame, chicken karaage, and takoyaki. Nothing special about the edamame. The karaage was ok. Felt like I ate more fried batter than chicken. The takoyaki came out hot and were small enough to fit inside your mouth although you have to be careful not to burn yourself! I felt they skimped a bit on the toppings and sauce so it didn't come out as flavorful as I expected.

For ramen, we ordered the curry chicken katsu ramen, chashu ramen (with extra chashu), tan tan ramen, and chicken cold ramen. Overall most of us liked our orders. The ramen was al dente (which I love) and portion size was decent. My friend who ordered the tan tan was disappointed though. He said it was a bit too salty for him.

Check in on yelp and you get a free appetizer: chicken karage or daruma tofu (valued at $4.95).
Overall: 3/5

SERVICE:
Service here can be a hit or a miss. This time there weren't very many tables occupied. The servers were pretty attentive and refilled my water on numerous occasions.
Overall: 4/5

DECOR/AMBIANCE:
Simple decor and fairly clean interior. There is a small bar area and some tvs on both sides of the room playing sports channels. You can see the kitchen in the back and watch them make your food. There isn't a lot of space inside the restaurant though, so getting in and out from your table can require some work.
Overall: 3/5

I always have to give myself extra time when coming here to eat because of parking. If you're lucky you may find a metered parking spot on Geary. Oftentimes, I have to drive a couple of rounds and hope someone is leaving on the side streets for a parking spot.
author: Melisa C.

description:
I'm with Nobu K. on his visceral reaction to this rather plasticine place, and I have to ask the same question I asked when I ate at 5A5 Steak Lounge...is 'lukewarm' the new black? If the quality of the food is of such high caliber, I guess the temperature could be secondary...maybe. But when it's middling to begin with, why add insult to injury by making the broth just a cut above room temperature? That's what happened when I ordered their house special, the $9.75 bowl of Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen. The tonkotsu broth would have been so much more flavorful if they bothered to light a switch under the burner.

The roasted garlic and spinach were fine, but the concept of "pork soft bone" threw me since I nearly cracked a molar with some of the pieces swimming in the broth (photo: http://bit.ly/16lfIe6). I also went for a pair of the Robatayaki barbecue skewers which I found a bit overpriced for the paltry amount of meat provided. The $4.50 Lamb Chop with Mint Sauce was barely a lamb chop with little trace of the mint sauce. I was about to call in CSI when it dawned on me that the mint could have been in the marinade. A more reasonable deal could be found in the $2.75 Pork Neck with Soy Sauce where assume to innards of a pig's esophagus were threaded onto the stick (photo: http://bit.ly/11oWVxJ).

I frankly liked both skewers but they were gone so soon. An added bonus came by way of my virginal check-in which yielded a "Free Daruna Tofu or Edamame" coupon which had me shoving my iPhone into the young waitress's confused face. She informed me in an indifferent tone that the free deal that evening would be a pair of Potato Croquettes (normally $4.50) (photo: http://bit.ly/10JY9Ms). I was disheartened by the prospect since I had a flashback to a classic Yasujiro Ozu film where the unmarried daughter came home to her traditional Japanese family much too late to have dinner with them and could only have croquettes with rice before going to bed.

This sad scene of rejection was accompanied by the moan of a mournful oboe indicating how the daughter lost face as she nibbled on her croquette. But when my croquettes arrived, I actually enjoyed them. They reminded me of the pocket hash browns you get at McDonald's but less greasy. I actually meant that as a compliment. Anyway, I just found the whole dining experience at Genki Ramen on the lackluster side, although that doesn't appear to stop the hipster parade from coming in here, something the waitstaff appears to anticipate with brio. When I got up from my chair simply to adjust my pants, I was given the heave-ho with an abrupt "Oyasuminasai!" Well, OK then.

FOOD - 2 stars...lukewarm ramen and skimpy skewers make the free Mickey D-style potatoes the default winner
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...synthetic is the only adjective that fits here (photo: http://bit.ly/10mfCur)
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...nice enough until it was time to release my table
TOTAL - 2 stars...genki desuka?...only semi-genki, dude
author: Ed U.

description: some of the best ramen i have had on the west coast. Being a vegetarian it is hard to find good ramen. Strongly recommend the two veggie ramens on the menu.
author: Rup S.

description: It is a very standard ramen restaurant. Sometimes, the Chef made the food a little salty. I do appreciate it when they play sports on the tv and have other food options if you don't want ramen.
author: Niki Y.

description:
Love this place! 
It's my 2nd time here and the ramen is so good!! I ordered 402-Chicken Karaage, it's like this fried crispy chicken nugget pieces and you get your bowl of ramen (miso based soup, noodles, corn and green onions). The chicken was really good!

The strawberry smoothie was good, fresh strawberries with milk and ice all blended. My son enjoyed that and the French fries.

My mom ordered like a veggie ramen and the soup was REALLY good. Like better than my miso based soup good. 

Service is good and everyone was attentive. Def will come by again whenever I'm in the area.
author: Aileene C.

description:
Four stars?  Man, I was pretty charitable back in 2009!  Maybe that explains why I have so many four star reviews.  Either that, or maybe I really am just a nice guy.  ;)

While I'm genuinely surprised with how many stars I gave Genki, I should say it's not because their ramen is bad.  Rather, it just seems so unremarkable now compared to what you can get at newer places in SF.  Something like the Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen is fine and all (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/genki-ramen-san-francisco#o15fNqy49Qaz6KTNhBLsRA), but it falls short compared to the Spicy Garlic Tonkotsu at Saiwaii Ramen or the Spicy Tonkotsu at Men Oh Tokushima.  Between the mediocre broth, average noodles, and lackluster meat, there isn't anything about the ramen to distinguish itself.

What Genki can (and should) hang its hat on though, is its menu.  Beyond staples like Gyoza, Agedashi Tofu, and Takoyaki (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/genki-ramen-san-francisco#RO91LjXQ90opGakYS70GKg), it's cool how they offer up unique dishes like Seafood Fried Rice and favorites like Seafood Okonomiyaki (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/genki-ramen-san-francisco#77mln--fYhO2OySTR0e27Q).  Of course, it doesn't hurt that the Takoyaki and Seafood Okonomiyaki were pretty decent as well - both had a good amount of octopus/seafood and were cooked quite nicely.  Also, on a side note, it's surprising more places don't include okonomiyaki on their menus considering how people love it so much.

Even though Genki is more wallet friendly than other ramen joints, I'd personally be willing to pay a few bucks more for something much more satisfying.  But if you're looking to eat in the area (especially if it's late), Genki isn't the worst choice you could make either.
author: Mike L.

description:
Fast service, delicious food, great ramen (a little spicy but good).

Go for the fast service, don't go for the well supported tables.
author: Jenn B.

description: Sooooo delicious that I can't stop thinking about the dish I had. The wait staff is very kind and attentive, the food is delicious, the vibe is fantastic and prices are great too.
author: Alexis Lynn E.

description: We came on a recommendation from my brother in law and was lucky enough to score two tables for dinner! Thanks to you fellow yelpers I went with the Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen and it was delicious! The broth was really tasty and the meat was super tender. I've heard it's a pain to park in the area, but we were able to find a spot around the corner (it was about 8pm on a Monday night). The restroom was really clean (a big plus for me, especially in the city!) and the restaurant overall was tidy. Would definitely drop by again if we're in the area!
author: Meryl C.

description:
An hour and a half for delivery estimated to be 60 minutes MAXIMUM. 

They claimed 45-60 minute delivery MAXIMUM. Food wasn't delivered for just over an hour and a half. What a joke. I doubt we'll order from this place ever again, and I have a hard time imagining we'll use Yelp or Eat24 over other services that don't take as long. 

Yelp/Eat24's response was that the restaurant was "busy."  Thanks.  I *love* estimates that are I incredibly, horribly wrong. Sounds like a bad interface between Yelp and the restaurant. Not sure I'd trust "estimates" for other places.
author: Lauren C.

description:
To say that I love coming here would be a grave understatement.
In my day to day interactions and habits, I often find myself feeling like Beyonce in her Deja Vu video; except instead of seeing Jay-Z in everything around me, it's the garlic tenderous rib ramen that I just can't get over.  It is literally the only thing I have been able to order from here for the past 5 times I have dined at this fine establishment.  I have also tried the spicy tofu ramen from here, and it is delicious as well-but I would not want a whole bowl of it to myself-I'm sort of lame when it comes to dishes that are spicy and have to tap out.  

But back to the garlic tenderous rib.  It comes with spinach, half of a hard boiled egg, and the rib meat on the bones up in with all of your ramen.  The broth is really good, not too salty, and you have the option of adding more vegetables or another egg and whatnot to any ramen.  Their menu is also packed with other items that are not ramen such as chicken katsu, veggie plates etc.  Good happy hour prices on drinks too-sake and beer, or if you're someone who is into fruity things they have those sweet drinks too.
author: Amber D.

description: Love the curry ramen. My girlfriend likes the side of corn on the cobb and the frozen lychee drink.
author: Peter B.

description:
Absolutely love this ramen place! This is probably my 10th+ time here. The servers are friendly, the drinks and food came out quick, and we got hi chews with our check! And the background music is on point too!

I definitely recommend the chicken karaage ramen, pork fried rice, and pineapple iceberg smoothie! Thank you, Genki Ramen for a great time!
author: Kyle S.

description: Just about average Ramen place. Food was decent, but there are better Ramen places in town, service was pleasant.
author: Olivier L.

description:
Overall: delicious and not over-priced!

I ordered delivery which is not very typical of me, because I can sometimes be a bit particular about the temperature and freshness of food. Well, I was pleasantly surprised as everything was still piping hot. I would say it would almost pass as dine-in quality. 

Wakame: If you like standard seaweed salad then you will have no complaints with theirs 

Shots Niku Ramen #419: Fantastic. Tonkatsu was tasty and rich. Beef was sautéed in a ginger-green onion sauce, and the noodles had a nice soft bite to them. Would order again. 

Takoyaki: Its always risky ordering to-go something that's fried. This was still hot and still had a little crisp on them. Flavorful and really enjoyed. (Only bummer was I asked for the sauce on the side to try to keep things more crisp, however they came sauced up.)


Look forward to a dine-in experience!
author: Jessica L.

description:
This was my second time here.
Not crowded. But the service here is ridiculous!
My friend and I met up with 2 other people who were already here. We were sitting for about 15 mins and no one came up to us so my friend tried to get a waitress' attention but she ignored us. 
Another friend tried to get a waitress' attention but again we were ignored. So I raised my 2 arms up and waved it back and forth and yelled if we could get a menu so we could order. A lady rushed towards us. I had been sitting in the restaurant for about 40 mins with my tummy grumbling really loud! 

We finally received the ramen we each ordered but were never given napkins and chopsticks. Also at this point we found that the restaurant had a check in offer through Yelp of free daimaru or gyoza. So again we flagged for a waitress so we could order daimaru and ask for napkins and chopsticks.
She came. With half of her attention to us and the other half trying to sit a group down we asked for the daimaru and then she immediately walked away. This didn't give us a chance to ask her for utensils so we just grabbed some from another table. 

I don't have a clue what was up with the people at Genki Ramen last Monday but I surely will not return here. 

The place was not busy at all and service was HORRIBLE!!! The first time I came here my waiter was very kind!! Very helpful and even took the time to describe to me what each appetizer was. But this second time was just horrible!!!
author: Majileen C.

description: If you're a vegetarian, go for the Yasai Ramen w/ veggie broth (and get spicy miso as well). Quite tasty!
author: Khushboo M.

description: I've been going here for a long time and I use there delivery service all the time. The Chicken Curry Katsu Ramen is amazing
author: Mike D.

description:
Stopped by here for lunch on a slow Friday and there were only 3 tables seated. Service was pretty quick and I took advantage of the yelp deal and got a free seaweed salad, the char sui ramen and some fried rice for my son. 

The fried rice was WAY too salty - my son, who is all about fried rice refused it after a few bites because of this. I tried it too in order to make sure, and it was pretty salty. 

The broth of the ramen was OK - tasty, but not the best I've ever had. The noodles tasted like they were prepackaged noodles that you would get from cup-of-noodles honestly. Sad! And the char sui was TOUGH...almost like pork jerky, although I think pork jerky has more give than the char sui in this ramen. That hasn't happened to me at any ramen place. 

The only saving grace was the nice waiter who was super attentive to my son and I. I don't think we'll be back given how many other awesome ramen places are in the area.
author: Marie S.

description:
Decent ramen. Top favorites are: beef stew ramen (nice brisket, spinach, tonkotsu broth), spicy mabo tofu ramen (chinese style mabo tofu with minced pork in a thick sauce, so delicious!), noodles with meat sauce, beef enoki mushroom rolls, yakisoba, and chahan. 

This isn't one of those authentic japanese ramen restaurants. They've got a huge menu consisting of different types of ramen, noodle dishes, sizzling platters, rice, appetizers. Happy hour 4-6 pm and 10 pm is amazing. $3 appetizers and cheap drinks ($15 for a huge pitcher of beer). If you check in you get a free appetizer as well. Lunch menu you can order a ramen and pay a few extra bucks to make it a combo (choice of gyoza, karaage, or chahan). All three are yum.

I used to come here a lot when I was back in college. Pretty good food for the price you pay as a college student. Plus they deliver :)
author: Ava F.

description:
This is my boyfriend and I's favorite ramen place to go! There are many other ramen restaurants in SF and San Mateo that are well known with lines out the door. However, Genki Ramen has little to no wait time for some spectacular dishes! 

The ramen noodles are the star of the show! A tasty home made carb overload in a sodium packed bowl is all that I crave for in a cold SF night. 

In addition, the sizziling hot plate Seafood Yakisoba was divine!

Tips:
Happy hour 3-6 and evening happy hour
Lunch menu until 5pm
High chews instead of mints!!!
Check in for free seaweed salad!

Enjoy!
author: Briana H.

description:
This ramen place is usually not too crowded. They have good happy hours in the early evening and late evening with food and drink discounts. However I will always get their ramen. My favorite is the tenderous pork rib ramen. The meat is super flavorful. Their soju cocktails are also pretty tasty. 

The one thing I would ask this place to improve is their broth. It's not quite flavorful enough... I always end up having to add the spicy flakes and chili oil to oomph up the flavor. It needs more salt or something. 

I would come back here again because it seems to be one of the few ramen places in this town I can get into without having to wait in a massive line. And it's good enough that it hits the spot. It stays open late too, which is perfect for the late night crowd.
author: Jeanne M.

description: The food is alright. Service was quick. I ordered Karaage chicken ramen with tonkatsu broth. The noodle is not home made, broth is decent but not the best I have had. The side was a set of gyozas and they were underwhelming. The total price was 12.50 before tipping. Given the price it's pretty good value.
author: Shengyin G.

description:
Did they change owners or something? All the servers here were speaking Thai.... Could I please have a pad Thai or pad see you instead of some ramen? 

Service was slow and waiters were rude. 

Won't be coming back.
author: Tee Y.

description: Been here twice, our first time we sat for probably 4 hours eating & talking with friends coming & going. No one seemed to mind, & they kept serving us food & beer. Love the ramen w the pork & fried garlic pieces & an order of kimchi on the side!
author: Brittney H.

description:
Ok so far ... THIS is the best Ramen I've had  in SF! If their ramen and service is this yummy every time as my first visit, this place will soar with business! 

We ordered the Chashu Pork Ramen and it was off the hook!!! I'm married to a Japanese and he really enjoyed this miso ramen! That's saying a lot he's very picky!

I wanna go back !!!
author: Bahvee V.

description:
Meh!

I was craving for a bowl of ramen, but it was late and Genki was the closest to us that was still open.  Their fried appetizers were not good, including the generous size free karaage when you check-in on Yelp.  Their yakitori skewers were okay.  How about their noodle?!  NO!  There was hardly any soup in the bowl and the soup has no flavor.  The ribs in my ramen were dry and hard when it supposed to be tenderous.  The noodle tasted like those packaging ones you can get in any Asian supermarkets.  *Sigh*  I have made better ones at home for Mr. J!
author: Kay Y.

description:
The food here is okay, but the service is so awful. Just...like..okay, I'm so sorry I'm patronizing your business, and inconveniencing you by not knowing what I want 2 minutes after being seated. And yes, I STILL don't know what I want after you rudely left and came back within another 2 minutes. Oh, by the way, I notice there's only THREE other occupied tables, and you have 2 additional servers working, so WTF is your deal? 

Can I get some extra kimchi with your rudeness? It's no wonder they are not nearly as busy as they use to be.
author: Mary S.

description:
My ramen buddy Allen took me here for lunch after discovering that I've never been.

We both got the lunch special: chasu ramen and a side of chicken karage. And shared a seafood okonomiyaki. The chasu ramen was pretty standard with the broth was lacking some depth. The chicken karage was good. Hot, crispy, juicy! But the star was the okonomiyaki. It was delicious! I've had ones in the past that had too much batter and cooked unevenly. But this one was perfectly cooked with the seafood cut up into small pieces so they are in every bite. 

I highly recommend coming for lunch! Fast and friendly service!
author: Marti L.

description: Genki Ramen is better than some of the ramen places in Hawaii. Miss this place. Will come back to this place when I visit home.
author: N A.

description:
I will start this review by letting you yelpers know that Genki is not authentic Japanese ramen. They offer a mix of "asian" style foods, which I don't actually know what that means, but I watched the owner of Genki say that on a video. They have items like Kimchi ( which is traditionally korean), and also Shumai which is a chinese dumpling.

Anyway, the ramen was average and it curbed my ramen craving. I was looking forward to trying Ramen Dojo, but couldn't make it out because of the rain. 

I opted for the Negi beef ramen with extra green onions. Totally not traditional. I was most disappointed to find out that it was not typical ramen. Did not come with a soft boiled egg, which I was craving. It came with good beef stir fry with onions and green bell pepper with ramen noodles and broth. The broth was good, I think the saltiness and garlic flavor of the beef added to the complexity of the broth. 
My two friends I was with, said that their broth ( the same broth as mine minus the beef ) was very bland and had no flavor as far as typical tonkatsu broth it did not meet their expectations. They both chose the chasu ramen and weren't very impressed. They were both disappointed that the ramen came with only 1/2 of an egg and it was hard boiled. 

We were disappointed to learn that Genki no longer offered okonomiyaki.

Genki seems like a fun place to drink with friends and enjoy a mix of asian bar foods, an american izakaya if you will. It was super cheap, only 30 bucks for 3 ramens. Not really my style, but I know a lot of people would find the atmosphere enjoyable. The ramen was "okay" overall, but not the authenticity that I look for in ramen. The service wasn't anything spectacular. Probably wouldn't come back unless I was in the neighborhood, walking distance away.
author: Alexandra C.

description:
Location: On Geary, which is bustling with Asian restaurants (sushi, Hong Kong style desserts, etc). Parking is limited to street parking with meters, and can get filled during dinner time.

Service: Waiters and waitresses are very attentive. Every time I come, they seat us immediately and are always ready to take our orders and give the checks.

Food: I always get the curry chicken katsu, and my SO gets the tonkatsu ramen. I like the option to add corn. Both dishes are amazing, due to the deliciously made ramen. The ramen is soft, packed with flavor and the broths are hot. I especially like how there's not excess oil in the broth.

Drinks: They have a lot of cocktails with soju, and I'm a fan of the "So Cool" Drink (soju and yogurt mix).

Bonus: I usually check-in on Yelp and there's usually a promotion for free edamame or karaage. Also, you get free hi-chews! I once embarrassingly dropped my hi-chew and was trying to hide it, but they gave me another!
author: Ruby K.

description:
What a good day to come here while it is rainy and gloomy. I was excited to try this place even though their rating is not high. I have no clue why they do not have a higher rating when their food is delicious. They also have great service and the place looks clean and decent.

I ordered :  1) Chashu ramen = love the broth and the noodle. 
                    
                     2) Okonomiyaki Seafood = awesome sauce and perfect as an appetizer!

This is going to be my second favorite ramen place to go to. I forgot to mention that they give generous amount of pork compared to other ramen restaurant such as Orenchi, Ramen Dojo, Maru Ichi, etc... 

Will definitely eat here during happy hour where the appetizer and alcohol drinks are only $3!
author: Owie N.

description:
I have been to Genki various times, and even ordered take out from the restaurant. I absolutely love Genki's flavor & quality. The food is always on point, and they do have vegetarian miso soup base available! The food comes out relatively fast, and so was the take out. The people who work here are also very polite. :)

The prices are awesome, but the portion sizes are a biiiiit small... That is my only problem!

I recommend trying out: Fresh Watermelon Juice & the Curry Vegetable Ramen with Vegetarian Soup Base. especially during happy hour...Which is twice a day! ;)
author: Tricks J.

description: I like that this place is open up late. I came on a Saturday night around 9pm and it was dead empty. It looks like they do quite a bit of delivery. The fact they have two different happy hours for their appetizers is great. I like that they have takoyaki. They only place that has those is Quicklys. Plus they just don't serve ramen. Their service is quick and food is hot.
author: Nick N.

description: I really enjoyed their Chashu Ramen, but portion size could have been a bit better.
author: Orlando M.

description:
I'm hooked on ramen from here. We often get this to go and order the Tan Tan or the Mabo Tofu--both are excellent.   I really love the Mabo broth.  

We have ventured out to the actual restaurant only once--food was even better sitting there (duh).   We ordered the pot stickers when we ate in house and they were quite good. 

I can't say I'm a ramen expert, but I've had it a few places and this is one of my favorites--especially since it can be delivered.
author: Amy J.

description: In general, when someone goes to the bathroom, but hasn't paid and left their bag at the table, you don't throw away more than half of a dish away.  When I came back and told you that you threw away most of my dinner, you brought me less than I left I left on the plate in a to go box.  Error on the side of caution when replacing a meal next time.
author: Kevin S.

description:
The wait took forever, but it was expected since I did come during the evening on a weekend. The place was relatively clean and had a nice layout. The waiters and servers were very knowledgable of the menu and recommended Stir-fried Beef Ramen, which was surprisingly good. I actually had ramen before, which left a terrible impression so this was definitely a good save. 

I walked out satisfied, although the serving was little for the price. Their lunch specials might have been a better alternative for $$. I did check in for a free appetizer, which quickly squelched my remaining hunger. 

I would recommend this place to a friend.
author: Chinsin S.

description:
Genki Ramen has been one of my favorite ramen places in San Francisco for a while. I love chicken karaage, so as expected their chicken karaage ramen is a personal favorite. I've been here several times for lunch, happy hour, and dinner.

Lunch:
I love that their lunch combination is extremely customizable. You can select your choice of appetizers or mixtures to complement your bowl of ramen, ranging from the customary chashu to katsu or tofu.

Happy Hour:
Their happy hour offers several appetizers are a lower price. I haven't ordered the regular portions of these appetizers, but I was shocked by how small the portion was for the Nasu Gomaae (which by the way is absolutely delicious) and daruma tofu (just okay - not that special).

Dinner:
As I don't live in San Francisco, I most often find myself enjoying the ramen here for dinner. I almost always stick to my chicken karaage ramen, but occasionally deviate to chicken katsu or chashu. 

Overall, this place has good food at reasonable prices, a nice atmosphere for conversations, and almost always no wait. Plus, remember to check in to snag a free appetizer!
author: Michael L.

description: The tonkotsu broth has no flavor. The edamame was boiled with the same water they made noodles with, I know this because there were a lot of noodle pieces in my edamame. The gyoza was made too soft so the filling kept falling out when me try to grab it.
author: Vivian H.

description: Another pretty good ramen spot in the Richmond area. (The other being Men Oh!) but I'm gonna see if I can expand my horizons in the area... Anyways, back to genki, we went on a pretty slow time (around late lunch) so we got seated right away. That's actually a big plus for me as some other places close for lunch but here at genki, the door is always open! As far as the food is concerned, it's pretty on par with other ramen places but it's nothing spectacular.
author: Marco M.

description: I enjoyed Genki Ramen the first time around. The second time we went, our group felt VERY THIRSTY afterwards. Maybe it has MSG?? Their drinks are sweet but very weak, after 3  of their soju cocktails, we didn't even feel anything and opted for the beer instead. I really like thier wings but the second time around, it was burnt! Happy Hour is 3-6 and from 10-close.
author: Vanessa Y.

description: Place is amazing if you ever have a chance try the watermelon drink with ice this palace is perfect for the night person
author: Alex D.

description:
Don't order here through the Eat24 app. They state the arrival time is 45-60 minutes.
90 minutes later and still no food. I ended up calling twice and they kept telling me that my order was "on its way." 

When my order was finally delivered, everything was cold. I called to try and get a discount for my $50 order, but they just said sorry but they don't give discounts.
author: Mandi W.

description: 2nd time I made the mistake of ordering from this place.  Got the seafood Ramen and found multiple pieces of paper floating in the soup...  Disguisting.
author: josh d.

description:
This is a great place for late night hearty eats. They even have a late night happy hour. I have not had a dish that had disappointed yet. My favorite is the mushroom ramen and tonkatsu. The croquettes and the beef and enoki rolls are yummy as an appetizer. Yeah, I love mushrooms. ;)

Again, happy hour starts for a second round at 10pm... Can't beat that when most things seen to close early in the area.
author: Amelia M.

description:
I just became a huge fan of Genki Crepes. So I have decided to check out the sister location for some ramen noodles, which is located one block over on busy Geary Blvd.  

Many of my admirers know that I have an unusual craving for Ramen noodle soup on nice days. With the recent nice weather in the Bay Area, I indeed have that sudden craving for Ramen noodles in the inner-Richmond District. 

For my evening lunch, I had the Curry Chicken Katsu Ramen Noodle Soup. For $8.50, I get generous slices of Panko-battered chicken with sliced carrots; potatoes and thick ramen pasta in a thick curry soup. A hearty meal the noodle soup was. But the thick curry soup was a bit too salty for my liking. 

By any stretch of the imagination, I may not be a ramen-expert. But my meal was okay. The hustling ladies were really nice. 

I do like the late hours. The blended drinks (alcoholic & non) look refreshing with fresh ingredients. I may try those drinks and maybe give another chance and try other dishes next time. 

Also if you check-in with your mobile device, you get a special deal with your meal on the visit.
author: Matt G.

description:
This is our neighborhood go-to spot. I'd say we end up at Genki Ramen once every three weeks or so, maybe more often. The menu is somewhat limited, but if you want ramen or a few other of their specialties, I find the food quality high and the prices reasonable.

All of their ramens are good, but I think the ton katsu curry is the best.

If you're going to get a yakisoba, get the black peppered beef.

You might read some other reviews here about the japanese pancake thing. I was unimpressed the one time I ordered it.

They also have really good skewers. Give those a try. Service here isn't amazing as the appetizer often comes out at the same time as the main course, and they move people in and out pretty quickly.

It's a great little ramen spot, and I really recommend the black pepper yakisoba.
author: Kevin H.

description:
For basic, delicious, tasty ramen this is a great spot to stop into. Their ramen is tasty, good textured noodles, and offer a late night happy hour! My usual order looks like the following:
- charsiew ramen with corn added
Or
- butter and corn ramen

- watermelon smoothie is delicious! Tastes like you're biting into a watermelon. Yum. 

During the weekends there can be a long wait but weekdays after 8 is a great time to grab dinner without a long line.
author: Belia P.

description:
I had never been to a ramen house before but I'm so glad I had a great experience at Genki Ramen. I pass this place on my way home and always see the sign reading "Happy Hour 10pm-close". That's a first! I usually never make it in time for happy hour anywhere else. They offer $3 drinks and appetizers during happy hour and it's definitely worth it to wait till 10pm. 

My boyfriend and I shared some pork pot stickers (about 6 perfectly fried and hot), 3 mini egg rolls (crispy, hot and delicious) and a bottle of sake. I also had the Sour Pinky Cocktail...it was too sweet for me but tasted like the description said. 

For my main course I got the curry chicken ramen. Oh. My. God. So delicious I had to eat the whole bowl! The ramen was cooked just right and the broth made me want to pick up the bowl and drink it. They blended just the right amount of curry and spices. The chicken was crunchy on the outside and flavorful on the inside. 

The staff was very friendly and attentive to our needs. They always smiled and greeted us right away when we walked in. I don't know if it's usually like this but it was pretty warm inside the restaurant and by the time we were done with our hot ramen we needed some fresh cold air. The other thing was our appetizers and ramen came at the same time. I usually like to have my drinks and appetizers before my main course but I could easily overlook that for how delicious it was. 

Before we left I saw another table order a chocolate fondue that came with rice krispies, bananas, strawberries, and more. Next time I want dessert I might just go there for that! They also had a yummy looking Creme Brulee that I was too full to try.

Next time your craving some hot soup and cheap appetizers, go to Genki Ramen! I assure you that you'll never buy packaged ramen again!
author: Ashley M.

description:
tl;dr

This is one of the best SF ramen places! What a sleeper hit.

---

My girlfriend used to live a 5 minute walk from this place, so we came to Genki at all hours - for lunch, for dinner, for late dinner, and best of all, for happy hour (we were in love with their blue So Cool drink that is literally 95% Yakult and 5% alcohol).

Over the three years she was in SF, we found ourselves returning time and time again to Genki, and slowly we've also sampled most of the menu. 

Honestly, I consider this one of the best ramens in SF, and I'm saying that with a straight face, totally serious.

What Genki does right is not the traditional miso, shoyu, shio...traditional ramens. What Genki does right is making impeccable fusion ramen, so don't come here expecting a solid bowl of traditional tonkotsu.

Genki excels at blending flavors together, even superimposing dishes like Negi Beef and Shoga Niku on top of a bowl of ramen and having it work (which, incidentally, are my two favorite ramens at this place). The flavors are always delightful and super yummy. Granted, sometimes the ramen tastes so good that I wonder if I'm just having a healthy dose of MSG, but since I trust my tastebuds which are essentially ultra-sensitive detectors (I get super thirsty an hour afterwards), it so far passes my test.

Very broadly, the appetizers are so-so (but great during Happy Hour when they are discounted), yakisoba and okonomiyaki are alright, but the ramens - ALL OF THEM - are fantastic. The skewers aren't worth it - save your money and get a second bowl :)

Oh, while you're at it, make sure to indulge in some So Cool Yakult goodness. Can't wait to go back!

+ Recs: Negi beef, shoga niku, kinoko mushroom, kimchi, mabo tofu
+ During lunch you can add a small chahan or karaage to your ramen for $1 extra. The extra portion is tiny but I do it anyway :P the karaage is very average.
+ Ask for more of the little plates of pickled cabbage they give you in the beginning :P
+ Happy Hour: 3-6p, 10p-close, 7 days a week, $3 appetizers and $3 drinks! :D
author: Chris S.

description: Mehh the ramen was alright. I tried the garlic tendinous rib ramen with char siu and my boyfriend got the spicy mabo tofu ramen. Both of them were super salty and the mabo tofu soup was not spicy at all. The free cheese dumplings from the yelp check in deal was good though. It's nice that they are opened late but i don't think i would ever come back.
author: Michelle H.

description: Flavor okay, service just okay even with the place being barely occupied at lunch, portion and lack of ingredients a concern. Maybe I'm just used to a larger quantity of fresh ingredients but here aside from a scoop of noodles there was minimal amount of kimchi, one shroom, and three small slabs of pork which all had partial fat cuts. Average.
author: Patrick O.

description: I try the curry beef Ramen, so nice!!! I love it and the price are so good. I live around there just 5 mins walk, love GENKI lol
author: Sunny W.

description: My ramen was top notch, so tasty!  Stopped in late at night after a long motorcycle ride and I was starving and tired.  I would have given 4 stars, but the music.  They obviously cater to the young crowd because it was hard to relax and eat my food while listening to loud pumping rave music.  The ramen was so good though!
author: Linda C.

description:
Seriously???

We have been living in Pac Heights for 12 years and we JUST NOW found this place???

Unbelievably tasty food, loved the Yakisoba and the Ramen was fresh tasting...Oh, did I mention this was DELIVERED...?

Friendly people taking the order and a very timely delivery...Love this new place for us to order from...TRY IT!
author: Christos L.

description: Today I got two dishes; the Kinoko Mushroom Ramen and the Seafood Okonomiyaki. The ramen broth was very flavorful. We enjoyed our meal and my daughter was happy that they gave hi-chews at the end with our check.
author: Mark W.

description: Came here for lunch and got the Tan Tan Ramen. It smelled really good and had a lot of minced pork! Service was really good and food came out quickly.
author: Christine P.

description:
i love RAMEN ...especially when it's a good joint and convenienty located across the street from KPSFO French Campus and i just finished a class just in time for lunch ;)  ...and they have a free perk for checking in on YELP!!!  

*great food * great place to eat * Happy Hour is 3-6p 7days a week
author: Omar N.

description: Food is decent, but service sucked. Right when we walked in, we signaled for a table for 3 and the waitress signaled to us to wait with a very stern look on her face. We didn't wait very long. I ordered chasu ramen with corn and a kids meal of pork tonkatsu and chicken teriyaki. The taste of the food was not bad, but during the meal, my ramen bowl tipped over (not very sturdy) and all the broth and ingredients spilled all over me, my seat on the bench, and on the floor. I asked for a mop to clean it up because it was everywhere and I could not sit in the space anymore. Both waitresses would not clean the area or offer a mop so I could clean it, but did offer some napkins, however, it was much more than some napkins can hold. Regardless of the spill, there was not one instance prior to the spill or after the spill did I feel our waitresses exemplify anything close to good customer service. There are better ramen houses and Japanese restaurants to bother with bad service.
author: Jean S.

description:
The ramen was not good. I ordered a negi beef ramen which was stir fried Mongolian style beef in a tonkatsu ramen. The sauce from the beef really ruined the rest of the ramen because everything tasted like the beef. That was disappointing. I ordered chahan rice, chashu fried rice, which was also disappointing. The meat wasn't flavorful like chashu usually is. The pork was just cooked not pinkyness to it. The rice was just plain. I often expect sweet and salty fried rice from Japanese restaurants so this was pretty bad.
The check came to us and they had already added gratuity to the check. We only had a group of 5. The check didn't even show the total amount but all the food items we ordered, tax, and the total with gratuity. When we paid and got the receipt we saw the total was about $38 and we paid about $44. 
Overall the food isn't that good and they're unprofessional.
author: Kristyn G.

description: Made our way out here to eat after going to the nightlife at Academy of Science.  Sadly, they denied letting the two of us in to sit and eat even though it was only 10:20pm.  Maybe you should change your closing time to 10:30pm...  Then maybe I wouldn't have gotten my hopes up about eating ramen.
author: Yvette S.

description: San Francisco doesn't have too many good traditional ramen places that i know of but i do definitely like coming here. The broths not fatty but still pretty good. I'm giving this place only three stars because its always a hit or miss on service here. Food is always good and so are the drinks. Coming here on a friday night though means you've got a wait ahead of you. Service, like i said is a hit or miss. There are days where service is on point while other days you might just get someone completely rude and have it ruin your day. Otherwise if service was on point every time... I would have given this place four stars for better effort.
author: Linda L.

description:
Great place to get ramen, but part of the reason I like it is because I never had to wait in line here like at other ramen places. Not sure if everyone will have the same luck with this place as I have had.

The two bowls I like here are the chashu ramen and the butter & corn ramen. During lunch, you have the option of adding a side dish for $1. I usually get the chicken karaage since they give you a lot for just $1, versus only two pieces of gyoza.

You can watch some sports in here too - one time during the Giants' playoff run we came here during lunch to catch part of the game. It was pretty nice too because not a lot of people would think of watching games at a ramen shop.
author: Allen C.

description:
So... It's Saturday night around 10:15.
 Parking was not bad!

No wait for two.

Ordered one appetizer and free short ribs with check in.. And two ramen bowls.

Everything comes out promptly and our waitress was busting her butt working so hard. She did not stop for one minute.

When the check comes, you get hi chew! I'm in love!!!! I'm coming back soon all the time.
author: Neek W.

description: The beef ramen bowl was good, maybe a bit too salty for me cause I can feel my fingers swelled up the next day.
author: Ms R.

description:
The ramen is meeeeeeh....

(Yelp thinks I'm writing in Dutch... what??)
author: Jess C.

description:
My go-to place for Asian comfort food in my neighborhood. Reasonably priced and never a long wait.  

The lunch combos are great: I usually order the garlic tenderous rib ramen (with the garlic on the side) + chahan (BBQ pork) fried rice.   

Happy hour prices are hard to beat:
$3 appetizers like chicken wings, chicken karage, gyozas, and croquettes.  

Other goodies: 
-peppered-beef yakisoba (comes on a sizzling hot plate!) 
- tako balls (deep fried croquette balls with pieces of octopus)
author: Catherine C.

description:
We keep on coming back from the pepper beef yakisoba. It's great with a beef on draft.   

http://www.yelp.com/menu/genki-ramen-san-francisco/item/605-black-peppered-beef-yakisoba
author: Tony T.

description:
So many negative and one star reviews - this place was actually pretty good to me. Are my taste buds way off from everyone else?
I had the chashu ramen. It was good. Noodles were good, pork slices were good, hard boiled egg was good, broth was good to me, and had lots of green onions which I liked.
We also ordered the gyouza (gyoza?) and chicken karaage which tasted good. For the 3 ppl the bill was $60+tip.
Service? Just alright. Wasn't terrible so I have nothing negative to say, but I will say: 1) they asked if we were ready like 2 mins after sitting down, not enough time to take a good look at the menu and decide unless you're a regular and know what you want. and 2) no one came and checked up on us the entire time until we were done eating and she asked to take our plates away.
I might come back if I'm ever in the area again and craving ramen or something. It was good for my first time though.
Last but not least they had an awesome song selection and give you high chews with your bill :)
author: Leizel P.

description:
Hubby and I love this place. Anytime we have a ramen craving this is where we head. It's not the greatest ramen in the world, but it's up there in SF. What makes it a frequent destination is the good service, Yelp check in offer that usually gives you free edamame or karaage, good happy hour options and the fact that they often have $2 beer specials. 

My go-tos are the Mabo Tofu Ramen, Curry Ramen and Karaage Ramen, all around the $8.50 mark.
author: Mariko F.

description:
So we got sat down at 4:50pm, just in time for the lunch special. We didn't get acknowledged at the door for a few minutes. Mind you the restaurant has 3 tables that were being occupied in a restaurant of 20 tables. There are 3 staff workers and one of the didn't even walk to us, he (she?) picked up some menus and plopped them on a back table and waved us over while on a cell phone call. 

We ended up waiting another 10 minutes to even get a server, who passed up 8 times, to say anything to us. So when we finally become good enough to get some service I asked for the lunch special, which was the ONLY menu given to us, and she said it was too late for the lunch special. Wtf???!?!?!?!?! Where are we supposed to order from? 

Anyways, I'm too #hangry to leave because it took forever to find parking so we are gonna tough it out. I will edit my post if necessary. Let's see how this food turns out. ......
author: Chrissy C.

description:
This place is my best friends go to spot - so she took me here one night and we were lucky enough to catch happy hour. Which they have during normal times and late night. They offer half off some of their appetizers and drinks. 

My favorite ramen from here is the garlic tenderous rib ramen - the meat is very tender and flavorful. The gyoza is amazing here as well.

Can't wait to go back :)
author: Kim L.

description: For the price and convenience of not waiting, it's a fine choice.  Other ramen places have incredibly long waits.  The waitstaff was curiously inattentive, thought it wasn't the end of the world.
author: Lucullus L.

description: I've been wanting to come here for some time now! The bf and I shared a bunch of things. We got the free tofu app for checking in on yelp! Chicken wings, Gyoza, Chicken Katsu Curry w/ brown rice, and Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen! & of course, a large sake! Everything was soooo good, we ate it all! I have to come back to try their skewers, okonomiyaki, and other ramen. The service was great and the check was surprisingly inexpensive for the amount of food that we ordered!
author: Michelle L.

description:
What I ate: Spicy Mabo Tofu ramen with a side of gyoza
Visit date: February 1, 2012
First time? Yes.

Nom. This seems like it would be a good place for late night ramen cravings -- they are open late AND they deliver! Today I had the spicy mabo tofu ramen. My first mabo tofu experience was disastrous, but I thought I'd give it another try at Genki. Yum! The ramen is on the salty side, but quite tasty. Portion sizes are fairly large (I had two more snack servings after this meal). I also tried some of my friend's chicken karaage. Oooo, that stuff is gooood.

The only negative: service is slow (they were short staffed. They are hiring, according to the sign on the door.)
author: Erin G.

description:
Saturday afternoon. Starving and driving aimlessly down Geary Street. Due to the joint indifference and parking right out front, we decided to grab a late lunch at Genki Ramen. 

Star #1: Happy Hour is 3-7 and you get a free appetizer with a Yelp check-in. It was also still considered lunch hour so cheaper entrees.

Star #2: Several TVs with the Giants game on.

Star #3: We ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry Ramen and Beef Stew Ramen. Good sized entrees that left us both very full. The Takoyaki and Chicken Kaarage are worth trying for appetizers.

The ramen itself was a bit disappointing. Maybe because it took me so long to work through my bowl of Chicken Curry Noodles but it was a bit overcooked and limp. Think Vermont Curry over soggy noodles. Service itself was a bit slow given that the restaurant was fairly empty. A good meal for two for under $25 but I'm just not wow'd.
author: Jenn Y.

description:
I went to Genki Ramen on 11/24 by myself to grab a good dinner.  It wasn't very busy, and there were about 4-5 waiters/hosts milling about the restaurant.  The host was standing at the back of the restaurant chatting with some waiters who were going about doing their jobs.  After standing awkwardly for about 2-3 minutes waiting to be seated, a party of 6 entered the restaurant.  One of the waitresses asked, "Party of 6?" after I had been standing there.  Then the host walked up to the host stand and said, "I'll be with you in a minute" to me while he seated the party of 6.
So I left.  I'm sure they have great food, wish I could have tasted it.
author: Laura L.

description:
Oh Goodness!!!!!!!!!!

Called for delivery. 

Had to repeat my address 4x, my phone number 6x.  Still got it wrong when delivering. 

Repeated my order 3 times and still got it wrong. 

Quoted 45 min.-1 hr., 1.5 hours later, they came, no change, I told them never mind.  

Do yourself a favor, go else where and save your tummy and patience stress!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I feel like I am on a ramen binge right now, so I HAD to try this place! And it was delicious!! For appetizers, I tried the croquettes and unagi tempura. The croquettes were perfectly cooked and tasted like Japanese hash browns. The unagi tempura was light, crispy, and delicate. 

The ramen I tried was curry chicken Katsu. It was perfectly portioned, and I really liked it. I just wish there was a bit more broth because the noodles seemed to absorb them, and I also wish there were more vegetables in it. But the soup was flavorful and a little spicy. And the noodles were cooked perfectly!

The waitresses were really prompt at refilling my water, and they let my friend and I relax and chat until we wanted to leave. They were very nice!
author: Rachel H.

description: Customer service is okay. I usually get the Chashu ramen. Decent ramen spot and everytime you check into yelp, you can get a free appetizer!
author: Jenn L.

description: Can't even give this place 1 star because I never got the chance to try it! Came in at 10:35pm and it closes at 11pm. They told us the kitchen was closed and refused to serve us. I understand we came in near closing but it said close at 11pm, not close at 10:35pm!!!
author: Sarah Y.

description:
Not bad.
Not the best ramen I've had, but it is pretty good.
Beer is only $2!
Yelp check-in gives you a little appetizer for a table.
I'm glad we didn't have to wait in line to have ramen on a cold SF night.
author: S ..

description: This is my go to place every time I have a late lunch. They're fast and really nice. I love #409.
author: Sandy S.

description: Great menu. Everything I've tried was good, especially the wings and soup and this little pile of unagi rice I can't think of the name of right now. It can get busy but it's worth it!
author: Jody G.

description:
Located on geary, relatively close to USF, which is why I decided to try it with my friend one night. I ordered the chashu pork ramen, and wasn't very satisfied with my meal. It was bland to me, I dont know, it was just a decent bowl of ramen- I've had a lot better.

 I just wasn't impressed, and don't plan on coming back.  I rather have just had traveled a little further to Japan town or Men Oh for better quality ramen. I mean hello, if you're in SF afterall, you might as well get the real authentic ramen.  But if you're hungry, and  want quick food, this is the place to go, as there's usually no wait to be seated. When I went, they came out with the food in adequate time.
author: Cindy D.

description:
Came back to try another dish, but it was a miss. Would definitely stick to the garlic tenderous rib ramen next time.

Chashu Ramen - 2/5. Again the tonkatsu broth flavor wasn't as strong as other ramen houses. Noodles were cooked well again, but the chashu meat was underflavored.

Chicken Karage - 2/5. Unfortunately, seemed like the portion was left out and not prepared fresh. The deep-fried crunch was a bit lacking, meat wasn't piping-hot (it was lukewarm). However, a unique twist, instead of the mayo-base sauce it was served with a teriyaki style sauce (already squirted over the meat)
author: Gabriel C.

description:
Food: I like to come by here with some friends when I have a ramen craving. I highly recommend the butter and corn! It sounded like a really weird combo to me but it actually went really well in the soup! The happy hour for appetizers are pretty good too!

Service: Usually service is okay, but my last one was a big turn off. We gave our friend money and she paid on her card so it wouldnt be confusing for the server. We included tip so our friend was going to add the tip on her card too. She forgot to add our tip on her card and the waitress literally stopped us at the door and asked "only 1 dollar for 4 people?!" Honestly I worked in the food industry and I understand we should tip, but c'mon its still your job. When you stop customers at the door that's a huge problem. Maybe we just didnt like how you were as a waitress..
author: Mica C.

description: Says Happy hour from 3-6pm Everyday, but only open 5pm-11pm on weekdays.... Questionable. Other than that, a great ramen place despite being a bit pricey, but definitely cheaper than most ramen places in SF. Also, serving size is a bit small. I tend to find myself always ordering extra noodles because a regular order doesn't fill me up. Hard to find parking here too.
author: Courtney D.

description: Looks a bit ratty from outside (windows could be cleaned) but it's smart and attractive inside. My husband and I each ordered the okonomiaki (Japanese pancake) which was delicious. There was an option of  "ramen" for an additional $1.50 he chose. My mistake not to choose it as well. The addition of the ramen directly into the pancake batter made his serving much crispier. I've got to say that the waitress was curt and indifferent. I thought maybe she didn't speak English well but later she rattled away in it with another customer, a regular.
author: Paula H.

description:
I was always reluctant to try here cause I KNEW the ramen wouldn't be legit. I was right. It's not BAD though.

The good thing is that the menu is really extensive. So you don't have to get the ramen - which makes me more open to returning here!

Plus stars for 2 waves of happy hours every day. The matcha shake is bomb. I would probably return during HH to try a few more things and am not as averse to this place anymore.
author: Emily C.

description: Horrible service. Brought my companions food 20 minutes before mine. When asking where the food was, they said keep waiting. The brought me a pancake without any silverware and never asked us if we needed anything like more water, etc. Two girls working there chatted the whole time -- will not be back to this place.
author: Mima G.

description: Ordered the chicken karage ramen to go. The soup base was kind of bland and salty!, I should have got something spicy for some more flavor. The chicken karage was a good portion amount. Overall it wasn't the best ramen I ever had. I had high hopes this place would be bomb!
author: Jacqueline J.

description:
Love the asparagus bacon here! Food is usually pretty good and consistent. 

Curry is alright but there was one potato and a ton of onions. Definitely not one of their greatest dishes.

Service is horrible. Literally they have 3 or 4 people walking around while they have 3 or 4 in the kitchen and it still takes forever for anyone to take our order or pick up our check even though they walk by our table a few times.
author: Xbbygirl X.

description: Pretty good. Decent service. Clean. I'll eat here over other hipster ramen places definitely.
author: Boi S.

description:
This is a great place to grab a bowl of ramen. Since I came on a Monday night around 9:00PM it was hardly busy. Usually there's a list to put your name down when it gets busy so factor that into your visit.

I got the Chashu Ramen and it met my expectations for an above average bowl of ramen. The broth was had a good consistency and the noodles weren't too soft or hard. This one bowl of ramen is good enough to get you full. Maybe if you're in a big group go ahead and order some appetizers to tease your palette. 

The service was nice and I like the ambience of the restaurant in general. I'd recommend coming here for sure. If you're looking for a place in SF that has better ramen, I'd suggest checking out Izakaya Sozai or Sawaii Ramen.
author: Marlon T.

description:
3.75 stars

Happy Hour 7 days a week from 3 - 6p, 10p - Closing.

YOU MUST GET THE MATCHA SWIRL (5 stars!). It's a super delicious matcha green tea smoothie that is sweet but not overly sweet like how Starbucks makes it. It is the perfect break in between your slurpings of hot ramen. Only $3 during happy hour!

TAKOYAKI: (4 stars) squid ball (waitress described it as a Japanese street food). Lightly crispy on the outside and with tasty creamy sauce on top. Warm on the inside and the squid didn't have a strong flavor so if you don't like seafood, you can still eat this (I don't like squid but enjoyed it).

Chasu Ramen: (3.75 stars cause I'm decisive). The chasu was average, ramen was good, and the broth was excellent! I got the lunch size (good till 5pm, add an add'l $1 for a side). 

Free edamame if you check in thru yelp (it tasted just okay).

Hi-chews come with the check :)
author: Emily C.

description:
Genki has the right stuff.
First off, check in. Because you'll like what you can get from the check in 
(spoiler: tofu or salad). 

One check in per table, so don't tell the friend to your left ;)

Genki is a ramen spot! So I ordered Ramen.
The chasui ramen to be exact. 
I'm not the biggest lover of ramen, but I just came back from Japan not too long ago, which is the land of ramen. 
Literally ramen paradise over there.

I'd say Genki's ramen tasted like ramen I had in Japan - so I suppose it's not bad at all!

My friend who comes here often did advise me to only order Ramen when coming to Genki (for what it's worth). 

It's street parking.
The waitress was super friendly and refills water often (I only mention this because I was extremely dehydrated from the ramen).

All in all, If i'm around, I'll swing by for some ramen.
author: Ben T.

description:
Kept seeing this place on grub hub and just ignoring it.  Finally looked into it and was impressed by their giant menu.  Decided to give it a shot and was happy with the delivery results.  
We ordered:
*Sesame Wings/Samurai Wings- Both tasty Delicious
*Baked Scallop-Yummy but small
*Ebi with Garlic Butter-yummy but small
*Shrimp Tempura- good not too greasy
*Beef Enoki Roll- Was not sure if I would like it, but it ended up being the best thing we ordered! 
And all of that for around $43
There is so much more to try and I will be back.  Plus quick delivery and open late. 
Go Genki!
author: Chelsey G.

description: Close to the LJs place. It's not bad. Service is fast. It's easy to get a table normally. It's not spectacular, but it's not awful. We go here because it's convenient and not expensive, not for remarkable ramen. It's like comparing Wilbur to Babe. It's not "SOME PIG". It's "that'll do pig, that'll do".
author: Donna H.

description: Came in here from a recommendation from my hairstylist. Despite what others have said on yelp, I was satisfied. I got the negi beef ramen. Delish!! It def hit the spot. Very very flavorful! Their watermelon juice drink is the bomb!!!
author: Jessica A.

description: To help round out these reviews, I'll add a tip: This place is way more awesome for delivery. Their delivery service is pretty on point, and cold ramen isn't an issue when you have a microwave on hand. The gyoza is bomb, as well as the beef stew ramen, negi ramen, and seafood okonomyaki. It's not the most authentic ramen in SF, but it's good as a fusion ramen place.
author: Christina L.

description:
It's been a while since I last ate here, so coming back was a nice treat.  I took my friend here again for her b-day since she really likes it here.  We both ordered their Tonkatsu Curry Ramen with a side order of Chicken Karaage and one Spicy Sausage Okonomiyaki.  Yeah, were were hungry!  

They were pretty busy that day so our ramen seemed a bit rushed since the curry veggies were missing in our ramen.  It really didn't bother us too much though since we ordered hella food.  The ramen was still good, and I still love their okonomiyaki.  It was my first time having their Tonkatsu Curry Ramen, and while it was good, I still like their Chicken Karaage Ramen the best.

Still good stuff and I'll be looking forward to my next visit again!
author: Rodney H.

description: I wish I could give no stars. We got here at 10:30pm, and a female Asian server told us the kitchen is closed and sent us away. Three other groups were came in and were sat down until 10:44 and given menus to order from. We waited outside and the server who initially sent us off could clearly see us outside and didn't bother to let us know if they reopened the kitchen or not. Perhaps it was preferential/discriminatory treatment, but all I know is that this restaurant's actions caused to me make a review which i barely ever do. This was the lowest point, if not the only low point, in my first time in SF in 13 years. not sure about the food here clearly, but the greatest food can't overcome terrible service.
author: John Lendl C.

description: Was looking for a decent meal while my uncle was in the hospital and found this place on accident. Best decision ever!! Their Black Peppered Beef Yakisoba hit the spot!
author: Carmanda V.

description:
Holy shit. I ordered for delivery at 7:51pm and I'm at Geary and Masonic, which is maybe 6-7 blocks away? It is now 9:07 and my food still isn't here.


WHAT THE HELL?
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Ramen here was nothing special. Heard this place was good, and I only tried one other ramen place, so I expected this to be way better!

In my opinion, the broth was bland. The meat was tasteless and I ended up real disappointed. Very, disappointed. Service was average. Was expecting more from this place.
author: Ilyssa C.

description:
This is one of the lunch spots that we go to after church.  They can accommodate big groups which is great.  

Their ramen is ok
karaage is yummmmy!  
Fried rice is scrumptious!  
Lunch special is worth checking out!
author: Claire J.

description:
Really liked this spot. For a ramen spot, it is too cool (except for the bench seating along the wall that was pock-marked). Done up in avocado/lime green tones and dark wood, even the mirrored bar area was pretty darn cool. 

Moving on to the ramen, I ordered the kimchi ramen ($8 or $9?), it only comes in one size. Tender and flavorful, the chashu was how it should be. Broth-wise, this was not too salty or oily, but had a certain depth to it. Shaking on a bit of shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven spice), I inhaled the entire bowl.

For lunch time, you can order the "combo" and for a buck more have a choice of either karaage (fried chicken pieces), gyoza (potstickers) or chahan (fried rice). I opted for the karaage which turned up on a small dish and while not authentic (what, no lemon?), was still tasty. Imagine puffed up balls of KFC with a dash of tonkatsu sauce. 

Luckily, I had my handy Japanese exchange student with me to act as a barometer of authenticity. She agreed with my comments. 

Great restrooms. Stylish tiling job, modern glass sink and cleanliness throughout. 

Genki Ramen is so easy to find, just on your right hand side down Geary heading towards the beach. Parking isn't so great, but then, it is better than parking in North Beach.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Pretty yummy ramen

We even got free edamame from yelp!

They had a passionfruit soju drink and the watermelon drink was amazing!
author: Michelle T.

description:
My friends literally rave about this place ALL THE TIME... So I gave it a try. They are pretty big variety on their menu. They have at least 10 different ramen types too. Most places only have like 2. So that is cool. I got the Chashu with corn, fried tofu n spicy miso added. All in all the ramen was pretty good. A bit salty but still good. The gyoza I think is made fresh and to be honest they weren't that great. Fell apart and stuff. Different tho as far as the wrapping style. 

The service on the other hand was terrible!! The staff wasnt helpful when I asked questions. They didn't have an expressions on their faces. Like they were mad we came in an hour and a half before they closed... Boo hoo hoo. They took a fat chunk for tip that's already included. 

Not sure if it's a place I'll ever request to go to but I don't mind going there :)
author: Melysa T.

description:
4.5 stars rounded up

Feeling headachy & generally like a wreck on Tueaday night, I wanted comfort food. Despite knowing that the sodium-fat one-two combo could exacerbate my migraine & make me feel even shittier, I chose ramen anyways because the instant gratification of tucking my head into a big, steaming bowl of noodles trumps all potential ramifications. Genki Ramen, you made my owie all better! 

I chose butter & corn ramen ($8.25) & added bamboo shoots for $2. I asked for no fish cake (ewww), but lo & behold, there was the plastic-looking white piece with it's signature pink swirl swimming in my miso broth.
