The fact that she just snapped me with that line made my blood pressure shot through the roof. So I told her, "forget about it" and she walked away. 

So I gave two stars because the dry curry ramen is actually not too bad at all... but just the service was horrendous. It made me feel like i'm back in China town again. 

Definitely not going back anytime soon.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Solid place for ramen.  I had the Spicy Mabo Ramen which was pretty satisfying on a cold Monday night.  I also tried the tonkotsu broth which was very flavorful (I like tonkotsu better than shoyu ramen any day).
I've had better ramen at Izakaya Masa in SD, and Shin Sen Gumi in LA - but this place isn't bad at all.

Bonus points for the free chicken karage for checking in on Yelp!
author: Michele S.

description: The ramen absolutely delicious!! Pricing is pretty average, but their drinks are a bit overpriced. But overall they good a wide selection of ramen to choose from. I'd say to make a reservation as the place is well known to the people of SF.
author: Alexander P.

description: The ramen here is out of this world! Customer service was great and the portions are just right! I'd definitely come back and have 3+ times. If you are in the area you should definitely stop by. Happy hour was pretty good as well...don't come here drunk or you'll order too much!
author: Aaron S.

description:
Lunch special:  

 $7.95 for CHASU RAMEN (normally $8.95.) Add a bowl of pork fried rice for just a buck more. 

The look was there, but the taste was not.  The pork soup was just, well, taste like boiled pork.  There were 4 slices of chasu, half an egg, some bamboo shoots, green onion and red ginger for garnish.

The fried rice was really greasy.  

They try to be creative with their ramen by having many different types of toppings for you to choose.   They even have stir-fried meat and vegetables as toppings.  What....  take the YASAI Ramen for example, it's stir fried mushrooms, asparagus, tomato, carrot, onion, shredded cabbage, green onion and shelled edamame in tonkatsu base.  They also have MABO TOFU (BTW I think it should be MAPO and not MABO like they put on the menu) as another type of topping.  I feel like I'm eating Chinese food and not Japanese ramen.

Free appetizer if you check in at Yelp.
author: Tadaa T.

description: I could use a little heftier serving of the noodle and soup base, but otherwise it was fine
author: Drew B.

description:
The Food: 3 Stars
The Service: -2 Stars
Overall: 1 Star

I used to use Eat24hours.com and order ramen from them since they're one of the decent places that you can get ramen delivered in SF.

Everything was fine until one of their punk-ass delivery drivers complained to me, quite aggressively, that I didn't tip him enough for the delivery. Wtf dick.

I don't apply the standard 20% for good service for deliveries...I throw in a few bucks and treat it like a delivery fee. I don't think I'm alone here.

At any rate, if this guy is typical of the people this place has hanging around their food, then I don't want none. I haven't ordered from this place since.

This is an Asian-owned restaurant, so good service is as foreign to this guy as was the English language.
author: Spencer C.

description: Been here twice and the ramen was delicious and affordable! My boyfriend absolutely loved his order, it was the Spicy Mabo Tofu Ramen. The Curry Chicken Katsu Ramen I had was okay. We also got the free crispy daimaru, which was indeed very crispy and the stuffing was so good!
author: Sandy N.

description:
I rate this place a 10! For one...the restaurant had a nice vibe and was very clean. The server was friendly and it didn't take them too long to bring us our food. The quality of the ramen was outstanding! Noodles were just the way it supposed to be. I've been to Shoki in Sacramento and their noodles were garbage! Lots of flavor on the House Special Ramen and good amount of chasu pork as well. 

I highly recommend this place to everyone and will definitely come back! =)
author: Natalie D.

description:
My new favorite Ramen restaurant! I am absolutely CRAZY about this place. A friend of mine who lives in SF recommended this place to us, so we call decided to come here after a long day of hard work. 
Upon entering, this place looks pretty darn nice. 


Recommended items on the menu:
1.Okonomiyaki Seafood
$ 9.50
shrimp, squid, scallop, mussel and imitation crab meat

2.Garlic Tenderous Rib
 $8.75
sliced roasted garlic, pork soft bone, half boiled egg and spinach in tonkatsu base

Alcoholic Drinks:
So Cool
$ 5.00
soju & Yakult, famous japanese yogurt drink

You cant even taste the alcohol in this drink! But its there, I drank half of this and got so buzzed so quickly. the So Cool is my new favorite alcoholic beverages of all time!


Minus 1 star for the wait!
author: Vicky H.

description:
Still yummy, love the mushroom ramen. However the portions have gotten significantly smaller (broth barely passed the halfway mark of the bowl). Maybe I was just particularly hungry but I finished the whole bowl (soup and all) and I was still hungry. I'm not a fan of huge portions but the pricing should decrease to reflect smaller amount of food. Instead, the price has increased to $10 for a bowl of my favorite mushroom ramen :/

4 stars for the food, but minus 1 for pricing/portion
author: Connie H.

description: Great place for vegetarians! Lots of options where a ramen can be had with vegetarian broth. We ordered the curry ramen and veggie yakisoba along with the veggie gyoza. Good portions and the staff were so friendly with quick service.
author: Priya G.

description:
Food was good but was distracted by the blaring Irish rock music, Pink, and Britney telling me to "work bitch" I wanted to stab my ears with the chopsticks they gave me. 
I like ramen.
author: Christina A.

description:
Genki ramen is more than ramen, they have various appetitizers udon, and a dinner menu.

flatscreens(4) sports, news
music: rock
decor: industrial warehouse overhang with flatscreens on white walls.

sampling: chashu ramen (8.95) combo (+$1)
*comped pickled something : ok
*chashu ramen : 3 stars
-4 thin pork slices with marbling, green onions, half boiled egg, bamboo shoots, red ginger
-ramen had the texture of sphaghetti.
-tonkotsu broth milky and watery
*karaange chicken (3 small pieces, +$1): 2 stars
-small,  overbreaded, overcooked, semidry,  and crunchy 
-not juicy, not tender

temaki:
-dry mouthed afterwards, msg?
-3-7 daily, happy hour, $3 drinks, $3 appetizers
-seating: 12 tables of 4, counter for 5
-friendly, efficient service
-typical j. hello greeting and "thank you" salutation.
-good venue for late night snacking.
author: Victor G.

description:
This place rocks when I need a ramen fix. There have been several ramen places that I've tried in or around the peninsula but I always seem to find myself comparing the broth/noodles to Genki Ramen (feeling a bit guilty). Some have come close but never like this place. I just don't know what it is! 

Haven't tried much variety because I always order my default (Nori) but thee bf enjoys almost all the flavors of ramen they have..with an order of chicken karaage on the side. I highly recommend the watermelon juice to sip on... It's refreshing and quite tasty! 

4 stars because it's not out of this world but that's a pretty high rating in my book. I am one tough cookie lol!
author: Jae S.

description: They get an extra star cause their menu is extensive and they offer a vegetarian option for their ramen, which is always a plus for friends who can't eat meat. I ordered their Sesame Chicken, Chasu Ramen, and grilled corn cause I was really hungry. Sesame Chicken has a sweet glaze, crispy skin, and covered in black and white sesame seeds. The pork in the ramen was soft with the broth being just a bit salty, but not too much. Now the grilled corn was off the hook! Buttery goodness dripping down the sides of your mouth good! So ask for extra napkins if you get the corn.
author: Theresa D.

description: The price is cheap, but the ramen is not as good as I expected. But when you check in here on Yelp, you could get free appetizer.
author: Jason L.

description:
I had the Chashu Ramen here and the soup was rather bland.  It certainly was salty enough but not rich in flavor.  The noodles had good texture though - slightly chewy.  I also ordered the Chicken Karaage here and it was nicely fried.  The meat texture was fine but flavor was definitely lacking.  I ended up dipping the chicken into my soup for flavor.

I would not recommend this place but I understand that decent ramen restaurants are lacking in SF.
author: Allen T.

description: Nice spot to fulfill my ramen craving. I always get a seat. Not too crowded most of the time. The portion is just right, not too big, not too little. I had 2 free appetizers with check-in on Yelp. Happy hour $3 appetizers. Can't complain.
author: Ferdy S.

description: Great place and the tan tan ramen was the bomb! The fried rice was pretty good as well and the price is very fair. I'd go there again. Great place!
author: Lakeen W.

description:
Don't go here looking for gourmet quality food.  

Genki Ramen is an under-appreciated Japanese restaurant that is a combination Izakaya (Japanese tapas) and Ramen shop all under a single roof.  Genki Ramen is like Randy Moss.  When you first look at him, he looks like the best receiver in the league.  Upon a closer examination, you realize that there is something slightly wrong with him.  If you use Moss in the right system (New England), he could be very useful.

When you examine Genki's dinner menu, you are impressed by the number of authentic Japanese dishes.  When you eat it, some are very good, but others have some fatal frauds.  They make mistakes that normal Japanese chef would never make, which suggests that the chef is not Japanese.  If you know how to avoid these landmines, Genki could be very useful.  Of course, if you are not an expert in Japanese cuisine, you will probably not notice these mistakes, so you might enjoy their food without any issues, which is a good thing.   

HOW TO USE GENKI:
* Go there for lunch, order Chashu ramen ($8) with $1 fried rice and $1 gyoza.
* Go there with friends, order a bunch of grilled robata-yaki items and enjoy them with Kirin or Sapporo draft.

HITS:
Okonomiyaki - While not perfect, it was pretty good.
Charcoal grilled items, including Chicken Gizzard
Homemade gyoza
Pumpkin and Yam tempura
Ujikintoki - nice dessert

LANDMINES:
Grilled onigiri - what the ?!? Genki's version was really bad.
Noodle pouch - ???  It looked good.
Papaya salad - forget it.

ATMOSPHERE:  Who decided to install 5 flat-screen TVs?  Is this Best Buy or a ramen shop?  If you get past this confusion, it's actually the nicest looking ramen place in San Francisco.  J-POP videos included Otsuka Ai, Goto Maki, Country Musume, Morning Musume, and an episode of Music Station.   

PRICE:  Nice value!  Note that their lunch and dinner price differ.

A sample dinner for two:
$2.50 A stick of grilled chicken
$1.50 A stick of grilled shishamo 
$2.50 A stick of grilled chicken grizzle
$2.25 A stick of grilled minched chicken
$2.50 A stick of grilled asparagus bacon
$8.75 Okonomiyaki
$4.75 Gyoza
$8.95 Chachu ramen
$5.50 Large Kirin Draft
$7.50 Ginjo class sake by glass
$11.00 Tip and taxes
----------------------------------
$58 for two people

------------MY RAMEN REVIEW-------------
Their regular ramen was pretty good.  Not dynamite, but I am glad that I found another ramen place in San Francisco, although I prefer Katana-ya.  Genki has some embarrassing 'pseudo ramen' (as quoted by Nobu K.), like curry tonkatsu ramen and shrimp tempura ramen.  It required some guts on my part to eat at a place where the chef thought it was okay to throw in a tempura into a ramen.  Do they think ramen is soba or udon?  If you stick to their standard Chashu Ramen, you'll be fine.  

MEN (Noodle): C-.  Probably the weakest part of their ramen.  Medium thickness, not so wavy, not so yellow.  I wished there was a little bit more firmness ('koshi') and elasticity.  I have no problem that Genki uses packaged noodles.  As mentioned in my past ramen reviews, many famous Ramen shops in Japan also outsource noodles to big factories.    

SOUP: B-.  I liked the fact that they have one soup, instead of offering the usual 3 choices (miso, shio, shoyu), which indicated that Genki spent the time and effort perfecting one soup.  They use a pork bone based soup, brownish color.  It was very smooth and easy to eat.  If you are not a fan of fatty Santa Ramen soup, you might like Genki's soup, which was not oily ('sap-pari').  While the positive word is 'smooth', another way to say this is 'lacking substance'.   

TOPPINGS: B+.  Their homemade roasted pork (cha-shu) was very nice, although I wished it was not so thin.  Green onions and bamboo shots (menma) was just fine.  THE BEST part was their boiled egg, which was flavored.   It is common in Japan, but quite rare the U.S., probably because it is an acquired taste.  If you never had your eggs this way, you might not like it.    

Important note: As with all my ramen reviews, I avoid comparing these ramens to the ones in Japan as that would mean that the majority of ramen shops in the U.S. would receive below average rating.
author: トモ T.

description: Such a good lunch option! The garlic tendorous beef was amazing, and the pork fried rice was top notch, I highly recommend getting a side order of it. My only complaint is the chairs here are very uncomfortable, but they look really cool.
author: Ealon H.

description:
I had never been here before, and came with some friends who have never steered me wrong when it comes to food.

It was a really pleasant experience!  We ordered takoyaki and gyoza appetizers. And I ordered the seafood ramen.

The ramen was perfect and just to my taste! The noodles were cooked perfectly and the broth was simple and perfect for the other ingredients. 

The gyoza was solid. My only negative was the takoyaki. It had perfect flavor, but the texture was off for me as the inside was a little gummy. Wont order that again, but I will definitely be back!
author: Trevor D.

description:
I've wanted to try their ramen for a very long time, but the few times I've walked by here at night they've been pretty crowded.  I finally discovered recently that they're not quite as busy during the weekday lunch hour so that's when I made my visit.

I was greeted by the lone waitress who gestured to me to take a seat anywhere.  The interior is quite nice with soft avocado green tones, dim lighting, comfortable custom-made chairs with high back support and flat panel televisions throughout airing CNN and the Food Network (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ml0zISgWDnt1hDWorSMNiw?select=skSB5mgp0CCRpY6zD-I-8g).  The empty bar looked quite nice with all of its soft colors (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ml0zISgWDnt1hDWorSMNiw?select=wm3JCj88qgn6Wzaskkf0oA).  There's a large window in the back of the restaurant that looks into the open kitchen.

As the waitress served other tables I got a chance to study the lengthy menu which has good descriptions of all of the selections.  I asked about the seafood sampler appetizer dish, but the waitress quite honestly told me it might be too much food (along with an order of ramen) for one person.  I selected the deep fried Chicken Karaage and the Chashu Ramen with the addition of corn.  There are about a dozen items you can add to your ramen, for additional costs of course.

The wait was quite lengthy for the food to arrive.  I understood this though because there appeared to be only one chef working in the open kitchen preparing food for many tables.  I sat back and watched some decadent desserts being created on the Food Network.

The Chicken Karaage (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ml0zISgWDnt1hDWorSMNiw?select=098hWFpepQEafzvxnSTAYw) arrived first, but my order of ramen was fast on its heel.  I allowed the ramen to sit a bit while I sampled the chicken appetizer.  Maybe I expected more than just deep fried chunks of lightly battered chicken thigh meat.  Just slightly tastier than an order of McDonald's Chicken McNuggets, the moist chicken chunks arrived with a drizzling of sauce.  I couldn't make out what that sauce was because the chicken was so salty that it overpowered the sauce.  I've never been more thankful for that cup of complimentary hot tea.

The Chashu Ramen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Ml0zISgWDnt1hDWorSMNiw?select=pmSWIkmZMvpLcwD7pE9TMw) was much better.  The menu states that the broth used is meat-based.  I couldn't really tell because the broth was very milky in appearance, but this was the best ramen broth I've ever had.  It was perfectly seasoned and just mighty tasty.  I often eat up all the ingredients of ramen dishes and leave the soup to be discarded, but I liked the soup so much that when I had finished the bowl was nearly empty.  There were lots of flavorful slices of tender, marbled pork and the bamboo tips were nice and crunchy.  When they add corn, they really add corn because there was lots of  it.  The single negative was the hard boiled egg half whereas the egg white was steaming hot but the yolk part was room temperature cold.  There was a fair amount of ramen noodles underneath those ingredients too.

I'm not familiar with the different types of ramen noodles, but these appeared to be similar to angel hair pasta in appearance and texture but much softer to the bite.  I loved the ramen, and I'll certainly return again for lunch.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
I'm a believer that if you put a food item in your name then that should be the star of the restaurant. Thus, when you go to a ramen house, you have to try the ramen. I came to Genki one afternoon with a friend craving some ramen and soup. I got the garlic braised ribs (i think thats what it's called) and it sure was delicious and filling for $7.95. The only reason why it gets a 4 stars is the portion of meat to noodles and soup is way off. Too much soup and little..little meat, and the noodles just sort of float in between. However, flavor wise it hits the spot. 

Thankfully I love ramen for the soup and not a big fan of ramen. My lunch companion on the other hand doesn't share my love.
author: Linda L.

description:
The food, and the prices especially during happy hour, are really quite good. Their karaage is excellent and their tako-yaki are the best i've had in SF. The tonkatsu broth is rich and flavorful and the noodles are of good quality. 

Unfortunately, Genki Ramen has truly some of the most cripplingly terrible service just in terms of speed/remembering what we ordered. It really took like 30 minutes to pay at the end. What they need is these buttons they have in japan on your table which signal the waitress like the flight attendant button does in a plane.
author: Misha T.

description:
Yummm!!

Might be the best ramen I've had in the city. Looooved the kinoko ramen --- was super good with added egg.

Just wish they didn't play pop music but hey, food was worth it 

:)
author: Alejandro G.

description: The chicken okonomiyaki was good, but not great. Edamame we're warm, which I prefer, but a little bland - better with a little soy sauce. Wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again.
author: David K.

description:
It never fails that this place smells like... dog?!

Not sure what's up(dog) with that, but their food is good. Love how they have the monthly free appetizer when you check into yelp. Just went here last night and ordered the chicken katsu curry ramen. So nice and filling on a cold summer night.
author: Michelle C.

description:
RUDE!!! 
The service sucks and the food is so average. We sat around for 10 minutes waiting for the waitress to acknowledge our existence, then after taking our drink order she was didn't come back for another 10 minuites. It wasn't like it was super busy. There were only 4 other patrons in the whole place! She was bumbling around the restaurant with a stack of napkins as if she was trying to avoid us. Awful. I've been to plenty of Asian food joints to know when service sucks and its not just a brusque cultural thing. 

We ordered beers, wings, short ribs and two bowls of ramen....the only thing I liked was the Asahi bottled in Canada. Nuff said. 

Came home and had major tummy rumbles and I know that all the MSG and grease in the broth was to blame. BTW - i know that we were supposed to get some Hi-Chews with the check...not odd that we didn't get any considering the wait staff had something up their butts. I'm inclined to say that i'll never come back...even if someone else is paying and that's saying a lot.

Underground Ramen beats the pants off this place hands down.
author: Stacy T.

description:
Genki Ramen was another try to find a good ramen place in San Francisco....sadly a bust.  I ordered the Garlic Tenderous Rib (with that name, how could I not?), which was all that the name would lead you to believe.  Garlicky, with tender short ribs.  The ramen itself, though, left me wanting more - the broth and noodles were "fine".

The search continues!
author: Cathy Y.

description:
First and foremost- the service  isn't that great. I feel that there is a language barrier but at least the waitresses understand you enough to get by and get the order right. A lot of the time they take forever to ring you up. 

Ramen: I ALWAYS get the Kinoko Mushroom ramen. It's SO good. It's flavor, perfect balance of saltiness and the noodles are in perfect texture. I always leave the bowl empty. 

They're happy hour is the bizness too! 

Although, service isn't great, I still keep coming back for their food.
author: Diana P.

description:
Tasty Japanese ramen and more! 

Waitresses are friendly and nice.  
Restaurant is neat and clean.  
You are surrounded with big HD plasma TVs. 

Don't know what to try? 
Get the Chicken Karage.  Noodles are drenched in miso soup, corn, seaweed with a side of popcorn chicken.  Yummmmmyy!  Yummmy! 

This place is open late on the weekend.  A great place to come with a group of friends or just stop by for a late night meal/snack.

Nom! Nom! Nom!
author: Deborah C.

description: Happy hour is well worth it! The beer and fried popcorn chicken is a must before every meal. Their ramen noodles are always quality but the broth is a hit and a miss depending on the flavor you get. I always add corn, egg, and extra noodles. Good for late nights.
author: Nicholas G.

description:
bad customer service!!!

i left my credit card by accident. she ask for my name, stated then she ask for my id. i'm like why? i need to check id. i just ate here less then 5 minutes ago and your the one that took our order. she said i'm sorry but i don't remember (short asian girl). are you kidding me? there was two other table tops that night. why are you asking me for why id now but not when i got the check. doesn't even make sense, then large asian girl said "bye". yeah, its the end of it! rude!!!

i'm done with this place, never again!!!
author: JessePanda C.

description: I returned to Genki for a really late dinner on a weekday. In comparison to my last visit, the restaurant was super busy this time. Although almost every seat was taken, there was no wait for a table for 2. Unfortunately, my meal was subpar. I ordered what I had last time, the garlic tenderous rib ramen. The noodles were too soft and my bowl of soup had more bones than actual meat pieces. Also, my bf ordered a side of spicy miso and the waitress forgot. We had to remind her and although she brought it out, it tasted like sweet tomato paste with a speck of spiciness. On top of that, our waitress charged us for 2 servings of spicy miso although I never asked for it. Had it been less busy, I wonder if the visit would have been better.
author: Maya S.

description: Overall the ramen was pretty good I thought it got a little expensive after you put on a couple of extra toppings. Might end up being like $13 my friend got the stir fried yaki soba which was a little bit on the greasy side and not as much veggies I hope for but the vibe was really nice. For appetizers I recommend the chicken or the takoyaki but don't get the fried crab ragoons that's all I got to say about that
author: Jordan S.

description:
This place is pretty good. 
The wait can get a little long on some days.
 Its nice and small but can also hold a group. 
The rib ramen is really good.. the meat practically falls off the bone.. yum.!
author: Tiff C.

description:
Next to Izakaya Restuarant on Irving St. this place is delicious if you were looking for something in San Francisco. Don't go to Saiwaii Ramen if you are picking between three resturants!

1) Izakaya
2) Genki Ramen
3) Saiwaii Ramen

If you are in San Jose- I highly recommed Orenchi Ramen or Kotetsu!
author: Jae U.

description: The ramen was really good, however the service was pretty terrible. I called ahead for a larger group and was seated quickly but when I inquired if they were able to split the check prior to ordering I was met with a snarky "are you serious?!" Followed by several other passive aggressive statements. There was also a long wait for the bill (which we ended up not splitting and venmo-ing one person in our group). I hate to leave a bad review but I was honestly blown away by the comments I received, all for a $140 bill.
author: Maddy S.

description: Ordered ramen delivery on a whim (bold move, I know) and surprisingly, Genki has a pretty good one! As many reviews stated, the food arrived later than predicted (and thus was room temp), but the driver apologized and said he was the only one out that night - a holiday - so that was forgivable. We each got the 401 Chashu ramen with the spicy miso paste. Good flavor and more than enough food to fill us up. Although I think ramen is better suited to be eaten at the restaurant, I would order from here again if I was really craving it (and immobile).
author: Lauren C.

description:
First, I would like to say I've been here 4 times before writing this. I just went a hour ago so...I may be bias because my tummy is full and all smiles. Just kidding! I will not let my satisfied tummy get the best of me! Here's my thoughts and views in all honesty! 

PARKING SUCKS. Genki is located on a busy street so do try to find parking in the neighboring streets but be warned that it spent me a half hour or more each time I've gone. 

HAPPY HOUR IS COOL. $3 appetizers including Takoyaki (6 pieces) and $3 drinks like Watermelon juice, which tastes fresh, and the Matcha Swirl, which is like a Matcha Frappucino. 

SERVICE IS FAST. Food usually comes out in 20 minutes or less and that means all the food! The waitresses are also very efficient in taking your order and giving you your check.

The place is also pretty big so you do get seated pretty quickly. The only bad part about the seating is that all the tables are very close so if you get up, you probably will booty bump someone in the face. However, there are TVs on each wall so you're highly entertained while eating. 

They have a LOT of choices of ramen (around $9). The noodles themselves look like they came from the ramen packages but the broths are very flavorful. Do try the House Special Char Shu if it's your first time! Chicken Karaage is good since they give you a lot of the fried chicken on the side. Shoga Niku is also very good but note that the stir fried flavor does overpower the broth. And my fav is the Beef Stew because I think that the portion of meat to noodles is just right. All the portions are just enough to make you happy. 

I love their Okonomiyaki! It's a huge portion so it's easy to share and the flavor is really good! 

I didn't like their Yakisoba. It is a giant mound of noodles stir fried with meat and vegetables on a sizzling platter but it does get very salty after awhile. I kept guzzling my water. Also, no on the Crispy Seafood Roll because it's not worth the price and the taste is bitter. Same thing goes with the Crispy Daimaru..there's barely any filling and you only get three pieces. 

I know I wrote a lot but the menu is HUGE. Genki Ramen is affordable, fast, and great for groups! Enjoy!
author: Joy L.

description:
Curry chicken katsu FTW!  Parking is easy peasy.  Next day hangover recovery spot of choice!

If you get other dishes here... it's not as good.  I would only get the curry chicken katsu (amazinggg) and chashu (pretty good).
author: Erika C.

description:
1 star because I cannot tolerate the horrible service anymore and ridiculous service staff! Food has been very inconsistent/hit and miss. Waitresses are SO OBNOXIOUSLY Pushy and rude!! I cannot enjoy my meal when they constantly ask me if I'm finished with my meal. It's all about the $$$ here at Genki. I've never had a positive customer service experience here. I won't be returning.

I keep giving this place second chances and  service is still pretty bothersome. I shouldn't have to ask for a water refill. Especially, when the restaurant is empty. Smh
author: Andrew V.

description: Not sure if it was slow or I was just in a hurry, but what a nice surprise when the basic chashu ramen arrived. Calm, integrated broth, good texture on the noodles, the pork melted in my mouth, and I don't know what was up with the hard-boiled egg, but it was really good.
author: Chris D.

description: I've never had this bad food ever! We ordered food online and it's arrive late and cold. Chicken teriyaki had six pieces of chicken and hella cold rice, ramen was so cold and we had pancake it was soaked in a water and everything fall apart my boyfriend tried it and he through it away right after also there was no fork,spoon, chopstick,knife or napkin (forget about the extra soy sauce) when call to the restaurant lady keep telling me excuse me, excuse me... While I'm talking and put me in hold for 3min and said "well take 20% off next time okay!" And I was like really I don't want any discount!!! If the server apologized me or at least explained to my why the food was cold and all soaked in a water I wouldn't get hella mad and writing this horrible review!!!!really really disappointed!
author: Nomiko B.

description:
After a fantastic honeymoon in Japan, I have had a serious craving for some of the harder to come by Japanese cuisines - namely okonomiaki. After a quick Yelp search, I found that Genki had a number of these tasty Japanese pizzas to sample.  I went over for lunch one day and shared the Sumo with a coworker.  While it couldn't stand up to the real McCoy, it was bursting with savory flavors and a hint of sweetness from the Japanese mayo on top.  Yum!  In addition to the okonomiaki, we had a beef and enoki mushroom roll which I enjoyed, as well as some standard but tasty gyoza.  If none of these things are quite what your taste buds are seeking, Genki had a very extensive menu with most Japanese staples well represented.  

The restaurant itself is spacious, and the décor is decent and simple.  I don't know that I would head there for a date with romantic ambiance, but it will certainly fit the bill for most meals.  The staff were quick to serve and very pleasant, making Genki an overall solid spot to eat.
author: Virginia B.

description:
I tried this place out for the first time and thought it was awesome!!! I'm not the biggest ramen fan in the world as there are several other types of food I prefer to eat. However, I do like ramen and I do appreciate a good ramen spot. Recommended to me by a friend, this place did not disappoint.

We ordered the gyoza and samurai wings to start and then the Negi Beef Ramen which was amazing! Honestly the best ramen I've ever had which is definitely saying something. I may try the pork and ginger ramen next time but this may be the "goto" combo going forward! Delicious!
author: Brian C.

description: Came here for the first time yesterday for lunch. Ordered the Butter & Corn and the Curry Chicken Katsu ramen dishes. Both were delicious! Also ordered a side of the Chicken Gizzards with light salt. Tiny portion for the price. Having a pretty decent size appetite for such a small person, wish there were more ramen noodles in the bowls though. Would definitely come back if I'm in the area.
author: M J.

description:
This review is for delivery and take-out only. Wow, Genki Ramen is my new obsession. I'm consistently amazed by the fact that every time I've gotten food here, it's always been fresh and surprisingly delicious. Delivery has been speedy and I'm impressed that the fried food is always really crispy. It's near impossible for me to get genuinely good delivery anymore. I'm always disappointed with the experience in some way... Well, not with Genki Ramen. I only wish they had dessert or some kind of sweet thing on their menu, because their dinner menu is so vast and creative. 

One of my favorites tonight was the boiled pork. I randomly ordered it not knowing what to expect. It was juicy, delicious slices of pork that tasted poached or lightly cooked. Amazing. Reasonable size for the price, too, unlike some other items. One weird quirk on the menu is the size of tofu for the price. Their version of agedashi tofu is delicious, but it's in really small portions and I usually order 2 ($7). I feel like it's wrong to pay that much for tofu, but the toppings are pretty delicious and the sauce tastes expertly made. I think the problem is that they consider it fried tofu and think they can mark it up, but other nearby places offer the same amount for half the price. 

'Im not a huge ramen person, but I did enjoy their tempura ramen. Curry chicken cutlet is amazing too. Definitely a greasy dish, maybe more on the unhealthy side of versions I've had, but good. This place is ideal if you want to go on the healthier side of unhealthy. If you order all fried, it's obviously pretty bad, but they offer a bunch of grilled items that are amazing. I always get 2 orders of the roast buttered corn skewer ($1) each, and it has this amazing charcoal grilled, light buttery flavor. Once we ordered the silken tofu salad and was shocked at how fresh the sliced tomato an avocado were. We ordered the soft shell crab thinking I'd get half the amount. There were 4 huge ones, all delicious, light, fluffy and crispy. The balsamic vinaigrette sauce obviously has an American twist, but I think it adds a huge kick.

I'd say that yes, it is a little pricey, but I feel this place deserves 5 stars because it offers free delivery that for me has been both speedy, with food still hot. Full disclosure I live nearby, but in all my time ordering from other places--near and far-- precious few have quality, delicious food. Tonight one of the employees was a little snippety on the phone because I messed up my Eat24 order, but I don't even care because the delivery was super quick and everything is amazing. Go Genki Ramen!!!!
author: Elle M.

description: Super cheap that I can't even rate the ramen properly. The lunch special was ramen + $1 side and was under $10 and you get a free dish for yelp checkin (or atleast for 2012). The romen bowls were deceptively big though so we weren't insanely full and the sides were small but what do you expect for that price? The spicy miso add on was actually spicy. The parking in that arean't wasn't too bad but the service when trying to get the check was insane slow.
author: Lily P.

description:
A local Inner Richmond favorite :)

+ Reliably good ramen (not the best, but hits the spot)--and I love their curry+rice dishes
+ Good and speedy service
+ Cheap cocktails and beer
+ Hi-chew candies with your bill :)
+ Multiple TV screens with sports games or news playing line the walls
author: Joanna M.

description:
Two words: Kimchi Ramen.

GET IT.
author: Linda K.

description: Terribly slow at lunchtime. No communication. Food is good after waiting 20 minutes for one bowl of ramen!
author: Marci N.

description:
3 stars because that's what Genki Ramen is...A-OK. It's not amazing food, but it's not horrible either.

I've been here several times before and every time has been a decent experience. Ramen isn't bad, although this last time that I went, I got the seafood ramen and there didn't seem to be a lot of broth :T
I really like the yakisoba and I remember the unagi don being yummy! :)

Good happy hour deals here! $3 appetizers and the ramen, yakisoba, and donburi are about $1 cheaper PLUS it comes with a side, like gyoza or fried chicken.

It's a clean neat restaurant and the waitresses are nice enough, so if you want Japanese food spur of the moment and don't have time to compare and contrast, I'd recommend Genki!
author: Kei H.

description:
Genki ramen is spacious and pretty modern looking...and guess what, they have a happy hour! But I missed it. :(

My friend and I came here for a quick dinner before my treacherous study session, and luckily it was pretty quick. We were seated right away as only half the restaurant was full and had our orders placed in a timely manner. I glanced over the menu quickly (they have a huge variety of ramen) and decided on the shrimp tempura and seasonal vegetable miso ramen. We also ordered takoyaki and food came out in no time.

I don't have much experience with takoyaki, but I will say it was pretty good. The fried batter on the outside reminded me of potato and there is a small piece of octopus inside along with the pickled radish and fish flakes and kewpie on top. For 6 pieces, it was about $4. My ramen came out right after and I was happy to see a large plate of assorted tempura with my bowl of ramen and nori. The broth was good because it wasn't too salty, which is the case a lot of the time for me. It is different from some other places because it's also not as rich. Nonetheless, the noodles and broth were pretty decent.

Lastly, while we were eating, I checked in on yelp and noticed a free offer and decided why not use it now? You have the option of seaweed salad or these crispy spinach and cream cheese wontons. Of course I went for the wontons...It came with a sweet chili sauce and was ok.

Total came out to be a little under $25 with tax. 2 ramens, 1 takoyaki and a free appetizer. Not bad! I will be back for happy hour.

P.S. They give hi-chew candies with your check!
author: Stine H.

description:
The reason why I am giving them a 4 is because they are good but they are my first. The takoyaki was on point but did not hold a candle to the takoyaki I had earlier in the day, which was plump, juicy and delicious. I still need to ask Lee where he got them from. There were a lot of choices but I went with a beef and ginger ramen.
We also had some deep fried chicken nuggets, Japanese style. The service was good, didn't have to wait or did I feel neglected. The drink I ordered felt a little watered down, lacking some serious alcohol but to the main dish. It was steaming hot, the aromas were intoxicating and the flavor of the broth was so inviting. The beef was tender and the noodles were perfect al dente. The ambiance felt young, dark but vibrant, seating was a little cramped but not uncomfortable. I would come back here when I am in town but not for the takoyaki!
author: Victor A.

description:
Pro:

- If I can eat Chicken Karakage for $5 and not have to take a Chicken Crapakage by the end up the night, than you're good in my hood. 

- If Ramen is not your thing and you only came here cuz your peers wanted to come here and you didnt want to be that 'one guy' who screws it up for everyone and wants to eat somewhere else, then lucky for you there is alot of other choices here also besides ramen. Theres Cryquettes, Deep Cries Seafood, Yakisobbing, Shrimp Tearpura, etc. 

Con:

- If you come on the weekend at night, be prepare to drive around the block at least 30 times before you find a parking spot, unless you got really lucky. 

I would come here again on a rainy day.
author: Viet N.

description:
Stopped in for post-dinner drinks. The hostess seated us at a table, so the husby and I decided to try an appetizer as well, it was happy hour after all. We ordered sesame chicken wings to go with our soju cocktails. The drinks were fruity but not quite as soju-y as we'd thought they'd be. They had Yakult yogurt in them, which gave them a nice creamy texture. My husband's drink had ice in it, so it eventually got watered down. The chicken wings were crispy and had good flavor, but you only get 4 wings in the happy hour appetizer. 

All-in-all, it was an ok experience. I'd like to give them a 3 but the appetizer plate was dirty. And it wasn't like the plate had been sitting on the table for a while, the waitress set it down in front of me with dried stuff stuck on it. Maybe next time will be cleaner and I'll bump them up a star.
author: Tiffany E.

description:
Craig C, Kim T, and I were starving after our yoga+climbing session at Planet Granite and needed a place to eat at 10pm. This can be tricky since a lot of good places in the Richmond close at 10pm. Interestingly Genki Ramen was full when other places were closing up, so our party of 3 sat at the bar. We ordered chashu ramen, chicken karaage ramen, and curry chicken katsu rice dish.  We also got some beer, sesame wings, takoyaki from the happy hour menu - probably way too much food on top of the main course but who doesn't love a HH deal? Oh, and some edamame - can't turn down a yelp check-in offer either.
The service was decent, a little attitude-y, but it was past 10:30pm and there was no harm done.

This place is worth checking out for cheap late night eats. Almost everything on the menu is less than $9. I'd recommend the sesame wings, takoyaki, and chicken katsu dish.

[[my ramen rankings]]
1. Men Oh
2. Suzu
3. Izakaya Sozai
4. Katana-ya
5. Tanpopo
6. Izakaya Roku
7. Genki Ramen
author: Jennifer L.

description: ****RAT ALERT**** Was just waiting for a table a saw a HUGE RAT running around! We all screamed and pointed and the workers just looked up like it was a normal tbibfb. GROSS! Contacting the health department STAT!
author: Jenn V.

description:
My friend brought me to this place for ramen lunch the other day when we were working around the hood.  Price is very reasonable and food is decent.  Dishes serve hot on table.  I ordered their Curry Chicken Katsu Ramen, which is not bad at all.  Their ramen is okay but the curry soup base is a little too watery to my taste.  Overall experience is great.

A friendly reminder to Genki Ramen:
"Some of your interior fixtures are falling apart, please fix them, or it will truly hurt your business and your customers."
author: Steve L.

description: If you want to use the check-in offer, make sure you bring your card! My friend did not know about this when we went and wished they would have mentioned that before she did the offer. The waitress mentioned it after we finished our meal when giving us the receipt. Would have been handy to tell before instead of expecting us to know about this little fine print. (Since most free offers don't come with a plot twist). Besides that, the place was decent.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
More like 3.5 but I'll round up. Decent place to grab some ramen. Full bar and the seating arrangement is good for groups. Ramen is the thing to get here, but they some good appetizers as well. 
Open late Friday & Saturday (1am). 

- Chicken Karaage: ok, but nothing to talk about
- Gyoza: not bad, good app to share
- Kinoko Mushroom Ramen: soup was ok, not enough flavor, mushrooms were bland but at least had a good variety, pork & noodles were good
- Chashu Cold Ramen:pretty good, dressing was flavorful and chashu was ok
author: Linda C.

description:
I ended up this place by accident. I was looking for Burma Superstar nearby but then lost and gave up looking for it 30 minutes (I was visiting from DC). 

I settled for this place by looking at decor of inside. It was a hot Saturday afternoon and wasn't really feeling 'Ramen' for lunch, you know....

I ordered Okonomiyaki - it's like sweet Japanese pancake with meats (or seafood). I got the one with seafood. Boy! I'm glad I got it. It was very tasty! I didn't have great expectation for this place because it wasn't all that crowded and didn't have good vibe from this neighborhood. I was also very determined to check out the Burma place (never got to check it out during this trip) so settling for Japanese wasn't really my option.

The interior is great. Very modern like. The bathroom is amazing too (one of those from high-end nightclub!). It's perfect little place for lunch or dinner if you want something light but still want to enjoy good quality foods. I've seen too many Japanese where they focus on Sushi rather than Ramen & Okonomiyaki, so this was a nice visit. Wish DC had something like this too - I think we got too many Sushi only and they're way overpriced.

The foods were delicious. I thoroughly enjoyed the foods and service from waitress. She was very nice and attentive. She occasionally smiled at me - maybe she thought I looked good. I doubt it.
author: Josh S.

description: I like this place a lot! Been here three times and went again today. Good is good, cheap and fast. The servers and friendly. Definitely a neighborhood favorite!
author: Midori H.

description:
This place is one I actually visit pretty frequently because the food is consistently okay, and if I can get a huge bowl of decent Ramen for $7.95 (basically, with leftovers, it's two meals for me) then I will return. 

They also offer a nice check-in deal: you can get an app of fried chicken bites that are good (not great) in the ramen or on their own. You can pretty much always get a table too.

However, I pretty much always get my food to go now, and that is the reason for my two star rating: not to be negative but the service here could be a lot better.
author: Milli J.

description:
The ramen was good but not great.  I don't claim to be a ramen expert, but the broth seemed to be missing something.  I got the chashu and the boyfriend got the chicken karaage.  The chashu was very thinly sliced darker meat with very little fat.  Unfortunately, I like my pork pieces fatty. The chicken karaage was little chunks of deep fried chicken that soaked up the broth nicely or were tasty nuggets on their own.  We also split an order of the gyoza, which I liked.  The bottoms were seared with a thin soft layer of folded dumpling goodness on top.  

The service was really slow, and it's not because the workers didn't try.  Owners:  hire more people.  It's self defeating to nickel and dime with staff when the result is turning customers away.  The line was only growing as we left and there were tables that needed to be cleared.  

I'll go back at some point, but it won't be for a while.
author: Daniel F.

description:
The boy and I are on a quest to find the best ramen in town. Enter: Genki Ramen.

Now, is it the best we've had? No, don't be silly. No, but it was pretty delicious and equally satisfying. 

We each got the chashu (with boiled pork, a half boiled egg, bamboo shoots, green onions, and red ginger in tonkatsu base). I got mine with extra kimchi, while he got his with spicy miso paste; both were super tasty. We also ordered a side of pork shumai and, though tiny, they were excellent. The sizzling yakisoba looked really good, so we might be back to judge that.

Free appetizer with a Yelp check-in (though we didn't partake), attentive service with a smile, and fair prices.
author: Adena B.

description:
Cheap go-to place for ramen on that normal chilly night in San Francisco.

Not the spot if you're a ramen connoisseur or if you're on a quest to find the world's best ramen.
author: Con L.

description: Worst lunch ever. The food there is OK- do not expect authentic Ramen there they are just average taste. The thing makes me angry is their customer service. I am traveling back to home and before I take off I thought it is good to have some comfort food and I left my scarf in the restaurant. Right before I took off I found my scarf missing and called the restaurant, they told me"maybe it is in there" What does maybe means??? There were only three tables in the whole restaurant and you can't see a big red scarf on the ground?and they refuse to help to send me the scarf even I offer to prepaid the fees. "you can only pick it up by yourself" THIS IS SUPER FRUSTRATING!!!!!!!!!
author: xb s.

description: Love their beef stew ramen. The brisket is so flavorful and tender. My kids love the chicken karaage. Again, very flavorful and not oily at all. Plus, they give you Hi- Chew candy with your bill. Will be back!
author: Ami B.

description: WHY DID YOU CLOSE AT LUNCH?!?!?! My coworkers loved going to lunch there. Please reopen for the lunch crowd!
author: Catherine M.

description:
As my girlfriends and I got done with our foot massages a little after 9pm on a Monday, we needed a place to eat that was be open late.  Genki Ramen opens until 11pm on weeknights?  Score!  

We arrived a little after 9:30pm last night to find the restaurant was PACKED.  We sat for about 5-10 minutes in the tiny waiting area until we were seated.

FOOD: 
*Clam broth ($4.50) - The broth was flavorful and served in an individual soup bowl with chopped garlic and about 4-5 clam shells in it.  A bit on the pricey side for a small bowl though.

*Fried tofu ($3.50) - Delicious and recommended!  Silky pieces of tofu were deep fried perfectly so that the outer layer remained crispy when served.  Bonita fish flakes and green onions were sprinkled on top while the tofu sat in the yummy broth.

*Kaki Age (Oysters) ($5.75) - The oysters seemed as if they were cooked a tad too long and over battered.  

*Spicy Sausage Okonomiyaki ($8.95) - The spicy sausages tasted like hot dogs.  The Japanese pancake was flavorful and tasty, however, I wish there were more pieces of spicy sausages.  

*Chashu Ramen ($8.95) - The tonkatsu soup base was a bit on the salty side and I drank the miso soup base from the butter and corn ramen instead.   The ramen was garnished with bamboo shoots, half a brown egg, chashu, and chopped green onions.  We opted to add $1 for spicy miso which came out as a paste

*Butter & Corn Ramen ($8.25) - YUM a must try!  The miso broth was delicious and the sweet corn perfectly complemented the dish.  My only gripe about this dish is that it didn't come with enough broth.  TIP: Ask for a lot of miso broth.

EXTRAS:
$4 for the watermelon slushy drink - FRESH watermelon blended, it was quite refreshing
Genki has a large variety of sake

BONUS:
Hi-chew candy with your check!

SERVICE:
The waitresses were nice but they never came back around to check on us.

PARKING:
Metered street parking which is often difficult in the area, even at 9:30pm we found ourselves circling for a space.
author: Nicole S.

description: I've been to this place more times than I can count and I love it so much. Amazing ramen, whether you're getting pork, chicken, or veggie, and great Yakisoba and Gyoza and the list goes on. Bonus points if you get Hi Chew when your check comes!
author: Tania C.

description:
I don't know if it was coming straight from hearing David Chang from Momofuku Noodle Bar talk about noodles and ramen for more than an hour, but Genki Ramen turned out to have the best Japanese ramen I've had since I left L.A.  My sister and her friends were in agreement, and they live nearby, so I'll take their word for it.  There was no equal to Daikokuya among any of the ramen places near where I work in San Jose.  Kumiko in Japantown, Kahoo in Santa Clara, all very average.  

I usually order chashu with tonkotsu broth as a measuring stick for a new ramen spot.  If they can't do that right, I won't try anything else.  Served in a sleek black bowl with a long curling spoon, the noodles were buried deep under shaved green onion, a broth-infused hard boiled egg, soft bamboo shoots and ample slices of pork, though not grade A as far as tenderness.  The temperature was perfect; at other places, sometimes I feel as though I burn my tongue right off the bat, and have to wait 5-10 minutes before I can try it again.  

Despite a few minor imperfections with the rest of the dish, the tonkotsu (pork) broth was Daikokuya good, but a tad lighter on the pork flavor which could actually be an improvement.  A perfectly-sized portion for me and my friends, not too much as many places tend to serve.  Granted, I had about 4 pieces of the deftly fried chicken karaage.  Genki gets my stamp of approval, and henceforth is to be known as the Daikokuya of the North, without the hour-long wait.
author: Danny K.

description: I actually really like this place.  Their ramen is consistently good and their katsu is always great.   Plus, they have a good veggie ramen to accommodate those friends.
author: Edgar C.

description: Ordered dandan noodle. It was divine! Really authentic! Would definitely come again
author: Yaqi G.

description:
Liked the croquettes & Green Tea Matcha Smoothie!
Happy hour! 
Everywhere I go,
Why do I always feel like all ramen tastes a bit too salty?
author: Amy C.

description:
Its official, I really like you genki.  The first time I had genki was for delivery...I was sick, and since my family lives on the other side of the country I had no one I could convince to make me chicken noodle soup.  But luckily I was dating someone, for like a minute, who decided the next best thing to homemade chicken noodle soup was to order ramen, sit in a t-shirt and underwear (his idea) on the couch, watch a bad movie, and de-sickify.  I don't know if it was the guy...who was kind of a catch, the sitting in our underwear, the movie, or the ramen...but it was exactly what the doctor ordered. The ramen came quickly, it was cheapish, there was a ton of soup and the ramen was pretty brothy and plain...which is what I wanted.  he ordered some breaded chicken thing (which now I believe to be chicken katsu, though at the time i couldn't care less)...and it was yummy.

This weekend a girlfriend and I decided to go for ramen.  It was the residual effects of two days of yucky foggy rain that came to san francisco earlier in the week but we were craving ramen...iT didn't matter that it was now four days later and super warm...

Genki is located in the inner richmond, easy enough to get to, parking not too bad...like 5 tvs....their happy hour prices for beer was 3.00....(or 12 for a pitcher) had a free app on yelp...which was kind of awesome because it was this crispy fishcake spinach thing that there is no way in hell i'd ever order, but since it was free we tried it..and I'd probably order it again...

Then the heavenly bowls of goodness arrived...I got the boiled pork ramen, which was pretty amazing...The egg perfect, the broth tasty...but the pork itself had no flavor and sort of tasted like turkey...and my friend got the beef ramen which was good too despite the pieces that were a little too cartiledgy...

The lose a star because it seriously took them 15 minutes to even come to our table and take any orders...luckily they gave us happy hour beer prices even though at that point it had ended...
author: Kierstan G.

description:
Is it late at night and you've got the munchies (ahem I won't ask) and haven't a clue what to eat? Then head on over to Genki Ramen as their menu is pretty darn extensive and can satisfy most late night cravings. Can't say the food is great but it is pretty good considering the size of the menu...and if you're hungry you're hungry. A sampling of a few dishes I had:

Chicken Karaage: Probably the only dish I was disappointed with. Orenci Ramen in Santa Clara sets the bar for this dish, and to date I haven't found anything that comes close.

Fried Tofu: Pretty much on par with other places as it's a pretty simple dish. The dashi stock is tasty and I love watching the bonito flakes dance on top b/c of the heat from the tofu.

Takoyaki: Mmmmm...definitely reminded me of the versions I got at various street cars in Japan.

Chashu Ramen: The restaurant name-sakes lives up to it's name. Pleasantly surprised at the quality and flavor of the ramen. Would definitely get this again.
author: David H.

description:
WTF?
I don't want my Ramen warm.
I hate warm Ramen.
I like my Ramen hot.
I also like my curry hot. Spicy hot and hot temperature.

The Curry Chicken Katsu Ramen was totally BS!
The Ramen broth was warm, and suppose to be a Ton-Kotsu but did not taste like anything, really lame.
The Curry was warm, not spicy enough, and has no flavor what so ever.
The Chicken Katsu was so flat.

It seems like all things came from instant frozen food like.
The curry may be packaged already made kind from Asian market.
I can make better than that.
What a disappointment!
Displeasure caused by the nonfulfillment of Genki Ramen.

I don't know.
The menu changed.
It used be an OK/good late night Japo-place but something changed mainly in the kitchen.
May be the new owner hired a new kitchen helper doing not a good job.
Yes, it was that bad.
But I still hope the place gets better because it's open late night and the service was still good.
author: Nobu K.

description:
The spicy mapo tofu ramen here ROCKS my damn world. The chashu ramen is also excellent.

Reasonable prices, decent service, and they always seem to be playing music from Apple commercials. Genki Ramen is one of my favorite comfort food spots in SF.
author: Sabrina V.

description:
This is one of thee best ramen spots by far. It's reasonably priced, the food is always full of flavor and the service is pretty fast.

I must say I was quite disappointed in the service this time around. For once the place was not busy. Our server appeared bothered when my husband asked her for extra sauce for his chicken karaage. I also asked her for extra bowl for my son and she gave me a look of pure irritation... Seriously, it's your fuckin job lady! It is unfortunate that people like her lack the customer service skills . Especially when working in food service.

I will definitely return because we love the food here. We just hope we don't stuck with her  serving us again.
author: Marie C.

description:
Surprisingly good! Noodles were a good texture, not too soft. Soup was flavorful, not too bland or salty. 

I ordered the wakame ramen which had two types of seaweed and corn and it was goodd, i love "simple" ramen. 

My boyfriend ordered the garlic stewed pork or something ramen and he really liked it, flavorful and tender. 

The free tofu that comes in checkin is really small. Cheapos. 

The only thing bad about this experience was the waitress. One lady working there at 3pm and helping 4-5 tables out. She never smiled and looked at me blankly when I asked what wakame or nori was, as if I were stupid. She just seemed like she wasn't enjoying her job at the moment.
author: Emily M.

description:
The food is actually pretty good.  Good not great.

Now the real problem.  Worst service of any restaurant in SF.  Seriously. They are rude, inattentive and just plain mean.  Sorry to bother asking for a glass of water that you didn't bring the first time I asked 10 minutes ago.....t may even throw a racist claim in there.  I sincerely hope not, but would be curious to see how others have been treated.

I've been here 7-10 times and have experienced god-awful service at least 50% of the time.  Why go back you say?  good question!  My own fault...  No more.  Nope, never again.

Go to Le Soleil or B-Star on Clement, Halu on 7th street or Citrus Club on Haight- all have better food and better service.  

Sorry Genki, never again.  Actually, I'm not sorry, you should be......
author: S M.

description:
Food was average or less. I got the house special curry and vegetable ramen. The ramen and curry was quite flavorless.

Two stars because they charged me %18 gratuity because I was in a party of 5, which is fine (although the service didn't warrant that) then they added  on ANOTHER %18 tip on to that!!
Disgusting misuse of power. I tried to take off the extra %18, but I still got charged for it when I looked at my bank account. 

ISNT THAT ILLEGAL 

will never be eating here again. They did the same thing to another person in my party
author: Taylor D.

description:
I've ordered Genki takeout at least a dozen times and visited the restaurant once.  The food is definitely better when eaten at the restaurant, but they do a good job of packing the ramen components separately for delivery.

The shrimp tempura ramen and chicken karaage ramen are my favorites, although I find it odd that the "shrimp" tempura ramen comes with only 2 shrimp, but 3 or 4 slices of veggie tempura.  More shrimp please!

The karaage appetizer is good and the gyoza is OK.  I've noticed that the miso base broth has had a metallic taste lately.  The tonkatsu base doesn't seem to have this problem and is quite tasty.  The noodles are OK.  I don't get the impression that they're made fresh, but they satisfy.

I'll continue relying on Genki Ramen for quick, easy and inexpensive take-out dinners.  Their food sure is comforting on cold SF days!
author: Helene O.

description:
Can't go wrong with ramen. Always enjoy the seafood ramen. Gotta add some roast pork as well:). 

 The BBQ rib eye skewer appetizer was lacking some kind of seasoning.  But that's just me. 

Service was quick and friendly.
author: walleworld w.

description:
Genki, Genki Ramen! King of the wild frontier!

I'm not sure anymore what the factors of a five star review should be. I mean, I wouldn't give my firstborn child for a bowl of ramen here, but it's consistently hella good and fits nicely into a childhood nostalgia song, as clearly detailed above. 

I've been coming here for several years when my ramen craving gets intense, and the spicy mabu tofu is always really satisfying. I tried the garlic tenderous [sic] rib yesterday and it was tenderous and tasty, but I don't see it overriding my one true ramen love. The gyoza is fucking tasty and everything else we've ordered has been good. Yesterday we scored both happy hour AND the lunch special, somehow, so we washed down our heaping ramen bowls with a pitcher of $12 Sapporo and rolled off burping into the beautiful SF afternoon.
author: Missy V.

description: Oh my goodness. Just walking in here, you get that super sticky and gross feeling. The walls and old booth seats are sticky and greasy as well. There are old food particles stuck to the menus, and the food is over-priced. The service is grouchy, but fast-paced. Don't think I'll ever come back. I definitely felt like I needed a shower after leaving this place, and I'm a Chinese kid who has been eating at dingy Chinese restaurants my whole life. I'd rather eat at Chung King in Chinatown. Yeah, Genki is that dirty.
author: Danny C.

description:
I'm not sure what the Genki means, but assuming simple, "casual spot for ramen."

We got in around 930, and noticed the check in deal... But beware its served super hot. Temp that is.

The ramen we had was tofu & pork, and this was the first time I've ever used scissors in soup! My companion helped and we enjoyed the scenic detour of dinner.  

And the staff was friendly to boot.
author: Chris M.

description:
Gyoza - 5 stars
Chicken Katsu Curry Ramen - 5 stars
Yelp Check-in Offer for a free appetizer - priceless

go here. you will love it.
author: J S.

description:
We ordered delivery.  It took 1.5 hours. Driver said he spilled ramen broth.  Alas, what we received was practically no broth.  I called and lady said they "may" be able to bring more broth later????  So when is the driver coming back? "I don't know".  So exactly how long should I wait for the soup I already paid and tipped you for. She said she couldn't refund money because she already had it.  Well you don't get to charge people for something you didn't get.  All of the ad-ins were totally tiny on top of that.  She was totally unapologetic.

I never review places and this made me go find my Yelp login just to talk about how much terrible this place is.
author: Michelle B.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Chashu Ramen - yummm craving ramen and this hit the spot. Taste kinda reminds me of like egg noodle, soup was good though.
2.) Beef Onion Skewer - yum

*loved the selection on their menu :) Def willing to come back to try stuff.. Maybe during their happy hour for the appetizers!


SERVICE:
Good


ATMOSPHERE:
It's nice, clean, spacious, Japanese feel
author: Angela L.

description:
My friends have been going to Genki for some time and always rub it in my face since I'd been living too far away.  When I finally moved into the city I made it a priority to get over and try the ramen.  The first time I came after a short run with a group of ten.

Most of us ordered the ramen from the lunch menu and got an additional side for $1.  The ramen was huge, I wasn't expecting such a large meal (granted I did down most of it).  It was the perfect size for a voracious individual, so probably a but large for normal humans.

The only issue we had was the order of getting our food.  Those that ordered first received their food early (about ten minutes before the others).  It was odd that half our party had their food while the others waited.

I've returned to Genki a few times since and enjoyed it.  I'm a big fan of the curry chicken katsu ramen.  Not sure about the other food, but I don't think that is the main appeal of this restaurant.  Make sure to check in on Yelp to get a free appetizer.
author: Michelle K.

description:
I came here after passing by, it wasn't packed but there were lots of people, so I decided to give it a try. 

I got the chashu ramen and two skewers. Skewers came out first, and were just ok, the slices were too thin so they became charred chips on the grill. The ramen was just ok. Broth was really good. Noodles were extremely overcooked. My main problem though is that the toppings are refrigerated. The chashu was super cold when I tried a piece, they could at the very least stick it in the oven to warm it up. The egg should definitely be done to order.
author: George T.

description:
I am a huge fan of this place because of its Yelp Check-in Offers and their late night happy hour.  I love the "So Cool" soju drink and the fact that a pitcher of beer is only $12 after 10.  It is a great place to come if you want to hang with friends and don't want to stand around at a bar.  This place doesn't play loud music though, so if you are looking for a bar scene, this place is not it.
The Ramen here is not as good as those in South Bay but it is good enough to satisfy my craving. I like the "Ma po tofu ramen, short ribs ramen, and the mushroom ramen".  I tried the Okonomiyaki and the Takoyaki here and it is a bit doughy. The sesame wings here are awesome.  Super crispy / crunch on the outside and has a great seasoning. 
The price of the food here is reasonable given its quality.  I plan on coming back often.  Please keep the Yelp Check-in offers coming!
author: Wendy K.

description:
The ramen is not bad. It's a little saltier than usual, but not bad when you're hungover.

Check in with your Yelp app for free appetizers.
author: Yonder B.

description:
The restaurant was nice, simple. I had the butter & corn ramen and to say it was a pleasant experience would be an overstatement. :/ the noodles were just okay and the broth had little to no flavor. 

The boyfriend ordered some garlic something ramen though which was pretty tasty, maybe I'll try ordering that in the future. We also had the complimentary croquettes with our check in which were tasty too.
author: Valeria O.

description: I've been here twice now for the ramen and I think they make a solid bowl of ramen. Definitely not near the best that I've had (I'm such a ramen snob, I swear), but if you are craving ramen and don't want to wait forever, this is a good go to.
author: Kelly B.

description: This place is awful don't even get delivery from here. I ordered the chashu ramen, my gf had the yasai ramen, both tasted terrible, as if the food was old, and had a distinct oder with reaffirmed the fact that this was not fresh food.  However I was so hungry I tried it anyway. After a few bites I began to feel sick, and decided it wasn't work it. How hard is it to make fresh, good tasting ramen? This place needs to have some dignity and not serve people crap. What a waste of money. Needless to say your food ended up where it belongs, in the trash. I wish there was a option for no stars.
author: Charel G.

description: Was excited to find a place on yelp that was not closed and we got there around 10:25 but we didn't get to eat. So Better get there before 10:25 because after they only allow to-go orders. Unfortunate that I couldn't base this review off of the actual food itself.
author: Paulina N.

description: the ramen is a bit salty, for me, and the service was a bit rude. I've only been this once and will give it another try.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I looove the beef brisket ramen.

the ebi with garlic butter is scrumptious, and most of the skewers are really tasty, especially the bacon and asparagus one.

It's a little on the loud side in the restaurant, so I usually ask for delivery which is always quick and hassle free.

Totally recommend to anyone.  I eat there usually at least once a week.
author: Ben R.

description:
Four stars! This place is cheap, open late, has decent food, and only 2 blocks away from my apartment. Pretty wide variety of snacks and fried foods. If you want something healthy, this isn't it.

We ordered the spicy yakisoba which is eggs noodles with bacon, kimchi and sausage. The noodles themselves were slightly spicy. We like picking at the crunchy pieces stuck to the sizzling platter. I had the curry chicken katsu. Typical comfort food, but a little spicier than what I was in the mood for that day. Portions were generous and I was able to bring some of the curry home for a snack. No wait at noon on Sunday and the food came out scalding hot.

Good food for its price range, fast service, and cheap. Expect a Hi-chew with your bill.
author: Mimi X.

description:
I like like like lots, and will definitely be coming back soon! 

So the ramen isn't the best that the city has to offer. However it is better than Tanpopo in Japantown, but not better than Katana Ya in Downtown, however the prices are reasonable for ramen about $8 a bowl, which isn't bad, considering I paid around $15 in NYC. The ramen was cooked well, not too mushy and with a bite. The broth was good, however nothing to rave about, missing the wow-factor that some ramen places have, like Santouka in LA, or Totto in NYC. By wow-factor I mean after having a taste of the broth and receiving a few flavors on your tastebuds, but as you let the broth linger more tastes come about out of no where. That's the wow-factor. The chasu was pretty flavorful and wasn't too lean nor fatty which is good. The soysauce egg was definitely soysauced. 

What will bring me back to this place is that they actually make decent takoyaki and okonomiyaki. The takoyaki was fresh, the batter wasn't too watery and there was a decent size portion of octopus inside of it. I appreciate how there was the right amount of okomi sauce, mayo, bonito flakes and ginger slices. The okonomiyaki was good too, ordered the one with beef. The size was a good amount (bigger than Sake Hagi in NYC, which was tinnnyyy) and again the batter was good. The okonomiyaki had a nice crisp about it and the beef wasn't undercooked. Again just the right amount of toppings. Besides the mix modern yaki that I can get in Japantown, Genki has a yummy okonomiyaki. I may be back next week!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Had a wonderful lunch.  First time here on recommendations of friends.  Ordered the #405 Seafood Raman, the Chicken Karaage and the #307 Noodle with Curry Veggie.  

The Seafood Raman was great:  noodles were done nicely, the broth was just right and not too salty.  There was a lot of different types of seafood:  shrimp, oysters, imitation crab, fish and other goodies.  Done just right and not over cooked.  I'd do this dish again.The ingredients were fresh and appreciated good seafood.  Also, the karaage is part of their lunch special and a nice added appetizer.  

My partner had the #307 Noodle with Currie veggie.  This was good and you really should enjoy an entire curry meal.  It was a lot for her and boxed about a third home.  

There was one waitress and the place was fairly busy and full.  It was good that she was able to hustle, seat, take orders, serve and clean tables.  They could use a little more help in the dining area.  

All told, it is a worth while experience and plan to enjoy again.  Thanks.
author: Stefan L.

description: Came here hoping for some warm delicious ramen on a cold SF afternoon. Was hoping for spicy tonkatsu ramen on their menu (I think most places have that) but unfortunately, their menu did not. Closest thing was the Chasu ramen but I like to keep things spicy so after reading a couple yelp reviews, I opted for the mapo tofu ramen. Though it didn't taste bad, I don't think mapo tofu belongs in my ramen (to each his own if others love it - just not my thing). Hubby got the shrimp fried rice and he said it had a very strange sweet flavoring to it. He ended up adding a ton of sriracha to his rice and I topped some of my mapo tofu from my ramen onto his rice too for added flavor. My son had the pork tonkatsu and the gyoza which he ate. The staff were nice but our waitperson was a bit hard to understand. All-in-all, I don't think we'll be back.
author: Ruth L.

description:
I came here today for dinner. I liked the layout of the place, the seats were comfortable, and the table was large. There were flat screen TVs by the wall, which was nice. They also had a side bar displaying a selection of sakes. 
The menu was extensive, with a selection of appetizers, ramen, yakitori, donburi, robatayaki and okonomiyaki. We ordered the garlic tenderous rib ramen, a chashu ramen and a seafood okonomiyaki. The food came out relatively fast, and was fresh. The ramen was really hot, and the texture was nice. The portion was just enough, I liked how they didn't give too much. I found the soup to be a little salty, but the chasu was tasty. I've had a lot of ramens where they add bean sprouts, lettuce, baby corn or some kind of uncooked vegetable on top. I actually don't care much for those, and I liked how Genki ramen didn't add any of those toppings and kept it simple. The okonomiyaki was also very flavorful, and had a lot of seafood. We also checked in on yelp, and got a free order of croquette, which was very crispy and fresh. 
The waitress was very nice, and overall the food was solid and fresh. I liked how comfortable the place is. We watched the game on TV during the meal. The bill came out to be $35. I will definitely come back to try some of their other dishes.
author: Helen Y.

description: I had heard a lot of good things about this place but I'm not sure why. I found it to be very mediocre. Broth was mostly bland, with an unpleasant aftertaste that made me think of garlic powder and seasoning mix out of a packet. Noodles were sparse in the bowl and overcooked, with none of the springy texture found in good ramen noodles. To add insult to injury I was assaulted by loud pop music the entire time I was there, in a mostly empty restaurant at lunch. Is there an unwritten rule that requires so many places in the Richmond to play terrible pop music at high volume?
author: Deacon B.

description:
The food here was pretty good, but the service was terrible. We went here at like  7pm on New Years Day, so maybe it was busier than usual since most other restaurants were closed that day. However, reading reviews over the past couple months makes me think the bad service is a common occurrence no matter what day you go.

We waited at least 40 minutes for our food. It was probably longer, but I wasn't checking my watch constantly. We didn't order all that much either. Two of us got soup which took the longest to get out. Another person had an appetizer and one other person had something else. As we sat there for like 40 minutes waiting for our soup, we noticed that takeout orders were being cooked and going out the entire time. It seems that they are priority for this place and not their customers who have been waiting for their food for a really long time in the restaurant. Looking around the restaurant, there were lots of people like us with dissatisfied expressions on their face as they sat at their tables with no food.

It appears as if they have a small kitchen here which is probably part of the problem, and they've decided to prioritize takeout overs over customers that dine there. The Ramen I had was pretty good, but I am not going to wait 40-50 minutes for soup here again, while I watch all the takeout orders going out.
author: youdontneedtoknow R.

description:
The ramen here, at least the mapo tofu one, was pretty decent. Just avoid the yakisoba, the chicken one comes out bland and the pepper steak one comes out ridiculously peppered. That and the heat of the hot plate it was sitting on made me break a sweat!

They have pretty good happy hour prices with different happy hours everyday and even some late night after 10pm happy hours. Another thing, they seem to be running promotions on their website or yelp check-in for free chicken karage. 

3 stars for now, until I get a chance to come back and try some of their more traditional ramens.
___
Aug '11 Health Score - 90
author: Dennis L.

description:
I really like the Beef Stew ramen with spicy miso and extra broth.  My boyfriend loves the Tan Tan ramen with extra broth.  Since our dishes are pretty spicy, I really appreciate that they are constantly refilling our water glasses.  I've tried the Garlic Tenderous Rib ramen and the meat is a tad sweet and I'm not interested in sweet stuff in my salty ramen.

We come here all the time and I have to admit, the parking is tricky around here...  We once drove around for 30 minutes and decided to call in our order for delivery because we couldn't find parking.

Note: if you check in on Yelp, you get a free appetizer like edamame or croquette.
author: Teena O.

description:
Kind of between a 3 and a 4. The food was pretty decent. Was going to order alchy, but was still a sick. 

Got a free side for checking in. woot.

I got the Chicken Karaage ramen. delicious. lots of food though. definitely made my throat feel a lot better after having ramen. good flavor the broth. and great size for the price. 

best part = hi-chew when getting the check. green apple! yum.
author: Nina Y.

description:
I'd given this place 3 stars if it wasn't for the bad service I received last time I went in.

As a vegetarian I know it's hard to eat most kinds of Asian cuisine, as they use fish sauce or chicken stock for pretty much all their dishes. However, when you advertise that you can make "vegetarian broth" for ramen, you'd expect that you can have a vegetarian meal at Genki Ramen. Apparently that is not a possibility.

For the lunch combo you can get gyoza with your meal. On their menu they have both regular and vegetarian gyoza, however, for the lunch menu you can only order the pork gyoza with your vegetarian meal. How does this make any sense?
Even when I pointed it out to the server, she just looked at me and said "you can have the pork, not the veggie one." 

The ramen is fine, veggies for the veggie ramen are crunchy and fresh. This place is really quick when you eat in, but when you order delivery it takes them an hour (even when you live 15 blocks away, yes next time I'll definitely just pick it up).
