Squid tentacles.  Delicious as always.  I love the chewy texture.  It's more tender than the dried squid snacks but more firm that poorly fried calamari rings.  BTW, does anyone else get suspicious when calamari comes only with rings?  Where have the wiggly bits gone?  This dish was only the wiggly bits.  

Lamb Chop robata - Marina loved it.  I passed on it and ate the shiitake mushroom skewer instead.

Shiitake mushroom robata - Tender, flavorful, over-sauced.  The glaze was a bit thick.  I like just a hint of seasoning.  More smokey than sweet.

And....that's it!  $28 dinner for two girls.  The last half of the Jets-Broncos game.  Some quality drool time when Tebow did his interview while wearing only the inappropriately tight undershirt.  It looks like one of those baby-ts that were so popular in the early 90's.
author: Christina C.

description:
Ahhh Oiiishiii! 

One of the best Ramen shops I've had in Northern California.  I've eaten ramen around LA, Sacramento, Davis, and Hawaii.  The noodles are way above average -- cooked just right.  I got the Chashu Ramen and I fell in love with the broth.  It was a pretty small ramen for me, but when you talk about a free Karaage chicken appetizer when you check-in, I'm sold!  The Chashu Ramen broth is quite catchy and satisfying.  

Way better than any Ramen shop in Japantown San Francisco for sure.
author: K W.

description:
FOOD: If you need a quick fix of ramen, I go here especially on cold san francisco nights. I usually get the curry katsu ramen. Deep fried chicken in a spicy curry base that tastes like potato fries. The portions of the soup is fairly good. I can finish a bowl without feeling too full or too hungry. 

SERVICE: Sometimes its a hit or miss. I have had slow service and have had quick ones as well. They're really nice don't get me wrong, but it depends on when you go. Sometimes they would be busy, but would have one server. If you order in your food, they make your food promptly. 

PRICE: Pretty cheap. First time checkin on yelp you get a freebie appetizer. 

OVERALL: I like this place. Nice spot to catch up with friends and have a light lunch. I recommend this place.
author: Isabel N.

description:
Genki Ramen,

Today I feel like FUNKY Ramen because of you and so does my boyfriend.

We both ordered the ramen curry
First off off we had to pay $5.50 extra for stir fried vegetables, bamboo shoot and spinach EACH, I barely saw the spinach, got 5 bamboo shoots and they forgot the vegetables.
Same thing with bf dish.

It was SO greasy, I literally went to the bathroom during dinner.... I know GROSS... get over it, I poop too........ flowers and Swedish flags.

TODAY as I am writing this, I am not feeling like a sexy lady more like ...well you know, my tummy feels like shit and once again so does my boyfriends.

It took them 65 minutes to deliver a horrible Ramen and a horrible day after.

Poop on you!.
author: cecilia k.

description:
Real fruit passion
Watermelon juice
Mango smoothie
Strawberry smoothies 

Lots of tables for a ramen place
Chashu ramenlots of meat

Free offer
Okonomiyaki-good
Karage-
author: Timothy G.

description:
There was so much hype about this place, that I really wanted to like it.  Even after reading the reviews on how their service sucks, we went anyways.  I'd like to report that their service still sucks... they asked everyone else if everything was ok, but never asked my husband and I anything though their turn point to circle the restaurant was right next to our table, each girl passed by at least 5 times each, and not a word was said to us.  

Their ramen is SUPER oily.. there was this sheen over the broth in my bowl, that I had to scoop out to eat my ramen.  If I wanted to lap up oil I would've bought a bottle of cooking oil from the market across the street.

I got the garlic tenderous ribs ramen  combo with 2 gyozas (gyozas... I've had better store bought ones.  ramen-was only tasty because of the added garlic chips and ribs)  while my husband got the chashu ramen combo with chicken karaage (he said it was tasteless and mentioned the oiliness).  We've been to plenty of other ramen places that give you a full oozy boiled egg with your ramen.  This place is greedy enough to give you HALF a hard boiled egg (close to being over boiled as it was a hint greenish grey).
We both got the caramel milk tea smoothie which was probably the tastiest thing we had from there, sad it's not what they specialize in. 

I don't recommend coming here to be ignored, nor pay close to $10 for oily and mediocre ramen with half a hard boiled egg.
author: Joy-Lu B.

description:
I had preconceived notions about Genki as I stepped through the double doors of this trendy hipster establishment.  Flat screen televisions, colorful menus would surely suck the taste out of their food.

I was wrong.

Genki serves up a good solid bowl of ramen.  But as I scanned the landscape of the restaurant, I noticed the faces of non-ramen origin eating patrons.  Did I land in a tourist trap?

Eh, if I did.  Who cares?  The food is good the beats are solid.  I'll be back.
author: Rochelle D.

description: Came with 3 friends, and there were not a lot of people there. we were seated and waited 20 minutes without receiving any attention or service. We decided to say "fuck this place" and leave. The snooty waitress smiled as we left and said "THANK YOU!" as if we had eaten or been served. Extremely displeased with this place, HIGHLY discourage this restaurant. I will never be returning here again and if I could leave a 0 star review, I would. Simply AWFUL
author: Alex K.

description:
Not too bad; a good bang for your buck. It is a good place to come with some friends who are as hungry as velociraptors. A dish that you have to get when you come here is the okonomiyaki. It comes out on a sizzling plate with a selection of meats and veggies. It is pretty much a smorgasbord of deliciousness; perfect for sharing with friends. 

Atmosphere/decor here is standard for the Richmond. 5 flat screen tvs all around the restaurant mashed up with pop songs of the American or Asian variety. A good place to come with some friends for casual dining.
author: Angela L.

description: No. just no. why would you go here? this place is basically in a little chinatown. the food isnt bad, but its expensive and only decent. if you are in the area, go down a block or two and get food there. i promise you it will be a lot better and CHEAPER!
author: Patricia K.

description:
Came here yesterday night for a friends birthday. Arrived around 8:15pm. It was at less than half capacity. There was a lot of flat screen tv's hung up with football on. They played a lot of 1990s songs like backstreet boys and n-sync. 
I ordered the chasu ramen. It was pretty good with a good amount of noodles. I enjoyed it.
My friend ordered the veggie curry. I tried some it was good too. =] 
We got a cake and had the waitresses take it out. She miscounted the number of plates and didn't give us forks. Also she was going to take a picture for us but got distracted by the phone.
author: Sarah C.

description:
On a cold San Francisco afternoon, there is one thing that hits the spot...

RAMEN!

My girlfriend Min Jung lived in this area before and recommended we hit up Genki Ramen. First off, let me confess this: I am an incredibly picky eater. I don't eat fish, curry, coconut milk, anything with small seeds, anything with pulp...the list goes on and on.

The folks at Genki Ramen were kind enough to make my Fried Chicken Katsu with a miso base in lieu of a tonkatsu base. So delicious. Portions were generous, prices were reasonable and service was quick. What's not to love?
author: Tara H.

description:
Yuck yuck yuck!

This review is based off of their delivery. The service at the restaurant must be awesome because the positive reviews here are totally not similar to my experiences. 

Note I said experiences, because I ordered from here twice, assuming my kind second chance would enhance what occurred.

This is everything wrong with Genki:

1. Delivery guy was a jerk! Late, unprofessional and essentially threw my food at me. Didn't even ask for my signature, does that mean I can call my bank and say this experience was not authorized?? I wish I could because I can't believe I paid for that service

2. The food was wrapped so sloppy! My ramen spilled all over my rolls. I literally just had a puddle of soup in a plastic bag for dinner...not worth the $20 minimum if you ask me

3. Ramen was so bland! How do you mess up ramen? seriously, it's just fried noodles in water with some veggies...how can you ruin that?

4. rolls were gross! They were super covered in that gross mayo sauce. My rolls looked like those bloated, gross, not fresh rolls you can buy at a grocery store.

Never again.
author: Vanessa T.

description:
I have to say, I do not enjoy their Ramen at all. However, I do very much enjoy their appetizers and small plates. Their tempura (veggie+shrimp or Yam+pumpkin) is perfectly light and crisp. Chicken Kara Age (fried chicken) are breast pieces that are juicy and drizzled with tonkatsu sauce. Their okonomiyaki is really good as well, I love the Sumo one. My all time favorite there is the takoyaki (octopus balls) which are fried with a nice piece of octopus inside with all the works. Yummy!

The mixed alcoholic drinks are very good as well. Pinky Sour *tastes like peach rings!* and Blue...something. With lychee in it. That was really good as well. $5 a pop - very reasonable prices I think. 

Give this place a try if you can! But I wouldn't recommend the ramen lol.
author: Tracy N.

description:
It's hard for me to rate this place fairly considering I only ordered delivery from this place. I just want to say beforehand that my low rating is based on the food that I ordered and not the establishment itself since I have never dined in. This could be a charming place for all I know, but regardless the food that I ordered was sub-par. But in all fairness I would still sit down and eat at this place just to give it a shot. Maybe it was just the food I ordered.

First I want to applaud Genki Ramen for adopting such an easy to use online ordering system. Pick your food from the menu and pay with a credit card online. Simple and easy. I wish all delivery places had a system like this.

Now on to the food. For starters my roommate and I had the Pumpkin & Yam Tempura and the Baked Scallops. The tempura was soggy and incredibly oily. This could have been result of us ordering take out and not eating it fresh at the restaurant. Regardless the pieces were also cut really small. The Baked Scallops on the other hand were pretty delicious. Those scallops were pretty tiny, but the garlic butter it is cooked in made up for it.

I also ordered the Seafood Yakisoba. This was pretty bad. The noodles were pretty bland and incredibly greasy. I had to add soy sauce to give this dish flavor. In my opinion if food tastes good you don't need to add anything extra to it. This was not the case here. The seafood pieces were small and mostly imitation crab. My roommate ordered the Curry Tonkatsu rice plate. The curry itself and the katsu cutlets were pretty good. But the entire dish is made up of mostly just rice.

The food we ordered was not very good. Despite its poor showing, I would still give Genki Ramen one more chance. It has the word "ramen" in its name, so I will make the assumption that ramen is what this place is known for. So I will try that next time and avoid all the other stuff I have already tried.
author: Allan Y.

description:
As a first timer, I went in without any preconceived notions of this place thus no expectations - just with the hope of a no fuss, no frill place with a tasty bowl of ramen. 

They had a lot to offer in terms of ramen and izakaya style foods. I was impressed by their extensive menu and wanted to try many things but my tummy can hold only so much food. That, and I had my sights set on ramen. 

I ordered the Spicy Mabo Tofu ramen and it was, more or less, what I expected to get. I dove right into the tongue-burning hot bow of ramen  and it was just the perfect temperature. (Yes, you read that right - piping hot broth is just the way I want it.)  A couple of notable differences was that the broth was slightly thicker than what I'm used to and I could have used a little more of it.  I usually don't finish the soup portion anyways so it wasn't too much of a bother.   

We also had the chicken karaage - it was crunchy (not greasy) on the outside and moist and tender on the inside. 

There's more on their menu than just your standard ramen and appetizers so I plan to make my way back there soon. Namely, to try their sizzling pancake. 

By the way, I am vehemently against paying an extra $1 or $1.5 to make my broth spicy (unless it delivers a significantly spicier flavor and usually it doesn't) but to each their own.
author: Cyndi G.

description: Great place for late night ramen, considering that there's a happy hour from 10 until closing! I haven't been here in a year or two but had a late night craving for ramen. We got a free seaweed salad thanks to the yelp check-in! We ordered the gyoza which wasn't bad but not the best I've ever had. As for ramen, I opted for my favorite ramen of all time-tan tan! It was such a disappointment .. Overly salty with a spicy kick but on the bright side, there was so much pork! But soup .. Didn't even attempt to drink it after the first sip! I've been spoiled by ramen parlor and all the ramen places in San Mateo area but this .. Was just unacceptable to all ramen fans! I would come here again maybe just to get the appetizers. I wish I could say this was a fast food for ramen .. But it's not even close! Come for the appetizers and happy hour but pass on the ramen (unless you're absolutely starving!).
author: Jennifer W.

description:
solid Ramen place...

We've tried 

1) Katsu chicken- very good and i love that they give you a lemon wedge for it. 
2) watermelon juice- awesome drink 
3) chasu ramen- very good broth and other excellent Chasu. 
4) Negi-beef ramen- way too salty! They use a sauce to saute the beef in and then pour into the tonkatsu broth...not a good combo like the Chasu ramen. 

I really appreciate that they have add-ons for the ramen such as half a boiled egg (75cents), mushrooms (not on menu but they do it for $2). 

chicken yakitori skewer- yum! 

This is a good place if you want a warm bowl of ramen, but I think they use too much salt or MSG, because I'm always thirsty when I leave this place...for hours!!!
author: Yva D.

description:
Came here one night with a few friends. We had originally picked out a different place, but someone suggested ramen, so we opted to change locations. I ordered the Chicken Karaage ramen. Tonkatsu broth is pretty oily, but it does give the ramen flavor. The bowls they use are huge, making the ramen look measly. The Karaage was quite tasty, so I definitely recommend ordering that!

We also got two orders of vegetable tempura, an order of samurai wings and sesame wings. (free with yelp check-in). The vegetable tempura was definitely worth the price, but the samurai wings definitely weren't.

Tables along the walls are very close together creating a slightly cramped dining experience, but also puts a damper on any conversation. Asked for water and tea refills a multiple times before we got them. Same thing happened with the check.
author: Steph W.

description:
Food: I'm not a ramen expert, but I thought it was good. It was the other side orders like the short rib, egg plant, gyoza and other items that were better then good that made the meal extra nice.

Ambiance: Small, intimate modern noodle house with an open window to the kitchen and TVs on the walls to catch the game.

Service: We were sat right away and they did a good job.

Price: It can add up if you order a bunch of appetizers and side dishes.

Overall: Parking on Geary can suck, but I'd definitely go back.
author: Binh D.

description:
Found this place on accident while going up Geary and just happened to pull into a parking spot right in front! It was a Saturday around 6 pm but it wasn't too busy, we were seated right away, and the servers were kind even though they were all lacking smiles (don't know what that is about, but anyway). 

The menu choices are quite overwhelming and I have to admit I went for something familiar and popular at other places that have ramen; Chasu Ramen. It was good, but not out of this world good and doesn't come with as much condiments as other places. The basics were pork, half boiled egg (why not a full egg...1.50 for an extra half an egg..ridiculous), bamboo shoots, green onion in tonkatsu broth. I definitely won't make a special trip out here just to get it but maybe if I was in the area and didn't know what else to eat. 

We also got the Samurai Wings which were pretty good also. Had a lemon-y kick to them and if it was happy hour I'd certainly get those for a snack.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Speaking as a person who has tried ramen all over Asia, I can't say that I'm impressed with Genki's ramen. Yes, the ramen is still yummy, but I wasn't a big fan of the butter and corn ramen that I ordered. With that being said, I will be going back to try their other entrees as they offer quite a number of options on their menu with a few items that catch my eye.

I am definitely looking forward to try their baked scallop, curry entrees, chashu fried rice, and their grilled onigiri.
author: Erica J.

description: Great place to have ramen good price food was delicious!
author: Charlie H.

description:
Genki Ramen looks very nice inside. I've never been here at night, but I've been here in the afternoon and it's always nice and clean. The staff is usually quite attentive and refill my tea to the brim. They check on us often.

They have a pretty extensive menu, from ramen to okonomiyaki to rice plates.. Yummm.

$3 appetizers from 3-6PM! I love happy hour. They have eggplant with sesame, and I loooove eggplant. A good choice for vegetarians.

I've never tried their ramen, but I've had their chicken okonomiyaki and it's delicious! I really recommend any of their pancakes. They are perfect and a decent size.

I am going to come back to try more stuff on their menu. I wonder if their ramen is as good as Katana-Ya's? :P
author: M J.

description:
LOVE the Yasai ramen with vegetarian broth.  Although the menu is huge, there aren't a ton of veg. options, but the fact that they have vegetarian broth makes me a pretty big fan.

Service can be a little slow
author: Cate M.

description: I loooooove this place. I live right accross the street from them and eat there all the time. I don't need to vouch for them, they are awesome and their food kicks ass. Beef Stew is my jam jam.
author: Sr. Misha T.

description:
I would rank this as my number two spot for ramen in the city. 

The place is pretty modern looking. I like how you can check out sports games on the various tvs all along the walls. 

Ramen is very good. The cooks are asian so I see that as a good sign. I don't know if they are Japanese or not but doesn't really matter. 

My standard dish is the 409 Chashu Ramen. Very tasty. I also sometimes get the Mapo Tofu Ramen. Its a really chinese style of ramen but I like it a lot. I occasionally get the gyoza and chicken karaage. Both taste great.

This place has a pretty wide sake and alcohol selection. I have come here for my birthday a few times before hitting the bars in the area. Genki is open fairly late and is usually very easy to get a seat. I'm going to come back and check out the happy hour situation.
author: Lawrence S.

description: I ordered the mushroom kinoko ramen and it tasted pretty good. I got a free seaweed salad after checking in with yelp, which was nice. I tried to order an Asahi beer but couldn't understand the waitress' response, which I take to mean that they didn't have it, so I ended up getting a Blue Moon like my friend did. Overall the food was good and the atmosphere was nice, but it would have been nice to complement my meal with an Asahi...
author: Douglas M.

description:
Date/Time:  Saturday - 9pm
Occasion:  Post-trampoline jumping dinner get together
Party of:  Five
Location:  Pretty young and cool vibe for the fobby. Lots of seating available. Open kitchen window in back.
Ordered: To share: spicy sausage pancake and seafood pancake, spicy teriyaki chicken wings, and bacon wrapped asparagus.  Personal entree: kimchee ramen with side of hard boiled egg
Total incl gratuity: ~$21pp

I was pleasantly surprised with this place.  It turned out to be pretty tasty.  They had a considerable menu of all different kinds of goodies.  Our group opted for a few different appetizers to share, all of which are highly recommended.  I wasn't initially very anxious to try the pancakes but I'm glad I did.  They both turned out to be very good.  The seafood pancake was probably my favorite of the two.  The bacon wrapped asparagus was pretty amaze.  It was hot and so flavorful.  Too bad it was such so small.  I was very pleased with my ramen.  It was a hearty portion.  The additional hard boiled egg was a smart addition.  The broth was savory and the noodle texture was perfectly chewy.  I would highly recommend a bowl of ramen if you choose to come here.  Service is basic; server took our order and left us alone for the most of the evening.

There's a lot to try here so I wouldn't be surprised to find myself back ordering some of the other things on the extensive menu.
author: Jess C.

description:
Came here twice.  

First time, service was not great, but I still had hopes for the place because my mom and I decided we liked their ramen.

Second time, came with mom and brother.  Mom's Oyasu(?) Ramen was ok...but my brother's ramen came out SO SALTY.  As a fan of sodium...(unhealthy, but salty spicy food are so delicious)..I normally don't complain, but when i took a spoonful of the soup from his ramen, it tasted like heavily salted water.  Made me wince.  He asked the waitress politely if they could redo the order--something we never do..we usually just suck it up, but this time it was just too much.  They said they could not....ok....then can they provide some broth so we could mix it into the too-salty ramen?  They said they had to charge us extra, and were not apologetic at all--rather rude actually.

Can you say, not coming back?
author: Jane K.

description: Loved it! I know most people crave ramen/sushi between hours 3-5?!?! Well Genki Ramen is open when the rest are closed! Their hours are not the only great thing, their spicy tofu ramen was really good! I would totally come back
author: Jess A.

description:
I had their Yasai  (mushroom flavored) ramen and thought it was delicious. A mix of shiitake, hiratake, bunashimeji, eryngi, my noodles were super flavorful and aromatic. Definitely a stimulating olfactory experience. There were so many things I wanted to try: their baked scallops, veggie gyoza, noodle with curry veggie, their cold noodles (seafood and veggie), their robotayaki (grilled items). The menu is large and my ramen was filling so I didn't have much room left for other dishes. I definitely want to try more items next time. 

Open until 1 Friday and Saturdays, this seems like a good spot to go with friends for a late dinner or after a long night. Dimly lit, LCDs relaying the highlights of games from earlier. Hot food to ingest before heading home for the night? I couldn't be more pleased.
author: Alesia T.

description: Had lunch. Seafood ramen with spinach appetizer. Excellent only con was the small amount of spinach for the price. Also had watermelon smoothie which is great with the salty soup. Broth was great seafood had a really enticing smokey flavor. I read some of the other reviews about rude service. My experience was very good but the restaurant was almost empty. Also liked the proliferation of flat screen TV with different programs. Will go back
author: Lambchop B.

description:
I had a random idea of a Ramen Run, see how many ramen places I could go on my day off of work. I actually went to 4 places, but only 2 were open, Sapporo-Ya, and Genki Ramen.

Genki was my last spot, it was MLK Day and the parking on the street was not free, it is SF and guess no holidays are free in the city. I ran into the restaurant and asked if I could break a $1. I only had $1 in cash and was planning on using my credit card to pay for food. $1 for parking is only good for 30 mins, so I asked if I would be able to get a bowl of ramen and consume it in 30 mins. The waitress said, "oh yeah you will".

I got my change and paid the meter. I went back into the restaurant and sat down, made a quick glance at the menu and ordered the Chicken Karaage Ramen.

I loved how the Chicken Karaage was on it's own plate, not dropped into the ramen bowl. The chicken was really crispy and tender. The broth was tasty, not too salty, and was a bit spicy (the way I like it).

When I finished the bowl, paid, and went back to my car, there was still 9 minutes left on the meter. Genki had some fast service, and the ramen was great.

Between Sapporo-Ya and Genki, Genki wins my vote.
author: Alen K.

description: It's all about that garlic tenderous rib ramen! So yummy.  the lunch prices are pretty good, and the service is decent.  I would come back if I'm in the area.
author: Brian C.

description: Good and affordable ramen. I would not say its the best but it is pretty good. I wish there was more soup since it was tasty. The ramen was cooked al dente and there was enough chasu for the order. It just comes in a large bowl and you wished there was more broth. Huge selection of ramen and other dishes if  you weren't hankering for ramen.
author: Eve C.

description: Ordered through Grubhub.  Food arrived 30 minutes after the expected delivery time.  Tan Tan Ramen tasted like commercial lettuce wraps in luke warm broth.  Calamari was soggy.  Ordered +egg, received 1/2 boiled egg.  So disappointing...
author: Andrew L.

description:
I came here last night and was seated quickly at 10:45 pm. It wasn't my first time at Genki Ramen so we decided to try new dishes. 

We ordered the Seafood ramen with the miso soup base and the Chashu Yakisoba. The ramen was really good so I'm glad we tried that but I didn't like the Chashu Yakisoba as much as the Black peppered Yakisoba. We also showed them my phone and received the yelp deal! We chose the free crispy daimaru which was filled with cream cheese inside. It was delicious! 

Our entire total was a little less than $20 which is such a great deal. I also noticed they do happy hour on the menus so I might go back for that! 

Definitely try the black peppered yakisoba and five stars for their late hours on the weekends!
author: Vikki K.

description:
This place is so delicious! My bf and I decided to try so many different things...from curry, to ramen, to karaage.

Everything was delicious! I will definitely come again if I'm in the area.
author: Karen H.

description:
This is not Ramen Dojo in San Mateo, Daikokuya in Los Angeles, nor Santouka in Torrance/Culver City.

What this is, is a homey place to get a reliable bowl of ramen and various izakaya style foods. It's what your average reliable ramen in Japan taste like.

And that is definitely fine by me!
author: Sean L.

description: Good stuff.  Plenty of skewer options.  Chose pork neck and chicken gizzard. Both were good.  Had the butter and corn ramen. Comes with pork, 2 pats of butter and corn.  Surprised by the pats of butter but other than that, it was good.  If you check in on Yelp, they have rotating appetizer freebies.
author: Will I A m.

description: Great place for ramen delivery.  We love it.  Its perfect for a cold SF night, or when you are sick.  Even our NY friends rave about it when they come visit.  The tan tan and the spicy mabo tofu are our favorites, by far.
author: Jill G.

description:
My favorite ramen place is in Mountain View, so I've been searching for my favorite SF ramen for some time now.  Granted I've only tried about 5 different places thus far, but Genki is currently my favorite.  

I enjoyed lunch here with the coworkers on a rainy day in June (that really shouldn't be allowed in California...rain in June that is).  3 of us got ramen, one got yakisoba, and one tried miso soup and octopus.  

I opted for the basic chashu ramen, to see if this place was legit.  First of all, the soup came with 4 slices of pork, the most I've been given with a standard order of ramen.  Other accouterments included the obligatory boiled egg, bamboo shoots, scallions.  The broth was a meat base, and while not kicked up with anything, still not bland, and currently one of my favorite basic broths.  The noodles too were more ideal than others I've had.  The right size, consistency, and taste.  

Perfect rainy day ramen.  Now, in terms of more exciting flavors, they have a lot to offer here, but none that stood out to me as being really unique.  I still need to try more ramen places in the city, since I know there are better ones out there, but so far, this is the only place I'd gladly come back to and order ramen from again.  

Plus they have such a huge variety on the menu, you can satisfy pretty much anyone's tastes in your party.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
After my first time at Genki Ramen, I was back the same week.  This cold, foggy hood makes me want what they have!  I've liked both my ramen soups and everyone else's, too.  The scallion pancake dishes are great, and so are all of the things that come out of the deep frier.  Genki manages to fry their food in a way that keeps it very light and crispy.  I am thinking they use good veggie oil and change it out often.  I had a watermelon ice drink that I liked as well, and I find that a draft Sapporo is always welcome.  
The only thing that I don't like is the large number of TVs.  I am not a fan of TVs in any restaurant and it takes away from my experience.  That's the only reason I'm not giving 5 stars.
author: Erika W.

description:
This is my sister's fave ramen place. The decor is super cute and modern, with lots of green-ness and I think I counted a total of 5 flat screens on the walls! There's a bar lined with some of my favorite sakes, but unfortunately the bar was closed on that Sunday.

The service was disappointing. The waitresses were busy, so it took a while for them to get to us, which was understandable. But when they finally did, they were less than enthusiastic about helping us. 

My sis and I ordered beef okonomiyaki, beef/enoki roll and cha siu ramen with butter. The combination of their ingredients and flavors were creative and unique. It was all so delicious, though it was a bit oversalted, and left me dying for water for hours after we ate. 

I can't wait to come back and try all the other goodies on their menu!...perhaps on a day when they might have more staff on hand, yeah?
author: Shiki W.

description:
Hey, what's going on?  The last time I was here (like four years ago), it was okay-not-great-and-overpriced, but now it's really good.  And I guess inflation has caught up with their pricing, so that's all right, too.

Anyhow I went back last week and had the Garlic Tenderous Rib ramen and it was delicious.  The garlic tenderous rib reminded me a lot of Filipino adobo with pleasantly sweet, soy sauce flavor.  Good broth.  Kind of light on the veggies.  Anyhow the dish scores full thumbs up, so now I have to go back and try the other ramens, too.  Oh well.  It is a sacrifice I am willing to make, because that's just how much I care.
author: Eric W.

description: decent but not super flavorful broth ramen.  tonkatsu lacked body. one star for being open late. extensive menu but all else not so well done - eggplant needed more salt (and was a bit oily), the several robata we had was overdone and under seasoned, karaage tasted a bit off (but was free!). loud bad music.
author: Kimby T.

description: This is one of my go-to places for delivery.  The food is consistently good and the delivery is fast.  I was so happy to see that they also have okonomiyaki, which is a hard to find favorite. The yakisoba and the ramen are also incredibly good.
author: Gavin M.

description:
I've been a regular at Genki Ramen for about two years now, and they have NEVER let me down! If you're looking for great tasting Japanese food other than sushi, this is the spot! I'm always full and satisfied when i leave Japan Town! 

For starters: Deep Fried Donburi

Then, it's time to dig in: Seafood Okonomiyaki, Seafood Fried Rice, Short Rib Skewers...Yumm.....

For desert, (if you have room) make your way down the street for some sweet crepes at their sister market, Genki. 

This is a great spot to go at any time of the day or night. There are so many delicious items on their menu! And if you go early enough to catch the lunch special, grab yourself an Unagi Don! The one thing that makes this place ever better is that they close at 3am! Shaoo!
author: Lily S.

description: I've been a regular here for a year now. I'm still in love with the Unagi Tempura and Kari Age fried oysters that I get both everytime before even getting to my ramen. I've only had to wait for a seat once, and food always covers the table about 5 minutes after ordering. The service is always extremely sweet and polite. Usually just sticking your head up and making eye contact is enough to get some help at your table. I would advide this place for anyone who is cold, needs a soup fix, loves fried food, doesn't want to go too deep into the Richmond, etc. The only bad thing about this place is you can never find parking. But that's a Richmond thing. If you ever have room after dinner, walk around the block to Genki Crepes. Probably not owned by the same company, but it's a dreamy 1-2 punch to enter a nice warm food coma on the way home.
author: Brian G.

description:
We were here for dinner on the night of the World Series.  Despite all the flatscreen TVs inside, not one had the game on.  They were all tuned to the same channel.  Boo.  The modern décor was definitely nice - dimly lit, black wooden tables and wooden chairs.  The place looks clean and new.  Prices are reasonable and the menu is lengthy (with appetizers, okonomiyaki, donburi, yakisoba, cold ramen, hot ramen, BBQ skewers, deep fried dishes, sushi, desserts, etc.).  

I had the Kimchi ramen ($8.95) which comes with boiled pork (chasu), mushrooms, cabbage kim chi and a tonkatsu broth.  The noodles were straight, limp and not chewy.  I like my ramen noodles to have a little more bite to them.  They weren't stingy with the chasu slices but the thin slices were overboiled, tough and pretty bad.  However, the tonkatsu broth was flavorful, not too salty and not oily.  The cabbage kimchi was okay.  The ramen wasn't served piping hot which really disturbed me.  

I had a bite of the "garlic tenderous rib" (not sure what that means) and it's a stewed, fatty piece of meat - much tastier than the awful charsu in my ramen.  

The hard fizzy candies that came with the bill were really good!  I'll have to look for those.

I don't think I'll rush back here.  Come to think of it, the Genki pearl tea was average as well (at Genki Crepes) but I loved the grocery store portion at Genki Crepes.  They must carry the hard fizzy candies?
author: Lolia S.

description:
I love the interior of this place. Very clean and brightly colored.

Wait staff was really friendly too.

Now the food. Being Vegan Im skeptical of someplaces, but the waitress was very nice and understanding. My GF and I got Ramen with veggies in it, and also a "tea" broth instead of the Miso (the Miso, like most Asian restaurants, has fish in it).

It tasted a lot like Miso, but Im pretty sure it was the "tea" blend. It was very good and we got a lot of ramen and soup and veggies for under $10.

Well be back!
author: Mike D.

description: Where should I start?  We ordered a variety of food: Yakisoba-GREASY! Chaohan-GREASY & burnt. Ramen- noodles in bland stock.  Chicken robatayaki- rip off! Overall the food was gross, greasy & disgusting. BEWARE: we had a party of 7. The wait staff charged 20% gratuity on the food, tax and a take out order! That is unethical.  Service did not warrant a tip. One of the waiters was rude when we complained that the Chatham was greasy- his response was "That's how we make it." Pulease!  We will never got to this restaurant again. Shame on you Genki Ramen- Genki means well or good- that's a joke.
author: Luri S.

description: Had a late lunch with a friend and ordered the butter&corn ramen. It was lacking a bit of flavor, but I don't mind because I don't like overbearing MSG in my ramen. I also tried the Ebi in Spicy Mayo Sauce. I really enjoyed that! The two things I don't like about this place is that the food comes in very small portions (so small, I actually finished my bowl.. and I rarely ever do that) and that the service was bad. It took 10 damn minutes to get my check and there were 3 tables filled within the entire restaurant.. Including the one I was sitting at. All in all, it's pretty good ramen. Probably will come back!
author: cadence p.

description: My favorite ramen place to go to when I'm in the city. The tender pork ribs are "oh so good". If you are ever in the area, it's a must try.. Also, they have late night happy hours..
author: Tony Y.

description:
I shall return for more ramen and to try more items in their extensive menu.

Ramen portion size is smaller than Katana-Ya, which suits me just fine. I don't have to worry about leftover noodles expanding in the soup or eating too much and getting a stomachache.

Moreover, that tonkatsu soup base is awesome! It's not too salty but definitely has enough flavor, so I kept slurping it up. Noodles were on the tender side of chewy, but I still liked it. Slices of pork (I ordered the Chasu Ramen) were big, and they gave me half a soy sauce egg with the scallions and bamboo shoots.

I should talk about the egg. It's marinated.
It's also one of my favorite parts about eating ramen. When the egg isn't there, I'm sad.
You can add the egg (and extra meat, noodles, corn, and other toppings) to any ramen. This is excellent. It means I'm free to order whatever type of ramen I want and still get the egg.
End discussion of egg.

We also had two robatayaki items: chicken gizzard and saba. The saba was huge and not on a skewer. You get a whole half of fish. Value! It's covered in the same sweet sauce you get on unagi, which was surprisingly good with mackerel. Gizzards were kinda tough (they're gizzards, wasn't expecting tenderness). Next time I'm going for the minced chicken and beef tongue.

Since we were there during happy hour (3-7pm), certain appetizers were $3. Gyoza and croquettes were both fried very well and delicious. I will come back for those, too.

They also have takoyaki, okonomiyaki, and yakisoba. All things I'll eat in the future because I can't find them in most Japanese restaurants. There's lots of sake variety, too.

The restaurant is kinda dark inside in the evening. There are 4 TVs playing 2 sports channels with no sound because music is blaring. It's a little hard to hear the person you're talking to. It's a decent-sized place where, on a Saturday night around 5:30pm, the place was nearly empty. No waiting. It filled up a little more later, but not much. 

$40 including tip for 2 people. Considering how much food we ordered, not bad at all. 

Mmm... ramen...
author: Amy N.

description: Beef stew ramen is my favorite cold weather snack :)
author: Ariel L.

description:
On a rainy drizzly night, 2 friends ducked in for some late night grub.
I ordered the kimchee ramen while Leap Leap got the chasu.
As we sat, we were given tea (which was good cause it kept my hands warm) and a small plate of pickled cabbage.
So the broth is good n salty, not as thick and msg-y as Santa Ramen of course, but still good. It's decent and passable. Much more flavor than that of Tanpopo.
The noodles though, I wasn't too impressed. They were not quite al dente so they were a bit TOO chewy if you know what I mean. Had that slight undercooked bite to it.

I'm going to have to give this place another shot; however it is a good alternative if I don't feel like driving down to Santa Ramen..
author: Susy C.

description:
oh genki..you're a hit or miss for me.

i used to live two blocks away so i would make a quick trip to genki on those cold, foggy, inner richmond nights when i didn't feel like cooking. i was always full and satisifed after but never once did i think "this is the best ramen ever!"  

two years go by and i stopped i here again with a bunch of friends after a long day at the beach.  perhaps you brought your A game that night or i was famished but my kimchi ramen with egg (an extra) was pretty darn tasty.  it's also a plus that you serve beer and other adult beverages in shades that should only belong in a pack of highlighters.

but help me understand how half a boiled egg is 75 cents?  if we do the math here (someone help me with this...) that's a lot of hardboiled eggs i could make at home, no?
author: Sally T.

description:
Can't wait to get back to Genki Ramen!  Next time I'll try something from their drink menu too!

I think they are 1 of 2 (3 at most) restaurants in SF that serves Okonomiyaki-which we first tried in Japan.

The waitress said it would take 15 minutes to prepare it but it was much quicker than that.

My bowl of pork ramen with side of chicken karaage was perfect for the chilly weather-it warmed me up nicely!

I like the design of the interior too!
author: Kendall L.

description:
Genki is one of those Japanese words that is intangible to define in English.  It lies somewhere between wellness, vitality, how one is, etc.

Along those lines, this eatery is appropriately named.  Coming off the blustery bustling Richmond street, this Ramen house instantly revitalizes.  The dark wood, the lime green cushiony chairs, the plasma screens (yay - TVs), the well stocked bar of sake (they also have beer, wine, soju), and the slick Genki chopstick holders (see photos) are one of a kind.

Menu has a wide array of ramen (both veggie and meat based), okonomiyaki, donburi, fried appetizers (mmmm fried), non-fried apps. (yay healthy), robatayaki (a.k.a. shish kabobs), teriyaki, rice-based dishes, kids menu, desserts, non-alcoholic drinks (smoothies, milk teas, ice coffee, ramune (a fizzy lemon-lime soda with a marble).

Happy hour 3p-7p.  $3 drinks. $3 appetizers.

Go and be Genki!
author: Cathy K.

description:
Ive had it every which way. Delivery and sit down both are fine. I felt delivery was better though. they sperate everything so it doesnt come to your house all soggy. Put the pieces together and your all set. 

I'm giving this 3 stars with my gut feeling. Every time I eat their food I'm content. The flavor is just meh...
author: Zachery H.

description:
I LOVE this place.... I must state that I have never set foot in this place and I am only yelping about the take out/delivery. Being a single guy, I always look for places that deliver when I'm lounging at home on my off nights. It only took 30 minutes to come to my house after placing the order through grubhub.com

I ordered the Chicken Karaage Ramen and it came in 3 containers. I love it when they separate all the items so your food stays fresh. I also ordered the Robotayaki items which included the chicken wings, and bacon wrapped asparagus.. Both were ok and will try some other items in the future...

if you're craving decent food and just too dam lazy to do anything but watch Netflix, give this place a shot.
author: Vincent Q.

description:
I always knew this place was around but never actually came here until I had my first ramen bowl somewhere and just had to come try it out. The place always looked a tad empty but also pretty sophisticated inside so I thought it might be kind of high end or something. When I actually came to try the place out, it's not as out-of-reach as I thought it was.

I usually grab the chashu or the beef ramen bowl as a meal to have the side dishes and tried all three sides out (popcorn chicken, gyoza, fried rice) and my favorite is the gyoza. After having the chashu dish for sometime, however, I felt like there was some weird funky odor or taste to it so I started to order the beef ramen. Other favorite dishes that I love ordering from here is the croquette and especially the grilled ika yaki!!! Whenever I can find grilled squid, I try my best to get my hand on it! Although it's almost $10, I feel like it's so worth it because it's grilled just right and isn't dried out or hard or anything. I've also had their samurai wings (which is pretty juicy), takoyaki (not too great of a deal, there's like 1 or 2 pieces of octopus in there; more dough than octopus), agedashi or fried tofu (also not too great of a deal, you get 4 tiny pieces, or 2 cut in half), and also beef stew ramen (it soaks up the soup too much so I didn't really like it).

On my first visit here, they were trying really hard to promote their watermelon slush drink and so I got it. This better have been the best watermelon juice drink I've ever had because it was $4 fir about 8-12oz and although I admit it was tasty, I can't say I'd want to grab it again because of the price.

This place also offers extra ramen or soup (+$1-$2 extra or so) so if you prefer to so it's good for those with big appetites.
author: Judy C.

description: Great place. Ramen only so so. But i come for Chicken Karaage when visiting from LA i make detour cause it is so good.
author: Audrey S.

description:
Does the job. Close to home.

It has a lounge-y feel to it. Seems to be a spot for student and late night ramen hunters.

Curry Tonkatsu = warm belly.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Really 3.5 stars

I can't believe this is my first visit!  I love the different options they give you. 

I had the Tenderous Pork Rib Tonkatsu Ramen and found it was very good. The meat was very tender. I also like the option to have the noodles cooked to the desired tenderness (you can also ask for the broth to be extra rich with oil/fat).   I really liked the soy egg which is a lot better than Santa or Dojo's plain hard boiled egg. 

The broth is not as rich or good as either Santa or Dojo. Himawari is still a little better. 

My wife had the Chasu ramen and the chasu was very flavorful (again better than Santa and Dojo)

Salmon fried rice was ok but there was a bit of sweetness that I didn't like. The chicken Karage was good but Orenchi's is a little better. 

All in all, this is the place to go to for a wide menu selection and decent food. It's my go to for SF now for Ramen.
author: ray r.

description: The first and only time I tried tonkotsu ramen was at the ramen festival at the japanese store back home in hawaii. They brought over a company that makes it all the way from japan for the festival... I loooove tonkotsu ramen. Hawaii does not have any where that sells so when my sister brought me here I was soooo excited! I ordered the kimchee tonkotsu ramen and a side of gyoza... both were excellent!! The gyoza was home made and tasty. The kimche tonkotsu ramen was sooo good my how I've missed you!  The service was good too. I hope I can go there once more before I return home.
author: Lindsay G.

description:
Best late night place in town!
Dependable.
Consistent.
Well-staffed always.
Decor: could care less
TV: nice distraction
Food selection: superb

My fav: Their black peppered-beef Yakisoba & chicken karaage.

Perfect ending to your meal: free Hi-Chews :)
author: Keiko C.

description: Pretty good, fast, warm ramen. Price is incredibly reasonable and the service was fast and ateentive.
author: Evel K.

description:
This restaurant is a very chill spot in Inner Richmond. The ramen is decent, not any wow though. However, the hidden gem here is Okonomiyaki (Japanese pancake) called "Sumo" (bacon and cheddar cheese) is very unique and something nice to have to go along with the ramen. I also try some Sake which hit the spot nicely.

PS. If you could make it, there is Happy Hour at 3pm to 6pm & 10pm to close 7days...very cool and affordable price ($3) for appetizers & drinks!!!
author: Ryu K.

description: Food is ok. Just ok. I was hoping it'll be good as the one at San Mateo. Service is ok. The light is to dim. Can't even see the menu right. The funny thing about this visit is, they serve their Ramen first. By the time we done with our ramen then come the appetizers. Weird. Overall just ok.
author: Andy L.

description:
Genki Ramen is one of my 4-yo niece's favorite restaurants.  Seriously.  We were sitting at some other restaurant a few weeks ago and sat down and she looked around and said, "Hey! This is not my favorite restaurant - Genki Ramen!"

Anyway, A and I were in the mood for some soupy noodles one rainy Saturday afternoon so we headed over to try the niece's favorite restaurant.  It was about 1pm and fairly empty.  Only about 3 tables were occupied, so we were seated super quick.  We ordered two grilled onigiri as an appetizer and then I got the beef curry ramen while A got the kimchi ramen.

The grilled onigiri is so good!  It has unagi in it and the grilling is just perfect.  Nice and brown and crispy on the outside, while soft and yummy on the inside.  A has been dying to go back just to order some more onigiri for snacks!  My beef curry ramen was just right.  You could taste the curry, but it didn't ruin the taste of the broth or alter my ramen.  It hit the spot.  And A really liked his kimchi ramen.

So, even though we had doubts because it's a 4-yo's favorite restaurant, I'm pretty sure we'll be back.  At least for the onigiri...
author: Kris L.

description:
I felt a bit rushed to get a drink and appetizer when I dined here the other day. Sure, it was happy hour but there wasn't even that many people. 

I always order the same at every ramen place I go to and that is either Shoyu Chashu or just Chashu ramen. Mmmmm, mmmmmm! I would make my own but it takes 5 hours to make the broth alone :( so I ordered the chashu ramen.

The bowl the ramen came in was kind of sticky (Ew). But it didn't affect the tasty noodles. The quality of the food has changed quite a bit. It's not as I remembered from a few years ago. Service was better and I sure remember the food being better as well.. Sigh, I think I'll pass the next time.
author: Amy C.

description: Pretty good ramen. Not so packed like other ramen restaurants. A variety of items on the menu. Many TVs to watch sports.
author: Peter Z.

description:
If you're living in marin, it can be a bit of a challenge to find a ramen joint.  
thats the kind of challenge my friends and I came upon, which then means we gotta go on an adventure across the golden gate bridge in order for us to get our ramen fix.  

My group of friends are no strangers to driving across the bridge just to eat...(we tend to do that quite often) so eating ramen on a hot afternoon?! no biggie..(hot in marin, perfect in the city)

I don't know if they usually get busy for lunch, but we came at what would usually be consider after lunch.(i like to call it happy hour) 

i gotta say I like their interior, its cute! 

as for my order: i got the chashu ramen with a side of karaage chicken.  as for the broth, i wished that it had a bit more spiciness to it.  (just the way i like my ramen) the ramen was still pretty good, but i've had better.  Can't forget your $12 pitcher of sapporo during happy hour:)
author: Hong T.

description: Seafood Ramen #405 with added corn. Superb!
author: Scott A.

description: Better than I expected!  I had the curry tonkatsu ramen and a pan fried kimchi noodle dish.
author: Sandy C.

description:
We went to Genki's this evening for ramen noodles.  We had a party of five.  One of the orders was to go since one of us was not very hungry.   The ramen seems ok--though it seems to be better before.  The prices, likewise, seem to be about a dollar higher per order than before as well.    And the service was hardly exceptional--basically, they provided you with glasses of water and served you the food when it was ready.  The waiter/waitress never bothered to refill your cup or provide you any additional service.  In other words, the service was mediocre to below average.   Therefore, I was shocked when a gratuity amounting to 18% was written into the bill.  And the waiter that provided that bill with the 18% gratuity wasn't even the one who took our order or served our food.  Needless to say, I complained about the 18% gratuity because there were only five in our party and there was no mention that a gratuity would automatically be charged to a party of five.  It seems that the waiter just made that the decision of 18% on his own for mediocre service which was not even worthy of a 10% gratuity let alone an 18% one.  

Because I complained about it, he took some time before he returned my change.  I guess he thought I was right--that the "basic service" of putting our food on the table and providing us each with exactly one glass of tap water was not worthy of a 18% gratuity.  Therefore, he brought it down to a 16% gratuity instead!  I guess for this "waiter"--bringing food to a patron and giving them a glass of tap water is to him--superior--"A+" service.  

I don't think we will be coming back to this ramen joint anytime soon again.  The food is ok but the service is mediocre to below average but they want to be paid with a gratuity of 18%.   Please note that a gratuity is left for you if you provide good service only--we are not your employer--just your patron.  Your employer is responsible for paying you your wages--not the patron.  And if you want a worthy gratuity--learn to provide better service.
author: Sharmagne A.

description:
Tried the Chicken Karaage Ramen with a side of Gyoza. Overall I enjoyed my meal! The lunch combo portion was big enough for me. I also liked the miso base with my ramen (originally it was Tonkatsu but I asked to get the miso instead). 
Service here was fast and friendly.
Also there were plenty of flat screens around to keep entertained! 
Prices are cheap and lots of different dishes to choose from. They also have stir fried noodles and rice dishes. Looking forward to coming back soon!
author: Miss H K.

description:
The Okonomiyaki was terrific - just the right amount of seasoning and perfectly crispy on the bottom.

I thoroughly enjoyed the mushroom broth in their Kinoko Mushroom ramen and we shared perfectly grilled Robatayaki chicken wings and a mango salad with fresh crab.

I wondered if the waitresses/kitchen would be able to handle the order efficiently because the restaurant was so crowded, but I was pleasantly surprised. The arrived quickly and was delicious.

The restaurant has a warm Japanese ambiance to it. It was a tad noisy, but there were also four boisterous little boys sitting next to us. So, maybe it would've been okay if they weren't trying to wrestle at the table. 

I would give them 5 stars but for the fact that we were seated at a table literally 5 inches on both sides from the tables on either side (and the boys who almost landed in our soup twice were beginning to get on my nerves).
author: Sharon K.

description:
Love Genki for the crepes so decided to head over the Genki Ramen to see if we would get that same lovin' feeling and..we did!

Nestled on Geary Street, once you walk into Genki Ramen, you feel like you are in a different neighborhood. It has a modern Asian fusion vibe to it with dark wood furniture and "genki" stamped wooden chairs. There's a sake bar to the right and plenty of table seating all around.  Outfitted on the wall are some flat screen tv's showing sports and channels like Current TV (saw a funny cartoon about relationships on there while we were eating but I digress).

They brought us hot green tea as we were seated and service was prompt and informative (she actually told us what was good as opposed to the "everything is good" answer we always get). 

We ordered the house special meat with noodles and the seafood okonomiyaki (one of the waitress' favorite).  Both dishes came out relatively quickly.  The noodle dish was ramen with chunks of beef brisket sauce in a savory sauce with peppers and onions.  The pancake was sizzling and had the perfect amounts of crunchiness and softness.  Mike also ordered the watermelon drink which he thought was refreshing.

We paid under $28 including tip for dinner for two and the place takes credit card! We can't wait to try the happy hour offered from 3-7 everyday. We are going to try everything on the happy hour menu!  Also, this is a good late night joint as people were coming in after 10pm to have dinner on a Sunday night.
author: Betty C.

description:
Came in twice in one week! The service seems to be a hit-or-miss kind of thing, but the food is great.

So basically I eat A LOT and I've covered quite a bit of the menu from my two visits. I would definitely say that their okonomiyaki is one of the best things on the menu. Cooked perfectly, served on a sizzling platter, not too much sauce, etc. I tried the spicy sausage flavour of the okonomiyaki, and it brings a little twist to the traditional okonomiyaki cuz it has that pizza sort of taste.

I really love the February special right now. A choice of a free chicken karaage or nasu gomaae for appetizer. For a free dish, it's pretty huge.

What I really liked about this place is the full bar and that they offer free delivery. I also enjoyed the lounge-y sort of feel of the place and that they're tuned into ESPN on their many large flat panel screens.

If the place is busy, it's going to be hard to find seats for groups of four or more so plan ahead and make a reservation. Luckily, I never come out to the city with that many people.

Back to the food, the fried stuff is good - Takoyaki, Okonomiyaki, Katsu, Chicken Karaage, etc. They're very crispy and flavourful on the inside. The ramen, however, is just mediocre. There really is not anything special about their ramen because there are definitely better places in the area that serve ramen. The Hiyashi is just alright too; I wish they had the hot mustard for it. What I found amazing was that they had Creme Brulee on the menu, so I had to order it - can never go wrong with Creme Brulee.

This place is great if you just wanna run to somewhere to eat some quick Japanese. Yes, quick - the wait time is pretty good. Also, there's a lot of stuff on the menu, so you won't be bored for sure.
author: Jenn D.

description:
My coworkers and I have a limited amount of time for lunch.  When I call ahead with our order I expect the food to be ready, or almost ready when we arrive 10 mins later.  After being seated we noticed that they didn't bother starting on our food and had to wait another 10-15 mins for our dishes to come out ONE AT A TIME.  This was very frustrating but forgivable if they were busy.  But they weren't; there was only two other people there.  Minus 1 star!  Ok, enough ranting.  

There were four of us and we each ordered our own dish.  I got the Kinoko Mushroom Teriyaki (7.75), and oddly it didn't come with rice.  The mushrooms were good but I wasn't satisfied.  The Noodle with Curry veggie (7.95), was a much better lunch choice with yummy fried tofu.  The Kinoko Mushroom ramen (7.95), is a favorite and we'll be coming back for this again.  And last, the Black Peppered Beef yakisoba (7.95), was very filling and flavorful.  

We will come back, despite the poor customer service skills that I won't bother mentioning now.  And again I will call ahead as we're walking over just to see if they will or won't listen to my requests.
author: Rosalind S.

description: We ordered and rib ramen with fried rice and curry ramen with chicken karaage, I think the place is clean with decent customer service, but the food is okay, nothing special, too much msg not enough authentic Japanese ramen ingredient. I am trying to find a good ramen place around Bay Area to substitute my ramen craving for Foo Foo Teng in LA, still in search for it.
author: Jac L.

description:
Slowly but surely getting through the ramen joints in the city.  I came here for the garlic tender rib ramen which seemed to come the most recommended from Yelp.  There were actually a good amount of ramen choices here and the fact that it's open late appealed to me.  Overall, I'd say it's special enough to be worth noting (but not special enough to recommend to others that are looking for Santouka/Daikokuya/Orenchi-esque ramen).

The broth was decently thick and not too salty, but there was nothing too special about it.  The noodles were pretty standard and the rib, while tender, didn't pack as much flavor as the special meat from many of the others ramen places i've been (doesn't come near Saiwaii which is pretty standard to me).  It hit the spot after a long day at work and offers a lot of appetizers and other food, but it probably isn't enough for me to warrant the drive back anytime soon.
author: Jeff N.

description:
My beloved Nizario's was not open for lunch, so I wandered in here instead.

The ramen was okay, a smaller bowl of noodles than I'm used to, but their ramens all seem to come with stuff, which helps fill you up.  I got the one with the fried chicken.  The chicken was pretty good, but there wasn't any sauce, and I don't think it was seasoned well enough to be awesome on its own.  

I was really there for the tonkotsu soup though.  Unfortunately, the soup here at Genki is only okay.  (Keep in mind, I've found my holy grail of ramen, (http://www.yelp.com/biz/la-men-buena-park-2), but, well, that's in Orange County, and I'm alllll the way here in SF.)  The ramen noodles are actually really good though if you like your noodles chewy. Nom.

Overall, I'd say it was worth a try, but the Richmond has just too many places to eat for me to justify coming back any time soon.
author: Lady V.

description: Sometimes I come here when I'm craving ramen noodles and don't want to eat packaged instant noodles from the store. My boyfriend and I were seated by a waitress who acknowledged us within a minute and were given menus at the table. She took our order when we were ready and I got the mango salad, curry ramen and he got some kind of steak. The last time I got the one with a lot of cabbage and vegetables which was really good. The curry ramen was fine. I think it would have liked it more if it had a more creamy and thick soup base instead of a more watery one. The steak was a little burnt tasting but was fine. The mango salad was some pieces of mango and crab mayo on top. It was pretty good. The food here is decent with average prices. Don't expect too much because it is just ramen noodles.
author: Carmen L.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of Genki Ramen. It's ALL RIGHT and they give a good portion of meat with the ramen.  But if you want bomb ass ramen, go to Japantown. 

I think it's the broth that doesn't do it for me. Ramen is ALL about the broth, and Genki's is just too oily. The happy hour specials look cool, but I never make it there before 6pm so I always miss it.

The dish that I do enjoy is the cold chashu ramen. But since having it there, I realized that I can make this dish myself with ramen, rice wine vinegar, cucumbers, and nori.
author: Gina R.

description: Average ramen place, not bad but not the best i've been to. The Chashu ramen had a little too much msg and the tayokaki wasn't that good. Would come back but definitely not my first choice for ramen. I would suggest places in San Mateo like Ramen Dojo or Santa Ramen if you are craving it.
author: Casey N.

description:
I'm obsessed. It's so good, cheap, and comforting, especially on a rainy night. I've never had to wait more than 10 minutes, even when busy. The staff's english isn't great and I'd say they are a bit brisk but my order is always right and service is fast. Nice atmosphere but who cares when the ramen's sooo good.
I'd recommend the tempura , the karage, tofumaki, and butter and corn ramens. 
As with all inner richmond places, street parking can be busy.
author: Allison L.

description: This place is okay.Happy hour menu only $3/item. I love the Mabo tofu, it tastes delicious! But I made a mistake of ordering the ramen, I don't like the meat in my ramen.
author: Andy Z.

description:
The ramen here was very good. I got the chicken karaage ramen (fried chicken nuggets) and it was pretty fantastic. The noodles were a nice texture and pretty eggy-tasting. The standard chashu ramen was also solid. We also had the pork gyoza which was very interesting. It was like a pork nugget wrapped in the gyoza wrapper, but was open kind of like a stubby taquito. Anyway, they were pretty good.

The atmosphere here is kinda funny- it's really dark and is designed like a night club. There is a decent amount of seating, but they seem to be pretty understaffed. The service was really really slow. Luckily they have 4 or 5 tv's with sports on, so it's not as bad waiting for the wait staff to crawl their way over to you. If it weren't for the service, I'd probably give this place 4 stars.
author: Tyler C.

description:
My running buddies are die-hard fans of this place. Maybe I haven't seen the light because I think this place is just ok. Good atmosphere and very large portions, but the vegetarian items I have had are only ok.

I'll certainly return and hope my lack-luster feeling towards this place turns into a die-hard fan like my running groups.
author: Jana C.

description:
Friends and I woke up from good drunken night and we were just craving ramen the next morning. I would have wanted to go to Katana-Ya because it's yet another place that's on my bucket list but I figured the line was going to be long and I just wanted to eat right away. There was another place I heard of and it was this place, just down the street from where my friend lived.

I got really excited because I saw that they had spicy mabo tofu ramen, something they don't have at Tadamasa near my place, and it's my absolute favorite ramen ever. I ordered it with a side of chicken karage and it was pleasantly surprised! The broth was full of flavor and it was actually thicker than usual, which I liked. However, as I was finishing the ramen I started to realize that it was a little sweeter than I'm used to. Towards the end of my soup, I was craving more of a salty flavor with more of a punch with the spice. But regardless, I still enjoyed the ramen and the chicken karage was quite tasty as well. 

Still nothing that trumps my all-time favorite ramen place, Foo Foo Tei, in the LA area but I still need to try Katana-Ya.
author: Brent C.

description:
On a cold, gloomy day this is the perfect place  for the comfort of warmth and hot delicious food. I ordered the Chicken Karaage Ramen which was consisted of succulent ramen, seaweed, and corn in rich flavorful broth with a side of crispy fried chicken. It was devoured in a matter of seconds. Don't let the small portions deceive you..I was full until the next morning.The happy hour is a steal too. 

Way better than Katana-Ya in every way- better ramen, location, and size of restaurant.
author: Denise W.

description:
My brother drags me to this place whenever I visit him because it only takes us 5 minutes to walk here and maybe that's why I want to visit him so often. Eventually I started ditching him and just started dragging friends here. This place is deeeelicious! Whenever it's cold out or I feel a hangover coming on, I salivate and think of Genki Ramen. 

I wish I would be adventurous and try other different kinds of ramen, but I'm so dead set on their Curry Chicken Katsu. Never too salty, the ramen isn't too soggy or hard, and the chicken stays crunchy even after being rested on top. I've never once finished a full portion of this ramen, but I always try and kick it up a notch by ordering a side with it like the gyoza or chicken karaage (both of which are always crispy and awesome), which is probably why... DAMN MY GLUTTONY! They're also very flexible with additions and substitutions (extra noodles, etc.) which is always a plus!

The service is fast so you're in and out in a pinch and the wait staff has impeccable water refilling timing so you rarely have to try and flag someone down. The bathroom is also nice and clean, but allows only one person at a time. Keep this in mind, because I swear I am always having to awkwardly yell to people outside knocking, "Umm.. occupied?"
author: Vinh N.

description: This place was A-OK for me ... Service was quick and cute ... The setting is ok ... But the Ramen I feel like I had better (had pork belly one) ... Great place to get a bite to eat but nothing out of this world but yummy none the less .. Worth a try ...
author: Anthony S.

description:
Acceptable ramen place.

At least it's open late. We were in a pinch to find some post-bar food in the Inner Richmond. And it was cold, as usual. The place was empty save for a couple of tables in use. I was too tired to find somewhere else.

The chashu ramen was adequate, but I think Katana Ya does it so much better. In fact, I just went Saturday again.

I probably won't be back.
author: Randy M.

description:
WTF! How you can you trust a ramen place that doesn't know the difference between tonkatsu (deep fried breaded pork) and tonkotsu (pork bone soup). They are serving tonkotsu ramen (pork bone soup) but their menu says tonkatsu base everywhere.

Sorry but that alone means DO NOT GO HERE!

Yea, I tried it since I was there, blech
author: Gregg T.

description:
I had been recommended this by a friend with good taste in delivery spots.

I was completely disappointed in this place in almost every way.   The lady on the phone was extremely rude and could not care less about her job.   She kept trying to convince me to just come pick it up instead of having it delivered but that kind of defeats the purpose.  Very strange. 

When I ordered what I wanted, the total wasn't $20 so I had to buy more than I needed.  When I got to 19.64, I asked her "Is that close enough?"  (Thinking that there is no way that they would refuse to deliver because of 36 cents.    But I was wrong.   She, very forcefully stated, "You must order MORE than $20."   I was shocked.  

When the food came it was all completely cold.  The $7 baked scallops that I was forced to buy to get over the limit was actually just ONE scallop, sliced into thin pieces.   

The portions were SOOOOO SMALL, filling a quarter of the take-out boxes they came in.  LAUGHABLE...

My $21 dollar bowl of Ramen was fairly tasty but if I saw a $21 dish on a menu I would expect a whole lot more.

I would have called them back to complain but I am 100% sure that the lady on the phone would not care at all.   This is the worst place I have ever ordered from.  AVOID!!!!!!!!

I agree with Rose t.   YOU SUCK GENKI RAMEN!!!!!!!!
author: William G.

description:
Got the Chashu ramen, which alright. I really enjoyed the soup base, but there was a bit too much meat, and everything else just didn't taste that good with it. As in, the noodles were alright, the bamboo shoots were nothing special, and the side dish of fried chicken was tiny (imagine 3 pieces of popcorn chicken). 

4 stars for the soup. -1 for everything else. And that's it. If you dont care for the soup, I suggest skipping this place.
author: Jessica H.

description: My husband and I tried this place twice.  The first time we went we were not familiar with ramen as much.  I don't remember what we order the first time around.  Once we got familiar with ramen, we tried the Curry Tonkatsu Ramen. LOVED the dish. It's not a place I would go to all the time, but the flavors of the ramen is good.  I still have to experiment more with ramen.  Atmosphere is great and the staffs are polite.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Disclaimer: I've never been to the actual place, I get the delivery.

When I move, I think I'm going to miss the bars and Genki the most. There is nothing like having your senses altered a bit and craving some ramen. I must admit, I don't venture out in terms of trying new things, but with how good the chicken karaage is, I don't think I need much else!

Sorry I can't comment on the actual place (seating, atmosphere, and whatnot), but I like being lazy and having awesome ramen delivered to me.
author: Frank M.

description:
3.5? Really, guys?

I'm actually a big fan of Genki Ramen. I come here for one thing and that's enough for me: the mapo tofu ramen. Mapo tofu...and ramen...I love both...and the combination of the two makes me salivate uncontrollably (kidding).

But I definitely enjoy this place. It's clean and there's hardly ever a line (from what I could tell), they open late, they have TVs everywhere, and the service is alright. I guess it's not the best ramen place ever but I'd say it's pretty close. The portions are pretty big too.

I'll agree with my friend Vincent K. down there that their noodles run a bit on the thick side but I kind of like that. I can't stand soggy noodles so a little "al dente" doesn't hurt for me. 

I'll be back at this place for sure. I have yet to find another place that offers mapo tofu ramen.
author: Susan J.

description: Okay, I guess I'm picky about eating Japanese food here in the U.S. since it's nothing compare to eating it in Japan. The ramen that I ate was eh...I feel like I could have just gone to Japantown to get better ramen but it was late night so I can't complain since many of the restaurants were already closed. I think the noodles were like not cooked all the way so it wasn't that great but the soup was good. Anyways, the service was alright though.
author: Monica W.

description: Genki ramen makes a pretty decent Americanized bowl of ramen. They also have a happy hour everyday (I believe it's from 3-6pm), consisting of $3-5 appetizers. I love the miso eggplant. The tonkotsu ramen is okay...nothing compared to ramen shops like Orenchi or Santouka located in the South Bay, though.
author: Alysha K.

description:
I like this place.

As far as ramen places go it was pretty good. Ordered the Stew Pork Ramen and was very pleased. The service is good. The place is upscalish.

Definitely deserves a 3-4 stars for the food alone.
author: Mike W.

description:
Tasteless, that's the word I would use to describe the Ramen in Genki Ramen.
The noodles were not bad but there was no broth in soup.  If you have had chashu ramen before, you would know that chashu ramen always have a strong pork both flavor.  

The side dishes, chicken karaage and gyoza, I thought it was microwaved!?
It didn't taste like they were just cooked.  

ummm... I've had better.
author: CATE Y.

description:
I've had better ramen, but this place wasn't bad.  The ramen wasn't very spicy, and I had add a lot of the spicy oil and red pepper to give some real kick.  The tonkatsu broth had a good taste, but was also a bit thin compared to many of the other ramen places.  The beef ribs in the soup were delicious though!  

My wife had the tempura ramen, but she didn't love her miso broth.  We also felt that they skimped on the noodles, so we had to order an extra side of noodles.  The noodles were cooked right though, and they had a good texture to them.  The chicken karaage we saw at many other tables look delicious, and we'll probably have to try them next time, as well as one of the curries probably.
author: Pilan C.

description: Worst service that i've experienced in a while. We walk in 25 minutes before 11 (closing time) and there was about 5 tables with customers, including a table with 2 people with no food on the table, advised us that we could not eat inside and we could only order to go. The food is not the best but doable. The service, even when we eat in, always seems pushy and always rushing people to order. They need to work on their customer service skills.
author: Luis L.

description: Something about this place doesn't seem legit to me, but it's always always reliable, good-tasting food that's worth the price you pay. I always get the curry beef ramen. Come before 5pm and get the lunch special --it's the same size bowl of ramen plus you can add gyoza, chicken karaage, or pork fried rice on the side for just an extra buck! And man the chicken karaage is so good and crispy everytime. Plus if you come between 3 and 6pm there's happy hour so you get $3 appetizers and drinks! Got the maccha swirl which was really good. I'd def say this place is best to go to for lunch! Can't beat that special! Plus they always have the free app when you check in on yelp!! And hi-chews with the bill!!
author: Miya Y.

description:
Since my first review, Genki has become more of a regular spot for my roommate and I.  Why?  we calculated the distance from our apartment to the nearest food to us, and Genki beats out Pho Clement by a few feet.  

I think the ramen has gotten better and I've had a chance to try most of the other dishes they offer here as well.  Considering it's easy for us to come here without making any fuss, it's definitely better than the 3 stars I originally gave it.  I've also begun to realize this place is getting a lot busier and it takes a little longer to get seated.
author: Tom Y.

description: Try the Chicken Katsu Curry ramen or rice plate. :)
author: Danika H.

description:
I like this place with a few exceptions. 

Perfect for a cold day. Ramen always hits the spot. I normally get the seafood ramen. It's filling and its good. It has fake crab, shrimp, scallop, mussel, fish cake in miso base. I normally get it with some spice (which is just a chili paste on the side of the bowl). 

I also get the garlic tenderous rib and that's pretty good. The meat is very tender and just is tasty and delicious. 

A lot of people complain about it being overly salty. I, however, am a fan of salty foods and therefore, have no issues at all with the soup. Miso is salty anyway isn't it -- add other contents that naturally contain sodium and that's probably why. 

I also get an order of short ribs, oily, tasty goodness and cheap for a nice teaser appetizer. 

Oh and for drinks, I love their maccha swirl. If you like any green tea drinks, you'll like this! mMm...

And now for the exceptions. They charge for you to make your broth spicy. How silly is that?! And their service is VERY spotty. I've come here more times than I can count... and sometimes, it's really good service and sometimes, they pretend you don't exist. 

But obviously, the food drags me back. Plus they have a bunch of TVs to distract you from noticing the spotty service.
author: Jeannie L.

description: The food here has been consistently decent for take out, but the service isn't. I ordered off of the eat24 app, & I usually pay with my card & tip cash. After I paid I realized I didn't have any cash, so I hopped back onto the app & asked them to add a tip for me, which they did, no problem. When the food arrived, the delivery ass actually *argued* with my bf about the tip. He kept repeating "tip is not included!" over & over, & when we tried to explain that it was added on later he told us no & I'm general had a crappy attitude. I immediately contacted eat24 & they confirmed that the deliverers are employed by the restaurants. I guess this guy is so FOB that he was never informed that tipping is voluntary, not obligatory. It was rude, & if I order from them ever again, I'd rather pick it up myself. Which probably won't happen.
author: Priscilla M.

description:
Genki Ramen is like a tongue ring; you don't quite understand the appeal.
