The Negi Beef ramen, which was described on the menu as "beef with lots of green onions," tasted like Mongolian beef from a Chinese restaurant, and was accompanied by a moderate amount of green onions.  I fiend for green onions, and was slightly disappointed at what their definition of "a lot" was.

The broth was basically hot soy sauce, and caused my body to immediately scream in thirst.  The noodles were chewy and uninspired.

The lone star of the meal was the $1 add-on pork fried rice.  Compared to the bowl of disappointment that was served instead of my ramen, the fried rice was a tasty deal.

The service was inconsistent.  It took a painfully lengthy amount of time for them to take our order and give us our check when we were done, but they made rounds often to refill our water cups.

I would never propose to pay Genki a visit, but I can be dragged there to give it a second chance.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Dont blink when youre looking for this place btwn 3rd n 4th ave or else you will totally miss it.  My friend and I walked up and down the street how many times before we finally spotted it.  Better sign please!

You always wonder how the food is going to be when the inside of ramen shop is so sleek and stylish.  Theyre never this nice in Japan. Beyond the flat screen tv's, interesting J pop videos, and cute chairs, the ramen was just ok.   

Actually, the gyoza wasnt bad.  However, the ramen was ok, the charsu pork was ok, and the canned bamboos were ok, until i took a bite into the halfed-egg.  WTF is this?  it tasted like its been sitting in grand marnier and sugar for how many years?  I guess my freind and I got the same egg coz hers tasted equally funky.  It was anything but GENKI!

Im not sure if I would go back to try the other ramen given this first impression.  Perhaps, Genki should just stick to crepes and ice cream.
author: Kris H.

description:
I only come to Genki Ramen for 1 thing - the curry beef ramen.

This is a great place for curry beef ramen on a cold or rainy day.

I wasn't too impresseed with their other items on the menu, and frankly felt they they were mediocre and over priced.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
I went here on a cold, rainy night in Richmond and the ramen instantly warms you up inside! It felt so good to dig into a bowl of steaming hot ramen. I ordered the chicken karaage ramen and I was amazed at the texture and flavor of the ramen and broth. The noodles tasted so fresh and it was cooked to perfection--not too soggy, not too hard. It had the most amazing flavor and the broth was just superb. It was definitely something to remember--I can't wait to come back here to eat the ramen again and try some of the other delicious looking items on the menu! Next time though, I'll probably try the other ramens. The chicken karaage is deep fried chicken nugget so the first few bites were good, but after having it soak in the broth, it just becomes a little too greasy for my taste. But oh my gosh, I'm in love with their ramen!!

I came here with a group of friends for someone's birthday and we did sake bombs. This seemed like a nice chill family-friendly place so when we did sake bombs, we got A LOT of stares in the restaurant. I feel like places like these (Japanese places that serve sake and beer) should be use to scenes like these, but I guess not??
author: Amy C.

description:
Normally I come here when it is super cold in SF (which happens a lot). I need comfort food and when I crave for some soupy dish, I think of ramen. Genki Ramen is one of those places that you know will satisfy your ramen taste buds. 

The ambiance is Asian contemporary and hip. There are a ton of TVs that decorate the place and a huge TV right above the kitchen. A small bar that serves various sake drinks is carefully situated on the right side of the restaurant. This place can be a sports bar if it wanted to! This is another reason why I like coming here is that I get to eat ramen and watch a game. Tonight was the Giants and Red Sox! Go Giants!

I always get either the chicken karaage ramen with tonkatsu base soup or the butter and corn ramen with the miso soup. Of course the karaage is the least healthy but it is my favorite. When I want lots of meat, I go for that. They give you a decent amount of chicken karaage that is served on the side to prevent it from getting soaked in the broth. Nice job. If I crave for corn, I go for butter and corn. It is fantastic with the miso base soup and the flavored boiled pork. EB usually gets the beef stew ramen. He loves it!! Although he has been noticing that they have been giving him fattier meat which I don't usually mind. However, I have to deduct a star because of the inconsistency with the meat and occasionally the broth flavor and amount. Ramen is decent and does not get soggy after a few minutes.

The bonus part of the meal is the Hi-Chew candy that is given to you when you get your check. Awesome!!!!

Service can be spotty but is usually quick.

Again, a great place to have comfort food and watch TV....almost like home.
author: Molly T.

description:
Lots of different types of ramen to choose from - we usually get the Chasiu ramen, the corn & butter, garlic tenderous rib, beef stew, chicken karage, gyoza. I think we've tried the pancake once - pretty good as well. 

This place is nice & clean, staff is friendly, the drinks are yummy as well.  They have happy hour from 3-6pm and then 10pm - close (?); however, their happy hour deal only applies to certain appetizers and drinks. And i think you save about $2 each?
author: MissJ J.

description:
This is a perfect example of how 1 person can turn this 3 star restaurant into a 1.  If you want to have one of the worst service ever, come here on Thursday afternoon and this one lady will give it to you.

This girl was absolutely terrible!!!  I had to calm myself down before writing this review.  I was so upset that I actually wanted to call the health inspector on them.

I came here with 3 of my workers for lunch today because I remembered the curry being decent.  I know the ramen sucks because I had it here last time.

I ordered Chicken Katsu curry with brown rice substitution
My other friend order the tonkatsu curry over rice
My two other friends ordered the curry katsu ramen

I know this has happened to many of us before where we get our food last when we ordered first.  There was this other table diagonally across from us that came later and got their food first.  That just irks me.

Order came out Chicken Katsu curry with white rice and 3 curry tonkatsu ramens.  

I asked our very sweet waitress that I ordered brown rice and not white rice.  My friend had the tonkatsu curry over rice and not ramen.  Since it already took 20 minutes to get our food.  My friend was already irritated and decided just to eat it.  The waitress then brings back a bowl of brown rice.  The rice was cold, like straight from the refrigerator to the table.  I told her the rice was cold.  She grabbed it back, without apologizing, and microwaved it.  By now I was upset.  We were all clearly upset yet she didn't acknowledge the fact that she made a mistake.  She rolls her eyes and walks away.

Finally, we get the check.  I usually never check but today, I did.  Guess what?!?  She charges me for a regular bowl of brown rice for 2 dollars when  on the menu it says 1 dollar for substitution.  I didn't really care for the dollar but her attitude made me want to aggravate her.   She brought out the worst in me.  I told her about it and she said "you ordered the brown rice separately with a heavy accent," (in a very demeaning tone.)  I said, NO.  I ordered Chicken Katsu Curry with brown rice but you made the mistake of not taking the order correctly for both my order and my friends. 

Terrible!!!!
author: jason g.

description:
I love the chashu ramen with spicy miso added. It's the only thing I want when I'm sick... aka right now. But waiting an hour and a half for delivery is pretty ridiculous. I work at a delivery restaurant and it's not that difficult to get an order out within an hour on a Thursday night. I know it's the world series and all, but this is a ramen spot not a pizza joint, and the giants aren't even playing so that can't be used as an excuse for the delay. Three stars because delivery is lacking and dining in makes me feel like I'm sitting in a sauna. Otherwise the food is good. The servers are uninterested and on the verge of rude, though.

Update: they forgot my spicy miso and I have to wait an hour to get it. Apparently they only have one driver who has orders in the other direction. Cold ramen is not what I wanted tonight, and I don't like plain ramen, so I guess I'll just have to wait :/

Knocked it down from 3 stars to 2 stars because the driver was rude when he came back to drop off the stuff he forgot. Not my fault, bro.
author: Melissa C.

description:
I would say that this place is a solid 3.5 stars.  They are always consistent and have yummy noodle dishes.  I like the fact that they have the fried oyster balls, and okonomiyaki here as well.

The service is always friendly but the food tends to come out at different times, making it a bit hard to wait for others in your party.  

If it's cold outside... this place soothes the soul.
author: Tiffany L.

description: not the best, but not bad...kinda busy on weekend, difficult parking
author: Long C.

description:
This ramen is prettty dammmmmmmmm goood!  

I went here the other day with my parents and uncle.  We came in just in time for happy hour! SCORE!  So, we ordered some delish $3 appetizers- Chicken Karaage, Squid, and Gyoza.  All these were definitely worth the price.  The chicken and squid were both moist and crispy and not overly oily.  The Gyoza were juicy and meaty....*mouth waters*

I ordered the Garlic Short Rib Ramen for about $10.  The portions weren't huge, but pretty good sized.  The broth was uber flavorful and the dish contained: tender short ribs, garlic, spinach, and oodles of noodles! 

The only con I have about this place is that the service was HORRIBLE!!  Geez, it's like  these waitresses couldn't speak or something!

This place is a must try. =OD
author: Kristen T.

description:
Just another night looking for something of Asian decent, so we was to inner Richmond hoping to get lucky.

Halu... Closed...

FML...

Does not want Pho...

Does not want K.BBQ

...

Genki Ramen? Ehh associated with the little convenience store? Why not...

So we park right out front and step right in.

God damnit it's loud in here, especially with bad top 40.

We take a seat and glance through the menu and find some good items here: 

^ yakitori, ramen, okonomiyaki.

Bad, Bad, BAD!

No Japanese here, all Chinese? 

Service was nonexistent. And blech...

Don't go here... Please just stay away...

Tanpopo is seriously not far away.

It makes me cry!
author: Christopher L.

description: If you are super hungry, this ramen may taste good. Okonomiyaki is served on hot plate which is good but the taste is far from satisfactory.
author: Kosaku S.

description:
Took advantage of their HH specials yesterday with a few friends and drank $3 Sapporos and izakaya style plates. I loved their chicken karaage, gyoza, fried calamari, and tried their unagi rice ball, too!  Next time, I'll come back and try their curry plates and their ramen! Service was friendly and attentive. 

Love the decor, feels like an upscale ramen noodle house with flat screens, etched wooden chairs, and a sake bar.
author: Mika D.

description: This used to be my go to place for ramen but it's been awhile since I've been here last. The happy hour menu was cut down severely and they took away my fav matcha drink :(. The portion size seems to have shrunk as well. It also looks like they no longer have the lunch special prices on the weekends. All in all a great disappointment. Good bye genki, time to find a new go to spot.
author: Shella C.

description:
Iam not a big fan of mainstream Asian food, but now I have developed taste for Japanese food. All coz of this place. I would definitely recommend this restaurant.
Good food, nice environment and good service. 
I reckon everybody should try the diverse range of Ramen bowls ... although my favorite  dish is one of the starters - Bacon covered Asparagus. Just by typing it I am thinking to go there and order it. Its that good.

All in all very recommended.
author: Anuj P.

description:
the ramen here doesn't do it for me.
Suzu in J-town, Santa in San Mateo, and Ramen Club in B-game all put out a better bowl of ramen.
but Genki has a nice setting and multiple LCD tv screens showing football games on this Sunday. 
another negative: Genki serves a weak soju mojito. the mint wasn't crushed and not enough soju in the tall glass.
good unagi fried rice (chahan) and chicken karaage
some of the yakatori items came out well, the beef and green onion had good flavor, the chicken wing was tasty.
worth another try...
author: Jeff W.

description: Basic ramen place. Service was quick and efficient. A very no frills kinda place. The food was decent and price was reasonable. I'd say it's a good place or a quick Japanese meal.
author: William N.

description:
Kim chi ramen with tonkatsu base! Yum!

I have been trying to find the best ramen in town since forever. Gotta say that so far, genki ramen is one of my top two. 

Many ramen places have very bland soup bases. I have to load it up with other condiments to get it to taste good. Genk Ramen's tonkatsu soup base is VERY flavorful. I don't have to add anything, save some chili flakes to give it a little "kick."

Oh, and the pork in the ramen was very tender, not tough and hard to bite into. 

They also deliver - i'll have to try that service sometime :o)
author: Wendy M.

description: Service is hit or miss depending if they're busy or not. My favorite dish is  #402 Chicken Karaage it's great with a side of gyoza.
author: Christopher C.

description: This place does not full me up! the ramen was ridiculously small for the price.  The soup base was just alright.  From what i can recall it was a bit salty.  although, i have to give it to them that their mango passion fruit drink is awesomeee!
author: Ann L.

description:
Like I put in all my Japanese food reviews: I used to live in Japan and have a high standard. Genki ramen is as good as it gets. If you don't like this place, then you must not like ramen!

It's super cheap (under $10); portions are huge; they have lunch specials where for $1 you get karage, fried rice, or gyoza; the theme is straight outta J-Pop with multiple flatscreens with screaming, singing teens; the decor is new and modern; the wait staff is very friendly; and service is fast. What else could you want? They also have an interesting selection of other Japanese cuisines (not your chicken teriyakis, but rather your okonomiyakis, etc.) and of course tons of desserts/drinks. This place is the real deal.

Rec: chicken karage ramen or chashu ramen. I'd rate their broths as tonkatsu, then miso, then shio (soy sauce); in that order.
author: dan s.

description:
3.5 stars.
This place isn't just about ramen. They have a pretty extensive menu.
We arrived at 5:45pm and had just 15 mins to order a couple of items off their happy hour menu.  They serve about 7 beverages, alcoholic as well as non-alcoholic beverages, 9 food items.  We got gyoza and sesame wings, both for $3 each. The gyoza came as 5 pieces (usually $4.95) which were good, but mishapened.  They were not nicely crimped.  Looked as if it was your kid's first attempt to fold and make, like rectangularish-crecents.  The sesame wings (4 pieces) were OK.  I'd try something else next time over this.
We had 2 ramen:
1. Chasu, $8.95.  Came with 5 large slices rounded, boiled, flavorless pork.  THe broth was OK, but you can do better at other places.  Also had bamboo and 1/2 marinated egg in it.  I added corn and seaweed for $1 extra for each.  Plenty full.
2. Hubby had chicken kaarage, $8.50.  The chicken came on a separate plate and it tasted like a corn starch batter, rather starchy, bland. He had extra noodles added to his ramen for $1.50 but the amt didn't look like it was that much more than the amt I had in my bowl.  He told me he would "come back here again".  
Not crowded at all for a Saturday at that time as there were only 3 other tables of diners.  
They also serve appetizers,salads, almost 20 fried items, house specialties, cold ramen, yakisoba, okonomiyaki, rice dishes and robatayaki in addition to their ramen selection.  The most expensive item on the menu was about $10.
author: Ry T.

description:
This place is garbage. last night dinner, I ordered "not so" garlic tenderous rib ramen. Broth taste like won ton soup. No miso taste, no garlic, rib not so tender because its was just bones with tiny bit of meat and egg is normal hard boiled egg.   For 10 buck, damn I was still hungry.  

not worth coming back.
author: food lover t.

description:
Mmmmm.....

Soup = Ok

Noodle = not a Japanese noodle

Egg = "half boiled egg" is misleading... When Japanese hear it, we think it's "half-boiled, egg". not "half of the boiled egg". since Ramen HAS TO HAVE half-boiled egg, it's kinda fail.

Menma (bamboo shoot) = It's a Chinese one, but since Chinese makes menma far better than Japanese, I guess it's ok like that.

Red Ginger = I ordered Tonkotsu. Tonkotsu has to come with BUTTLOAD of red ginger. NOT two shreds 

It's not a (ok kind of but oh well) rocket science to make a good (not great) Ramen... why none of the restaurants in San Francisco does it "good?"

As for Okonomiyaki

Cabbage = WTF? 70% of the okonomiyaki has to be composed with Cabbages. it's not an expensive material.. why so little of it?

Red Ginger = It should be in the dough. 

Nori on the top = it's not necessary 

Mayo = more please

Okonomiyaki sauce = more please

Bonito on the top = more please

Ao Nori on the top = more please

Pork = Okonomiyaki SHOULD BE based on thin sliced pork or beef.. that's the basic. why not in the menu?

Oil = uses too much

Carrots in the dough = not necessary 

Onion in the dough = totally not necessary 

Well, it almost tastes like okonomiyaki, but not quite. All those I bitched and commented, should be in the typical Japanese cooking recipe book and really easy to figure out... so While I have no objections that non-Japanese owns Japanese restaurant.. Please get the basics right, and at least try to provide a quality food.
author: Takahiro K.

description: When then Ramen Festival fails come here!! Super fast service, great food. Hardest working people!
author: M. W.

description:
Genki Ramen is so good!  

Here's what you should order:

Samurai Wings-spicy, sweet, sour, sticky, hot, crunchy ridiculous chicken wings

Chicken Karaage Ramen, in Miso base, add Kimchi.  Trust me, I've been here like 50 times.  That's not an exaggeration, either.

Black pepper beef yakisoba.

They also deliver until 10:30, and they always repeat your order to you before they leave the table.

I have never had anything less than awesome at Genki Ramen!
author: Alex T.

description:
WAS one of my favorite ramen places in the city, until their service went to sh*ts. I used to enjoy coming here weekly/biweekly. but having to wait for servers, menus, food, and the check even when they are slow/down time is unacceptable.

the ramen and appetizers are usually always consistently good. 

the service is usually consistently BAD....

place is usually really clean so thats a plus.

I'll return when I read their service gets better, until then I'll just go down the street to Men Oh Ramen or out of the city for BETTER ramen
author: C T.

description:
Had dinner here last night and I wanna thank our homie for recommending the spot. Since it was my first time, I opted to order some of the stuff she ordered since she's a regular. Here goes. Chicken Karaage for starters while they ordered Shrimp Tempura with some veggies and an order of spinach (which was soooo good!). While I savored the spinach, I was thinking about making this particular dish at home. I mean, I know it's just spinach but you don't understand how much I enjoyed it. The chicken was tasty and the tempura was...well, tempura. Actually, it was yummy! How can you not like deep fried thangs?!? For my main dish, I had the Beef Stew Ramen made up of tender, braised beef brisket with spinach and red ginger in a tonkatsu base. In other words...SOFA KING GOOD! It sure hit the spot coz it was quite chilly last night. I ordered (also upon the suggestion of our homie Liza) a refreshing blended watermelon drink (non-alcoholic coz it wasn't that kinda party on a Wednesday night) to wash down all the goodness.

This is another joint that I will come back to and frequent. Yup, like that! Nice ambience. Several flatscreen televisions surrounding the joint which Liza tells me, plays random Japanese game shows but not the night we were there. Good waitstaff. 2 thumbs way up!
author: Ivan F.

description:
Had a chasu ramen. Soup had no depth and lacked the consistency of having been given sufficient time and quantity of pork bones. Not expensive but a waste of calories nevertheless.  

Karaage was ok ... prefer if they don't douse it with bulldog sauce but oh well. 

Not a place I would ever go again.
author: Ian L.

description:
a very bustling place lots of to go specials and drink specials keep them crowded but the decent quality and cleanly ness keeps me coming back even though the whole place is staffed by vietnamese so it's not so much authentically japanese in feeling, but it has captured some of the japanese essence and is an all business place.  i like the ramen and meat sauce, and the garlic tenderous rib in ramen soup, and also the okonomiyashi.  they don't have any chawamushi... darn
like i said not really... that japanese...no sushi... it's like hotei on irving without the years of experience... but i still like it..  and the hours of operation make it appealing.   parkings a little tricky.
author: Adam O.

description:
Meh.

I haven't dined in, I ordered off of grubhub and am not impressed.  

I ordered chicken yakisoba and veggie tempura.  Comfort food after a long day.

The veggie tempura was mediocre.  I barely got any tempura sauce sadly :(  It was slightly burnt in a few places.

The yakisoba was not to hot.  It not only was insanely greasy but had a burnt taste.  Turns out it had a burnt taste because it was burnt.  Not super burnt, but def burnt.  I didn't eat the whole thing of course.  Too bad, it looks like this place has some good food, I guess I got the short end of the stick.  Maybe I'l try dine in sometime.
author: Jen K.

description:
3.0 Stars

Once I stepped foot into Genki Ramen I was thinking to myself, "Where am I?". It looked and sounded like a lounge/club with the dimly lit lights, TV screens, and chill beats playing over the speakers. Indeed, I might have entered a Ramen Lounge, something I expected to find in Los Angeles or New York and not in San Francisco.

The modern vibe of the restaurant reflects itself on the menu. There were non-traditional types of Ramen aside from more traditional Japanese items like Okonomiyaki, Rice Dishes, Yakisoba, and grilled Meat Skewers.

Genki Ramen has a promotion lasting until the end of the month of March where you can get a FREE order of Crispy Daimaru or Edamame with your meal. I started off with the Crispy Daimaru that comes with 3 disc-shaped fried dumplings with a sweet sauce on the side. These are filled with cheese, fish cake, and spinach. When I bit into the center, the cream cheese filling was soft and oozing out. I probably won't order this normally, but it was worth trying. 

For my main order I decided to try their Spicy Mabo Tofu Ramen, which consisted of stir fried spicy soft silken tofu and minced pork in a Tonkatsu base. I really enjoyed the flavor of the dish and it really packed a spicy punch. I wasn't particularly fond of the ramen noodles though. They just didn't have enough springiness to them and I found they were slightly overcooked. On the side, my server also provided me with a small dish of pickled vegetables. 

I commend Genki Ramen for delivering new variations on the traditional ramen. On the other hand, I just wasn't very keen on the noodles in my dish. A great thing to note about Genki is that they accept credit cards and provide Green Apple Hi-Chew with your check!
author: Jason H.

description:
i don't think that Genki has the BEST ramen, but i do like their variety.  I've dined in and dined out.  With vegetarians and without.  They pretty much have something for everyone there, AND they deliver!!!!  I had their tan tan ramen, good flavor, but really salty.  I almost liked it without the broth.  Sometimes their char siu is a little tough, but more often than not i've had it tender.  Great chicken karage and geso age.  
Genki is my go to comfort food restaurant.  And you can even catch a game on one of their many tv's to keep everyone interested.
author: Susan Z.

description: i love Genki on a cold day.  There's good things for everyone in the family.
author: diyosa c.

description:
The ramen here is a bit on the pricey side and it is okay. I've had better.

They do however have a pretty decent happy hour with a range of cheap appetizers and a few types of beers.
author: Vivian D.

description:
I enjoy coming here for ramen, but the meat portion sometimes feels a bit small.  But the broth is good and i really enjoy their ramen and different toppings.  Their lunch special includes option for fried rice or fried chicken, and I think the fried rice is good.  Ramen-wise, I tend to get the kimchi ramen the most; I've tried some others and they're good, but I like a bit of spice.
I'm still seeking a great ramen place - I haven't had time to search too many places though, so for this working parent, I'll continue to return to Genki until I have time to find something better!
author: Michael S.

description:
Ladies and gentlemen.. I think I've found a good competitor that happens to be somewhat nearby to me (work).  

I ordered the Butter and Corn Ramen (with soy bean paste, which means Miso!) with an order of Chashu Pork.  This is my typical order in most Ramen spots... so I had a particular set of expectations going into a place with the name "Ramen" in it.  

Maybe it was the fact that I was still mildly tipsy from our time at Fizzee's next door, or maybe my inhibitions simply gave them some leeway on my judgment on their ramen... who knows?  Regardless, I had a surprisingly good tasting experience.  The wait staff was patient with my drunken friends, so I definitely appreciated that.  

The dining room was a bit dark, indicating a slightly "fancier" environment.  Looking around, with their choice of lighting, fixtures, furniture and such, I'd probably have to agree.  

In the end, I think they can eek by with 4 Stars.  My second visit, and there WILL be a second visit, will determine whether or not this rating is valid and accurate.  

Stay tuned!
author: Johnson N.

description: I actually really liked their tonkatsu ramen. It was pretty good, I've had better but whatever. The seaweed salad was good, i think i liked the gyoza too. It's a little pricey in my opinion, service is mediocre. I like the vibe of the restaurant tho.
author: Bianca W.

description:
The last time I was here was two weeks ago.  It was the perfect weather for ramen, cold and rainy, and I'm sure the other people at the restaurant would agree as this was the first time I ever had to wait for a table during lunch.  The wait wasn't longer than 10 minutes so I can't complain.  There are many televisions located throughout the restaurant making the time pass by quickly, especially if your favorite sports team is playing.  The ambiance and dim lighting also make it great for a lunch date.

I ordered my usual Curry Chicken Katsu Ramen and my friend ordered the Chicken Karaage Ramen.  There is nothing better than a hot bowl of ramen to warm you up on a day like this, and that is just what it did.  The noodles were cooked to perfection, not too soggy like some other places and the broth was neither too salty nor too oily, which I love.  I recommend getting the katsu on the side so it doesn't get soggy from the broth.  

The best part about coming at lunch is that you can get the combo, which is ramen plus one side of either 2 pieces of gyoza, chicken karaage, or chahan (pork fried rice) for just a dollar more.  I opted not to get the combo this time knowing that the ramen would be more than enough for me.  Our total bill came out to less than $16, which I find decent for a ramen place.  

I would definitely recommend Genki Ramen to anyone looking for something to eat on a cold day.  I would have given the restaurant 5 stars if it weren't for the service.  The waitress seems to forget about you after you order and don't remember you until you request the check.  However, they make up for it a little with the Hi-Chew that they give you with your check and I'm a sucker for my Hi-Chews.
author: Mary Rose L.

description: Great value during happy hour. Really enjoyed the ramen, and the $3 beers can't be beat.
author: Jessica B.

description:
The food was overall very yummy! I got a tenderous rib ramen and my friend got seafood yakisoba, along with a chicken karaage appetizer. The ramen was delicious, good broth, the meat was super tender. I also got to try the yakisoba, which was flavorful as well. Crunchy chicken karaage.

Ambience was decent, too. But service was kind of slow despite there not being many people. But the servers were all very nice once they got to our table. I recommend this place !
author: K. M.

description: Their ramen is alright at best. I came here only because I was craving ramen and decided to come here. The ambiance is nice, but I personally think the noodles were too hard and the soup made me thirsty a few hours later, which makes me think there is tons of MSG in there.
author: Julie T.

description:
Ordinary. But served in nice bowls? Nah, they still give you the break apart throw away chop sticks. I should have read the other reviews on other things to try. But being a ramen lover, I needed to order the basic ramen, shrimp tempura ramen in this case, with an add of the spicy miso, which leaves you wondering why it cost extra when it isn't too spicy. At least with most pho places you get a free bottle of sriracha for the table. Oh well. It's not like this place is horrible, hence my rating, it's just not anything I'd recommend to you. The broth is okay, the ramen itself could be a bit more firm, and the appetizers were what you'd expect.

I would come back here for the happy hour special though. Deals look good and their tall beers are really tall. (dunno where I stand with that)
author: Khanh N.

description: We went to Genki the other night for dinner, a last minute decision, but in the mood for noodles, for tempura, for spice (we had a wide range of what-we-wants). Turned out to be exactly the right place! We had terrific spicy sausage noodles, okonomiyaki (light and flavorful), etc. Very nice setting, fun, simple. Highly recommend for the range of the menu and the setting. The service was good, not brilliant, but nonetheless helpful and polite.
author: George P.

description: Went here for the first time a couple days ago. Loved it! I tried some of my friend's Maccha Swirl and had to order one myself. Green milk tea blended frozen drink topped off with whipped cream. Fantastic! I ordered the Garlic Tenderous Rib and Wakame Salad. Both were outstanding. Bravo!
author: Anna J.

description: Its a nice place, but I wouldn't add it as a favorite. I've gone enough times to know that the food is a hit or miss; sometimes its amazing and other times it just doesn't fill that craving for ramen.
author: Cecilia R.

description:
Solid 3 stars. 

What I like about it is the fact that we can get delivery. Especially when it's raining and you just don't want to step out of your house. I usually get the chicken karage ramen. Portions are pretty big, I have never finished an entire bowl.
author: Janelle L.

description:
I ended up coming here again since it had been awhile... I should have continued on to some other restaurant.  I have no clue what has happened, but I knew to steer clear of the ramen (and my poor friend found out the hard way even after I told him not to order it).  The robatayaki was lackluster, the okonomiyaki has been over sauced, the takoyaki fried too long... What happened!  

I'm sorry, but I don't plan on returning anytime soon...  Genki ramen, you were close to being genki, but you stumbled and fell hard.
author: Brent A.

description:
Super cute cafe with flat screen panels playing cheesy japanese music videos (think women in school girl outfits running in a field)

started with the seaweed salad.  The mango shake was good too.  We enjoyed the curry chicken tongkatsu, resting on a bowl of ramen.  

The seafood pizza -- on a skillet -- was interesing in concept but bizzare in excecution.  Think of a korean panjun pancake but filled with whole shrimp, scallop, crab and then drizzled with mayo and bbq sauce. Too much going on at once.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
I really want to give Genki Ramen more stars but I just couldn't do it LOL. The place is nicely decored and there are TV screens everywhere so you wouldn't run out of things to watch. Big Daddy and I was busy watching the basketball game!

BUT back to the ramen! He ordered the Shrimp Tempura with Spicy Miso and I had the Mabo Tofu w/ Ground Pork and Tonkatsu base soup. The Shrimp Tempura Ramen lacked SHRIMP!!! It was actually really probably one shrimp cut in half hahhaa Come on now, if I'm gonna pay close to 10 bucks for some noodles and shimp you better give me more than one shrimp and try to make it look like two!!!

The Mabo Tofu Ramen was a different story. The flavor was amazingly delightful, spicy enough to make my tongue tingle and make me grab my tea cup. I liked that one more. Big Daddy and I shared both bowls. We would take a few bites and switch bowls! lol Can you just imagine us at the table while others are staring because we did it a few times. IDGAF we are SHARING and it was fun LOL! The noodles for both bowls were allright. Not spongy enough for me. I feel like if I need a good noodle I would have to drive all the way to LA for it... so sad! =(

Well all in all it wasn't bad nor was it super great. It was just allright. our bill came to 19.46 for two bowls of ramen, Big Daddy added an item to his for 1.50. We got free edamame, but I had to request it... Offer it when I order my meals bitch!
author: Lynna N.

description:
BF and I came in around 2:00pm on a Wednesday and were seated immediately. After receiving the menus, we expected our glasses of water to arrive shortly, but we were left disappointed. When we were ready to order, it took a while to flag down a waitress... Not that they were busy helping other people, but they were busy talking among themselves. After we placed our order, we then asked for water, since it seemed like they were not going to bring it around anytime soon.

I ordered the Unagi Don and BF ordered the Beef Stew Ramen. The soup and salad that came with the rice bowl arrived first and then the rice bowl came. The ramen came and still we have not received our glasses of water. We asked a second time and finally got them.

The portions seemed a bit small, but perhaps that was due to the fact that it was lunch and the lunch menu prices were approximately a dollar cheaper than regular.

When it came time to leave, the waitresses lagged on giving us the check as well as taking it and giving us the change.

The food itself was okay... Nothing too special. The service was disappointing. We will probably not be going back.
author: Roxane L.

description:
Usually, when I head here, I order their chasu ramen, which is good, in my opinion. I decided to get the Butter & Corn ramen instead. I should've stuck w/ my usual order or even the Chicken Karaage ramen. The butter & corn ramen was a bit on the bland side. I don't know what it was, but, the ramen didn't stand out. The pork was good, though.  On the plus side, the takoyaki and bacon wrapped asparagus were good. Their agedashi tofu was on the small size. It's been a while since I last visited, so, not too sure if they downsized the agedashi  tofu. What a shame.  Might have to skip that next time though. We did get a free side courtesy of checking in with Yelp. A choice between edamame and the wakame (seaweed) salad (my friend and I chose the wakame). It's not too far from where I live, so I don't need to worry about parking. I can just walk a few blocks. But again, being in the Inner Richmond district, parking can be a pain, especially with other establishments surrounding the area. 

I love their Happy Hour prices and choices! Cheap and good!
author: Shall P.

description: Great ramen noodles. Decent ambiance. Nice but overworked service (which meant that they were a tad bit inattentive). All in all still worth it.
author: Vanessa M.

description: Decent ramen that's not too expensive either. They have Yelp check-in specials sometimes.  . The draw here is that there's tons of seating and no wait! Take that, Katanaya/Dojo/Ippudo!
author: Calvin W.

description:
Craving some ramen, I came here for lunch with a friend to talk about life and finance. It doesn't really stand out on Geary. I actually walked pass it upon arrival. But once you get inside, it has a nice elongated layout (green chairs, white walls and a couple of TVs, with a bar).

I ordered the Curry Tonkatsu Ramen (deep fried pork chop, potato, carrot with curry sauce in tonkatsu base) with a side of gyōza (potsticks). What makes for a good ramen bowl is the broth. It was a little dilute, but thick enough to accompany the yummy noodles. Overall the broth was good, but nothing special. I enjoyed the tonkatsu, although I wish there was a little more. Customer service was very good. It's a nice place to grab some ramen.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Genki Ramen is a good place to eat, but it's not that great of a place. To me the food is just okay, nothing too special about it screams come back for more. The prices here are a little on the moderate side and I would hope to get more for what I am paying for. For the same price that I can buy a meal here I can get two things down on Clement St. Overall, this place has decent food and I won't knock it, but I will just say that the food is just average. I will have to visit again to try some other stuff.

Recommended Dish: (check photos)
- Seafood Yakisoba

Other dishes my friends ordered are in the photo section too, but I did not try them.
author: Michael J.

description: Good ramen and noodle.  But the service is too slow during lunch hour.
author: Lucy J.

description:
This would be my first time trying okonomiyaki and takoyaki and it was pretty good.  I was caught off guard by the texture of the Okonomiyaki which was very soft (almost mushy) rather than spongey and fluffy like an American pancake.

The small takoyaki balls were more crispy and tasted very similar to the okonomiyaki, but with octopus stuffing inside.  It was nice to take advantage of their happy hour deals for this too.

They also provide extra okonomiyaki sauce upon request.  Overall, I believe it was a very filling and flavorful lunch meal.
author: B F.

description:
finally got to try this place last night. 

I ordered a chashu ramen, since it's the only type of ramen i always eat. It tasted ok, nothing special about the ramen here. I still prefer my katanaya which is ok ramen also but at least better. One thing i like about their ramen is the portion is just right, it wasn't too much or too little. The amount of meat was just right and the noodles as well. also had some potstickers, (gyoza), which was an interesting one. it was wrapped in an interesting shape. there was nothing special about it tho, it was just ok.

One complaint will be on the menu, so if you read the description of the broth, it says "tonkatsu," i think they mean "tonkotsu," i never heard of tonkatsu broth in my entire life, including my life in japan. Tonkatsu means fried pork, and tonkotsu means pork bone, so tonkatsu broth does not make sense to me.

I would come back here to try out their other ramen. I wanna try their miso broth next time since the chashu ramen was ok, not bad. 

service is, o-k, but not great. My experience was not that bad. servers were attentive and nice. I really have nothing to complain about.

I'm giving this place 3 stars because of the food, it was just ok. I would probably come back here for lunch instead since i think the quality of the ramen is just ok, not worth it for dinner.
author: Toni Rose M.

description: Mediocre overall.  Decent spot for lunch, but nothing really worth returning to unless you have to grab a meal in the area.
author: Andrea L.

description:
I've been here twice, and both times I've been more than satisfied. 

The place is on Geary, which means trouble for parking. I would recommend taking the 38 MUNI bus, which goes straight onto Geary. I'm pretty sure there is a stop very close to the store. 

Coming in, the restaurant is dark and dim - something that annoys me. I can't stand eating at a restaurant with dim ambiance because it makes me want to fall asleep, and I can barely see the people across the tables. The brightest light comes from the kitchen, which is flanked by glass windows so customers can watch their bowls being made while waiting for the bathroom. 

The restaurant is split up into two ramps, with a higher ramp leading to booths for larger groups and the floor for smaller (2 people) groups. The decor is nice, but again, hard to tell because the restaurant is dark. 

There is a TV on the right side of the restaurant, which can be viewed if you are on the booth side on the higher ramp. The "booths" are parallel to the wall, meaning there are booth-like seats on the wall side, but seats on the other side of the table facing the wall. It's quite a problem because the tables of different parties are really close together, so if you are on the booth side, it will be difficult to get out to go to bathroom.

The ramen is tasty, but a little on the expensive side. The bowls are a little heavy, and the portions are not enough to fill. There is a large variety of items to add with your ramen, and the dishes are around $10. Appetizers are about half the price and bite-size to say the most. I ordered the kabobs and tongue, and wasn't too impressed with either. There was less than a handful of each, which wasn't enough to taste.
author: Vivian L.

description:
I love this place. The prices are great and the ramen is so flavorful. My go to foods are the chashu ramen (with added corn and spinach), the garlic tenderous rib or the spicy mabo tofu. Between these three you have nothing to lose. 

If you head over here for lunch, you can even grab a pork fried rice for the same as the dinner price (which still puts you under ten bucks). Super score!

They're also mighty quick, so chances are if you're in a hurry, you'll get out in thirty, as long as you're not in the dinner rush.
author: Amy N.

description: This is one of my favorite ramen places in the city! The broth and noodles are delicious. I also love it because we never have to wait in line to get seated and our food comes out quickly. The only thing I don't like is that the pork is a little fatty, but the rest of the ramen makes up for it. I always order the chasu ramen - you can't go wrong :)
author: Gaby A.

description:
I believe the food you serve should reflect some what along the name of your business. How old must you be in order to cook yourself a bowl of ramen? I've been cooking ramen since age 7 and never had it as bad as this place. It was horrible! Seriously how difficult is it to boil some ramen? 

I got the DonKatsu Ramen and came out really salty and soggy. My friend ordered a bowl of brown rice that was literally straight out of the fridge. How the hell do you mess up on these simple things? They're Asian, they eat rice, and they should know that rice is suppose to be served warm! 

Trying to get some customer service from our waitress was like getting on our knees and begging for food. Our food came out 
40 minutes after we ordered and she messed up our order. After waiting for that long to get some food on the table, we weren't going to order again to wait another 40 minutes. 

Customer Service SUCKS and the Ramen SUCKS!!!!! 

Close the business!
author: Isaac B.

description:
I feel a teeeeeny bit bad for giving this place an unfluffed rating because I did get free chicken karaage from checking in with Yelp...but ehhh...not that bad to offer a sympathy +1 star. =T

Ramen here was ...so...*whatever*.  No happy-food-dance. =(

The ramen bowls are the funky-shaped upside down cone type that try to trick the consumer into thinking they're being fed more than they are......but..umm..my voracious appetite and belly can't be tricked!!!  Portions..skimpy.  And....HEY, where are my bean sprouts?!?!!?  The single garlic rib in my soup was above average at best but insufficient to make up for the soup lacking in depth of flavor.  (Add some miso paste to your instant noodles and you have your very own homemade Genki ramen)

There are better ramen places in the city...If anything, Genki's ramen wasn't worth the search for a parking spot around and around and aaaaaround the block.  Might as well go to Katanaya for that experience.

....And since I'm on a b*tch roll....something about the seating of the place IRKS me.  I don't enjoy strangers sitting in my BUBBLE when there's plenty of space elsewhere in the restaurant... It's weird!!!
author: Tokki M.

description:
I usually get ramen here. So far my favorites are the [garlic tenderous beef ramen], [cha siu ramen] and the [beef stew ramen]. Most recently, I tried the [tan tan ramen] and boy it burned the senses out of my tongue. It was so spicy I wanted to scream HELP. Due to my stubbornness, I refused to switch ramen with my sister. Bad idea. I barely survived finishing this dish. I broke out in a day or two after eating this, so be warned how spicy this dish is!

In the past, I have also tried the [butter & corn ramen] and I wasn't a fan of that. 

Before I forget, you get a complimentary appetizer when you check in. My favorite is of course the croquette. Remember to check in!
author: Forest T.

description: Me and my boyfriend ate here and the service wasnt that good we waited for them to get our order didnt refill our water and it took them forever to give us the check. And to top it off the worker who took our order, stopped us on the corner asking where is the tip..like really who does that? You dont get tip for bad service. I really like this place the food is good but the waitresses are something else.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Too pricey of a place for decent ramen. I could probably throw in a bunch of stuff at home to make a similar bowl... so why would I pay 11 bucks for one made by Genki? 

What's odd to me is that Genki's other dishes (not ramen) are actually pretty good. The seafood pancake is probably one of the better things I've had. Personally, the ramen is always either a) undercooked or b) overcooked -- never "just right." I ordered a Spicy Tofu Ramen once, and I vividly remember the soup looked so murky and dark brown/red. It was way to salty for my taste. My friend ordered the Seafood Fried Rice, which was better than my ramen. I say if you're craving for some ramen, make the ones that come in the instant packages from the comfort of you own home.. because at least you'll be able to tell when it's fully cooked.
author: Linda T.

description:
I think Genki Ramen is good if you're looking for a solid, cheap meal in the Inner Richmond district. I came here for happy where they had $3 Sapporo, Asahi, or Yogurt Sake Cosmo. They also have a variety of $3 appetizers and I would recommend the chashu (roasted pork) and geso agi (deep fried octopus tentacles). 

I had the Chicken Katsu Curry. That was good and filling. I also tried their garlic, tenderous rib ramen. That was fine too. Again, nothing amazing but it wasn't all too bad either. It's worth a try if you're in the mood for Asian food.
author: Jane C.

description:
I had a strong craving for ramen last weekend on a cold and foggy day. I couldn't make the drive to Santa Ramen so I looked up ramen places in SF and found Genki Ramen.

The place was packed but we managed to get a table in the back. Everyone in our group ordered a different bowl of ramen. I was so excited and overwhelmed to see they had a lot of variety in their ramen, including vegetarian ramen. I ordered the garlic rib ramen with spicy miso added and some extra toppings.

This was everything I hoped it would be. Salty, rich, spicy, and hearty. It was so good, I force fed myself to finish all of it when I was full. The garlic pork rib was so amazingly tender and delicate. The noodles were the perfect consistency and the broth was delicious. Even my favorite ramen places tend to oversalt their broth on occasion, but this seemed just right. Hopefully they're consistent with their broth.

Everyone in my group enjoyed their ramen of choice, even the vegetarians. I'm so happy I found this place. Now I don't have to drive too far for ramen!
author: Michelle N.

description:
Ordered my food via Eat24. Food is fantastic and I highly recommend but...

The delivery is absolutely terrible. I ended up calling the resturant to complain it was taking so long, I had to repeat myself several times and had to change who I was talking to on the phone for them to understand, and got only the word that 'my food is on the way'. The Delivery guy shows up even later and asks about getting a tip. I informed him that he was very late and I was not at all happy about that, and he goes 'Whatever it's your call.' and walks away before I am done talking to him. I try to give him what cash I have on hand as a tip, I get the bill out and go for the coins, and he gives me attitude and refuses it before I can even get the coin pouch of my wallet open. It wasn't much yeah but that was just rude. Is it crazy to be upset when your food is late compared to what you're told to expect?! I mean I know that delivery persons work hard and practically live off their tips, but seriously giving me attitude when you're late and my food is lukewarm?!

Genki Ramen, please talk to your delivery staff. Your food is amazing and the people on the phone were patient with me despite how upset I was, but the delivery guy was just plain rude.
author: Schuyler H.

description: I'm a bit surprised to see that Genki is rated so low.  San Francisco is a city preternaturally suited to ramen almost year round and this is one of my go-to places.  I generally stick to the Spicy Mabo Ramen which is one of the best I've had anywhere.  The broth is incredibly flavorful and the overall tasty.  I think it will be difficult to knock Genki for anyone who's tried it.
author: Joe B.

description:
I should have known what I'm walking into when we were the FIRST ones to walk through the door at 7pm on a Saturday night.  There was NO BODY there.  But WTH, we sat down.  The decor was modern and cool...but the food sucks.  We both ordered the Chashu Ramen and it was small (for $9) and only had 4 slices of chashu, 5-6 bamboo shoots & 1/2 hard-boiled egg. That was it.  They had TONS AND TONS of green onions, probably to mask the fact there was nothing else there.  The soup was OK, Ramen noodles could be better.  

We also ordered the Gyozas.  Not the greatest.  Bland, bland, bland.  What a shame for such a nice looking restaurant.  Better off going to Tampopo to get some authentic Ramen.   I don't think this restaurant  will last long if it doesn't do something drastic to turn it around.
author: Jannie Q.

description:
I've had three kinds of ramen bowls here and each was over-the-top awesome. A friend was raving about Genki's crab leg ramen bowl, so I gave that a whirl on my first visit and loved it - the meal came with REAL crab, for one, and the noodles were topped with several large legs and claws. It's a messy dish (they give you a claw cracker and scissors to help) but well worth it at under $13. 

The second time around I sampled the "Garlic Tenderous Rib" ramen, which came with pork on the bone (which fell off the bone with ease), sliced roasted garlic, egg and spinach. I'm making myself hungry just typing this. On my third visit, I went against my carnivore inclinations and tried the Kinoko Mushroom ramen, which had several mushroom varieties (Shiitake, Hiratake, Bunashimeji, Eryngii) in a tonkatsu soup. Delicious! I think I may rotate these three bowls as I continue to dine at Genki Ramen.
author: Janine K.

description: I came here with a friend and got the Kinoko Mushroom Ramen (she got the Garlic Tenderous Rib.  We were first given a small dish of pickled veggies; shortly after we ordered, the food came. Though I was a bit underwhelmed by our portion sizes and the amount of mushrooms in my ramen (there were three types, but I don't think the amount of mushrooms could fill half a cup), I noticed that my friend got a good portion of meat in hers. Despite this, we could not complain about taste- the mushrooms were perfectly cooked, and the noodles al dente, her ribs spectacularly tender. Didn't eat much of the broth, but what stuck to the noodles was good, considering I don't like too much salt in my broth! I would come again to try more food.
author: Jin T.

description:
Genki is a decent ramen joint in the City, not the best by any stretch of the imagination, but good enough (especially if you live close).

Appetizers:
-Chicken Kara-age: Well done.  Fresh, crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.

-Fried Tofu: LOL same as the chicken...Crispy outside, soft on the inside and great flavor!

Meals:
-Curry Beef Ramen - One of the few places that the curry is done perfectly in relation to the broth.  Not overpowering, and not a yellow colored broth.

-Mabo Tofu Ramen - Is also pretty good here.  They do the Mabo right and add in a decent ramen?  Right on.

-Cha-Han (Japanese Fried Rice) It's quite flavorful and I must admit that I come here just for the cha-han rather than the ramen some times. (Who goes to a Ramen joint and doesn't order ramen!!!???!!!???) hehe

Overall, decent spot.  Clean, great service and I've gotten to use my Yelp coupon for a free fried-tofu appetizer!  Free99 is the best price!
author: Anthony L.

description: My go-to late night ramen spot if I'm in the city. Parking is really hard around here, it's a busy location. Food is yummy though! ..even better when you go during the HH.
author: Nicole D.

description: how can you not love this place??!!! the best ramen ever!!! if it wasn't for the bad service i'd give it 5 stars.  chicken katsu curry ramen is the bestest!
author: Kurt N.

description:
I know this is going to sound like a heap of self-loathing on my part, but the main reason for my distaste for Genki Ramen is that the food tastes Korean. The ramen didn't have that milky, fatty, umami-laden goodness you'd expect from the real deal (even at the crummiest of the Japanese-run restos you're bound to get a smidge of it) and the croquettes and katsu were undercrisped and a bit greasy. Operational touches indicated Korean nuances, like the filet used for the katsu that was on the thinner side (as Koreans used to serve it before they caught on to using chop-size cuts like the Js), which I actually prefer, but it just indicates to me that I'm having more of a fusion-y, interpretive experience. What saves this place for me is that they have decent happy hour offerings, and beers are actually quite affordable.

If I happen to be mistaken and there is, in fact, no Korean involved in the operation of this restaurant, then it is truly my mistake and for that I am sorry. But then again, if this is the case, this is a bunch of Japanese people who just don't know how to make good Japanese food. You tell me which is worse. It doesn't really make a difference for me, since I have bags of Shin Ramen-- what Korea really does well.
author: Nuri K.

description:
I'd give this place 5 stars no problem if it were not for the devastatingly awful music I have to endure every time I go there. It actually has pushed me to do pick up there a lot. Also, I really hate the tvs. I've never been to a ramen spot that has so many (if any) tvs. It's like a saki and ramen sports bar meets a trying-to-be-fancy mall restaurant. 

Despite these turn offs, the ramen is quite excellent. In fact, I'm tempted to say it's amongst my favorite (if not my favorite) in the entire city. I haven't read the other reviews for this joint, and maybe other people are put off by the decor, too, but I really don't understand why this place is rated 3 and half stars. It should be at least 4, if not 4 and half, especially in light of the fact that there are not many places in SF to find a consistently good to great bowl of ramen. I've had at least half of the ramen dishes there, and 3/4's of them have been fantastic. Here's a list of my faves: 
Spicy Mabu Ramen - hands down my favorite dish here. I get it about half the time I come. Not gonna leave your mouth on fire, but if you're spice-phobic/ a wuss, I would stay away.
Tan tan, Negi beef, and Shoga Niku are probably my next favorite dishes here. I'm not one who can describe tastes very well, but suffice it to say, these are all excellent, in my opinion. Surprisingly, their Chashu Ramen has never knocked my socks off.

I'd say their Okonomiyaki is really good, and their yakisoba is pretty good. I'll occasionally order one of those dishes to switch it up, but normally I go for the ramen. 

Their Robatayaki is pretty awesome - it's just a little pricey for what you get - however, if you have a couple extra bucks to spend, it's worth trying any one (or more) of their Robatayaki with your Ramen.

Once again, if the atmosphere were any less obnoxious it would be a hands down 5 stars in my book, but even still, it's one of my favorite Ramen spots in the city. Highly recommended.
author: Bobby R.

description: Curry tonkatsu with cha su pork.. Bomb :-)
author: Fat C.

description:
I felt like we were on an episode of Amazing Race. Friend and I went to our fav ramen place but the wait was ridiculous! We drove to the next closest one and it was closed. So we finally made our way to Genki. On the journey I was tempted to convince my friend to stop at the first burger joint but we arrived and it was amazing!

Quick, fast, and friendly service. Large flat screen TVs around the restaurant with channels ranging from CNN to ESPN. The music ranges from hip hop to top 40 hits. I loved their decor! The entire package is a bit random but I loved it! 

I had the beef stew ramen dish. So delish!! Their ramen is slightly different than other places and the waitress explained that their broth is slightly thicker. Didn't really notice the difference. Friend had the BBQ ribs & ramen. Very interesting combo and I highly recommend. We were too full to try their dessert but perhaps next time. Parking was surprisingly easy but it was on a Sunday night. I would definitely come back but only if parking is easy to find ;)
author: Adriana G.

description: It was good. Not the best ramen in town, but it satisfies your ramen cravings. Will come back again.
author: Elena O.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place since I've seen it so crowded on weekends. I finally came here this past Wednesday night after doing errands nearby. The interior is pretty nice. As usual, I ordered the miso ramen. When the order came out, I was disappointed by the portion size. Maybe it's because they used large bowls with slanted sides but only filled it up halfway, therefore making the portion seem small. The soup and noodle was good though.

On the other hand, the servers were nice and attentive when it comes to refilling the water and tea. Also they served a pretty good grilled shishamo (smelt fish) on a skewer.
author: H K.

description:
It was Monday night.  I was sick.  Quite sick.  Porridge, pho or ramen?

RAMEN!

We were seated quickly.  The restaurant looks a lot better on the inside than it does on the outside (I don't know why I always thought this place was janky.  It's rather nice and fancy feeling).  Service was great.  The waitress kept checking in to make sure we (and the food) were OK.

We ordered the nori and the garlic rib ramen.  Prices were reasonable, portions are generous.  What's not to like?

I only ate half because I was sick and my taste buds were shot to hell.  It did taste delicious the next day, though.

And the waiter let us play credit card roulette.  I won!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Genki Ramen has become a regular dinner spot for my family, but each time we visit I find more reasons to research other nearby purveyors of noodley goodness.

At first, we got hooked on Genki because their curry ramen bowls are just the sort of warm, flavorful, belly-filling comfort food we need to ward off the chill of a foggy, windy, SF night. Both the chicken and pork curry bowls really are purr-inducingly good.

The other ramen bowls? Just OK. They'd be great if the base broth was not so bland and watery. But it is, and there's no yummy curry stuff floating on top to cover for the crappy broth. Avoid.

The other Japanese delights? So far, I'm unimpressed.  The ones we've tried (I forget the names now) have been wholly unremarkable. 

Service? Well, it's consistent, anyway ... (wait for it!) ... consistently bad. Dishes always come out of the kitchen one at a time, often 5 or more minutes apart, and you may have to tackle someone if by chance you need something during your meal. (If my wife or kid needs a fork instead of chopsticks, I now get up to get it myself; it's just easier.)

But, we do go back, at least every other week, for the curry ramen. Stick to that dish and you'll have a pretty good meal.
author: Todd H.

description:
Get the unagi tempura! Had to put that in first in case you're just skimming reviews. The perfectly crunchy exterior with the warm unagi taste is a match made in heaven. It's good enough that I'll likely be special requesting it at Japanese restaurants here and there from now on.

Although they say they are basted with soy sauce, I swear the tasty little asparagus bacon robatayaki we had was covered in sweet bbq sauce.

I kind of wish I had tried more of the non-ramen dishes like the okonomiyaki but since ramen was in the name, I had to give it a go. For the record, if you have a craving for ramen, this will put the hungry monster to rest. But if you're going to rate the ramen as ramen then there's more to it. The broth was average, the noodles were subtly too hard, and the pork was pretty decent. The egg was on its way to being great but yolk didn't fully achieve that gooey texture nor did the egg white soak in enough flavor.

So like I said, the ramen is good enough to quell a craving, but I'm sure there are better ramen shops in SF so stick to the rest of the menu. Unagi tempura... mmm....
author: Allen F.

description:
I REALLY love the Macha Drink they have. The ... frappachino thing. SO GOOD! The Okonomiyaki is also great, hard to find a place that makes it good. I LOVE the ramen. This place is also great that they have bamboo shoots in the ramen ... Some places don't.



My only issue is that I wish the delivery time wouldn't be so late ... 5pm :( I always have to drive here during my lunch at work to eat. Bummer.
author: Iris L.

description:
I've never been a big fan of Genki Ramen. It's Japanese food can't compare to a lot of other similar restaurants in the city (Tanpopo, for instance, is far superior) and it is much worse than anything in Japan. I never go to Genki Ramen expecting quality food or even service. But tonight was particularly bad. 
My friends and I came in a little before 10 and ordered drinks and appetizers plus ramen. Happy hour started at 10, so we asked for the happy hour prices on our food and drinks. Our waiter nodded, so we assumed she'd understood. We got our ramen, which was so-so as expected. But when we got the bill we saw that we had been given the regular prices for our drinks and appetizers (even though we'd received our food after 10). To compensate, we decided not to tip. The waiter confronted us about it and then angrily told us "Don't come back." 
The iffy food and TERRIBLE service have convinced me not only to never come back, but also to warn all of my friends against going back to Genki Ramen. Any place that tells its customers to not come back, no matter the reason, doesn't deserve to stay in business in San Francisco.
author: Jackie S.

description: Service was really slow here.  There was only one waitress and she was not very nice and seemed annoyed at everyone.  It was not very busy either...there were only 3 other tables at lunchtime (should of been our first clue).  I ordered the Garlic Tendrous Rib Ramen and it was just gross....the pork was super dry and didn't seem to be braised.  It looked and tasted disgusting...It seemed more like it was fried..I ended up barely eating any of it.  The soup was bland.  There was only three pieces of spinach and half of a boiled egg that didnt seem fresh in the bowl.  The noodles were okay but I would definitely not come back here.  There is way better Ramen at other places.
author: c L.

description:
Hey, it may not be the most authentic ramen joint ever, but it's nice, clean, friendly, there's like a million TVs so you can catch the game in any direction you glance, and it's not overly crowded, so it's comfortable.  The price is right also, very reasonable and the cold ramen was tasty!  Would definitely come back here.

We really liked the pickled cabbage they serve as an appetizer, mmmm.
author: Ricky S.

description:
This place is amazing! I wish it wasn't so far out, but worth the drive.

I have been here three times now, and have never been disappointed. 

As a vegetarian, I am really happy that they can substitute the broth for a vegetarian one on any of the soups.

My favorite ramen is the curry veggie one. I have not tried any of the other dishes yet, but I am planning to in the near future.
author: Maciej M.

description:
Solid ramen, it won't blow your mind but it is always consistently satisfying.

Spacious, clean, and never any wait.
author: Lynn B.

description: Good but not great. Make sure you check in on Yelp to take advantage of their freebie! I had the curry tonkatsu and it was alright, I expected amazing but left underwhelmed. There also wasn't enough soup. Maybe I'll order the tan tan men next time.
author: Ricky N.

description:
Service: We were seated promptly and were given menus. Nothing special, but it was professional. Nuff said.

Presentation: My ramen came to me with a half-boiled egg in one part of my bowl, beef brisket in another corner, and spinach with sesame seed in another corner. It looked beautiful to look at.

Taste: The egg was boiled and I crumbled the yolk to make the broth more creamy. The broth was spot on. The ramen had the right texture to make it perfect for slurping. The brisket was fatty and seasoned just right.

I would definitely go to this place again for ramen.
author: Jim B.

description:
I like pork. I like real ramen noodles. I also like free wakame salad. I guess you could say I value the good things in life.

Genki Ramen is one of those very valuable good things. Definitely worth the drive over from the somewhat ramen-less Mission. For about 10 bucks, I got the Yasai ramen (a vege combo of asparagus, fried mushrooms, cabbage, edamame and something else I don't remember), with pork slices added. It wasn't the generic rubbery kind of pork you can get sometimes slapped on top of your ramen. Rather, it was seasoned and delicious the way I remember good ramen noodle soup pork to be.

I happened to get a free wakame salad because of a Yelp check-in coupon. I don't generally check-in at all, but if anyone waves free seaweed salad in my face, I'm sold.

FANTASTIC BROTH, TOO.
author: Helen I.

description:
I went here today and had to get the food to go because I felt like I was in a scene from the Fast and Furious. Maybe I just wasn't in the mood for the enviornment, but I felt overstimulated by the 10 flat screens surrounding the place with the cartoon network on, the lime green chairs and booths, and "oo baby I can make ur bed rock" blastn... 
 
I had the veggie ramen (to go) and the gyoza. It was decent for the price. Mmm. Not my kinda place to go to, but if you're lookn for a hipster kinda place to get some ramen... This might be for you. 

Tons of ramen and noodles to choose from. Not too convinced I'll be coming back to try it all BUT the food is not horrible...

Oo! The service was awesome and they give hi chews with the bill. Best part... Just saynnn.
author: Mary June H.

description: The ramen place is pretty good. First time I came here I checked in on yelp and they give us a free sesame chicken wings which tasted awesome! The ramen that I ordered was good; it has a lot of stuff inside. The soup was really good that I wanted to drink the whole bowl. Haha. I would come back and try their ramen with chashu in it.
author: Nhung C.

description: Hard to find parking in the area, but the atmosphere inside is pretty modern. Chasu ramen wasn't extraordinary as I hoped they would be. Noodles were really good tho. Takoyaki chicken gizzards were super dry. Sesame chicken wings were ok (but I've been spoiled by San Tung). Overly-hyped in my opinion
author: Kitty K.

description:
Since it was pretty chilly on Friday, I decided I wanted to gt something soupy. Ramen it was! I've passed by this place a million times, but never had it before so i decided to be adventurous and try it. Once you get in here you can tell its very modern. Lots of flat screen TVs around showing sports games. There is a full bar, and a 7 days a week happy hour from 3-7 ($3 dollar appetizers and beer!). 

Lots to choose from, but no sushi! Well it is a Ramen place right? We started off with an appetizer - Takoyaki ($4.75) - which were octopus balls fried in this batter. Pretty tasty....but anything deep fried is always tasty. We ordered the Chashu Ramen ($8.95) and the Beef Stew Ramen ($8.50), both are in 'tonkatsu' base. I asked the waitress what that meant, and she said pork based! I did notice some of the other Ramen were in a miso soup base. YUM, the Ramen was delicious, cooked perfectly..and the soup was so tasty! i drank all of the soup!! 

Lots of other things on the menu too. Too many choices, not enough tummy space. I will def. have to come back here to try more things. Looks like Ramen was the most popular dish here tho. Parking can be tough..just street parking.
author: Betty S.

description:
+1 for providing a coupon on their site every month
+1 for happy hour
+1 for attentive service

I ordered the tonkatsu and it was decent but the outer skin may have been crunchier. Decent but I've had better. It began tasting better after the second beer so no complaints there. $3 beers and $3 appetizers.
author: Ced C.

description: Took my mom out for dinner.  She was craving some noodle and soup.  It was not a busy night - got seated with in minutes of arriving. Took 30-40 minutes to get our two bowls of ramen.  We were debating to leave and find another place.  We were starving and decided to stick around.  Mom ordered the ramen with mushrooms.  The bowl of noodles wasn't very big. She said it wasn't spectacular.  My chicken karaage ramen wasn't anything special either.  Have had better chicken karaage and ramen. Won't be back.
author: Lisa C.

description:
My boyfriend and I are on a search for the best ramen in San Fran.  We did not get it here at Genki Ramen.

The ambiance was fine.  There was a bunch of dust on all of the lights that hung above the tables- which has always been a pet peeve of mine.  It can so easily fall into the food.  They were also playing the hits of today.  We must have heard 3 Lady Gaga songs- and we weren't in there that long.

We ordered:
Chicken Karaage Ramen
Kinoko Mushroom Ramen
Veggie Gyoza
Green Tea

The veggie gyoza was really greasy and soggy.  The dipping sauce (which usually makes everything better for me) was odd as well.

Both of the ramen dishes were just lacking flavor.  Even with the red salt they offer at the table- it just lacked.  It felt more like noodles in plane water with a few veggies floating in it.  

We were both really disappointed and will not be returning.  We found that the Ramen at the Farmers Market is much better then this.
author: Sherri B.

description:
you know...if i had never eaten at santouka in san jose...maybe i would've given this place a higher rating.  santouka set the bar...and no other place seems to be able to beat it.  

i have to say though, that genki is probably one of the better, if not the best place for ramen in sf...wifey and i weren't super hungry at the time so we decided to share a combo with chashu ramen and fried rice...the ramen was definitely on the saltier side...but the noodles were cooked perfectly.  and the fried rice? well, it was just plain fried rice...nothing special...only used as a filler.  

i do love the set up of the place with the televisions playing japanese cooking shows...i'm a sucker for those...haha.  the dishes were cute...and the service was just so so...not much expected from this sort of place.  

so all in all, i wasn't thrilled about the food here...but i'm giving them the benefit of the doubt by saying...if you want some decent ramen in the city, then this is the place for you...or head over to their crepe place on clement afterwards...they're pretty a-ok also.
author: Jen W.

description:
There is one thing I get here and one thing only:

THE CHICKEN KARAAGE RAMEN!!!!!!

In my honest opinion, this place is better than Katana-Ya in downtown, which I've frequented a few times before. The fried chicken comes in a separate plate, so you have the option of eating it by itself or dipping it in the delicious, creamy tonkatsu soup. The noodles are firm, just the way I like it and the broth (so flavorful, I had to resist from drinking the entire thing) was swimming in corn and green onions. 

I suppose the other menu options are just as good, but I'm only sticking with the chicken karaage, but honestly, I love it THAT much! My favorite comfort food during the winter... or actually, any time, really. The only drawback is a bit of a salt/MSG kick at the end, but then again, small price to pay for deliciousness. The appetizers are pretty good too. Do come in for the happy hour specials, as appetizers are $3 each!
author: Sabrina C.

description: Very good, consistent and love their BBQ yakitori, and watermelon shakes!
author: Diana S.

description:
I yelped the crap out of ramen places in order to find the perfect post sickness food.  Genki Ramen, you did not let me down.  Your grease laden noodles were the perfect thing for my sore tummy.  Other yelpers reviews led me to believe this was the most well rounded unscary place.  Thanks yelp!

The menu is great, lots to choose from and I understood all of it. I am not asian, so I was never aware of the vast array of things you can order in or on or with Ramen.  Its amazing.  And you can watch football while doing it.

Love it.  Next time I should definitely walk home to walk it off....
author: jessica b.

description: Not outstandingly good and not outstandingly bad, I don't really know I have only been here once and a while back, when my food thinking wasn't as refined, displaced is okay I guess
author: Rachel N.

description: Sign in the window says "Happy hour 10pm until closing, 7 days." But at 10.20pm they tell me "sorry take out only" and keep repeating it when I ask about the sign in the window. Probably the owner is not there to see their lazy and rude staff more interested in closing up and leaving than in feeding customers during posted opening hours.
author: Ritch G.

description:
Ramen may be what's in the name of the place, but you'll be limiting yourself if you stick to the Ramen.

If you care about ramen, I'd say that it's on average of ramen shops. The noodles could have had a bit more texture, the broth is decent, the chashu is a bit bland. It's passable, and it probably suffices for lunch, or if you happen to be nearby and really want Ramen. I think in Japan town, there are some better Ramen choices, but Genki is fine.

But, like I said, try going beyond the Ramen, and explore. The appetizers and grilled items were tasty, especially the ribs. Order a serving per person. They are great.

Things to get:
* Kim Chi Ramen if you like something with a bit more kick than the Chashu
* anything with curry
* a smattering of things off of Robatayaki

Service was friendly and helpful, albeit a bit slow for a place that is only half empty for dinner.

Decore for dinner is dimmed, and is a good place for a quiet conversation.

Parking can be a bit of a challenge in the area. And while there is a standard beer and sake selection, if you want to go for after dinner drinks (and before dinner too, why not!?) a few doors down each way, there's the Richmond pubs.
author: Boris C.

description:
I crave (and I mean, like a pregnant woman craves) the Chicken Katsu ramen here. We just moved to North Bay and I am so heartbroken that I have not found a ramen place as yummy as Genki.

The curry broth, the fried chicken... ugh, it makes me almost cry. I have drunkenly demanded that my husband drive me here whenever we're in the city so I can get a pick up order of the goodness (don't worry, he's the DD!). Which by the way, they package it up all nicely so the chicken is separate form the broth-- making for a perfect bowl in the comfort of your living room.
author: maranda w.

description: Great prices for the amount of food you get.  You will not leave here hungry.  This is my go to spot when I don't want to wait in line they always have tables available.  Everything I have tried here has been delicious.  The atmosphere is fun and always love to bring my friends.  Everyone I bring ends up loving it.   Can't think of anything bad to say about this place.
author: Merrell D.

description:
I ate here many many times before. The food can be a bit more consistent. However, few weeks ago, I was really disappointed with the service and the food quality.

I came around a day before the president election time. There were 2 lady servers at that time, and 2 lady cook as well. All the TVs channel was airing the debate. I ate alone and would like something else to watch. Even sports is fine.  I requested the server, she gave a me a bit of attitude and changed it. I was like whatever, I'm here for the food. But, how disappointing I was when I got my food. I can taste the broth was very watery and the noodle doesn't have any flavor at all. I informed the other server. Her reaction was, walked away and talk to the cook. She didn't even say "Sorry," or "Let me check/ask something to someone and I'll be with you shortly." No... this is plain rude, walk off, don't care. She then returned to me and said, "There's nothing wrong with your noodle."  Owwkay... I was giving you a constructive feedback, but if you can't take it, that's fine. I'll go eat somewhere else then. And I did. I haven't returned to this place since that time.
