Even tho it start raining and windy as hell and I'm craving for some ramen. Heck! I'll bring my money to somewhere else that appreciate my business.
author: Icey M.

description: Been meaning to go here since they opened. Was hella craving ramen and i just had to have some with a friend. I had the garlic tenderous ribs and my friend had the chasu ramen, and lets just say, we slurped that ramen up and by the time we were done, the bowl was empty, food, broth and all. I saw they deliver too! must utilize this next time.
author: Tiberius T.

description:
Ok so there are plenty of times that I get really indicisive about what to have for b/l/d and it took hours of time consuming management to know what to find and where to go. 

I was starting to ache for takoyaki and okonomiyaki so I was checking out the yelp listings and here I am...


What to expect / what did I get:

- Takoyaki
- Okonomiyaki (seafood + ramen) ramen was $1 extra
- Bottle of kirin
- Garlic Tendorous Pork spareribs ramen (to go)

At first when I decided to go on this mission to find this place it would have been easy but due to my indecisiveness of looking for something for dinner for about 4-5 hours at the most made me a bit dizzy. I finally found it because I was on the opposite side of the street and was looking for it. The store sign was hiding behind a street post or something. My vision isn't best at night but it wasn't all too bright either. Hrm, when I came in it was a bunch of kids on a weekday so it seems like a hangout of all sorts. there's like flat screen TV's mounted on the walls.. probably about 8-10 of them so wherever you turned you would be watching the same thing on every screen. I'm surprised that they didn't have one that was on the ceiling. D:

First waitress sat me at a table closest to the podium. She didn't seem to happy that night but the other waitress that did help me that night was really friendly and she had the decency to smile. I took a little time before ordering to see what was good on the menu. I was... but didn't.. go for the kaki fry... I thought it would have been over my budget but then again I can go to basa at any time for that instead of having it as just an appetizer. Anyways, so I ordered a takoyaki and it it came back to me piping hot... was pretty good and I think I was really happy to get it cause I burnt my tongue eating it D:  next on the list was my okonomiyaki.
Now, there are two types that I seen before I went to find this somewhat of a beer snack, There's Kansai (which is literally everything mixed up including the batter)
and then there's Osaka (traditional, which they start off with the batter first and start placeing everything in order... including yakisoba) but Osaka style was the one that I was gearing my stomach towards. Unfortunately, this was more of a Kansai style but they instead had ramen. I swear... I don't think that I got the ramen placed with my Okonomiyaki... I felt a bit cheated but I shrugged it off. Next in line was a Kirin and oh man... when you do have that rich taste of okonomiyaki and the kewpie mayo... you definetely need to balance it out with the beer. After having takoyaki and okonomiyaki I was just about stuffed. I didn't have any room for dessert or anything so I passed. I do have to compliment the second waitress on smiling and being alot happier than the other waitress who seated me though. 

Lastly, I ordered something to go and I asked the waitress for a suggestion. She immediately pointed out the garlic tenderous spareib that was on the menu... (I was thinking to myself that it was a bit pricey, cause I asked her in between that and another ramen selection) she didn't really give me another option but I got it anyways. However, this time only from the time that I did go to Ebisu to take home sukiyaki it wasn't as disastrous or near disastrous as having the coated paper bowl leak through. They had plastic containers at Genki, thank God...

Final comments:

Atmosphere is almost like a bar... generally the college type crowd that would hang over here. I'm surprised that they don't have a kareoke showdown here... or something like a 'free ramen' contest on a special day/night. I think that would totally be better. Then of course everybody would be "Genki". Most of the waitresses are attentive and will get to you but make sure that they smile because that sets your mood. After all its supposed to be Genki after all...

I don't mind coming here again but I would recommend it to any or all people that are sports fanatics or like to dine by yourself or come in late night with a few friends to hang out.


Thats it for now guys!!! And good hunting to you all :D
author: Xeirhen V.

description: If you like pseudo-Japanese food with a Chinese kick to it, then this place is for you!  I'm sure they drown their dishes with MSG and evidently PLENTY of cooking oil.  Although I have a palate for Japanese food and I generally dislike pseudo-Japanese food, this place is OKAY and I keep coming back here for more...not because it's good nor is it cheap, but it's convenient and I think they have some sort of addicting additive in their food.
author: J H.

description:
I was really feeling the Santa Ramen fatty pork but decided that I didn't want to make the drive all the way out to Burlingame so I came to Genki's.  

Genki Ramen is simply and nicely decorated with dark wooden furniture that give it a slight modern feel.  We were seated after waiting about 5-10minutes.  They have a good selection of food, ranging from rice dishes, curry, fried noodles, cold noodles, noodle soup, deep fried dishes, and much more.  We decided on getting the pumpkin and squash tempura (because that's all that I eat anyway in the vegetable tempura), the garlic pork ribs ramen, and chicken katsu curry.  

The noodle broth had a really good flavor, and the pork ribs were similar to the fatty pork at Santa Ramen, however, they only give you 3 pieces with really nothing else... It would have been nice to have at least one more piece of meat or vegetables in it.  The noodles were really good though, nice and chewy.  As for the curry, it was good, but I prefer  Muracci's curry much more.  There was definitely way more rice than actual curry or chicken.  More curry please! Lastly, the tempura came with a lot of pumpkin and squash!  It was pretty good, except that they only give you a TINY dipping bowl with hardly ANY tempura sauce... We had to ask for another one and that still wasn't enough.

Overall, food was good, service was okay... It satisfied my noodle craving, but I am not sure if I would always make this my noodle stop... it would depend on my driving mood/traffic/ and type of noodles i'm craving.
author: Diane L.

description: Chasu soup was tasteless, eggs were overcooked (hard boiled), and the tan tan ramen was way too salty.
author: Radclyffe C.

description:
Agreeing here with Nobu-san again. Not Japanese, not bad. I also think this place is run by Koreans. At the risk of being un-PC, Koreans understand Japanese food better than Chinese--yes, I know, generalizations can get one into trouble. But still, not overly greasy, flavors are balanced, except that I can be sensitive to spice, and I was reaching for the rice bowl when I least expected to.

I thought the ramen broth was weird, but edible. I preferred the yakisoba.

The menu is huge and varied, and I obviously did not sample everything. The sake menu is also impressive. If I were in my 20s, I'd come back for happy hour for various appetizers and a sampling of sake. Maybe I would still come back....I couldn't suggest this place to someone asking for 'good Japanese' though.

Service is friendly and prompt.
author: 和子

description: I've been here a few times and I like this ramen house the most at the moment.  I ordered a spicy mabo tofu ramen w/extra corn.  My friend and I went during lunch, so we ordered off the lunch menu.  She got butter with corn and gyoza.  I got a seafood fried rice in addition to my spicy mabo tofu ramen.  The service was good, and it wasn't very packed inside.  Overall the food was good, and this time we got free street parking! Yay!
author: Mina Y.

description:
*Services: If I can give it a negative review I would have. *
For a restaurant that has been opened for a while, I'm surprised it has such poor service. 

It isn't far to give such negative without a full story. So here it goes., 

First arrive on a Sunday evening at around 6pm, with about 15 customer already dining and 30% of the table fill serve by 6 waiter as I counted.  I was directed to a table promptly by one of the waiter and presented their menu.  After I sat down it's a totally different story,  I was sitting there for over 8 minutes without being approach by any waiter or server even a glass of water to start with.  As I turn around, I turn around, I saw the male water just chatting away by the bar with other waiter and the others just doodling around.  As I try to wave down a server, 3 choose to ignore me as I wave and I finally found one that's actually delivering food and ask her for a glass of water.  As she deliver my water the lazy male server jump in but didn't even greed or said a word, so I just told him what I wanted.  Then, he give a some what under hand look as if, "OH,. I got your order, Geee,.. " In a way I felt offended,... Even though the service at this point is enough to drive me out the door but I still hold some hopes with so many decent review... so I've decided to stay hope the ramen that I had order will be the saving grace.  

Unfortunately, the chashu ramen that I've order was a disappointment as well.  The menu stated that all the ramen is in a beef broth, however the broth for this ramen was very weak.  I've had ramen all my life, and found the broth resembling the Safeway 99cens ramen broth. It was weak, thin, without enough grilled onion and simmer of bone in the broth .  The pork loin was cold in the middle, the egg was over cooked  and cold. The only fresh veggies were the green onons. The noodles be your regular yakisoba noodles, that's typical. As soon as you take your last spoon, they take the bowl away. 

Overall experience, NOT COMING BACK and I DON'T RECOMMEND IT.  Don't let all those 3-4 stars review fools ya, you may end up being disappointed like I do.,.. if you are looking for quality ramen for a reasonable price, I would pick alternative.  I do think there are more quality ramen restaurant in SF.
author: Hanson H.

description:
If you LOVE crab, HATE peeling them, and CRAVE good flavor then the Crab mango salad appetizer is for you! I know what you are thinking... Crab meat with rich mayo, mango cubes, and tobiko?! Everyone I know that tried it loves it! 
 
Now onto the ramen portion of my review...  Beef curry ramen is what I ordered. The broth was soooo rich and good. The beef curry part stays on its side of the bowl. The fifty yard line of the bowl is where the curry sauce remixes with the broth like a P.Diddy remix. 
"Take that... Take that.." Its like a symphony in your mouth! The potatoes were cubed tiny, the meat was tender and flavorful...  and you can get a little bit of everything in each bite. 

After you enjoy heaven in y0 mouth, walk it off around the corner and head to Genki Crepes where you can indulge in the finest of Japanese candies, chocolates, drinks and crepes!
author: BYRON D.

description:
Went to Genki Ramen on a Monday night when it was freezing in the Richmond. It was alright... I feel... ambivalent towards this place and so am reluctant to write a review. Maybe what I ordered wasn't that special. I got the shrimp tempura ramen.

I mean, it was good. It definitely hit the spot if you're looking for warm soup noodles. The place is clean and decorated simply with tvs and the price is right.
author: Abbey S.

description:
This is definitely my go to ramen restaurant whenever I have a sudden crave for it and I'm not in San Mateo (cuz Himuwari is off the hook!) 

I always want to try something new when I'm here, like yesterday when I was here, I thought about it. Maybe try one of their rice plates, perhaps the curry. But nope, I always come back to the ramen section and order the chashu ramen. If you like fried chicken, I really recommend the chicken karagge ramen because it's hella good. I usually tell my friends to order it so I could steal a piece of their chicken. 

I've tried the scallops in the robatayaki section and it was delicious! Yesterday I had croquette for the first time--they're fried potato cakes. Pretty good. 

But for serious, I come here for the ramen, because the broth is good and the noodles are good. 

CAUTION: wait for your ramen to cool, and your croquette cuz I always be burning my tongue! I can still feel my burnt tastebuds -_-
author: Amy X.

description:
Their food is nothing too spectacular. 
Their service was decent.
Very nice bathroom though!

Disappointing story.....
My friends and I went to Genki desserts/market and got crepes and walked over to Genki Ramen. Two of us wanted ramen while other two were going to just sit and watch. I thought it would be ok if we brought Genki crepes into Genki ramen it would be fine. However, after they found out two of us weren't ordering. They said we can't bring "OUTSIDE FOOD" in the restaurant. They then wrote on a piece of paper and put it on the door saying "No outside food."
When the bill came, they charged a fee for not eating of a dollar per person who didn't eat.... Clearly there was no sign or announcement in the menu mentioning the fee. They said exactly, "We will only charge you one dollar this time, next time it will be $5." 

Since they thought we were young and easy to take advantage of, I felt that "fee" was not fair for my friends. We were the only ones in the restaurant from the beginning to end. 

Never going back there again. There are many other ramen restaurants much better and nicer.
author: Tony C.

description: First review I am ever writing so you know I must really mean it! I have been here twice now and I am always begging my boyfriend to go back .(he doesn't need much convincing though!) Both times I have gotten the Spicy Ma Bo (I think they mean Ma Po) Ramen and it is amazing!! Silky tofu with bits of optional pork in a spicy broth with a ton of noodles. The noodles have a great chewy texture to them. The staff is very nice and the food always comes out quick. The tab is usually about $20 and for how full and satisfied we are that is certainly a steal. Go here!
author: Simma R.

description:
This is one of my favorite ramen places in the city.  I really enjoy their Chashu Ramen.  Every time I eat here I finish every last drop of the soup.

The service here is great, at least whenever I'm there.  They bring everyone's food at the same time in an efficient manner.  One lunch they had mistaken my order.  I ordered the Karaage Ramen with Pork Fried Rice, but instead they gave me Chashu Ramen and the fried rice.  The waitress immediately gave me an extra plate of Karaage for their mistake.  Needless to say, I was very happy with their quick and considerate response.

I was just a LITTLE bit disappointed in their Tenderous Rib Ramen.  Most of what was supposed to be meat was bone.  But what little meat I had was delicious.  I'd only recommend it if you are really craving it.   If you really want a filling meal, go with the Karaage Ramen. The Karaage here is alright, but not the best I've had. 

Tip: Go at lunch.  The ramen is a dollar cheaper and you can add Gyoza or Pork Fried rice  with the dollar you save.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Why I love Genki Ramen

1.) The food is good.  Quality is clearly important to this restaurant because everytime I have eaten there, the food is fresh.  Variety of Ramen is fantastic and you can even customize your Ramen to some degree.  I recommend the Chicken Karage Ramen.

2.) Televisions.  Yes, I know its rude to ignore your dinner partners but to me, its no different then when someone constantly checks their iphone.  It is nice to be able to keep up with the Giants game or whatever event, while out to eat.

3.) Open late.  You can get a nightcap from the bar and some food before you go home from a night out.  They have a nice selection of sake and soju.

4.) Music.  There are times at night when the staff puts on some super cool, next level beats from a PC computer.  It adds to the experience.  For some this may be a bad thing.  For me...it makes it surreal.
author: Patrick V.

description:
Ramen Noodle is fine but not the soup and other dishes!! SAD~

I am a noodle soup person. I finally give Genki a try last late night (an hour before their close time)

We order Beef Stew Ramen, Seafood Ramen and Samurai Wings.
My Beef Stew is just too much fat, even though I am a person who kinda like fat. I still consider it's just too over~
the quality of ramen noodle is fine. Not mush, still have good ramen texture with it! I kinda like the noodle. However, the tonkatsu base soup was not so good. Too salty (maybe also too many MSG) made me feel dehydrate after having the soup. 

My friend's Seafood ramen was not so pleasant either. 

Last, the wings are just a disaster!! the first smell of strong sour Vinegar makes you feel sick. The super over fried skin was dry and also super salty (maybe MSG problem again)

After the whole meal, we both feel super dehydrate by over seasoning of salt (MSG). If you are not a MSG salty person, you should not try this ramen shop.
author: JustinE Y.

description:
I've been here on a busy day and slow days and I just don't get it. Your ramen is so great but your service just kills you!!

I'm giving you two stars for because of the service. Not only do I get slow service each time I go here, I also get un-friendly service. I don't know if it's because I get there around 4:30, which is close to 5 (the time their lunch special ends), and your stalling. Who knows?! All I know is that it took me 15 min till a waitress took my order. Why? Caused she closed out two tables n then busses them after. Uhm... I'm sorry but I was ready to order after you handed me my water but I guessed you didn't notice cause you didn't even say anything or even looked at me when you handed me my water.

Not sure if you know but it's also about the service n experience that makes a great place, not just the good food.
author: James P.

description:
Food: 4/5
The ramen here is actually pretty good, the broth is always consistent as are most of the dishes; consistency is always important. The serving size is always enough to fill you up and sometimes a little more. I would recommend the chicken karaage, although not traditional it is very good and the chicken will stay partly crunchy when you put it in the ramen a few pieces at a time. Don't forget to ask for the additional hard-boiled egg.

Atmosphere: 4/5 
The restaurant's interior is very well decorated and chic. There is a bar area with stools that are pretty high, being fairly tall my feet only just touch the ground so I'm in a purgatory of foot on stool or off. For some reason, probably just that it's busy they always put my on the high seats; of course there is plenty of regular seating.

Service: 3/5
The service here isn't always the best, they have always gotten the order right but at the same time don't convey that they are really that happy to give you your order at all. The kitchen service is also fairly quick and you won't have to wait that long to get your food. 

Price: 4/5
Simply put you won't spend too much here and will always get a pretty good "bang for your buck."

That something special: 3.5/5
I will probably keep coming here just for the fact that the ramen is to my taste, although not the best and most traditional. The Karaage ramen is satisfying, especially on those cold days and you can always bring a good group of friends and have some drinks for a nice hang out dinner. 

Total score: 3.7/5
author: Aaron P.

description: We come here and have made an effort to try at least something different each time they haven't failed us yet
author: William W.

description:
Genki means good in Japanese.

On a cold Sunday night in the foggy City of San Francisco, not much is opened.  YELPed a spot to get my noodle fixin' before the 5 day work week.

The ramen is ok, not good; but ok.  I ordered the chick karaage ramen, which was quite bland.  I had to add a lot of the spicy powder on the side.  Other than that, nothing really special about this place, except for their advertised Happy hour.  I figure it was too far from where I work and we probably wouldn't make the cut off point.

Plus stars for the plasma screens and cool sink in the restroom.  Other than that, I probably would not spend $10 for a bowl of ramen when i can buy a pack and cook it at home for less than 2 dollars.
author: Elliot Y.

description:
As someone who has eaten a lot of ramen out of the little packages it seemed odd to pay $9 for a bowl of ramen... but this stuff obviously wasn't freeze dried, so... you know...

Anyhow, I had some of the cold chicken ramen... and cold it was! I enjoyed it very much but I probably should have ordered a non-cold ramen since it was already pretty cold outside... my friends ordered various other dishes and we all tried the various ramen iterations... all of which were pretty good...

place has a cool "hip" atmosphere and a there is a large window into the kitchen which is kinda cool...
author: Frank E.

description:
Is this real ramen?  I'm glad it's not, because this was my FIRST exposure to ramen.  Okay, it's not really a first, since it doesn't count, Maru Ichi is my first.  It took me three years after Genki to gather enough courage and pay for another bowl of ramen.

The place is very colorful, and the sign is HUGE.  I feel like I'm walking into a lounge that has $5 drinks, and something they called ramen.  I don't even remember what I ate, I just remembered I didn't finish it.  I was mad at my boyfriend for taking me to a dinner place where I couldn't eat the food.  

The soup was salty, not savory or flavorful.  the drink was good.  So yeah, dinner that night was a $5 mango cocktail.  At least everything was pretty....I had a bowl of instant ramen that night.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: No too happy with service. Distracted waiter. 45 minutes for a roll. Tables are sticky. Did not get a good vibe
author: Maybel A.

description:
The service here might just completely prevent me from ever coming back and enjoying this delicious ramen.

In short -- they have an excellent and different selection of ramen, much of which is too salty but somehow that makes it extra good. However, the waitresses are incredibly rude. They never come to your table when you need something and if you're try to catch their eye it's like pullin' teeth. You might as well refill your own water!

I asked the waitress if i could simply sit at a booth instead of the furthest back table. She didn't even acknowledge my request, but she did however shoot me a scathing why-would-you-ask-such-a-thing glare. Futhermore, she immediately went to whisper to her compadre something probably not awesome. When the dreaded girl came back to take our order, she slammed down the tea cups in a huff and begrudgingly nodded as we put in our requests. 

Even if the ramen is tasty, it's not worth feeling like you're bothering the staff by eating in their god forsaken restaurant. Two words: Deal. Breaker.

Try Hotei or Katana-ya.

**Update: They have since made some good decisions here and fired the aforementioned waitress(es).
author: Vicki T.

description:
I was a fan even before stepping into this place because I was hungry and it was open till 11PM; it's always useful to know which restaurants are open late when most eateries close around 9-10PM.

And yes, me and my friends were those annoying people that stroll in 10 minutes before closing time, but were still treated pleasantly. 

I didn't order anything overly special, it's actually quite common; I ordered Chicken Teriyaki, and it was tasty!

I hope to return soon!
author: Angelica C.

description: I have had ramen in a couple of places in the bay but none of them have compared to the ones in Taiwan. This one didn't fair any better. I got the Kimchi Ramen. It was alright. The pork was pretty salty so my friend and I kept on chugging water. The servers were friendly but they seemed to come by quite often and I like to be left alone for most of my dining exprience.
author: Jessica H.

description:
The fact that I will drive down from Marin for a bowl of their ramen should be review enough. 

I've driven past Genki many times on the way to the headache parking nightmare of Clement and thought it looked so cute that I must try it. I finally did a few months ago and their Kinoko Mushroom is the new gold standard. Five kinds of mushrooms and they offer vegetarian soup base which is a dream come true. Also a good feature are  the "extras" you can add to your ramen, like seaweed, corn, tofu, and extra ramen noodles.

I also really like the veggie gyoza, grilled and freshly assembled in their greasy goodness. The bite of yakisoba I tried was also good, with that "grill" taste to the noodles. Some here complain of the "hardness" of the noodles. I find the ramen noodles just right, where so many places over-cook them to just shy of mush. If you can describe ramen as "al dente" this is what they've achieved here.

No, the waitstaff won't be your new best friend, the flat screen TV's are kind of annoying with their ESPN and Disney Channel feed and the food might be more on the greasy end of the spectrum (regarding appetizers, not ramen) but most asian food is a bit better kind of oily. I've been here for lunch, late lunch, happy hour and for late dinner before a concert, always finding it a reliable destination.

Now, if only they'd open one north of the Golden Gate...
author: Laura R.

description:
The seafood cake is fantastic, as are the asparagus wrapped in bacon skewers and the unfiltered sake.

Unfortunately, this restaurant is going to have to take a hit because my friend is an idiot. By the time we got to this place, I was majorly pissed. Mr "oh, it's walking distance from Golden Gate park" made us trek all the way here promising me sushi. Genki does not serve sushi. I had even made a point of drawing attention to every sushi place on our 3 mile trek from the park (there were at least 10). So, I did not have as great an experience as I may have had otherwise.

The service was ok. Our server made minimal screw ups with regard to the splitting of bills (we had a group of 7 and wanted the checks split in strange ways). And, for some reason, they kitchen wanted to put different people's food on the same plate, so there was much reaching across the table. The sake/soju cocktails got rave reviews from my friends. I very much enjoyed the unfiltered sake, which went for about $6 (as opposed to $13 for the same bottle at Rock Sushi). The steaming seafood cake was the best and I may actually be persuaded to go here again just for that.
author: Mo C.

description:
Unfortunately Genki Ramen gets 1 star from me specifically with regard to their delivery service. I have ordered from them before and enjoyed their ramen but it had always take a long time to make the delivery - at least 40 minutes and generally more like 60 minutes. Today was no exception with regard to delivery time except after waiting 1 hour they delivered the wrong food. When I called to explain this to them they questioned me multiple times about what I had ordered (ramen) to make sure I had the wrong dish (beef teriyaki and pork neck). They also asked me to return the incorrect food to them (hopefully not to re-deliver - super gross) and said they would get me the correct meal in another 40 minutes (translation: another hour). After waiting an hour, spending 20 minutes trying to get a hold of them and communicate the situation, another 40 minutes to wait seemed sort of ridiculous so I asked to reverse the charge that they had already made on my credit card and they said it would take them 5 days to a week? WTF?!

Anyway. 100% lame delivery service and poor customer service when the issue was brought up.  Order delivery only if you are masochistic and want a huge dose of frustration to end a long day at work.
author: Veronica Y.

description:
Service wasn't that fast, I guess they really need more waitress.  

Takoyaki was just so-so.

Fried chicken wings--first bite tasted good, but after a while, it's a bit too much vinegar. (Make sure you don't inhale while you are eating the wings)

Yakitori-- all good, we got beef w/scallion, minced chicken, and pork neck.

Vegetable Yakisoba--good flavor, but need more vegetables, it was mainly all noodles with sauce.

Pricewise--Cheap

Will be back!
author: Elena L.

description:
Not bad ramen.  I had the mabo spicy tofu and ground pork ramen.  Spicy,  flavorful, and hot!  Just a tad oily for me.  My wife had the charsiu ramen. Noodles? Good.  Soup? Good.  

The servers are competent, but not very enthusiastic.  That's not a complaint, but about what I'd expect at a place like this.  The dining room has a bit of nightclub/lounge feel to it with TV's and some low club music.  Open late is a plus for bar hoppers and late diners.  

We always get a kick out of ramen, because the Japanese call it "Chinese style noodles" and the Chinese call it "Japanese style noodles".  Which is it?  Just depends on the restaurant you're in, I guess.  We also had the takoyaki (octopus balls).  Tasty, if you like that kind of thing.  Normally at a place like this, the thing to do is order many of the small dishes to enjoy with lots of beer.  We just didn't indulge this time.
author: Stephen F.

description:
Ramen with half of a boiled egg some spinach, garlic, and ribs= JUST OK. The Broth was good, the meat was dry and salty, the egg was a bit salty, and the noodles were good, it had a bite to it.
 
Seafood Pancake looking thing starts with an "O" = Ok my 1st time eating this, it was mushy in the middle with lots of fake seafood. Uhh is it supposed to taste mushy? and not like a solid pancake? If it's not then I'm in major trouble tonight! I won't order it again, it needed hot sauce or something! 

Chicken wings= Yuck, it was all vinegar, was not balanced tasting at all

Best part of my meal, the free pickled cabbage! MMM. They give you literally 2 tablespoons of this stuff for like 3 people! WTF! How cheap can you get?
author: Karen T.

description:
They have a lot of TVs in there considering the size of the space. Maybe I would've liked it better if that had more interesting programs going on. 

Went there after a day of tanning in Napa and it was freezing back home in the city. We decided to try to warm up with some ramen. I can't really say the food was the best I've ever had, but good enough for the cost. And they DO deliver, which I may utilize if I'm ever that lazy to leave the house. Pretty neutral. Probably not my first preference for ramen.
author: Natalie S.

description:
It's just wrong.
This is NOT Japanese food.
The seasoning, the combinations, the flavors, the sauces are so not the way it should be.
Obviously, the chef was not Japanese because if he was, he would know what sauce to put on the unagi-don.
The ramen soup also taste just like a soup and not a ramen soup.
The combination of soup base and the items you can get are something you would never see in Japan, but I guess if you don't care about traditional Japanese ramen, then you won't be too disappointed.
The noodles were too soggy and I didn't even get to finish half of it as well.
Anyways, I'm not going back.
I'd rather drive down to San Mateo to eat at Santa Ramen or Himawari...now thses are good ramen places.
author: M J.

description: The food here is good, but seems to leave me in a food hangover. Got free edamame for Yelp check-in, that's always nice. Conveniently located on Geary.
author: Austin P.

description: Genki is dimly lit and the decor looks a little dated - like 90s pan asian. Whatever that means. But I digress. The husband and some friends were looking for late night ramen, and this place was open til 11pm. Sold. I had pretty low expectations with the 3.5 rating, but this place was not half bad. My "standard" is Ramen Dojo and Himawari in San Mateo - so in comparison to these places the miso broth I ordered was rather weak. Nonetheless it was not completely flavorless, and the shrimp tempura was crispy and not overcooked. They were generous with the egg noodles which had a nice chew to them - however a little skimpy on the broth. Perhaps because it was toward closing time. Ramen bowls ranged from $8.50ish and $10. The waitress forgot to bring out our check-in deal which was a croquette, but I was getting sleepy and it wasn't worth fighting for something that was free anyway. Wouldn't mind coming back for some late night noodles again. And during their happy hour and after 10pm, small beers on tap are $2. Nice.
author: Lisa H.

description:
food: 3/5
service: 5/5
decor: 4/5

Came here for dinner on a weekend. Try to arrive before 6:30pm because the place starts getting packed after that. There were still several 4 person tables available when I got here so there was no wait. We tried the ramen and okonomiyaki. Each ramen or okonomiyaki dish is $8-10 depending on the type you get. I found that all the broths for the ramen are great and they cook the noodles just right. I even finished the broth after eating the rest of the stuff. If you are a big eater, just be warned that all the ramen bowels don't come with alot of meat. I was never a fan of okonomiyaki so I can't say I enjoyed it that much. For those who don't know what okonomiyaki is, it is like a japanese vegetable pancake with chopped cabbage, this is the plain version. They put this mixture in a shallow cast iron pan and cook it like that. They have different meats they can mix in with the pancake if you choose different toppings. Over all for each person it was around $13 for one drink and a dish. Pretty reasonable price for a food they give you. I didn't have any left overs, but I was full afterwards.  

If you check in with facebook or print out the coupon on their website, you get a small free appetizer of croquette or tofu.
author: Cecile S.

description:
YUMMMY ramen, but that's probably due to the MSG they pour into their soups.

I really like the spicy mabo tofu ramen as well as their sides (chicken karage and chasu) and during happy hour or lunch specials it's only about $1 to add a side dish to your ramen. Seriously, what does $1 get you anymore these days anyway? But the food is good and the service is fast and friendly.

My only real complaint is the feeling of insatiable thirst that comes after you leave the restaurant -__-
author: Winnie T.

description: Genki is my go-to ramen house in SF. I've been to a lot of the ramen houses in the city, and this is one of the most consistent experiences I've had. I usually order the chicken karaage or tonkotsu ramen, and have had great experiences with them. Good noodles, well-seasoned broth, lots of ingredients. I did order the garlic pork ramen one time, and it wasn't the best I've had. So far, Sawaii Ramen in the Sunset and Ramen Dojo in San Mateo have had much better garlic pork broths. But, Genki is still the most consistent overall experience for ramen that I've had up to this point. Great service, short to no wait, good food, nice ambiance.
author: D C.

description: Fulfilled my ramen craving at the time but in comparision to Ramen Dojo it's flavorless and boring.
author: Jade W.

description:
Yes Yes and more Yes!!!! This is hands down thee best Ramen noodle house that I have been to yet and will remain number one until further notice LOL. The waitresses were super awesome and the food is to die for. My girlfriend had the tenderous pork rib ramen and she loved it to a point that if she could she would have went back to the kitchen area and slapped the cook. I had their version of Shoyu ramen and it took my breath away. The caramel milk tea was good (could be a little sweeter). 

All in all this place ROCKS!!!!!! I could eat here everyday.
author: Keith A.

description:
Found out about this place after a yelp search for "okonimiyaki". Our quest for the place with the right mix of taste and texture as the version we had in Tokyo has - to date - not been fruitful. We walked in just before 7, so in time for there 7-days a week happy hour. We ordered: gyoza - a little greasy, but with the best wonton wrapper I've had in awhile. Super fresh and tasty. Seafood yakisoba - delicious! Will order again. Okonimiyaki with ramen -the flavors were there, but it was a bit mushy in texture. Still, it's the best we've had since this quest started...
1 star off for friendly, but not exactly speedy or attentive service - had to ask 2x for the gyoza - tables seated after us got theirs before we did - and it still didn't come until after we were almost done with our entrees. No bother - we'll be back.
author: Eme L.

description:
The service is here is pretty good overall. 
The food is just okay, nothing really special about the ramen. It's not like it has the taste that you would crave for or anything. Other than that, if you would want to try some classy ramen noodles than the "cup of noodles", then try this!
author: Sandy T.

description:
The Yakisoba is awesome. The Ramen is also great but if you are wanting a clear broth, you will be surprised. It is a miso base (and delicious). 

The best part is they deliver.

I have not been disappointed with anything I have ordered.
author: Fancy P.

description: I had thought that with a name like Genki ramen that ramen here would be its specialty. What Genki did with ramen and Japanese food here is kind of like what McD's did to the burger. What you have here is a cheap, sloppy, low quality, generic tasting (actually every dish we ordered was over salted) Japanese food. What you WON'T find here is a bowl of hand made ramen with noodles of the right consistency, home made soup stock that has been deliciously boiled for hours and ingredients that are fresh and prepared with care. My 1 star rating is for the hip atmosphere, TV screens, good drink list and decent service.
author: Teresa T.

description:
Had dinner here the other night...
Had a Sapporo.
Had about half an order of Karaage.
Had a Garlic Pork Ramen.
Had a Chicken katsu curry rice.
Had a Kirin.
Some may feel that gluttonous escapade is worthy of an imminent triple-bypss and a stark "I TOLD YOU SO."
Others may wonder if I'm out trying to prove something.
Hey man, I just wanted ramen and katsu curry.
For me, close proximity to The Sunset makes this place worthy of consideration when trying to decide between Katanaya, Halu, Suzu, Himawari, and Santa.
author: Barry A.

description:
I ordered a vegetarian stir-fry dish that had shiitake and oyster mushrooms, which I love.  However, the actual meal had about five slivers of mushroom in it....so I was sad!

They have a happy hour every day of the week with $3 appetizers and beer, so that's a good deal.  Ambiance was nice but the music they play sucked.

This place was okay but if I go again I'd try something besides the veggie noodle stir-fry.
author: Carolyn N.

description:
Ramen was okay.. Had the seafood ramen.  Appetizer is out fast.  We had a big group and I they miss some orders.  This place seems good for lunch only, since our dinner was very moderate.  
They have TV so we didn't miss the sports game.  AC could have been better, since you're having soup; probably because of the cold foggy night.
Have to come back again a few more time.
author: Eric N.

description:
Genki Ramen is pretty nice inside, they have a bunch of TVs, and a swank atmosphere.  The Ramen was pretty delicious, but kind of a small portion for my liking.  

The best part was the fizzy Asahi candy that they gave us with the check.  Those little suckers are amazingly addictive.
author: Eric L.

description:
Sorry I wouldn't want to give 2 stars, but yes.. i've indeed had better. The Cha siu bbq pork was overcooked which i always hate. I prefer the juicy-soft-melt-in-ur-month cha siu in my ramen.

The broth was pretty decent. I liked it. The miso soup was a bit on the salty side but they give a good amount .. expensive though.

Takoyaki lacked some flavor on the outside.

The noodles was this ramen house's greatest weakness. It is soggy. Like disgustingly soggy. My friend described that it taste like soap. This is probably due to how soggy it gets. I like my ramen firm or at least decently firm so i can slurp it up.

What also surprises me is the pricing of the items. It's a bit on the high end with near $9 a bowl and each additional item is $1.50-2.00.

Adding in seaweed, eggs, tofu, corn, etc. might give you an highly overpriced bowl of ramen for what it is. At times like this i rather go back down to Shinsengumi or Daikokuya in Los Angeles area for quality ramen at a price point of under $7.00 with all the bells and whistles.
author: Stephen W.

description:
I had my heart set on trying out halu. but knowing my luck it was closed on sundays. We were starving and craving for ramen/noodles so we saw this place and decided to walk in.  Before I went i already did my yelp research on this place and that was mostly why it wasn't my first choice.  I had the pork rib ramen thing....It wsa too much meat for my liking and the soup base was nothing spectacular.  I got the happy hour combo which came with the chicken Karraoge and that was pretty good.  My bf got the curry chicken katsu ramen combo with the fried rice.  that was better than mine i thought and the fried rice is good but greasy...i guess that's how it should be.

we also order potato croquette appetizer.  I've had better...

On to the service.  We went there at 4 in the afternoon so no one was there...i felt like the girl had nothing to do so she kept coming over and clearing out plates and stuff...even though i wasn't done with some of them...that was rather annoying....

atmosphere was cool i like the music and the tables are nice and spacious.

This place is truely mediocre and If i wasn't desperate for a bowl of ramen I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here again....
author: Zu W.

description: Yummy ramen. Good if your around. but not worth it if you have to travel far.
author: Derrick M.

description: This place was not that good. The food was ok, but not up to par with some of the other places available in SF. I ordered the ramen and was not very impressed with the broth. The quality of ingredients was ok but they skimped a little on them. Not sure if I would come back to try some different items.
author: Sannie L.

description: Average place for ramen. I wasn't very wow-ed.
author: Trang N.

description:
I've been here on several occasions, and not once have I ever deemed it really noteworthy of a review.  The location is standard SF status as for as searching for parking (on Geary and its side streets), and its open late night.  The inside is a cute setting, and the bar is appealing with its low lighting.  I honestly just saw it as a place late night to grab ramen and grab a drink with some friends.

It was until I was recommended the Spicy Mobo Tofu Ramen that I became in instant fan.  I HATE TOFU.  I also HATE anything SPICY.  But the Spicy Mobo Tofu, with its bits of pork, is absolutely amazing.  Anyone could tell you that I'm pretty stubborn when it comes to tofu and anything spicy.  And for me to convert due to one dish that's a serving is both is definitely worth trying.

The only other thing that I could mention is how I miss their cute chop stick holders that I believe they've decided to do without thanks to the economy.
author: John L.

description: Pretty good ramen. i like the variety they have and the different soups they offer.
author: aaron t.

description: This place is good and at a decent price for what you get.  It's certainly not the best Japanese place in the city but if you need a good cheap fix this will do.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Good cheap ramen fix avec soju cocktails. No frills, & surprisingly unpretentious.
author: Eloy T.

description:
Went here with a couple of friends tonight for dinner. They ordered ramen while I had the curry tonkatsu with rice. I must say that my dish was just alright....the rice wasn't the traditional Japanese rice that I had expected, and the katsu tasted like something I could get at L&L. There also wasn't that much curry sauce, but it wasn't the most flavorful Japanese curry that I've had anyway so it didn't really matter. Guess it was my fault for ordering katsu curry in a ramen place. *shrug*

My friend didn't seem to enjoy his chicken karaage ramen much either. My other friend on the other hand loved her ramen, so I guess it's up to personal preference. I loved the decor though, it was very modern and clean. They also play techno/trance music haha. Nonetheless, the food was just average....I might return to try their other selections (ramen, okonomiyaki etc.).
author: Chrys U.

description:
Good ramen place in the Richmond District.  Had the chashu ramen and every aspect of it was pretty good.  Great noodles, good soup, and tasty pork.  Fairly generous portions.   The food mght not be authentic Japanese but it tastes pretty good.  Also serves okonomiyaki and it is very tasty.  Too many places go overboard with ginger and plum sauce when they make okonomiyaki but the restaurant makes it just right.   Most of the dishes I've had here have been good.  Also have had good experience with their skewers, samurai chicken, and cold noodle.  Service had always been excellent and attentive.  Having multiple flat screen TVs gives this place a hip, modern feel but you can never hear the TVs because they are always playing music.   Restrooms are clean, which is a surprise for this kind of restaurant.   Seems to able to handle group of up to 20 fairly well.

Take out is pretty decent, also.  They provide all the ingredients for the ramen in seperate boxes and that keeps the noodles from getting too soggy.

The only complaint about this place is that the restaurant always seems a little stuffy inside.  Really poorly ventilated.

Check the website before going, they often have coupons.
author: Re-pley Z.

description: Good ramen. Nice beer on tap.
author: Michael E.

description:
Not the greatest ramen I've ever had but I'll take it.

As is customary for me when I'm checking out a new ramen shop, I had the chashu ramen. Broth was okay at best. There wasn't much to it. Interestingly enough, we didn't get to choose which broth we wanted (e.g. miso, shio, shoyu). This was actually a good thing, since the broth is generally my favorite part, so I didn't have to labor over which one I wanted. Noodles were decent. Very chewy and apparently (according to other yelpers) not authentic Japanese ramen. I can't vouch for that as I'm no expert but I still enjoyed the noodles nonetheless. The toppings were pretty standard. Half a boiled egg, some bean sprouts, and slices of pork. 

Based off other reviews, we also decided to have the okonomiyaki. We went with the seafood one and added ramen to it. I was pretty happy with the overall taste. A great dish to share among friends as an appetizer. I would recommend not adding the ramen. We could hardly taste it as the other ingredients overpowered the noodle bits. 

Service is good enough. Waitresses are prompt and helpful. Decor is interesting. Pretty dark setting but with lots of flat screen tvs everywhere. 

Overall, I was going to give this place a 3.5 stars. However, I enjoyed the okonomiyaki, so I'm going to bump up my score a bit. I'd definitely come back again with a group and see what other dishes we could sample. 4 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Came here with some friends before going to a bar.

I was really feeling ramen that day, but for some reason ended up ordering their okonomiyaki. I saw an option for Ramen and thought "sweet! I can get both". yeah....thats a lie.

Apparently they just top your okonomiyaki with ramen noodles. so weird, It was good but weird. V. disappointed that I didn't get ramen. 

I tried the broth of the ramen though, and it was only okay. Nothing too outstanding. It didn't feel fatty enough, as if they skimmed the fat from the top. 

The samurai wings were DELICIOUS though, as was the fact that we got tea as soon as we sat down. Love tea. 

For the price, it was okay. I think I preferred the okonomiyaki in japantown more.
author: andrew c.

description: I love ramen very much and genki satisfied me:) The chashu appetizer is really tasty.
author: Siyu P.

description:
I wish I could give it 3.5 but 3 will do.  Must say that Katana-ya is still my favorite because I love how savory their spicy tofu broth is but Genki isn't bad either.  

Really liked their seafood okonomiyaki! It was still delish reheated the next say as well!  Tons of fresh seafood in each bite. 

Takoyaki balls and beef enoki rolls were good but missing a lil kick. Can't quite put my finger on it but they were missing the wow factor. 

Really liked the mango salad.  Chopped mango with a pile of crab salad on top and tobiko.  Rather light and refreshing =)
author: Beatrice T.

description:
Came here with friends not too long ago, & I was very happy that I did. I've never been to a Ramen place before & Genki was really good. 
I had the cold veggie noodles, the single serve pork- chop, and the spicy curry with chicken karrage on the side. Everything was great but the service was slow, & it wasn't even busy, that's why *** instead of ****.  
But I'll go back because it can only get better if what my friends tell me is true.
author: timothy h.

description: Large selection of Ramen. If you like noodles, this is a must try. Plus it's open super late, nothing better than topping off a party evening with this place.
author: Hannah L.

description:
If i was ever sentenced to eat nothing but Samurai Wings for a week straight would totally be able to deal with that!
I have had take out for Genki two times now. I'm not a huge fan of the entrees I have had. The black peppered beef is exactly that beef with black pepper, nothing else. lacks flavor in my opinion. Also tried the ramen and wasn't really into it.
But the SAMURAI WINGS!!!! awww sweet spicy tangy delicious Samurai wings. 
Genki is fast for take out, and also offers delivery. Due to the fact that I am completely in love with Samurai Wings, I will continue to order from here and try other entrees. Hopefully I find a good one soon.
author: Kelle K.

description:
This was my first time here. Came here with my brother during happy hour (3-7pm) b/c he says he loves this place because the ramen broth is soooo good. I had the SEAFOOD RAMEN: it was good w/ some shirmp, mussels, edamame beans, scallops, fish cakes, and imitation crab meat. The miso based broth was way to salty, but the ramen was cooked just the way I like it...chewy.

GARLIC TENDEROUS RIB: this was my brother's dish. his broth wasn't as salty, nor was it garlicy. the pork came on the bone, but the meat was so tender and juicy that it just slides off. it also had spinach and half a hard boiled tea egg.  the only problem I had with this dish was that it needed more garlic.

GYOZA: this was a pork filled, pan fried dumpling. the wrap was fried to a nice crisp. it was 5 pieces of these little things for $3.

CHICKEN KARAAGE: this was deep fried chicken pieces. we got a pretty good portion amount considering it was $3 during happy hour.

In all, the staff there was very tentative and courteous. With also a sapporo on tap, our total came to $30. I came out of Genki stuffed and wanting to just go to sleep.
author: Ivy L.

description:
Eh, you know I wasn't terribly impressed with this place but at the same time, I left with a kind of indifference. Didn't hate it, didn't love it, boom- 3 stars.

Really though, the food was fairly tasty but the noodles were pretty soggy and overcooked, the meat was overly fried, and the service could have been a little more attentive. My friends and I were seated and then never looked at us again for about 15 to 20 minutes, but once we got our order in, the service picked back up.

All in all, the place wasn't bad, it's got some good mood lighting too should you ever want to take someone out on a casual date. Can't say what plate to suggest though as the vegetarian noodle soup and the chicken noodle soup were both soggy and overcooked.
author: Anthony C.

description:
I am not Japanese and have NO idea as to authenticity, but I loooove the ramen here.  I used to be a Katana-Ya junkie, and will still probably frequent it more due to location.... but I thought Genki was delish.  

I had the lunch special with the Yasai ramen and the 2 gyoza.  I loved the amount of veggies in my ramen and for $8.75, thought the lunch special was a good deal.  They also bring out a pickled cabbage and radish salad that was yummmmmmmy.  

The only thing I like better about Katana-Ya is that you get to pick your broth (miso, soy, etc.)
author: Meagan C.

description: Every day I crave the seafood Ramen. I have tried every other place in sf... none of them compare! And the 7 times I have been there my service has been excellent!
author: Faith G.

description:
Just trying to get a ramen fix in the city.

Got the free potato croquette for checking in using yelp. BTW, it's one check in per table! it was super hot, nearly burned my tongue! it was ok. wouldn't order it.

chicken karaage: chicken pieces were on the side. it was OK. I actually really enjoyed the ramen on it's own. the soup was pretty flavorful. not worth the $10 bucks (including tips) because there just wasn't enough ramen.
author: Grace S.

description:
I was starving. I was cold. I was standing next to a restaurant with a jumbo-sized poster of hot noodle soup affixed to their main street-facing window. The choice was clear. Time to order. First thing on the menu? Yes please. For $7.95, it was the chashu with house made boiled pork, half boiled egg, bamboo shoot, green onion and red ginger in tonkatsu base. While waiting, let's go for a tall Sapporo. *//Pull out the iPhone. Let's see what others are saying on the Yelp feed. What's this? Check-in offer at Genki Ramen?? Excuse me miss... I'll take my complementary chicken katsu, thank you very much.//* Was this the best ramen I've had? Absolutely not. Did it matter? I was starving. I was cold. I was standing next to a restaurant with a jumbo-sized poster of hot noodle soup affixed to their main street-facing window. In terms of overall satisfaction (in the heat of that moment), Genki Ramen got a perfect 10.

+ Hot noodle soup on a cold night works wonders
+ Yelp check-in offer was a pleasant surprise 
-  Broth texture a bit dilute and on the salty side
author: Michael Paul C.

description:
Totally good izakaya style cheap eats. Come here with the same mindset you would if you were going to a place like TGI Friday's - that is, decent hot, fried food to accompany beer. 

Sure, the seafood okonomiyaki uses imitation crab, but this really is about having hot food with Kewpie mayo, so I'm not complaining. 

The takoyaki is totally rad, but likely frozen and fried, but, again, BFD because you're eating them like you would eat jalapeno poppers.

The robatayaki list is extensive and pretty cheap and the pour of soju for $5 is ridiculously large.

If it isn't obvs by this point in my review, I'll be back.
author: Joanna R.

description:
i had wrote another review about this restaurant and it was good but tonight the service and food were just bad! 
first i ordered chicken curry, but i meant with rice, and they gave me noodles, i didnt know there was chicken curry noodles. i didnt eat it for a while and nobody came to ask what was wrong. theen i just ate the noodles. and it was bad.
author: Abner P.

description:
After 90 minutes of sweating profusely in a Bikram Yoga class, the body craves replenishment: salt and liquids.  That's when I usually get a craving for ramen, and most specifically, Genki Ramen in the Richmond.  Though Hotei is just a few steps away, we like Genki for its uber-flavourful broths and noodle variations.

Take, for instance, my current ramen of choice - the beguilingly-named "Garlic Tenderous Rib" [sic] Ramen: you get with your miso broth and noodles, an almost obscene chunk of melt-in-your-mouth pork rib that tastes like its been stewed for hours (in a sweet-savoury sauce with hints of anise) until the meat and tendons are definitely falling off the bone.  You also get a marinated hard-boiled egg, a smidge of sautéed spinach and a savoury sprinkling of fried shallot... leftovers are delicious heated up the next day.  If you feel that the cha-siu pork slices that come with the other ramen options are meager, this particular chunk o' meat won't leave you wanting.

The husband favours the kimchee ramen as well as the mapo-tofu ramen; I also like their butter corn ramen. Char-siu pork slices are indeed a bit on the thin side, but definitely tender, juicy, and exceedingly tasty.

We recently tried their seaefood Okonomiyaki and find it delicious - we could not stop eating this wonderful, chewy, pancake mélange topped with brown okonomiyaki sauce, mayo, green onion, and bonito flakes... 

We have yet to try their delivery since we don't mind driving a bit for takeout...
author: Claudine C.

description:
I wouldn't kill for a bowl of ramen.

In fact, you'd probably have to threaten me to get me to go to a ramen joint. It's not that I don't like it, but I just don't crave it like other folks do (reminds me of the Pho craving some folks have).

Genki was surprisingly good. Went there on a Wednesday evening, no wait. Staff was helpful and courteous and the food came out quick. I ordered the chicken curry ramen and the fried unagi. The ramen was GOOD. Flavorful, and complex (at much as ramen can be, I guess). It wasn't just some soy sauce affair. The unagi was soft, and lacked a little flavor.. but probably because most times I've had it, its been soaked in something and slapped on a sushi roll.

Good place. Eat there.
author: mj m.

description:
My coworker loves this place so after work we decided to try this place out. It was about 10:30PM on a Saturday night. There's only street parking so I was lucky enough to find a spot in front. It wasn't busy at all..

I ordered the Spicy Mobo Tofu Ramen...and the Chicken Karage Ramen to share with two of us... not bad! I would definitely order them again. My friend ordered the teriyaki chicken and it was most impressive. It comes out on a metal skillet still sizzling on top of vegetables. It was pretty good!

I plan to return..
author: Heather H.

description:
400th review goes to Genki Ramen! 

I think I've finally found the exact type of ramen I've been looking for in the city: ramen that doesn't skimp on the chasu (4-5 pieces vs. 1 sad piece that seems to be the norm around the city), ramen that is soaked in the perfect miso/pork broth, ramen that comes with a half egg, ramen that comes with green onions and bamboo shoots. Okay so you get the picture. I've tried Izakaya Sozai, Katana-Ya, and Suzu Noodle House and I have to say...Genki is my favorite so far. No pork belly unfortunately, but the chasu here is fantastic.

We also got a side order of chicken karaage...also delicious but the best karaage is still at Suzu Noodle House (it comes with this magnificent dipping sauce). 

Cozy, modern atmosphere. You wouldn't think it would look all hip and trendy from the outside but it is. They have a full bar and a pretty great happy hour menu that goes from 4-7pm everyday it seems. Happy hour gets you $3 beers and appetizers.

And best of all - mention Yelp and you'll get a free order of edamame or crispy daimaru (think wonton dumpling filled with this spinach/cream cheese/shrimp concoction - so tasty).
author: Yee-Shing W.

description: Quick delivery service and food is consistently okay. Nothing spectacular, but it always hits the spot.
author: C. R.

description: Good variety - lots to select from on the menu.  The atmosphere very casual, cool place to hang out.  Staff is friendly.  Ramen was good, but I think I had higher expectations because our friend said it was the best she's had.
author: Regina N.

description: Clean, great environment and atmosphere! Satisfies my ramen craving but I have tried better okonomiyaki (japanese pancake) so I would not recommend that. Ramen is great but definitely not something I would crave like Ajisen Ramen.
author: Laura L.

description:
We've been going to Genki Ramen for 5 years. It's the kids' favorite ramen restaurant.  We will stop going there in the future.  I was there yesterday a little bit before 11:30, when the restaurant was going to open.  The door was unlocked so my daughter and I walked in and sat down.  A waitress whom we recognize for being frequent customers came out and said in a very rude voice "We are not open.  You can sit here and wait but I'm not going to give you service!"  I was appalled at her rudeness.  We exchannged words and I walked out.  Because my 3-year old daughter was with me, I couldn't say eveything that I wanted to say to her, but I was livid at how rude she was.  Maybe she had a rough morning, but what she needs to remember is that she's in a customer service business, and there's no place for that kind of behavior!  

We always took our families and friends to Genki Ramen in the past and I would always recommend it to all ramen fans.  No more!
author: Kathy V.

description:
Ever since dining at the legendary Daikokuya in Little Tokyo, Los Angeles, I've seemed to become obsessed with finding a Bay Area equivalent. Funny thing is that I'm not even a huge ramen fan. Santa Ramen in San Mateo has come close, but doesn't quite compare. After searching through various lists of ramen joints in the Bay Area, it seemed that Genki Ramen got pretty good reviews all around. It was close to my final destination that evening, so I figured I would give it a shot.

The atmosphere at Genki is pretty contemporary. It's dimly lit, decorated with lots of glass, and has plasma screens in different parts of the restaurant broadcasting Giants games and other sports. As I was a party of 1, I sat at the bar.

Since I've been comparing all ramen places against Daikokuya, I went with the tonkatsu (chashu) ramen, a dish in which the broth contains pork bones, fat, and cartilage that not only gives the broth a rich pork flavor, but also a smooth texture. The ramen was satisfying, but a little underwhelming. The broth was flavorful, but not as smooth. There was a hard-boiled egg, pork, bamboo shoots, and green onion, and that was about it. The noodles were just slightly undercooked, just enough to the point where you find them to be a little overwhelming. The ramen, though, was nice and hot, which was good for after a cold afternoon in the Richmond.

I'd come back if I were in the area again and looking for a place to eat, but I won't declare it my new favorite ramen place. That quest will have to continue elsewhere in San Francisco, or in the Bay Area.
author: Scott J.

description: The ramens have pretty flavorful soup base.  I usually chose from the tempura, seafood, garlic ribs, curry, or chicken katsu ramen.  If ramen is not your type of food, give the stir fried noodles a try, the seafood one is pretty good.
author: Def J.

description: I've been here many times, but just now decided to write a review.  A few years ago, it was great, the portion was huge and tasty. Just recently came here with a few others, we ordered a Ramen with the side of pork fried rice & Seafood Yakisoba.  Ramen portion was less double the size from I remembered.  Food was just ok, nothing to rave about. I was in the mood for Ramen and this was the closest Ramen place in Richmond.  Yakisoba noodles were a bit soggy, soft....also small portion from before.  What happened??
author: Alyce l.

description: I've got to remember to come back here. All around good options, with nice spicy ramen. Hell Yeah! Nice sake, etc. etc.
author: Ken L.

description:
I've had a serious problem with this place recently.

I will admit, here on Yelp, that I actually had a dream about eating their Chashu ramen.  The warming soup with the delectable flavor, perfectly sliced pork, green onions & a flavored egg . . . ooooooh man, I think I want it again.  Perhaps it's the cold, wet weather.  Or maybe the fact that I often come here after swim practice, so I'm always ravenous when I get here.  But I really think it's the simple fact that Genki Ramen knows how to make the best Chashu I've had since living in Taiwan (never been to Japan, so that's the closest I can compare to authenticity - plenty of Japanese influence still abounds in Taiwan).  

The gyoza are also exquisite, miso soups & fried rice are good as well.  Service can be spotty, but it's all quickly forgotten, drowned in the comforting, warm goodness of Chashu. 

-1 star for the ridiculous TV's all over the place.  Without them, the atmosphere would be the perfect hug to complement the love that is Chashu.
author: Ravena F.

description:
being huge ramen aficionados, i  would say this place is pretty normal as in we probably wouldnt come back by choice but we also wouldnt be opposed to eating here again if we had to.
i had the garlic tenderous rib ramen and that was ok, the beef wasnt particularly tasty. the tonkatsu broth was decent as was the ramen.
the beef stew however was way too salty. the beef stew itself seemed like it was over  seasoned and it made the broth too salty.
we got the free chicken karaage and it was nicely cooked. their menu has a lot of choices and from looking around, the dishes people ordered were pretty varied so maybe their other dishes are better.
author: Alex H.

description: I'm on a hunt to find the best Ramen around, and so far, this one definitely is up there among the greater ones. The girlfriend and I managed to catch them during an awkward hour, which was awesome, since we were starving and they usually get pretty busy. I ordered the premium pork rib with garlic soup, and my girlfriend order the standard Chashu ramen. Needless to say, we were both impressed with the place. It had a great vibe to it, the food was AMAZING and their rinks were pretty good too. This place is definitely a gold mine for great Ramen, so enjoy yourself my fellow eaters!
author: Michael N.

description: Great variety and quality of food available. A nice neighborhood spot to get some good ramen. I had the curry tonkatsu ramen with the FREE croquette (when you check in via yelp) which was very good. Also got a taste of the chicken karaage and the pork fried rice. Loved the smokey flavor of the fried rice. Will definitely hit up this place another time.
author: LL T.

description:
Just finished two terrible playoff games and was looking to walk down the street to Brothers, when one in the group said, "Hey, what about this place?"  I was mildly hungry but, moreso, it was friggin' cold and the pictures of soup in the window beckoned.  So we go in.

Cute little place with TVs and good music playing at a decent level in the background (Estelle/Kanye, Alicia Keys/HOVA, Rihanna, you get the idea).  Two of our five ordered the ramen, but I ordered the clam garlic broth (yummers), a side order of kimchee (not too spicy, very tasty), and the salmon kama.  All told, I was very satisfied.  Even the salmon kama, despite not having much meat at all, was still flavorful.  For 4 bucks, it was a worthy taste.

Since this is in the hood, I'll check it out on the next weeknight where it's cold outside and I feel like soup.
author: Tamar D.

description: If you want fast food ramen then this place is for you. I've tried most of the popular bay area ramen places and this one is on the bottom of the list. I ordered the ramen with ribs and the Tan Tan ramen. Both were not very good. The ramen with ribs had more bones than meat. The Tan Tan ramen was overly salty. Will probably come back if someone invites me to.
author: Harrison V.

description:
I feel like Genki Ramen tries to stand out with their "hipper" atmosphere. Actually, it's a kind of technique that has been employed a bit in Japan, where some of the newer ramen places want to break away from the no-frills, in and out, salaryman kind of ramen experience. It's fine I guess, it's just that it doesn't give off that homey vibe that I associate with eating ramen.

Genki Ramen looks pretty fancy through the windows for a ramen place. I'd think they're trying to get in on an upscale Japanese food market, but if they're going to have ramen in the name, they better do it well. So I tried their standard chashu ramen recently and they did it very well! I felt it was a little small (smaller than some of my favorite ramen hangouts), but the taste was up there in my book. I made sure to finish up my entire bowl, even the broth, which is a great sign for taste. I'd like to come back here and try some of their more non-standard ramen.

They also seem to hype up their curry ramen quite a bit. I haven't found a place yet that does curry ramen, so I think that in itself will merit a second visit. And yes, they've got okonomiyaki here! Another reason to come back again.

I'm also a big fan of the multiple TVs. I love television!
author: Roland C.

description:
This is hard for me to write.. because up until this Saturday, I would've given this place 4 stars.
3-4 stars is earned by the food, it's comfort food for me. I've had the okonomiyaki (all kinds except with ramen), takoyaki, chashu, onigiri, and a few other things. Probably have been here at least 6 times in the past 2 years. The food overall deserves a 3.5, the chashu is horrible, the onigiri is great but overpriced, the okonomiyaki is jackpot and reminds me of the ones I've had in osaka, and the takoyaki  was tasty but had a little too much ginger and not enough tako (octopus) in it. So overall pretty good.

But this last Saturday, the service was so bad I had to write about it:
1 - delayed seating, there were 3 of maybe 12 tables being used...
2 - they had a sign out for help in the kitchen.. which could explain the following ones.
3 - One of the members of our table never got a napkin or a pair of chopsticks.
4 - our water was never refilled
5 - fortunately the conversation was distracting, but we had to ask the waitress wth happened with one of the orders and it ended up coming out 15 minutes after the others (and it was a yakisoba dish too!!)!!! (we had to wait on him to eat).
6 - we ordered wine and the glass came with a dried up crusted carrot on the inside of it - it was half an inch long so don't tell me a waiter pouring out wine wouldn't have spotted it!!
7 - we were never asked about our meal or whether it was what we ordered.

Now I know 'real' Japanese restaurants don't pester you all the time at your table.. but this is no "real" Japanese restaurant - AND I've had good decent unobtrusive service here before - it's one of my favorite places.

But my experience on Saturday left me pretty unhappy, so much so that I didn't give my usual 20% tip..  I might give these guys the benefit of the doubt and head back once more since I live so damned close to it.. but I was greatly disappointed.

Genki ramen, you better get your waiters to shape up, or I'll go find my comfort food elsewhere!
author: Acid B.

description:
Late night dinner w/the brother! Still waiting on good ramen and this place is definitely a step up from my last adventure. 

Pros:
Open late
Great atmosphere/decor
CLEAN
Friendly staff

Cons:
Somewhat busy street
Limited parking

I ordered the butter & corn ramen, brother had the seafood ramen, and an order of spicy mussels.
The bowls were not ridiculously huge like other places. So that wasn't as overwhelming. The broth on mine was really flavorful.  I loved it.  The mussels were ok, not the best. Staff are Thai but still know good Japanese comfort food. Extremely nice staff :)
author: Lola D.

description:
so we decided to do a genki night. go to genki ramen and then genki for crepes and dessert.  i think both places must be owned by chinese people actually.  genki serves egg puffs which are hong kong street snacks.  pearl tea a taiwanese thing.  anyways this review is about genki ramen.  the place is unlike a traditional japanese restaurant.  flat screens all around and kind of a modern decor.

right when we sat down they brough tea.  the waitress didnt speak english very well but she was very attentive.  we were hungry so we ordered some snacks to munch on.  the robata is per stick and you need to tell them how many you want.  i ordered shishamo and there was just one.  but it was good.  i also had the common seaweed salad.  they also give pickles which are kind of chinese.

for mains i had the chashu ramen and okonomiyaki to share with the bf.  the chashu ramen was good.  the soup wasnt too thick or salty and i could actually drink it!  the egg of which we only got half was a soy sauce egg.  the okonomyaki was hot and good as well.

their menu has a lot of choices.  even their ramen is on the "fusion"y side.  not the traditional types.  shoyu miso etc.  but mabo tofu, curry etc.  they also have robata or grilled items, fried items and okonomyaki.
author: claudia y.

description:
For some reason I didn't wanna like this place, but it hasn't given me any reason to, which is a good thing! Something about it keeps me going back. Their okonomiyaki is actually really tasty along with their takoyaki, its already hard enough to find a place that even has that. 

donburi was not what I had expected though...I thought donburi was suppose to have egg on top of the rice. I ordered a fish donburi, but no egg...sadness, I was really looking forward to that egg.

Their ramen is no tanpopo but its still
author: Calvinn W.

description:
This place deserves a zero. Why you ask?

When the feeling's not that nice, and you have to flush it twice:  
Diarrhea, diarrhea. 

When your stomach really hurts, and you know that it's the squirts:
Diarrhea, diarrhea. 

Been here 3 times. Each time, the squirts. no joke. Don't go on a date, or before an important meeting. FAIL.
author: Randy K.

description: I forgot to review this place!!  I definitely must say that this place still serves great food!  I just had the spicy yakisoba and it was absolutely delicious!  It consists of spicy sausage, kimchi and bacon.  Absolutely to die for!!  I also like the happy hour times.  It's still a bit on the pricey side outside of happy hour, but it's not a bad deal during happy hour times.
author: John H.

description: Genki is soooo good!! They have bowls you cant get anywhere else! The Curry used to be my favorite until they introduced the Tan Tan and the Negi Beef. One should try the new shrimp with spicy mayo they have, you wont be disappointed.MMMMMMMMM Genki I love you!
author: Toni T.

description:
Love coming here for Ramen because it's close. Had a birthday party here, everything went according plan and the food came out okay and everything. 

One of my friends had to wait a while for her order, but it came eventually. Paid about $15ish with tips and tax.
author: Milton Y.

description:
Of course as fate would have it, I didn't read the reviews before going and got the Ramen, because why? Well it's got Ramen in the title, so I figured that's their specialty. Bam, think again.. I love Curry. I so wish I would have tried the Curry, based on the reviews. 

The Ramen was just ok. I got Chosu Ramen. The broth was very bland, noodles were ok. I asked for some hot sauce, hoping to get some kind of Japanese Chili paste of some sort, and they brought me "Huy Fong Sriracha Chile Sauce," which is a Thai Chili sauce made by a Chinese company from Los Angeles. BUZZKILL...

Prices were fair and affordable, especially the Happy hour prices of $3 select drinks and appetizers from 3pm - 7pm.

Atmosphere is much above par from your typical Ramen shop, this place has more a classy izakaya feel to it. with custom chairs to boot.
author: Paul V.

description: My boyfriend and I have been here many times and we love it.  We go specifically for their veggie curry ramen bowl.  We love it! Every time we go to another restaurant for ramen we always say "its still not better than Genki Ramen".  Highly recommended!
author: Angel J.

description:
ordered this for takeout after a loooong day, and it totally hit the spot. i can pretty much only eat asian food at this point due to a milk allergy, and this was on the bf's list of places to try nearby (he is very good about respecting my cheeselessness, i'm going to treat him to a trip to a dairy farm someday). so we found a menu online, did some ordering, and chowed the fuck down!
 
you can order online, but the online order form is only good until 10:30 on a saturday night. thus ordering at 11:15 on a saturday night means you have to call it in and go pick it up yourself. however, using the online order form to compile your order worked well.

nice staff, from the little interaction i had with them. the order was correct and when i added a can of coke at the restaurant, the waitress asked me if i wanted a straw. I LOVE STRAWS. HOW DID SHE KNOW? boom, $6 tip for that right there.

now for the food:
vegetable yakisoba: so good! do i have to explain what it was? no, yalls know what yakisoba is.
bacon-wrapped asparagus: it's bacon (king of meats) and asparagus (lord of tall green veg), so of course it was delicious. we should have ordered two and for $2.95, i don't see why we did not. 
potato croquette: "it's basically a japanese hashbrown!", said the bf in wonder. it was delish.
vegetable tempura: no broccoli? oh well. still bomb. 
gyoza: good! wish it came with more dipping sauce though. 

their menu has an entire section labeled "deep fried dish", so yes, i will be back to finish at LEAST that portion of the menu.
author: Shannon C.

description:
On my quest to find the best ramen in NorCal, one to rival LA's Daikokuya, my friend suggest I try Genki Ramen. I arrived at lunch time with a group of four on a saturday, expecting it to be busy. I was shocked to see that the place was fairly empty. There were at least 5 tables open when we arrived. We waited for a table for about 7 minutes and were asked twice how many in our party, mind you there were a few right in front of us that we open. We sat down and waited for another 10 minutes for a waitress to give us tea or water, but no one came. The only time we ever got someone to come over was when we flagged them down. It took about 15 min after sitting to get our order in for food and drink, and this place is still half empty. When they did take our order they rushed us. It felt like she thought we were the ones taking all day to do anything. When the food came it was decent. the croquets were really good, light, fluffy, and really crispy as well as the fried chicken. They have fried food down to an art. The ramen was ok at best. I got the garlic tenderous rib ramen. The broth was flavourful but the noodles were lacking. the ribs were more bones than meat and the egg was over cooked, the yolk leaving a slight, dry, sandy feel in my mouth. 
Would have been 3 stars but the service leaves a lot to be desired, they should at least refill hot tea for customers, my mom never got hers. Work on customer service, 3 servers for that crowd should have been more than enough.
author: Brian J.

description:
Top 5 Reasons This place rocks:

1. Its open hella late
2. It has kick ass happy hour
3. They deliver
4. They play hip-hop and techno music
