5. The food is delicious, prepared fresh, you can see the kitchen, and I think they make the noodles fresh.

Okay number five was more like 6, 7, and 8 too but I love this place. Be sure to try the curry veggie ramen, ma po tofu spicy ramen, and the bomb skewers, especially the beef and green pepper one! Service is awesome and for desert they give you a free hi-chew!!! :)
author: M K.

description:
I've only really ordered from here because of the ease of ordering from grub hub and everyone was buzzing about the ramen. 

The food is pretty decent. I've had the curry dishes, ramen, tempura and a couple others. Everything was more like Just-OK as opposed to A-OK. Clean, good and a pretty large variety of options on the menu. I would recommend the ramen or the rice dishes. Not sure about all the other stuff.

All in all - I wouldn't go out of my way to go this to restaurant to eat but as a reliable delivery option - it does the trick!
author: Liz S.

description:
Great local place for all types of Ramen, especially on a cold rainy day. Lots of options and great prices. My favorite is the curry tonkatsu Ramen which is unique and delicious. Now you can have curry, tonkatsu, and Ramen soup all together! They also have a great green tea smoothie type drink. It's like a Japanese green tea ice cream dessert in liquid form. Yums!

Give it a try when you're in the area, you won't be disappointed.
author: Josephine L.

description:
I've been here a few times and I think their ramen is pretty decent.  My favorite is the kimchi ramen because the broth is more flavorful.

Came here again with my boyfriend yesterday and we ordered the kimchi ramen and the seafood Okonomiyaki (fried pancake thing).  The ramen came really quickly and we devoured that.  It took them another 5 minutes after that to bring us the Okonomiyaki.  I was all excited and cut into it only to find that it was not the seafood one that we ordered.  Our server took it away, apologized and said they'll remake it.

So we waited...and waited...and waited.  After about 15 minutes, she apologized for the long wait and gave us a Caramel Milk Tea on the house...which appeased me for a while.  The tea was very floral and tasted like it had jasmine in it (but apparently it's just regular black tea).  Anyway, another 10 minutes pass before our food finally comes.  I would've been really pissed if the pancake was not as delicious as it was (super crispy bottom with lots of veggies and seafood inside ~ yum!).

They really need to improve their service though (noticed they screwed up the orders for another table as well).  Service is usually pretty slow too...they need to hire more people to work the front and back.

Just a note - has anyone ever played Diner Dash?  Because the whole charade yesterday totally reminded me of that.  I was the hungry customer who was waiting impatiently for my food...getting angrier and angrier by the second.  So then our server (aka Flo in the game) gave us a drink to make me happy again.  Then I get angry again, so they rush to bring me my food and I'm a happy customer again (sort of).  LOL.
author: Katelynn L.

description: the ramen is pretty good here, but the broths could be a bit better and the noodle portions bigger. i usually get the mapo tofu ramen or the chicken karaage ramen, which comes with a good amount of karaage on the side. i usually can't finish it and get to take the rest of my chicken to go for a nice little snack later :) they also offer a small free appetizer if you check in!
author: Sabrina L.

description: Best ramen & tempura I've had since visiting Japan!! It was so good we went there two nights in a row!! Open late so stop on by for those late night ramen cravings!!!
author: Steph N.

description:
I love Genki Ramen. It's never really crowded either, which surprises me. 

Usually, I get the chicken karaage ramen which includes seaweed and corn. The soup is so savory and delicious.
author: Young Y.

description: This place used to have very good ramen. Not sure if they changed owners but it's far from good now. Got the chashu ramen but the broth was bland and they raised  their prices.
author: K M.

description:
The sign outside the restaurant misled me to think Genki Ramen would be a "hole in the wall" restaurant.  When I walked through the door, I was shocked to see how trendy the interior was.  Genki Ramen could be considered as a trendy ramen shop that actually offers great tasty food.  Most trendy restaurants I've been to have horrible food because they don't need to offer anything good except flatscreens, an urban look and alcohol.  Genki Ramen offers all that and excellent food.  

Once you are seated, you will notice all the flat screen HD televisions on the walls.  Also, the venue is very trendy with "cool" place settings.  The chopstick holders were pretty cool.  Our waitress seated us immediately and gave us menus to review.  We both decided on the Beef Teriyaki Sizzling Platter, which was delicious!  The beef was tender and not overcooked and the vegetables were very fresh.  

The only complaint I would have is that the service was not that great.  It took us awhile to grab someone's attention to receive refills on water.  The prices are reasonable, the venue is clean and trendy and a nice young crowd patrons this restaurant.  I'll be here again, you can count on that.
author: Manton R.

description:
If it looks cleans and it smells cleans... it is really clean! I spotted the 100 point inspecton card.

Not really authentic but they try so hard.  A for effort and A for gizzard and the okonomiyaki is pretty good.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I came here with some friends from college and it was great! We got there around 6:45 and noticed that happy hour ended at 7 so we ordered our drinks and settled down to look at the menu. Our drinks came and we all ordered. I got the veggie curry noodles (dry, not in broth) and it was delicious. The only gripe I have with this dish is that the tofu tasted a lot like butter. What's up with that? Was it bad, or was it doused in butter?

The chicken karage is also delicious. 

Awhile back I also tried their curry noodles (with I think beef?) in broth. It was really good. Both of my experiences here were great and I would definitely come back. At around 7:30, we knew happy hour was over but asked our waitress anyway if we could still order drinks on "happy hour" price and she was totally cool with it... so another round for all of us! 

Good atmosphere and great location along the strip of bars on Geary. Definitely try this place!
author: Christina B.

description: This place has great ramen and the service is decent. I'm also a huge fan of their hours, since they open late and it's a great place to hit up after bar hopping or coming back from a drunken night of clubbing. They also deliver (I usually ordered through Grubhub), but it takes a little while for the food to arrive so give yourself some time when you decide to order. From experience, I can say that ordering from them through Grubhub when you're starving is really not the way to go; give yourself at least an hour before you'll have some awesome ramen on your table.
author: Gloria Z.

description:
My BF and I doubled dated with another couple friend on Monday. Here's the skinny on this place.

Happy hour - $3 draft beers and $3 appetizers. The beer came out in a 10 oz glass, so it really isn't worth it to drink here. Appetizers... ehh... we had the chicken karage, which tasted good and came out in good portions to share. We also tried the gyoza, but it tasted like a typical frozen dumpling from the supermarket. Overall happy hour experience was just ehhh. 

On to the ramen. I had the curry tonkatsu and added corn for $1. Hearty portions, but I could taste the MSG tingling my mouth at the end of the meal. I think it would have tasted better if I ordered the spicy miso like my BF and our other friend did. They seemed to enjoy their soup much better. Ramen noodles were standard, nothing special about it, yet nothing horribly wrong either. 

Genki is just an average place. Is it bang for your buck? Yes, unless you decide to order beer and extras on your ramen. 

Service was good and attentive. Parking was fine, we were lucky to score a metered spot in front of the restaurant.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
poor service!! 
i have been waiting about an hour for my online order, guess what? they didnt check any order from their online order system! ! Untill i called them to check my order, the only reason which they gave me was "i miss your order from online, could you wait for another 50 mins to get your order"?!! what? !! That means i have to wait like 2 hours to get my "DELIVERED FOOD" ?i know it happened before, why dont you just remove the online order service? i know its only 4 blocks to my house, i know i was a fan of your ramen,  but it doesn't mean that you can ignore my order without apology.!!!  That's your customer service! Good!!
author: Iris c.

description:
Everybody likes to eat healthy. I like to eat tasty. Looks like now I get both.

It's no understatement that there are a multitude restaurants to choose from on Geary, especially in the Avenues. Ramen and Japanese cuisine abounds in this city, but this is the first noodle shop to make their dishes (or should I say bowls?) stand out. I'd even place them ahead of my dining expereinces in Japantown.

The restaurant itself is sleek, stylish and simple, with hardwood floors, dark lacquered tables and chairs, and LCD flatscreen TVs lining the walls and playing JPop music videos. The bar to the right side carries a posh decorum,  and in the back you can see into the kitchen through the plate glass windows. This is a fun activity to do while waiting to use the zen styled bathrooms.

The girlfriend and I came here for a late lunch after moving her into the new apartment. It was something of a whim, and a pleasant surprise was in store for us. Selecting the curry chicken and chicken ramen entrees, we were first present with tea, and an appetizer of miso soup and a small salad. When the entrees arrived, the portions were massive, filling, and delicious. The broth was delicate and savory, not too salty like many places. The noodles strong, firm and distinct, and the chicken adding well to the bowl without overpowering. The gyoza side was an excellent addition. The whole meal left me feeling full, happy and refreshed. 

Even better, our two dishes together and drink cost us under $20 (the girlfriend returned for dinner on a weekday night and the price was slightly higher, though.) From now on, I know where I'm going for my ramen dining. Just most likely on a Sunday.

Genki desu ka?
author: Keith M.

description:
Yes, the decor is much to be desired and the music will make you feel like you're trapped in your Korean teenage cousin's basement party, but it's still pretty awesome.

I don't care about what anybody says: my BF and I LOVE this place. It's one of our regular go-to's for a casual dinner out. I actually rarely get the ramen but enjoy the skewers and eating a variety of little nummy plates. 

Oh, and do yourself a favor: order the strawberry smoothie. You deserve it.
author: YCat T.

description: The food are pretty good. I order the kimchi ramen with spicy miso added to it. The miso makes the soup really salty but it's still tasty. The only reason why I gave 3 star was the server that was a little bit sloooowwww.
author: fenny g.

description: Like Katana-YA, but little to no wait. The seafood ramen is de-lish! Great bargain for a huge amount of food. Ramen will run you about $8-$9. The miso broth was very good, almost refreshing, if hot broths can be refreshing.
author: Shira O.

description:
It's Japanese food gone wrong, but good. Nothing tastes like how it should in a traditional Japanese restaurant, but it's all for the best!

I want to give this place five stars but I can't because the chicken karaage tasted like Popeye's chicken. Batter-lovers would like it, but I prefer actual meat. The appetizers and small dishes such as the squid and the gyoza were just okay. I don't think I would order them again.

What's definitely worth trying here is the house specialities and the ramen. The ramen was good - nothing special, but still good. I actually like the other dishes more. They have their own version of okonomiyaki (Japanese pancake) - seafood, vegetables, or bacon with cheese (???) - and it's served on a sizzling clay plate. The fried rice had the right amount of moistur. Yum.

As for sweets, my friend really liked her matcha shake. The milk tea with caramel was not bad. Green tea sundae with azuki, yum. Their creme brulee, like everything else, doesn't taste like it should, but I still like it. It's thicker, kinda like custard which I love.

The decor is hip, modern, and most importantly, clean! Oh, and I really liked their restroom sink - made out of glass.

Most importantly, the restaurant closes at 2am on the weekends. Finally, a Japanese restaurant open past midnight.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: I got the butter and corn ramen. It wasn't that great.
author: Melanie F.

description:
So Shiny! So NEW!  Genki Ramen isn't a quaint lil' ramen shop. Flat screen tv's w/Japanese variety shows blare on three walls, the furnishings are very geometric-chic.  The utensils, plates, bowls and hella tall glasses are all swank.  I wanted to steal their soup spoons.

The pictures looked better than the actual stuff though.  We got the gyozas, the seafood okonomiyaki, and Berna got the curry tonkatsu ramen while I went w/the chasu ramen.  We both liked the our noodle bowls - good broth, ramen was chewy enough without being mush, and served up LARGE.  The lazily wrapped 'gyozas' were served with a sweet black vinegar-y sauce, were pretty good, too. But the okonomiyaki came out on its own sizzling platter, loaded w/all sorts of toppings: bonito flakes, scallions, teriyaki sauce...mayo?!?!  In it was some squid, shrimp and imitation crab. Ehhh.  They had so much on their flavors-of-asia menu, that I'd give the benefit of the doubt that they have other dishes that I probably would've liked more.

One definitely cool thing are the fun fusion cocktails in those tall glasses they've got going - Berna had a "So Cool" cocktail that was soju and Yakult - it was so good that even I risked a sip. MMM.  
Staff was eager but confused, double teaming us at times, then forgetting us at others. I'll be back when they've had a little longer to work out some kinks. For now, 3.5 stars.
author: CINDY K.

description: It's all right. Not great. Not terrible. Not sure I'd go here when there are other better options in the neighborhood... but again, not terrible.
author: Al Y.

description:
4.5 out of 5.

Went there for the second time the other night with a friend.  Honestly, I don't know anything about ramen except for the 10 cent kind you get with the little packet of MSG.

This was NOT that.  It was awesome.  

I had Shrimp tempura with a hearty bowl of ramen aaaaaand green tea ice cream.  I was still hungry afterwards, but I think that's because I eat like a horse.

Staff was attentive and courteous.  

Only random issue was a cold draft blowing on us as we sat against the wall, but that is probably only an issue when it's 38 degrees in SF, which just happened to be the night we went.  Don't judge them on that one please.

Great spot.  

LV
author: Lawrence V.

description:
Corn and Butter ramen...who woulda thought? 

It's pretty good stuff for a windy, foggy night. The flavors combined were hearty, sweet and slightly creamy. I'd definitely order it again!
author: kristin e.

description: I am big fan for a Ramen.. They gave me "Tan-Tan Ramen" with miso base soup adding hot oil that's it... that's Not Tan-tan Ramen.. the noodle texture just like instant noodle, and the noodle takes up the soup although done in cooking process. And the worst thing I was very thirsty after eat here.. the MSG was play role on this for sure. Sorry I'm not going back. If you're Ramen hunter.. this is definitely not a ramen place to go.
author: Vischa S.

description: Can't believe I have been walking past here for two years without trying it! My girlfriend loved the curry infused ramen, and I haven't had Okonomiyaki this good since I was in Japan.  I went for the vegetable Oko, and will go back soon for their seafood one. Chairs are comfortable here as well and staff friendly.
author: Aaron R.

description: This is the place to go when you need a warm ramen to soothe your taste of a Japanese dish.Prices are reasonable but the bowl of ramen are getting smaller each time I come and visit them. I will still recommend it to my friends. Friendly staff and attentive refilling your cup of tea and water.
author: Aries G.

description:
Genki Ramen is hella JANKI. I ordered the Chasu Ramen and sampled 2 other Ramens, Kim Chi and another one that I can't remember the name..

The Kim Chi was ok, but the broth had a tin taste to it.  Also for some reason, the kim chi in the noodles tasted very Chinese.  I really don't know how else to describe it.

My other friend had a very simple one, clear broth, but you can taste that the noodles were not well rinsed, leaving a powdery cake taste in her soup.

The Chasu that I ordered was probably the best out of the 3 noodles. Unfortunately the taste of the broth was tainted with canned bamboo shoots that left a funny taste in my mouth.

stinky tofu
author: StinkyTofu S.

description: Didn't get the ramen since I just had ramen at lunch at Ramen Underground. Got the yakitori and the yakisoba. They were both just so so. Nothing to write home about. My BFF got the scallop and fried chicken which were just ok... scallops seemed kinda overcooked. watermelon juice was good tho. maybe i'll be back for the ramen... not sure tho...
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I'm not sure why people aren't giving this place that much credit.  its actually pretty good.  the selection is good, and the price is reasonable.  I'm not sure if you can choose which nooodles, but the one i had for lunch was pretty standard.

Iono why, but I tend to have a thing for curry katsu (check my review for Curry House) and over noodles.  well that's what i got here with a side of chicken karage for $1 more.  pretty good i think.  Lunch menu goes until 5pm too so its cool.  Tricky on the Happy Hour with the $3 SMALL beer.   small is like smaller than a can i think.  

overall, my ramen was a little on the hard thicker side, but that might be what its all about.  it didn't stick to my teeth, so it was well cooked.  the venue itself was pretty impressive, kinda classier than expected when I've passed by this place so many times in the past.  I'll never hate on this place agan.  Definitely will be back!
author: Vincent K.

description: Love the Chicken Curry Catsu Ramen.... the Matcha Green Tea shake is the BOMB! Been here 4 times already and each time has been a GREAT food experience!
author: Ann Y.

description:
Personally I think everything here is a bit too salty but they don't mind if you mix in a cup of hot water with your noodles to bland it out a bit. The Happy Hour deals are good  though :)

The service is really accommodating & polite and everything (including the bathroom) is REALLY clean.
author: Van C.

description:
Ehhh it does the job.  The ramen is okay... I've been here twice, and both times, the ramen was hot and the soup was tasty, but its nothing spectacular.  I ordered the cha siu ramen which came with the normal fixings (spinach veggies, egg).  The meat was pretty good, but I wish it came with more.  The second time I went, I had the corn.  It was really plain like they just opened a can of corn and threw it in. 

The appetizers are just okay too.  The pot stickers are similar to the costco microwavable ones and their special beef rolled mushroom was not good at all.  I ate about half of those and left the rest on the table.  Again, this place is not that scrumptious as I would have liked, but it did the job.  

*nom nom*
author: Steve H.

description:
Toro E is very accurate about the chashu ramen, I'll just re-summarize
ambiance lounge-ish
noodles pre-packaged
broth tasty, less oily, but not as good as katana ya
chashu quite tasty, onion/bamboo good, salted flavored egg good
skip the takoyaki
author: Rob C.

description: My colleague said this place was good and recommended it. I ordered the shrimp tempura ramen which came with fish cakes. I opted out for the fish cake and added a whole egg instead. The ramen was nothing special. The broth tasted bland tho. And hardly had any garnishes in it. My bowl was somewhat filling, but only because I had to add more protein then it came with. My tempura which I thought was shrimp only, ultimately came out to be shrimp and vegetable tempura. Even tho the menu had said shrimp tempura... hmmm... The place is nice tho. Don't get me wrong. Its pretty fusiony for an Asian place. I don't know if I would come back tho. It just didn't thrill me all that much.
author: Nathalie N.

description: This restaurant is a very chill spot in the Richmond. It has a modern, hip look you would not expect. The food shares the same culture with a variety of choices all plated nicely. I really enjoy the fact they offer a plethora of dishes besides ramen and the dishes I had were all  executed well. The Japanese seafood pancake is very unique and something nice to have to go along with the ramen. Ramen is not the best compared to pure ramen houses but still very good. I also did some bottle service with some Sake which hit the spot nicely.
author: Ed L.

description:
Pretty Damn Good ramen and gyoza. Good Tonkostu soup base and good firm noodles. A little out the way but a good place for lunch if you're near by.

Wanted to try the okonomiyaki but they don't have it on the lunch menu.
Love the interior, the kitchen is located in the back in full view of everyone. 

The J-pop videos can get very annoying but the food more than makes up for it.

I'll definitely be back for some good "rammin'"

~uhuh~
author: Tak H.

description:
This place sure has a lot of flat screen televisions. They are on every single wall. Also, it seems like everything in this restaurant was custom made for them. Everything down to their chairs and barstools which have "GENKI" carved in the backs of them. Man, it would suck if they had to change their name.

My chashu ramen was pretty typical, but a good typical. The sizzling noodles are pretty tasty! Quick, competitively priced deliciousness.

And since Genki is so close to many different bus lines (33, 38, etc) you really have no excuse not to try it!
author: Richard T.

description:
Holy crap, I found a new ramen place.  Broth and noodles are top notch.  Meat could be better.  Service was OK, but food came out quick.  We also ordered Okonomiyaki, which I was skeptical of, but it came out hot on the griddle thing and was thick and full of seafood.  Very tasty, not the best, but tasty nonetheless.  I think they might have overcooked it a bit.  The reason I was skeptical was because I am use to making my own okonomiyaki (this is what they do in Japan, like  Korean BBQ style), so you can determine the crispyness of the product.

The kitchen is like an exhibition style Chinese kitchen where you can see the cooks do their thang.

Nice interior design work...cheap, but well thoughtout and lots of plasma TV's.  The damn Jpop they play was driving me crazy though.  To think, I use to like that crap when I lived in Japan.

They have an impressive selection of cheap sake too!  This is a convenient place for a quick ramen fix.
author: Hodie K.

description:
My favorite ramen place in the city.  When my friend first brought me here, I came here to eat 3 times a week!

The Place:
Nice and cute.  Small restaurant so have to wait sometime.

The Staff:
Attentive.

The Food:
Love the food here.  Always get the curry chicken katsu ramen.  And the lamb skewers are VERY tender and tasty.
author: Derek W.

description:
I really liked the food - we went here because it's the exact same name as the place i took my friend to in Hawaii *Genki Ramen!*  cept they have a gyoza happy hour with free gyoza.  

I'd never heard of Pork Tonkatsu Ramen before - and aside from the fact that pork tonkatsu is an oxymoron and that tonkatsu IS pork katsu it was really very good.  Curry was good, tasted great.  I'd like to say though that they did have some very weird things there on the menu.  But all - together not a bad meal. 

But i guess if you're a purist you'd say different.  I disagree with saying that it's actually japanese because some of the things they serve there are unlike anything i've ever seen in any Japanese restaurant in Hawaii...   and distinctly not actually japanese.
author: jacqui w.

description: I genki ramen's lunch menu it $7.50 or something like that and $1 more for a appetizer. The ramen was good. But I didn't really the fried chicken thing.
author: M L.

description:
Was pretty disappointed with my Chashu Ramen. I'd say about 2.5 stars, but have to round it down due to overall dissatisfaction.

Cute, modern, clean decor with a plasma TV playing Japanese music videos. The staff was extremely efficient in preparing my to-go order of Chashu Ramen ($8.95), consisting of "house made boiled pork w/half boiled egg, bamboo shoot and green onion."

I got it home and liked the fact that the noodles/pork/egg were packaged separately from the broth. I ordered miso broth rather than the one it usually comes with, based on a friend's recommendation.

I poured the broth over the noodles in a large bowl and pulled apart the chopsticks. As I dug in, I was immediately disappointed with the quality of the meat. It was extremely fatty (and the type of fat that is laced through the meat so you can't really just pull it off). The bamboo shoots were bland and chewy, and the pickled egg had a funny flavor to it. The noodles were alright, but the broth was extremely salty. I barely ate about half...

Eh.
author: Jill M.

description:
I was excited to learn that Genki (not to be confused with the crepe place on Clement) existed... I was craving me some ramen today!

We arrived there shortly after 7PM and there were three other people there. The decor was quite upscale for a ramen place... tones of muted green and deep brown were dominant in their modern-looking furnishings, with flat panel TVs showcasing Japanese pop music droned on in the background.

We both had a chashu ramen which was excellent. Thick broth, al dente noodles, bamboo shoots, scallions and a shoyu egg. Four slices of chashu made me a happy camper.

We also had the unagi tempura, which was good (when it was set down on the table, the BF said it smelled like cookies!), but I think it was a little too much food for us.

The bill didn't kill us at all. $38 after tip for the two of us... appetizer, two ramen bowls, one large Sapporo. Service was a bit slow, but we were fine with it tonight since we were in a food coma.

It started getting a bit more populated in the dining room right before we left. I think we hit it at just the right time, and we'll definitely go back.
author: Courtney P.

description: Great ramen noodle place, and a convenient location. The menu is large, and everything seems to be great. Maybe I haven't tried enough places, but it's also probably the only place I've been to that serves hot sake.
author: Zach H.

description:
For a place that's called Genki Ramen, you would think that ramen would be their signature dish. Maybe I'm spoiled because Santa Ramen is 5 min from my work, but I found their ramen so-so. The noodles were alright, but the broth lacked intensity of flavor. It's not alone, though... All the ramen I've tried within the San Francisco city limits have been totally subpar. 

I had seafood okonomiyaki and I enjoyed that a lot. The portion's pretty big, and it came in a sizzling platter, with a metal spatula-looking thing that you cut with. Gyoza was ok. Next time I go, I'd like to try the robatayaki. Overall, I'd say the food is slightly overpriced.

The decor is very trendy Japanese. Lots of plasmas on the walls showing (usually quirky) Japanese programming. The service was OK. They forgot our water, but other than that, I have no complaints.

There are few places like this in the Richmond district, however, so I would definitely go back, since it's in my neck of the woods.
author: Bekki J.

description:
About a week ago, I went to see Beowulf in IMAX 3D.  This was an awesome way to see the movie.  ("I am ripper, tearer, slasher...I am BEOWULF!")  After two hours of digital violence, lust, and glory, what should every red blooded Man do to follow it up?  What meal screams manhood and strength?  Noodles.  I should have just gone flower picking instead because that was more masculine than eating noodles.

Anyway, I can only blame myself for demeaning my masculinity by visiting Genki Ramen after "Beowulf."  Seriously though.  Can you imagine Achilles eating noodles?  How about Hercules?  Maybe King Leonidas?  Nope, nope, and nope.  In a vain attempt to reclaim some of my broken masculinity, I ordered the seafood yakusoba.  Those are fried noodles served on a hot skillet.  Fried = Real Man.  Skillet = Real Man.  It was excellent, and it came in a Hungry Man sized portion.  We also ordered the fried appetizer.  Not tempura mind you...FRIED.  When Genki says fried on the menu, they mean FRIED.  Like as in keep your nitro glycerin tablets close by level fried.  Also excellent.  

What I really do not like about Genki is that the actual restaurant looks like a video game.  Way too colorful and loaded with flat panel televisions.  The ladeez all know that we dudes are going to look at the shiny screen no matter what.  It was like the display wall at Best Buy.  Genki needs to tone it down.
author: Chris I.

description:
I have only been here twice (I know a good reviewer tries it at LEAST three times and gets something different each visit), but I can safely say that this is a goooood spot. Each time I went, I ordered the butter and corn ramen with sliced pork and fish cake. My boyfriend and I also ordered the scallops, which I didn't like very much because they were tough and not as juicy as I've had at other places. The place is open pretty late (11pm on weeknights and later on weekends), but the parking can be a hassle, depending on when you go. Also, the service was a bit slow at the end of the meals (both times). But, whatever is ailing your tender heart will be lifted away once you dive into some delicious and comforting ramen. The prices are also very reasonable (two entrees, an appetizer, and tea came out to $32 WITH the tip).

Overall, a fun experience and the perfect meal after a hard day at school and work.
author: Lizzy C.

description:
I like the ramen at Genki Ramen. It might not be very authentic, but it satisfies on a cold windy day. My best friend and I came here for lunch and they have lunch specials up until 5pm which are reasonable. I ordered the butter and corn, and she had the veggie stir-fry one with vegetable broth. Both of us had nothing but good things to say about the ramen, and it was so delicious that my pal "wished there were more noodles." I've also had the Chasu one which was yummy as well.

The decor is also very cute and modern, with flat screen tv's along the walls and cute bar stools for seats. Genki Ramen is open until 1am on Fridays and Saturdays for the late night drinkers and honestly, if I was hungover and was able to walk to get some noodles, I'd be here every week.

Every friend I've brought here likes the ramen, from vegetarians to straight carnivors.
author: Vanessa T.

description:
I've spent 3 years living in Japan, thus I'm a pretty picky diner when it comes to Japanese food, and especially Ramen since I love Ramen.

We ordered gyoza, chicken okonomiyake, and 2 bowls of ramen each (kimchi ramen and tonkatsu curry).

The gyoza was a unique shape/style, only one-side pan fried.  Overall 3.
The okonomiyake was the saving grace of the meal, very good.  If I returned to Genki, I'd get this.
The ramen overall was just average.  The noodles were too thick, the soup not distinct enough, that chashu wasn't that tender.  The tonkatsu was very good actually, but overall as a ramen, disappointing.  

I'm still looking elsewhere for the best bowl of ramen.
author: Neil P.

description:
I enjoyed this meal very much, possibly because of how generous they are with the sake.  The ramen was excellent, flavorful and filling - my only gripe was with the egg - why was it soaked in creepy sauce?  The white was brown and tasted a little bit gross with a very strange texture.  The pork was tender and plentiful, with lots of chewy connective tissue, nomnom.

Still - my dining companion, along with sneaking half my sake had the unagi tempura which was astoundingly delicious.  They've found a way to make unagi better, I'm impressed!

Although Noodlequest I: Ramen is officially over, this place is a definite contender!
author: Frankie D.

description: I had the spicy tofu ramen here. The noodles and broth are both pretty good but nothing remarkable. The sesame chicken wings here are tasty though. Service is friendly and fast!
author: Meesh N.

description: This is the best ramen place in the city that i have come across thus far. i usually order the ramen with chicken karaage, i cant have ramen without my fried chicken nuggets. the staff is friendly and the place is nice and the prices are fairly priced.
author: Darnell L.

description: Although I have yet to try the ramen, I've tried quite a few of their grilled food and it's pretty good. We got there a little before 10 and they had a late night special which is slightly cheaper than ordering the items separately so if you don't like all the items that it comes with, it really isn't worth getting the combo. The only thing is that everything is super small and although I'm not a big eater, the combo wasn't enough for me. I also ordered the fondue for dessert and although it was cute and tasty, it wasn't worth the $8. You are much better off going to the melting pot for dessert fondue. Other than that, I'll be back!
author: Diane M.

description:
I'm a 6'2 215lbs young japanese american male that lives for ramen.  A night after a 200 dollar bar tab and a mild hangover calls for either a burrito from santa cruz or ramen.  

Everytime I took a bite, a slurp, a taste, a sniff, a lick, a swallow, a breathe, a look, all I could think to myself was WHY DIDN'T YOUR LAZY ASS MAKE AN EFFORT TO GO TO HIMAWARI OR SANTA RAMEN????  

Noodles, nice smell to the noodles, but lacked chewyness.  Chashu lacked fattyness and was dry, egg was ok, too much green onions, bamboo was ok, but the most important part to ramen, the soup was horrible.  I'm generally a nice guy, but Genki ramen should seriously reconsider the ingredients and preparation of their tonkotsu soup base.  It was bland and the carelessness was obvious from the intial taste of tonkotsu which faded within seconds from my palate.   

I must go satiate my ramen craving next weekend at santa or himawari.
author: Tomo S.

description:
One Star. 

Ate here this weekend.  I am a ramen fan.

-The noodles were blah
-The broth was blah
-The pork tasted old and blah
-The waitress reached across our table to grab a menu for 10 seconds (The skinny Thai girl) - with her armpit in my face. I was like "What the fuck" ... so pissed.  There is no reason to reach across a customer's table when you can walk around to the other side and get what you need, dumbass!
-Appetizers (pumpkin and sweet potato tempura) oily and blah

I am a big guy... 6'1 230lbs, usually finish all my food.  I couldn't finish the appetizers and left a 10% tip for the lousy service.  They should have gotten ZERO tip for that move, or the waitress needs to learn American dining manners.

Fun atmosphere, nice interior, LCD's on every wall,  I won't be coming back.

If I am caught in that part of town again I'm going to Brother's Korean on the next block instead.  Maybe I won't have to suffer armpit torture.
author: D. T.

description:
I had consciously/unconsciously avoided this joint ever since it landed on Geary, as I've given up on the majority of Japanese-style restaurants in SF, especially those operated by Japanese and non-Japanese owners who don't give a rat's ass about the quality of food they serve.

So, I had very low expectations of Genki Ramen, especially since I went around 9:30PM on a slow Monday evening. Sheesh, talk about stacking the deck against myself! I hate going to restaurants when it's slow and near closing time, because kitchen staff typically are more focused on cleaning up the kitchen rather than their cooking. But due to some logistical issues I won't go into, I found myself in the restaurant, hungry and cold.

Well, since they have an exhibition kitchen, I could see all their moves. And they seemed to be focused on their cooking, thank gawd, as the last thing you want is errant splashes of Clorox in your broth.

I prefer my ramen noodles firm, so I specified that for kicks on my order. I chuckled to myself when I saw my server run into the kitchen to make the notation on my ticket. I suppose their order entry system doesn't account for noodle doneness. This was interesting, as the menu mentions in a footnote that you can specify the oil/fat content and the firmness of the noodle, which was a nice gesture suggesting that the restauranteur did some research into ramen.

At any rate, I had their #401, their chashu ramen, and it was decent. I avoided the other weird fusion ramen abominations (curry tonkatsu ramen WTF???), deciding to go for something much more pedestrian. I also skipped on the various toppings that were on offer like corn and extra chashu.

The slices of chashu had a nice sweet, ginger soy marinade taste, but it was a bit on the salty side. It probably sat in the stewing liquid for too long. Same goes for the shoyu egg as well.

Standard issue menma tasted fine. Their beni-shoga topping was straight from the jar. Standard foodservice stuff. No complaints there.

The soup seemed to be a tonkotsu style broth, light milky brown in color from the marrow and collagen that comes from hours of cooking down pork bones. Well, I'm assuming that. For I know, they're just serving up pre-made foodservice broth.

At any rate, the broth was served nice and hot. Perfect foil for a cold evening. The slices of scallions added a nice kick to the proceedings.

The noodles came out firm as requested. Nice. They tasted fine. Not too eggy or day-glo yellow like noodles you see sometimes in other establishments.

The portion size seemed a bit small, but not too small. I'll have to ask if I can order extra noodles next time. Don't recall seeing the option on the menu tho'.

All in all, it wasn't as bad as I thought. Especially if you are drunk and craving something hot, salty and oily. Definitely a better option in my book than a slice of 'za from Nizario's up the street.

I would go on a limb to say that Genki's ramen is probably better than the offerings at Halu, Katana-Ya, Oyaji, or Tampopo. At $9, it's not a bad deal.

But then again, that's like picking the lesser of all evils ramen-wise in San Francisco.

I think I'll come back again and check out the other goodies on their menu.
author: Bono B.

description:
I love the Genki brand.  Even if they served ham sandwiches, id at least have to give it a try. 

This place was pretty much like any place you'd find in a japantown ramen house.  Good quality food and nice decor. Not exactly cheap, but dont let that stop you. 

I am definately coming back. Open till 2! I foresee my Nizario's Pizza consumption to fall because of this. How bout my Genki Crepe intake? Now you're just comparing apples and oranges. 

Just eat here, genki people! then go get a genki crepe! genki genki genki! I love saying that word.

Later, genki bitches
author: Michael N.

description:
Err.., how should I start? Well.., the word GENKI supposed to have a positive effect, hence... GENKI RAMEN. However, that positive effect doesn't really go with this one. A good Ramen (well, even tho I am not Japanesse, but I appreciate food big time.., so trust me..)...has to have that succulent pungent broth, especially for the Chashu Ramen, GENKI RAMEN doesn't have that succulent pungent Chashu broth. It's blend, not so colorful (supposed to be yellowish creamy white-ish), and boring! So.., you know what it means...

But.., if you really want to go for Chashu Chahan..., then.., you can try the one in GENKI RAMEN.

The choice is YOURS!
author: Inne S.

description:
Tasty ramen though I felt the portion was on the smaller side compared to other ramen places in San Francisco. The broth flavor was on the mild side, but you have the option of adding soy sauce or chili sauce to spice it up a little. Affordable ramen. Beer selection kinda sucked so that takes away a star. Oh, and the tv's in the dining room really don't help the atmosphere, which looks pretty modern. 

I'll be back for more!
author: Foodie F.

description: good place to get a simple ramen, nice fatty pork and soup base, very little extra stuff with your soup.  A good staple place close to home.  I want to try their okonomiyaki and the other dishes next time - this place is cool also because it's related to genki crepes a few blocks away :).
author: Shinny L.

description:
I went there for my third time last night. Let me try to recall what I've had.

First time: butter and corn ramen-yummy! came with a little hunk of butter and when it melted it tasted pretty da** good. with the corn and everything. my friend and i also took advantage of the happy hour and each had a so cool for $3. she had a yasai ramen. i tried it and it was good, too. we found a coupon on their website and had a free gyoza. that tasted ok.

Second time: 2 so cools. one for me and one for my sister. by the way these, are yogurt flavored alcoholic drinks. this time it tasted a little more alcohol-y. i actually prefer the taste of alcohol masked amidst the sweet flavors, but it was still good. based on yelp reviews, i got a okinomiyaki(?), the seafood one. had about a quarter of it. just not used to the flavor. the sauce on top was sweet and i don't usually eat my entrees sweet, and mine was a bit burnt. but a good size. seems like something you would share while getting other entrees. my sister got a ramen, but thought other places she's had were better. then we also got a gyoza, which tasted ok and some other appetizers.

third time (last night): my friend said she likes okinomiyakis so she got the seafood one, and had some of my ramen. she said other okinomiyakis were better. she got a so cool. just tea for me this time. i got a garlic pork soft bone ramen. it was pretty good. we also had a coupon for free takoyaki, which actually tasted like the okinomiyaki to me with the sauce, but shaped like a ball and soft inside. we also got the squid tentacles. i think called geso age. a little too much breaded stuff for me. some parts seemed breaded with no squid parts within, but it tasted ok. and the meal ended with our check and (there's a diff kind of candy each time with the check) two pieces of Hi-Chew candy!

May come back since i keep knpwing people who want to try out the place, but i don't love it. i'll stick to my ramens and so cool.
author: Anita C.

description:
Having been back to Himawari a few days before, I suddenly had a craving for ramen yet again. However, I really didn't feel like driving to San Mateo again so we decided on here. Bad idea. Himawari. ALWAYS Himawari!

We came right before 7 (when happy hour ends) and the waitress was telling me all about the happy hour and whats on there. So we stuck with the Gyoza and fried squid tentacles. Gyoza was alright, nothing special, and the tentacles were just....fried squid tentacles. 

We also got the grilled onigiri which is basically a rice ball with eel on the inside, grilled and smothered in unagi sauce. It was alright but again, nothing special. 

I ordered the Chashu ramen and the gf ordered the seafood ramen. Both were pretty small portioned compared to Himawari. I had a generous helping of chashu and she had a decent portion of seafood, though her mussels were reportedly pretty sandy. The noodles had some texture to them but it just didn't have that "bounce back" that I expected. Broth was alright. I'll give them credit for not having globules of fat floating at the top like Himawari does, but at the same time, it does make me question the authenticity and the origin of the soup. 

Okonomiyaki was alright, good amount of seafood, lacking on the cabbage and was a bit underdone. 

In the end, the check came and we were charged full price for all the items, so when I addressed this to the waitress she argued with me that it was entered in the computer at 7:01 when I had ordered around 6:45, and had been told by the other waitress that these items were on happy hour rates. She was rude and argued back and forth until another waitress came and just told her to adjust the price. 

I don't even know if this place is Japanese owned or operated. Heck I'm not even sure if the chefs behind the window are even Chinese! All the waitresses spoke Thai and a good percentage of customers were Thai as well. Hmm...

Don't think I'll be coming back here again.
author: Derrick L.

description: I pass this place damn near everyday but was persuaded to check it out by neighbors. It's a very cute place that fits in well with the neighborhood: chic decor, affordable prices, and a very simple menu with wonderful offerings. I had the chicken teriyaki (boring, I know) and my girlfriend the chicken katsu (you can see why we date). The service wasn't anything to write home about, but the food, especially in decent portions, will probably give our "cheap night out" alternative King of Thai Noodle House II a run for its money. If you live in the Inner Richmond, I implore you to experience this place...especially for their very cool and affordable happy hour menu.
author: Rodney P.

description:
Great food.  Great Ramen.  I suggest the CURRY TONKATSU - it's deep fried pork, in a Curry (not usually fond of) Tonkatsu broth ramen dish.  

SOOOOO GOOOOD!!!! I had the Yasai too one time, when I was trying to eat vegitarian - this one... not so great.  BUT THE CURRY TONKATSU.... OOOH!!!
 I LOVE IT 
   I LOVE IT 
     I LOVE IT!!!!

Moderatly priced, great money well spent.  Beers and Sakes are very strong choices as well.  Kirin on Tap.  If you live near 4th and Geary or are in the Inner Richmond - GO HERE!  TVs on the Walls (mostly playing sports or Food Network - which always suprised me) : : :  then you can make your way to Abbey Tavern if they don't kick you out for NOT stealing a shot behind the bar... The bartender was drunk I think.   ANYWAYS ..... IT'S TONKATSU TIME!!!!!!
author: Steven S.

description:
Ever since I ate here last, I have been dreaming of going back. I want more! The rich, creamy broth. The hearty noodles. The meat! The vegetables!

This is the most solid Japanese style comfort food you can get, as far as I'm concerned. I only wish that it was closer to my house so I could eat here all the time. I'm seriously drooling right now as I type this, and even though I already ate dinner, I waaant it. ARRRG!!
author: Rachel H.

description: The food is barely eatable, and the service is so insultingly bad I will never give them my business again. It is as if this place does not want to make money. I predict another couple of years before it goes under.
author: Mary C.

description:
I came here with a couple of friends for dinner. I like their website and thought this place would be a cool place to hangout. It was ok but a little disappointed. I order fried noodles with chicken. A bit greasy and not that hearty. Not bad, just sort of bland. 
We came here on a Wednesday, so the place wasnt as lively as I expected. Decor was ok, a little cheezy. They have happy hour which was cool but ran out of one beer my friend tried to order.
Service half decent.
Overall, ok.
author: Leon C.

description:
I first tried this restaurant because a friend had suggested it and I am so happy she did! I have gotten several different ramen dishes and they were all great! I have gone back several times. However some of the other dishes have been hits and misses for me. If you are new to the restaurant I suggest trying the ramen dishes first.

Parking is difficult! So go at an off time (like really early) or be prepared to circle and park 2-3 blocks away ( or farther...)
author: Kikicoconuts R.

description:
I have been here twice already, the first time I tried their ramen and the 2nd time I had their okonomiayki.  The ramen was alright not the best, but decent enough.  Their seafood okonomiyaki was actually pretty good and I think that would be the only thing I get there.  The food wasn't horrible at all.  The only problem I have with them is that they AUTOMATICALLY add tip onto your bill even with a party of 5.  I find that pretty lame that I had to pay a 15% tip rate when the waitress only came to our table ONCE after the food was served.  I think people will tend to not see the tip part and will probably add more to their total for tip even though its already added on to the bill.  So I would suggest you carefully look at your bill before you pay.  

Did it become a law to automatically add tip onto the bill now?  when it comes to service and tipping I find it pretty shady...
author: Jess T.

description:
I hope my review will assist in food choice - I've only been here once, so my review will be based on that experience.

I walk in with two friends on a Saturday night around 6:45pm. We wait around the front for about 3 minutes and then are seated - wow! We got menus and tea as soon as we sat down. Everything on the menu is very affordable - even for a high schooler with a part time job!

I forgot what my friends ordered (mostly because I was too excited for my own order), but I ordered the spicy mabo tofu ramen. SO DELICIOUS. Maybe it's just because I'm a sucker for some good tofu, but man that was so good! 

The service was excellent and I love getting a hi-chew with our bill... I guess it's sort of a cushion for having to take my wallet out (I would like to reiterate that the food is very affordable - I'm just a cheapskate).
author: andy y.

description:
Ramen delivery!? Yes, please! Bonus - you can order the delivery online. Near zero interaction required. 
Have only ordered the ramen, but so very tasty. 

Delicious: 
Chashu - good standard with pork, and just the right amount of ginger  and the hard boiled egg is delicious due to its own personal soy sauce bath
Curry Chicken Katsu - their curry is delicious, and this one has fried chicken - why not!!!! 
Shrimp Tempura - fried shrimp, thank you! 
Kimchi - spicy chashu 
Nori - for the vegetarian in you 
Spicy Mabo Tofu - so very tasty, pork and tofu! 
Kinoko Mushroom - if you like mushrooms this is amazing 
Butter & Corn - BUTTER!!! 
Curry Veggie - Curry yum with fried tofu, the current favorite 
Curry Beef - again curry yum, bf's favorite 

Meh: 
Garlic Tenderous Rib - very flavorful, but too much gristle 
Beef Stew - very fatty pieces of meat 

Haven't tried... yet: 
Seafood 
Crab Leg 
Curry Tonkatsu 
Chicken Karaage 

So to sum up - I am a HUGE fan, ordering at least 2-3 times a month. Your order has to hit $20, so I always add on spinach, and the bf adds on extra ramen.
author: Janine L.

description:
This would be a good place to go if you were short on time and not particularly picky, but if I'm comparing it to other ramen and yakitori places that I've been to, there is just simply no comparison.

The Ramen noodles texture was decent, but what the ramen lacked in meat and vegetables was made up with an overabundance of salty and oily soup. 

As for the grilled yakitori items, they tried to be creative, but it just tastes like regular menu items, except it's on a stick. I walked by the kitchen and saw that they used a regular kitchen grill to verify my thoughts. There is a special grill and charcoal that is used for Robbato yakitori and it isn't used at this place.

I gave it two stars because it the decor was cute and the service was pretty good.
author: Julie T.

description:
Ah - decent ramen in san francisco!  Great noodles, solid broth.  Nice happy hour specials and j-beer on tap.  The okonomi yaki was also ok - slathered in kewpie mayo and sauce.

Sadly, I've had to revise my review - the food is trending down, the real shame is the service...went to Genki for lunch yesterday.  I didn't get my food until the rest of the party was done eating!  Not even an apology.
author: Klaus M.

description: I had the curry ramen and wasn't to impressed with it. But the Okonomiyak was very good. I will go back for the okonomiyaki. It was that good.
author: Larry V.

description:
We wandered in here on a Sunday night after hearing a friend's band play down at Ireland's 32.  We had missed our dinner and were starving!  We saw the sign, read the menu, which looked inviting, figured, "Well, it's either this or pizza." Since we had just had that lousy pizza at Villa Romana on Friday, we were not feeling like pizza at all.

What a pleasant surprise.  They menu was varied and interesting, they have a wide choice of sakes and interesting specialty drinks make with shoju, and the prices were quite reasonable.  I had a seafood ramen soup bowl, and David had spicy mussels, which were covered in a sort of "secret sauce," that was slightly spicy and contained bits of seafood.  He drank a "So Cool," which was a shoju cocktail made with yogurt (tasty, but dessert-like) and I had a shoju Mojito.  Very refreshing.  

The atmosphere was pleasant.  It was very clean, with lots of televisions and modern-looking Japanese-style furnishings.  Service was competent and friendly.  Food portions were generous, as much as I want to eat in a sitting, at least.  We left pleasantly full and only about $30.00 poorer, with tip.  I'd come back.
author: Angela M.

description:
Pretty good, but inconsistent food at a potentially nice albeit somewhat odd venue.  Allow me to explain...

The interior design is very warm and inviting with earth tones,dark wood, and quality, modern furnishings. That could provide a nice, serene setting allowing you to forget about the six lanes of traffic on Geary just a few feet away.  But the effect is spoiled by an over abundance of flat screen TVs. The brightness and unnecessary flickering and flashing from the TVs diminishes an otherwise very nice atmosphere.

The food also suffered from a similar inconsistency problem.  While my ramen bowl was well presented and the broth was tasty, the lack of ramen and other ingredients undermined the dish. For a $9 bowl of ramen I was expecting a bit better. Add another $1 for corn and the price - quantity - quality trade-off didn't really work for me.  I also tried a couple other appetizers that were similarly well presented, reasonably tasty, but not overwhelmingly good.

The staff was courteous, fairly discrete, and timely.  Kudos on that front.

I wouldn't travel out of my way for Genki Ramen, but if your in the area it's a reasonable place to drop by.
author: Tom Y.

description:
it is not as good as the ramen that you get in roppongi at 3am....but they do deliver to my house and it is pretty damn tasty

the chicken wings are good.  the gyoza are good...and the cha-su ramen with spicy miso gets it done every time
author: nick g.

description:
I miss combo places like this from living in Asia.  This ramen/izakaya restaurant is pretty good.  Definitely in places like Genki it's best with a group of people.  Ordering a bunch of dishes and sharing them.  Last time I went it was just my friend and I, and we ordered six dishes.  I had to control myself or the wife would sense my crossing the border into evil pleasures and then I would have to suffer a week of cold soup and crackers (yes, i'm kidding:).

Anyway, it's not the best combo place I've been to and would have given it 2.5 stars if I could, but it's SF so you have to be generous on the ratings for Japanese places.
author: Bernard M.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised.  Not the best Ramen I've had, but I will definitely be back.  The soup stock was tasty and the noodles were good.

The seafood okonomiyaki was, eh, ok (although under the influence of Snow Beauty, it seemed damn good at the time).

Nice folks.  Great cold sake selection. Easy to get to, easy parking on a weekday afternoon.

* I could deal without the CNN and loud R&B + techno music.
author: Amelia C.

description:
Since today was a holiday, we had the luxury of having a leisurely lunch in San Francisco.  Being a rainy day, we drove by Genki Ramen on Geary and the thought of noodles in a hot broth sounded very appealing.  We also thought the name was amusing, since we're picturing lively, animated, and spirited noodles (a definition of genki we use in taiko).
I had the Chashu Ramen with a side of Pork Fried Rice.  Maybe it was a bit redundant to order a pork dish with a side of pork, but sometimes you just have to go for it!  The restaurant gave a generous amount of pork slices in a broth that was flavorful ... not just salty.  Like the movie Tampopo stressed, it's critical to have a good basic soup stock. .  
My dining partner ordered the Chicken Teriyaki Donburi that came with a side salad and miso soup.  He said that the chicken was perfectly cooked and the sauce had a good flavor (not bitter).
We were sitting in the back so could see the cooks busily and efficiently working in the small two person kitchen.   Their output was very impressive, since we were there during the lunch hour and it was pretty busy, but we were served promptly by pleasant waitstaff.  The lunch menu was very reasonable.  I would definitely return to try some other menu items!
author: Susan N.

description:
I had the standard pork ramen here and it was fine -- nothing spectacular but nothing terrible either.  The pork was succulent but neither the broth nor the noodles were memorable.  I didn't quite expect it to live up to Tokyo's ramen standards but I was hoping to find a star ramen spot comparable to those in Vancouver and this isn't it.

Service was fast and friendly though - I just think I will give the other ramen places in San Francisco their fair shake before returning.
author: Mark K.

description:
Came here on Valentine's Day at night with my family, and... I expected better.
We ordered the scallops (no flavor, thin slices), rolled beef with enokitake mushrooms (those thin stringy white mushrooms), fried noodles (overspiced), mussels(OVERCOOKED, dry), fried tempura yams (pretty darn good), mango salad (skip this, not worth it - it's a bunch of diced mangos and a LITERALLLYYYYY a tablespoon/dollop of canned crab meat),  fried rice (usual) , & lobster balls (spicy).
Well actually, everything was spicy except for the fried yams and scallops. 
I think the idea behind the whole thing just didn't mesh well together. Something wasn't right. It is expensive, and TINY. TINY. TINY. TINY. TINY. TINY.
Food - just okay.
Surrounding - modern, nice, dim lights.
Service - bleek. One or two was helpful but the rest were... horrible. I understand working at night isn't fun and people get grouchy, it's human nature, but seriously they're getting paid. BAD. SERVICE. It kills the mood especially at night. 

The service was bad, and the heat of the food was overpowering. I just wanted to get out of there.

Easily $30/$40 per person at least.
Come here if you're willing to spend on tiny portions at a higher price. 
It's one of those places that you try out once and never come back.
SPICY! LITERALLY 98% of the stuff there are spicy. 

For kids? They do have a kids menu!!! It's actually not bad.
But seriously, save your money.. even if you're loaded. This place is not worth it.
author: Jae T.

description:
Really impressed with Genki first time.
I tried the Veggie Ramen, Okonomiyaki, and
Chasu Rice. The lunch prices are decent bang4buck
and the quality was really good. My fave japanese place
in SF right now. Definitely will come back.
author: yelp j.

description: A friend picked this place, and it was a perfect place for a cold and rainy night. We only had to wait a few minutes for a table and I had the butter corn ramen. The portion was not huge, next time I know I have room to try some appetizers!
author: christine l.

description:
This is our second time there, I must say i like this restaurant, they have this happy hours till 7 PM.  There are six appetizers on the menu, we ordered every single one of them, and it is only three dollars each, we love the fried squid the best, we had a big party and we pretty much ordered  a lot of different items on the menu, I must say the noodles are great and everything else is pretty good too.  

Service is a bit spotty, even though the waitresses are very nice and friendly, the food came out a bit unevenly, half of the party got served pretty quickly, the other half had to wait at least  15 minutes for the entree to show up,  my order -fried pancake actually took more than 1/2 hour before it was served.  By then, everybody else was done eating, and I found that to be quite unacceptable, and we also had to ask to have water and tea refills.  

Overall, we will go back again, maybe just the two of us and do nothing but appetizers
author: Raymond N.

description: This spot is our favorite lunch/dinner to go out now. They have amazing Sizling Salmon. The place is very nice. Get's really busy on Friday night, so try to stop by little early before 9pm to get a seats.
author: Anya M.

description:
Wifey and I were drivin' along Geary St. when the sign for Genki appeared.
More accurately, the Genki sign jumped out into the middle of the fuggin' road.
It's 
a 
BIG
sign.

There are also lots of lights and just a splash of neon to make sure you didn't miss it.

I slam the brakes and the shiny new Mercedes tailgaiting us nearly crumples the backside of my gas-guzzling but stylish SUV.  He flips the birdie at me and I laugh maniacally... a crumpled bumper is a small price to pay for good ramen.

Unfortunately, Genki ain't where you're gonna get good ramen.

It's halfway decent ramen floating in broth made from pure sodium.
A couple of sips and my kidneys nearly went into failure from salt overload.

Staff are nice and the interior made me feel like going to a Japanese disco.

Oh well, we'll keep looking.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
I was excited of the possibility of a ramen place here in SF, because we need some, especially ones that are open late like Genki is.

Now I know that some places could be fusion, but Genki is trying to make a very authentic and Japanese homestyle.
Sorry to say, but I was kinda dissapointed...

We ordered tofu salad and gyoza first. 
What came out was a long dish with sliced avocado on the left, sliced tomato in the middle, and tofu on the right. It wasn't necessarily a 'salad.' And the dressing wasn't the ponzu/shoyu based that you're normally supposed to get. It was the creamy sesame kind.
Then, the gyoza came out and the wrapping didn't even enclose the meat in. The gyoza wrapping was around the meat like a enchilada. The whole point of the wrapping is so that when you pick it up, the meat doesn't fall out. It's not like only a couple gyoza were made accidentally that way. It was ALL of them, and my boyfriend being optimistic said that maybe they were trying to be 'different,' but that was a fail. So I ended up eating all the wrappers and meat separately cuz they all fell out.

Then the ramen came, and I don't really know how to describe it, but it didn't taste like ramen. It tasted like some type of noodles in broth, but not ramen. Having lived in Japan for a year, trust me, I know what quality ramen tastes like. And broth is as important as the texture of the noodle, if not the most important. And this broth was...booooring. 

The reason why I gave this two stars though is because the people who worked there were nice and had speedy service (But then again, we were one of two tables there). And I do appreciate the fact that they were open until 11pm on weekdays. But I think I'll just have to go eat earlier and stick with Tanpopo...now there's some good broth and men (translation-noodle).
author: Emy s.

description:
broth is what makes ramen so enjoyable for me.  i've been here many times and i just can't tear myself away from the butter corn ramen.  butter and corn in one bowl, yes please!  my noodles have always been the perfect texture, never too soft, never too firm.  the broth has always been hot but not hot enough to burn my mouth.  my water glass is always refilled within it being on the low side within minutes.  

genki ramen is so consistent that i really do think it's one of my favorite ramen spots in the city.  i used to frequent sapporo-ya in j-town pretty often, but it has really fallen off in the last few years.  not only is genki ramen much closer to my spot, but they also deliver!  it's much better in the restaurant, but when you are too lazy to change into clothes that are deemed acceptable to the public and into your car, it's pretty convenient.

BONUS...it's right around the corner from genki crepes, obviously...
author: Jennifer S.

description: For those who think this is Japanese Ramen be forewarned. Don't let the name fool you. It does however have delicious authentic Chinese chaushu. They don't serve it with the appropriate soup to ramen ratio. All the ingredients are fried or greasy then put on top. The kimchi ramen was the best. Shoga pork isn't fresh ginger. It's the pickled ginger flavor. Bizarre.
author: A M.

description: I'm not even gonna lie to you guys. I came here on a random drunk night with some friends and I didn't even know what to order. I was just so hungry that the menu was making me mad. So I told the lady to surprise me and she ordered me some kind of a Shrimp Tempura Noodle. OMGaaaahhhhh sooooo good! 5 minutes later, I slammed that $hit! fast! haha. My friends seemed to enjoy their dishes as well! Will return.
author: Priscilla B.

description:
I heard the food wasn't that great. But my boyfriend and I were hungry at 10pm and we went from place to place wondering where we could get something to eat. We usually get crepes at Genki Crepes so we decided to try Genki Ramen.

We had the croquette (excuse my spelling if it is wrong), but no matter where you get croquettes, they should be awesome. I had no trouble with the ones they gave me.

Then asparagus wrapped in bacon. I didn't like the texture since only the outside layer of the bacon was fried the rest was still raw fat.

My boyfriend got a Okonomiyaki spicy sausage. The sausage was indeed spicy, but it ruined the texture of the okonomiyaki as a whole. If you're looking for something filling, this is indeed something you should get.

We ended our late night dinner with a chocolate fondue. Too bad they were closing and we didn't want to be the last people there so we quickly dipped our marshmallow, strawberries, rice krispies, placed them in a box for later.

Overall, I would go back, it seems like a good place to eat at.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
Ok I pretty much have beef with this place and plan to never go back, but to be fair I'll give you the lowdown.

The first time I went I was really excitied by the menu thinking it looked awesome--ramen being my favorite snack food and all.  I got the yakisoba and it was bland and the only flavor was an oily salty flavor; the meat didn't even help.  I ordered 2-3 cocktails only to realize that they must've been putting the alcohol in through an eye-dropper because it was pretty much non-existent.  Also, wtf $25 for a bottle of soju?

I went back for another dinner there.  They got our order completely wrong, brought out TWO of the same entree, WTF right?  Explaining to us in an angry manner that it was us who had made the mistake of getting two of the same thing when we had ordered, not to mention one of them was burnt.  The bf got ramen with ribs and there was only bone and a sliver of meat on the ribs.  I never get the ramen because it looks so overcooked..like the noodles get really bloated from soaking up all the salty-ass soup.
and OOPS made the mistake of ordering a cocktail again when I could've gotten the same drink out of the slushy dispenser at 711

Needless to say, after realizing that they don't own up to their mistakes and will bring out the wrong order to make money off a customer I will never return until there is a new staff.
author: Amber R.

description:
When we got in the restaurant, there were a few tables open, but it still took over 5 minutes for the waitress to seat us by just saying "Sit over there".  We got our menus, but had to wave the waitress down when they didn't come for 10 minutes.  I hate it when they take forever to get there and then ask, "Are you ready to order?"

3 of us had ramen and 1 had an unagi donburi.  The ramen was good, but pretty small portion, about as much as 1 pack of top ramen.  For $10 a bowl, you'd expect more. My wife, who had the donburi, said it was so-so.   

I'd give 3 stars, but the service was terrible.  Not once did they come to our table without our having to wave them down.  It wasn't so busy that it warranted the bad service.  The food wasn't so good that I would tolerate being subjected to that quality of service again.
author: W J.

description:
The decor and the food at the this place are a perfect match.  I was surprised to find out it also served several specialty dishes besides ramen and a good selection of cocktails.

Let's start with the food.  I started with deep fried tofu ($3.50).  It arrived in a well displayed bowl, four pieces, not too crispy on the outside while silky soft on the inside.  Next up was the seafood ramen ($9.50).  The nice big bowl was filed with delicious bites.  

The decor consists of a lime green color palette with nice sturdy and dark hard wood tables and chairs.  The several flat screen tvs were showing some J-Pop bands, maybe Morning Museum.  The service was fantastic with two waitresses working the room and my waitress always on top of the tea refills.

The bar area seats 5 or 6 and looks cute off to the side with a stocked shelf of sake.  At first the bar seems out of place but the more I looked at it the more it fit in.
author: Kevin A.

description:
Genki Ramen is a hidden treasure in my eyes.  It is located on Geary in the small shops area of 94118(single digit avenues).  I have witnessed this place for both lunch and dinner and found this place to be very pleasing!

From the outside it looks like a cheap chinese restaurant.  I used to drive by it on my commute home from work and noticed the bright flashy orange sign(very smart color to use).  I thought to myself that I would try it out cause it was new.  The menus on the front window were very nice and had good photographs of the food.   Genki Ramen has a low profile front.. so be careful you could miss it while walking!

Once you enter the restaurant there are Plasmas on the walls!  I worked for Best Buy as an installer and felt that the TVs were done up very clean indeed.  Nice and level... evenly spaced.. very proper.  The tables were very nice and the chairs all had the Genki words etched into the wood(Classy!)  I thought the overall atmosphere of the place is 5 stars!  There were paper chopstick holders that saved me the trouble of making my own normal boatshaped version out of the chopstick wrapper.  I must say the sake filled bar, the open window view of the chef, and the nicely planned locations of the seats and tables took my breath away!

The lunch menu is actually a smaller(photoless) version of the dinner menu.  I highly recommend going there for dinner to scout the menu out for the first time =)  The ramen was not the best I have had, but one of the best in the city that I have tried.  I am normally a Shoyu broth fan, but their own pork based one was grand as well.  The onigiri was yummy!!!  What else can I say... I also ordered the Yakisoba that came on it's own sizzling platter.  The waitress was super nice and the chef although he was very far from my seat.. would beam a smile here and there.  To top it off nonstop Japanese music videos cycle on the screens. 

In conclusion.. this place is definately a good choice for something different!  Although parking could be very rough, I recommend this place for people who want something different than sushi =)

UPDATE: This place retains the 5 stars just because it takes online ordering from grubhub.com!  And the last 3 orders I have had with them were superb!  Keep up the good work!
author: Benny S.

description:
Stopby for their Happy Hour appetizers, best time to go and excellent appetizers at $3/order.

As for food, I've enjoyed their soba dishes.
author: Kmaintl L.

description:
So my girlfriend and I almost walked away from this place when we saw the prices on the menu, 10 bucks for ramen.  But one thing caught my eye, Spicy Mapo Tofu Ramen.  So I had to try this place just cause I haven't seen it on the menu before.  I promptly turned to my girlfriend and said, "Oh my God!  They have Mapo Tofu on Ramen, I MUST try," with my eyes bugging out.

The staff is nice, and they give you lots of time to think about what you want to order.  I liked the TV sets on the walls playing Japanese music videos and the place looks pretty clean.  The ramen cooks in the back were using squeegees to clean their workspace.  The eating area is large and is good for groups.

What we ordered:

Spicy Mapo Tofu Ramen *****
Veggie Okonomiyaki ***1/2
Tempura Ramen ****

Out of ***** stars

I like everything spicy, and so the Spicy Mapo Tofu Ramen was just spicy enough for me.  The Veggie Okonomiyaki, a Japanese frittata on a hot plate, was not bad, but maybe I would try something different next time. Finally, the Tempera Ramen was not bad, and the broth wasn't that salty.

I actually liked this place, overall.  I would say that it is however expensive ramen.  With many things you could just make at home.  You do a Sandra Lee and do it semi-homemade and pick up some Mapo tofu from your favorite Chinese restaurant and toss it on top of some homemade ramen.  Which is what we did two weeks later.  Either way, I would go back and try it again.
author: Ed Y.

description: I love ramen, but not here. I ordered chasu  ramen and it literally tasted like water and ramen. No flavor at all. Never coming here ever again.
author: Tida P.

description:
Okay Genki. I give you three stars and here's way:

Your food is good, but nothing to write home about....especially for the price. The fried rice type dish I ordered was definitely not worth the $8.95 that we paid for it. While the Robatayaki Specialties were pretty decent, I think you could have given a we bit more food. The Hamachi Kama being the exception. That was indeed pretty nummie. The ramen was okay, but what we ordered was pretty basic, so I have a feeling that was where we went wrong. The service was friendly and quick :)
author: Zoeboe D.

description:
1) Waitress is really nice, big smile on her face (-:
2) They MIGHT still have this dessert, its called "Anmitsu", if they still have it, get it, cause its friggin good.
3) It's usually not busy around 9:30 or so, so its peaceful, I like peaceful.
4) Reasonable prices.
5) You'd find parking if you're lucky.
author: Csndra L.

description: Absolutely love it here.  Lot of selection from the menu and the ramen (what it's known for) is tasty and relatively inexpensive.  Haven't tried other things yet but I saw that they have happy hour drinks specials that seemed enticing.  It's usually a full house but the few times I was there, the wait wasn't long.  Nicely decorated inside and service was fast.
author: A t.

description:
i get random cravings for ramen so I usually come here because the only other ramen place i know of is all the way in Pacifica. 

Theres nothing here that i think is to-die-for, but its not bad either. Actually, i take that back. The food is pretty good, the appetizers mostly. The ramen is just mediocre, all the soups have the same base so anything you order will probably taste similar with different ingredients. The price is pretty average, not too expensive (but then again, its RAMEN). 

What i didnt like about this place was the service. The servers were borderline negligent, which i HATE. And they werent friendly either.  I mean, i know this isnt a 5 star, fine dining restaurant, but still. Its not like people come here to eat for free..Dont get me wrong, they werent mortifying or anything, just not as nice as i'd prefer. But i guess its deal-able, thats why i still come back.
author: Linh P.

description: Ok ramen but it's expensive.  The safe bet is the chicken katsu curry ramen.  It's not authentic ramen which you can get elsewhere but if you're in the Richmond, this place is a decent place to go to fill you up
author: Alex G.

description:
Yum.  Get the Okonomiyaki.  DELICIOUS.

I wish I could give 3.5 stars, though, because they get serious points marked off for the terrible music that they play (in my humble opinion, anyway.  Crappy pop-hip-hop, pop-rap-crap.  Not good hip-hop or good rap, and believe me, I like the good stuff).

Also serious points off for the fact that they have 5 huge flat-screen TVs in such a tiny space.  Wtf?  I was trying to have a romantic dinner and we both kept getting distracted by pro-wrestling...

At least the decent Sake they served us got us nice and toasty enough to have a romantic walk after dinner...
author: Lanie W.

description: Delicious ramen but service is hit or miss.  I wish the serving size was larger, it's that good.  Still on the search for good ramen in SF and this place is in my top 3. Price is reasonable too.
author: Ren C.

description:
Open kitchen, very traditional Japanese dining room with 5 LCD TVs.
TV repeats Jap music videos.... it is so boring no matter you understand Jap or not.

I ordered Chicken nugget Ramen.
They used different kind of ramen, like the pasta kind.
the soup, for me, is not good.
the chicken nuggets were put separate from the soup.

I tried the "Japanese pancake"
EXCELLENT & HIGHLY RECOMMANDED!!

Not many Jap restaurants offer such local tastes !!
Must try it when you go there.
author: Sue S.

description: Lively spot, good food, friendly service. I really liked the glassed in kitchen. I'm not that into having televisions where ever you look and could have done without the prostate medicine infomercials that were playing on the TV...
author: Jeff G.

description:
2008 update: been back and my review remains the same. However, service can be hit & miss depending on the waitress you have.
---------------------
I've tried lunch & dinner - GO FOR THE DINNER!!  Many more choices of food and drinks!

The noodles are excellent - I recommend 1) churry pork tonkasu or 2) chashu (haven't tried other ones yet...will report back).  

MUST HAVE: seafood pancake!!  OMG!!  To die for! so yummy!

Grilled stuff recommendations:
excellend: lambchop, gizzard, oyster (kinda chinese style but baked)
skip: beef tongue, shrimp

Good place but a bit on the pricey side.

Another perk: Kirin & Sapporo on tap!!  Get the large one for a buck more...trust me, esp if you drink it with the grilled stuff.
author: Bessie T.

description:
