Japanese food done by Chinese cooks. Beef stew ramen is Chinese beef noodle soup/stew (name varies but the idea is the same) with ramen noodles. It's still very yummy with tender slabs of beef but it's very different from the beef ramen at Japanese restaurants with Japanese cooks.

We've only had delivery, so no comments on the actual restaurant. Food-wise: everything has been good though the robatayaki isn't a very good value. $1-5 per skewer. (A piece of corn about the size of KFC's cob is $1.) The okonomiyaki is horrible cold but delish warm. The curry isn't very spicy... but tasty!
author: Amy O.

description:
I give this place 2 stars only because I thought the food was pretty decent. I came here with a friend that I haven't seen in years and she took me to this place to catch up. Since I'm a big fan of hakata ramen it was cool to try something new. The place is nice and jazzy and feels comfortable once we arrived, along with a nice bar area. The waitress promptly seated us while we looked at the menu to order. Now I know why your all asking why I gave this place only 2 stars instead of more and I will get to that part shortly. I really even considered giving this place 1 star but in the long run I have to admit the food was good.

Since it was my first time here I let my friend do all the ordering, after she did so I noticed that we got soft shelled crab (a personal favorite) hakata ramen and some other appetizers. I decided to order a coke since I didn't feel like water at the time and I can tell ya the wait was unbearable. Since we came here on a weeknight there weren't a lot of people seated but still the service was HORRIBLE! I have never waited so long for food, drinks, and service especially since there was no one in there! Even when we were done eating it took a good 15 minutes to get our bill and I never got refills on tea or water. It was frustrating to say the least considering the food was pretty good. I was pissed to the point where I wanted to skip the tip but my friend took care of it so I guess that was that.

The food itself wasn't bad. The ramen was good and the soup base was perfect. It wasn't too thick or too salty, and along with the soft shelled crab made for a good meal. If only the service was better I would have rated this place better. Maybe if I ever go back I would have a better time but I guess only time will tell. Don't know what to tell ya, go at your own risk and I hope your experience will be better than mine...
author: Jason Y.

description:
This is one of my favorite Ramen places in the city.

Located in the Richmond, this restaurant is good for lunch, dinner, and on the weekends a late night snack. The place is fairly large and can accomidate a good amount of people.

The Ramen. Very good selection of ramen dishes. I highly reccomend the chicken karage ramen or the tonkatsu curry ramen. There are other fantastic dishes besides ramen. They offer fried rice as well other noodle dishes such as okonomiyaki or yakisoba.

Service is always excellent when I come here.  The staff is friendly and prompt.

Genki is a must try for ramen lovers. Great atomosphere, good prices, yummy ramen! :)
author: David W.

description:
7 of us had a meal here for a total of 112 after tax & tip. Each of us had a bowl of ramen and the following appetizers: gyoza, unagi tempura, & fried tofu. Gyoza was crisp and good, unagi tempura was average, & the fried tofu was overpriced. 4 small pieces of tofu for $3.50.

I had the chicken karrage ramen. The noodle was chewy, but the chicken karrage was on the salty side and the soup base was boring and had too much msg. 

We shared two orders of green ice cream with red bean paste which was suprisingly pretty good. However, even with the cool modern decor atmosphere, we were dying to get out because of the Japanese teen pop music blaring inside the restaurant. Cute can only get you so far ................
author: Erica B.

description:
Definitely not a traditional ramen place.  The food is decent, but has more of an "asian fusion" style than a traditional Japanese style.  The onigiri was pretty tasty, although it apparently comes in only bonito flavor.  As others have mentioned, the chicken karaage pieces were way too large, and reminiscent of KFC, not Japan.

The nori ramen and the chicken karaage ramen differed by the addition of the chicken to their "standard" ramen.  Not very creative.

The beer selection (on draft) is limited to Sapporo and Sierra Nevada, although they have some other less honorable options in bottles.

The decor is nice, but distracting, which HD flat screens mounted on walls around the restaurant, and oddly, playing music videos that were not also played on the sound system.

The ceiling is an open-style drop-in ceiling, which allows a view into the ducts and electrical work above -- an interesting look that's been done before.

Two lunch specials, tea, and two beers was about $30, which is a bit pricey for ramen.
author: James D.

description: This is one of my usual ramen spots. What I love about Genki is that it's open late (usually until 11), service is quick & food is good. =) There's flat screen tvs, which is cool. They also have a "happy hour" menu which is good when you're on a budget. The only thing that sucks is parking, but go figure...it's the city.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Not bad.  I like their TONKOTSU-based soup.  It's a bit pricey, tho.

My friend got a "rotten" egg one time. It was a surprise.  I think other customers had bad eggs too because we saw others not eating those eggs!!! Also my friend got a very lukewarm soup.  I mentioned in the other reviews, but noodle soup should be hot.  I don't mind lukewarm one but this place was a bit too much... 

Despite all I said earlier, I like their noodle soup.  I like their noodle.
author: Mike M.

description: We used to go to Tanpopo in J town until they've changed management and Genki Ramen is the only place in SF that I would go to. I miss the real ramen flavor from Japan or Little Tokyo in LA, this is the closest pork flavored ramen I've found. The best is you can do a Yelp check in to get a free appetizer! Staff members are friendly. I haven't tried their other choices other than shoyu ramen and chicken karage yet. So this review is only for those two items.
author: Wine L.

description:
I've came here on multiple occasions and sometimes bring friends for their first-time. I guess comparably, the ramen here isn't the best. Maybe I just really like ramen...but I still really like this place! The actual noodles was A-OK, not as chewy and soft as I'd like, but you can ask the kitchen to make it softer or harder.

What I liked about this place was the different choices of things that came with the ramen. I usually order the Nori (??) ramen - with corn and seaweed, and an additional order of bamboo shoots. The additional orders are definitely overpriced, but they do make the ramen taste better. It's simple to make and probably not even worth half it's menu price..but it happily fills me up. :) 

Other small things that make me happy:
- I've never had to wait for a seat
- Seating's pretty comfortable, in terms of distance from other tables and setting, etc
- They have drinks 
- They serve the food pretty fast and have pretty good service
- They open late (till 11pm)
author: April Z.

description: This is a reliable spot for ramen and other types of Japanese comfort food like chicken katsu curry.  We tried this place for the first time yesterday, after finding out that they serve brown rice, which is a huge plus for  us as we try our best to opt for healthier alternatives.  We enjoyed the Tenderous Rib Ramen with spinach and the katsu curry dish.  My fiance loves the Japanese curry dishes but we don't eat them that often because of the carb overload.  Now that we know Genki offers brown rice, we can enjoy his comfort food more often.  The oolong iced tea was also good, although we were hoping they served matcha iced tea that we had in a similar place in Oahu.
author: V B.

description:
There aren't any real unique ramen flavors here that I haven't found already in other noodle joints.  They serve their typical pork broth with cha siu.  

I got the kim chee ramen... it was spicy at first bite, but once it sinks into the broth all you're left with is crunchy cabbage.  They do offer one meager slice of braised pork which turned out to be a real stingy piece.

The curry pork ramen is to be skipped.  The pork is prepared tonkatsu style and again, once dunked into the broth it just ruins the entire structure and original taste.  And plus the pork was so lean and dry, you're best left w/o it.  

The ramen was pretty good.  I've had ramen at japanese restaurants that tasted like the dehydrated packages you live off of in college.  This I could tell was at least semi homemade.  And the portions were substantial so I was happy.  

I thought the open ended gyoza was pretty good too.  Crispy, thin wrapper with a nice chunk of greasy meat inside.  

I think they price a little too high for noodles and soup.  Service was good and attentive, but I don't think it's a repeat visit unless I live in the neighborhood.
author: Chris T.

description:
I'd give this place a 2.5. I really like the aesthetic -- it's very Tokyo Modern (I am making that term up -- it's possible that such a term already exists and it does not describe the aesthetic of Genki Ramen. A thousand pardons.).

A friend and I went for lunch on a weekend, and it wasn't that crowded, but the service was a little slow. The food was good, but a little on the pricey end for ramen.

The J-Pop-blaring flatscreens around the restaurant are cute, but a bit distracting.

I'd rather go to Genki Crepes, but I'll give the Ramen House another chance.
author: Vandana M.

description:
Stupendous ramen in SF proper is so difficult to find, and Genki at least keeps the Ramen craving at bay, especially on those cold foggy days. The chicken karaage came on the side, and I was dousing the karaage in the ramen for the soft and crispy taste at the same time. Yum. I have to say, the karaage is quite addictive. I commend Genki on its balanced flavored ramen soup that is not too salty and no too oily. (You know you go for at least 2 full pints of water after eating at Santa Ramen, you know you do. Kinda annoying on a full stomach.) I wish the hard-boiled egg came in the soft-boil style. But alas, the eggs are pre-boiled, so PASS. 

Besides the extensive Ramen list, Genki has quite an awesome list of appetizers, chef specials, and small dishes. I wonder how they can keep the ingredients fresh day in, day out. The beef enoki roll topped with miso sauce was decent. The chicken gizzards had a great crunchy texture. My friend was looking forward to the ika yaki, but he still likes Kirala's ika better 'cuz Kirala grills the sides to a perfect crisp.

Genki is definitely a welcomed neighborhood ramen joint. If I ever get around for happy hour, I would be more than happy to get drunk and crunk on the $3 drinks and $3 appetizers.
author: Cathy H.

description:
There are something like 6 - 8 televisions in this restaurant, and it makes the entire dining experience very impersonal. I don't even like sports, but if there is a huge tv showing a football game in front of my face, it's hard not to watch and ignore the person in front of you. I think maybe they only need one in the back center of the room.

I got the "cha shu" ramen and my friend got the "curry tonkatsu". I liked the curry better than mine. I like Santa Ramen waaaaaaaaay better (in San Mateo) but this place isn't a bad alternative. I don't think it's very filling actually, and the service was kind of slow and inconsistent on the only day I was ever there. Also I wasn't a huge fan of their ramen, the yolk taste was way too distinct for my taste.

Also, the gyoza was waaaaay disappointing. They have a combo deal where you get a bowl of ramen + your choice of 1 of 3 sides, and we both got the gyoza. The other choices include chicken kaarage, gyoza, and one other thing, I forget. But the gyoza was basically something I hope to never eat again.
author: ting b.

description: I like the Ramen here:) My fave is the Garlic Tenderous rib and the Beef stew.
author: Shelley M.

description:
I love ramen so I was looking forward to eating here. It's fancy ramen at Genki Ramen. The broth is miso broth, being a shoyu broth lover I should have asked to see if I could just get a shoyu ramen. Still the Char siu Ramen ($8.95) was decent. To complete the meal I also order a side of white rice and goyza ($4.75). Pretty good ramen meal but I was topping $15 for my whole meal and that's a bit pricey for ramen.

My boyfriend got Chicken Karaage ($4.50), Lamb Chop ($3.50), Saba ($4.50) and Tomato Pumpkin ($2.25). All were really good and the closest we can get to having an Izakaya menu selection. 

Food was good but the price can add up. If I'm craving ramen I might just go elsewhere to get more bang for my buck.

Atmosphere is pretty cool with X girl J-Pop singer on the multiple flat screen televisions scattered around the white-walled restaurant.
author: Wendy B.

description:
You might find yourself drawn here if you're a ramen lover like us.  This place does deliver good ramen-- not the best we've ever had, but certainly comparable to the other ramen houses in the bay area.  However, as you can see from pictures and other reviews, this place puts a lot of emphasis on ambiance, and therefore, cha-ching, HIGH OVERHEAD.  Who needs 5+ Vizio flat-panels?  We can only watch Tila Tequila for so long while eating, before food begins tasting dirty.

The appetizers are good.  We've had the salmon, gyoza, and kara'age chicken.  All staples of these new fusion-y ramen places, so it didn't lose any points there.  However, it's the $9 chasu ramen and $8.50 basic ramen that makes us scratch our head.  Is it really worth that extra buck?  Especially when food comes so cheap in the Richmond?    We suspect this place would flood with foot traffic if they made their prices more competitive.  Yes, the ramen is ok.  Broth is clean, beef is tender.  But we're turned off by the premium price.

The service is pretty good.  They have an endless supply of water and tea, so they'll keep pouring if you decide to stay around and chat for a while.  This is a great place for a "cheap" date and meeting up with old friends.  Also, it's open pretty late, so if you're stuck out here in Richmond... stop by.  Genki Ramen is still a great place to eat.
author: Kel S.

description:
This time I give them an extra star. Yesterday I went there with my kids. Its been almost a year since my last visit. They changed the look of their menu. It used to be a nice folded menu with many nice pictures of each dish. This new menu is okay, but I always appreciate it more when there are pictures to show what the food look like. Any way, my son had the curry beef ramen. My daughter had the chicken karaage ramen. I can't help it to get the seafood fried rice again! hehe. Side orders we ordered the Gyoza dumplings and Shrimp Tempura. The ramen definitely taste much better than Majikku Ramen. Its not so overcooked. The chicken Karaage was still crunchy when we brought it home. The only thing I'm surprised is the batter they used for tempura. I prefer the original, which you will see it at Kiki or some cheaper Jap. places. But overall, we were happy about the food. I like the waitress who served us, I'm guessing she's a Japanese? Because to me, Japanese ppl are very polite. We will definitely visit them again. YAY! :P


As of 8/2012, it isn't that great any more, the portion is lot less. The soup is more than the nooodle. I will not return
author: The Black Cat C.

description: Ordered takeout here. I got okonomiyaki, and the boyfriend got ramen. The delivery took a while, so the food was only warm when it got here, which is why I docked a star. The food, however, was great. I had only eaten here once before, and that was over five years ago, so I didn't expect much. Surprisingly, my okonomiyaki was great. I definitely recommend putting noodles in it. Boyfriend liked his ramen too. The prices were also pretty decent for what we ordered, so we'll probably order from this Genki again!
author: Carolyn M.

description:
Food:3/5
Service:5/5
Organization:5/5
Price: 4/5
Atmosphere: 4/5

Got the yasai ramen and crispy daimaru. Ramen was nicely made ( not overcooked) but not that impressive. The daimaru  was surprisingly good. Crispy with hot cheese and fish. Yakisoba smelt legit, tried some and it was good. Service was very attentive and quick.
author: Mickey K.

description:
What a menu! Genki primarily serves ramen noodle bowls, with thick, delicious noodles and a hearty (but a little oily) broth. I couldn't tell if the noodles were house-made, but either way their taste and diameter were a whole different ball game then the $.60 ones you get at the grocery store. (not that I have any problems with those.)

The rest of the menu is almost tapas like, with small plates and lots of appetizer and a la carte items to share. We started with my choice of pumpkin and yam tempura and my bf's choice of shrimp shu mai. Both were excellent, although the shu mais were smaller than usual and therefore a little over priced in my opinion. The tempura I could have had alone as a meal itself. The pumpkin pieces are always my favorite when I get tempura, and in this order I got 2 pieces of pumpkin, 2 pieces of yam, and 2 pieces of wintermelon. Yum!

We then shared a chicken nugget ramen bowl, which was great because they put the crispy chicken pieces on the side instead of in the bowl so they stayed crisp. Off the a la carte menu, we sampled one lamb and one prawn skewer. My lamb was a full grilled lamb chop on a skewer stick! It came with a great soy-mint dipping sauce. My bf's prawn skewer was a whole, unshelled prawn with a skewer stuck up it's butt and the head still attatched. This kind of freaked him out a little, and he said the flavor was "a bit TOO fishy." I didn't try it. I think I could have 2 or 3 of the lamb skewers by themselves as a meal next time.

We rounded the meal out with a caramel ice cream sundae with big pieces of fresh watermelon, mango, strawberry, and kiwi. We usually don't order dessert but this was totally worth it. They have another sundae with a green tea topping that I will definitely try next time.

Overall: Worth it and a totally fun vibey experience.
.
author: Rosie B.

description:
We came here for lunch. The interior looks like somewhere in Arcadia, very very Taiwanese. I was surprised to see that they have a sake bar with a decent selection and the open kitchen. 

Their noodle tasted like ones from Ajisen in San Gabriel. It's edible, and when you want ramen and you are not by the gourmet noodle house, this would do.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I've got delivery twice from them and I'm pretty content with their food and the execution of the menu.

However, they have one of the stupidest bitches taking orders on the phone or answering the phone all together. Stupid, bad attitude, rude and unpleasant. For that I will never visit the actual location or recommend this place for people to go have dinner.

I'm sticking to Delivery.com to order from here.
author: Kokoro I.

description: I can't call myself a ramen aficionado, but when I developed a serious craving for ramen I hit up Yelp, found these guys and tried them out.  I went with the spicy tofu ramen and it was so full of flavor.  I was seriously impressed, and getting it by delivery, I appreciated how they separated out the ingredients.  Now I find myself specifically craving their spicy tofu ramen.  Good service, great food, I'm very happy with Genki.
author: Scott R.

description:
I've been here a couple times, first with Morgan, then with Russian Gene and finally, by myself. So far, my obsessive tendencies keep bringing me back to the Beef Curry Ramen... mmm mmm good. I have been having a variety of appetizers though, finally settling on a favorite: the Baked Scallops. In addition to the food, they always have something interesting on TV, whether it be Adult Swim, currenTV or Monday Night Football (I'm a major tomboy but I have fun). The service isn't exactly attentive but I don't really want them to be... I just want to sit back, relax and enjoy my noodle soup.

I also looove the little candies they give you with your check, which apparently you can buy at the sister crepe place/store on Clement St. I have yet to venture there, mostly because I rarely get dessert after dinner because there are so many good restaurants in this neighborhood that I never leave them still hungry... only thirsty ;).
author: Megan P.

description:
I'm a dedicated Santa Ramen (San Mateo) junkie who left the suburbs for life in the big city.  I admit that my noodle know-how is modest but finding good Japanese noodles in SF hasn't been easy.  Lucky for me, I decided to check this place out...

We started with the gyoza and the ox tongue robatayaki (yes, we're an adventurous lot).  I've had better potstickers and I've had worse.  These were piping hot (fresh!) and had a decent middle.  The ox tongue was good too, having enough flavor to be tasty but without overpowering the grilled smokiness.

Next, we moved on to the noodles.  The chashu ramen had a well-seasoned, rich broth.  There was plenty of chopped scallions, bamboo shoots, and slices of tender pork.  The marinated hardboiled egg was a nice add-on.  The whole bowl tasted fresh and wasn't too salty.

The spicy tofu ramen isn't a traditional Japanese dish but we tried it based on a recommendation from a friend who's more J than A.  This one was a bit too greasy for me, most likely due to the chili oil they added to put the spicy in spicy mapo tofu ramen.  The broth was a bit thin and had less flavor than the chashu soup.  It came with cubes of soft tofu and minced, seasoned pork.

The service was semi-prompt and friendly.  The atmosphere was a bit noisy with groups chatting over the J-pop music.  There were several screens showing J-pop music videos and after a while, I felt a little edgy and unnerved by the flashing, cartoonish images.  Think mini Lost in Translation moment.

This place isn't as good as Santa or Himawari (also in San Mateo) but I'd go back.  It doesn't hurt that this place is close to where I live now and Santa Ramen is now a forty-five minute drive away.
author: L Y.

description: So my boyfriend and I came here for lunch. We ordered our usual stuff, stir fry black pepper beef ramen and the curry tonkatsu along with a mango smoothie and watermelon juice. When the mango smoothie came, my boyfriend noticed it was really bland, no taste at all. So we told the lady and her excuse was that the mango was not in season so it wasn't sweet. Ok sure?  whatever. When our food arrived, i took a few bites from my curry tonkatsu rice plate and the rice was hard. I told the server that the rice was hard. The stupid lady said "oh she didnt cook the rice so its not her fault" ARE YOU KIDDING ME? Your the server. You represent the people in the kitchen as well. Do your job and satisfy your customer. Do whats best for your customer and make them happy. But they definitely do not understand the concept of good customer service. The worst customer service I have ever experienced. I asked for the manager and another server came by and said she was the manager. BULLSHIT. She is definitely not the manager. She was not understanding at all. Oh well. i Will never come back again.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Not good waitress on the phone very rude food is nasty and  it has a hail on my food ..waiting is terrible always on the cell phones ..... we ate with my friends left my jacket and my wallet and money there  i forgot my jacket.... next day came back to pic up my jacket the lady help night before and i came back next day ...... my wallet my money was missing  was gone... only my jacket  got return i ask her  where is my wallet and my money in my jacket she was nerveouse saying i did not see it.. she  left in the storage room.... i don't believe her i did even ask  did she take or anyone took it she keeps saying no one took it in a nervouse way...SO I  KNOW THEY STOLE IT I DID MAKE A POLICE REPORT.....    THEY ARE DIRTY THE FOOD IS BAD NOT GOOD  AND A LIER.... I KNOW WHERE I PUT MY WALLET AND MY MONEY ... JUST BECAUSE I FORGOT MY JACKET IT DOES MEAN U CAN TAKE MY MONEY AND WALLET AND LEAVE ME THE JACKET COMMON SENCE ...THINK ABOUT U GUYS ARE NOT TRUEFUL PEOPLE ....
author: Coco T.

description: The place is simply standard. The food isn't horrible and isn't great either. I came here last Friday pretty much expecting this place to be what it is. There just wasn't anything special about anything they served. The prices are fair compared to Nombe & Isakya Sozai. The chashu ramen wasn't too oily or too salty-- but the chashu was a bit dry. The tako yaki was a bit disappointing because there's only a small piece of squid in the center-- but again, for the price, it was fair. The ambiance of the restaurant is probably the best thing about this place. High ceilings, TV's everywhere, and nice bathrooms. This is a good place for groups and families-- but probably not for a date. If you do-- it'd be a pretty cheap date. They've got drinks and yummy looking soju mixed drinks (which is probably a sign that this place is not entirely authentic..). For a casual dinner (and no lines around 7 on a Friday) in San Francisco, this a good place to go.
author: Julie H.

description:
I want to cry; it's a common enough feeling in SF associated with the impossible, grail-like quest for good ramen! Tears flow bitterly from my face as I sat down to an average broth and nearly flavorless cha-shu. I was in that mood, you know the one where you want to scald your tongue on pipping hot hand-made white flower noodles but instead, as you troll the waters in your bowl, come up with chinese egg noodles? Yeah, that's the disappointment, I know you're feeling it right this very second as you nod your head in agreement.

Genki is fine for lunch, its a good place to take someone that has never eaten a really great bowl of ramen to go, but it makes you cry when you think how far from the mark this ramen actually falls. Make sure to read the menu, there's an option that will allow you to get a more flavorful bowl by asking them to keep the oil instead of skimming it off.... i mean seriously, why in the name of all that is holy would you ever want them to skim the fat and oil off the ramen!? Oh and another high point, they are more reasonably priced than Katana-Ya... karaage isn't bad either...
author: Len S.

description: Last night was my first time at Genki Ramen. It was alright. The food wasn't terrible, but not amazing either. It'll suffice if you only need a quick fix! The decor was a bit out-of-date. I wasn't too fond of the restaurant layout. My sister and I felt quite squished as there was barely any personal space in between the tables around us. The service was fine--the waitresses are friendly. Parking, unfortunately, was quite a headache--even at 10:00 PM. I had to drive around the area about 5 times before I finally found a spot. Ehh. 3 stars.
author: Emily C.

description: Ummmmm This place is awesome. Cheap food, fast service. A large menu to please any kind of craving. I love the beef stew ramen and their watermelon juice drink think is like crack!
author: Adriani L.

description:
Really?  Only an average of three stars?  I've had ramen from San Diego to Los Angeles to San Francisco.. and this place was definitely better than average.. at least for their ramen.  I wouldnt say it's five-star quality, but it was pretty decent ramen!  Surprised this place didnt get a higher rating.

Came here with two of my besties.  I have a thing for noodle soups, so ramen was the obvious choice when we came here.  I ordered the Chasu Ramen with Gyoza ($7.95).  I didnt try anything else on the menu though, so I cant speak for their other choices.

It definitely hit the spot as far as ramens go.. pretty tasty and a decent portion.  I enjoyed the atmosphere of the place as well.. looked like there was a bar against one of the walls, and I remember there to be two plasmas that were showing cartoons.  Nothing like watching cartoons with a bowl of ramen on a Saturday afternoon.  

The waitress was nice.. dont have much to say about the service.  She took our orders, brought us food, gave us tea.  The usual stuff.

If you're craving ramen, check this place out.  I know SF gets cold enough for you to want some ramen.. and you cant eat pho all the time. :)
author: Kevin M.

description: Nothing special here, but i did get a free croquet that burned my tongue.
author: Doug F.

description:
So my girlfriend and I almost walked away from this place when we saw the prices on the menu, 10 bucks for ramen.  But one thing caught my eye, Spicy Mapo Tofu Ramen.  So I had to try this place just cause I haven't seen it on the menu before.  I promptly turned to my girlfriend and said, "Oh my God!  They have Mapo Tofu on Ramen, I MUST try," with my eyes bugging out.

The staff is nice, and they give you lots of time to think about what you want to order.  I liked the TV sets on the walls playing Japanese music videos and the place looks pretty clean.  The ramen cooks in the back were using squeegees to clean their workspace.  The eating area is large and is good for groups.

What we ordered:

Spicy Mapo Tofu Ramen *****
Veggie Okonomiyaki ***1/2
Tempura Ramen ****

Out of ***** stars

I like everything spicy, and so the Spicy Mapo Tofu Ramen was just spicy enough for me.  The Veggie Okonomiyaki, a Japanese frittata on a hot plate, was not bad, but maybe I would try something different next time. Finally, the Tempera Ramen was not bad, and the broth wasn't that salty.

I actually liked this place, overall.  I would say that it is however expensive ramen.  With many things you could just make at home.  You do a Sandra Lee and do it semi-homemade and pick up some Mapo tofu from your favorite Chinese restaurant and toss it on top of some homemade ramen.  Which is what we did two weeks later.  Either way, I would go back and try it again.
author: Edmund Y.

description: The chashu ramen was decent but nothing to write home about. The service was great, which is why I plan to give this place another shot to try their small dishes.
author: Ross A.

description:
Make sure your waiter writes down what you dont want in your ramen and pancakes. I told the waiter "No bamboo shoots in my ramen, absolutely no bamboo shoots, and no onions in the seafood pancake."

The dude came back with bamboo shoots in my ramen and told me "Oh, but you said no onions", but ramen never comes with onions, stupid waiter went back to the kitchen, he looked pissed, and scooped out the bamboo shoots.

When he came back with the seafood pancake, my girlfriend and her mom were suppose to share, the cut it in for pieces, it taking 1 piece, alittle onion in her mom's, and alot of onions in my girlfriends, my girlfriend hates onions and gets sick when she eats it. The dude told us "yeah, i already took care of your bamboo shoots, and you said no green onion in the pancake right?" Little did he know, there was still green onion on the pancake. He told me to talk to the manager, he went to talk to the manager but he never came out....7 minutes later he switched out onion seafood pancake with an onion-free pancake. 

Not a good dining experience. The waiter boy with the red hair looks like he doesn't want to work there. Because he DID take care of the job, I gave them a $4 tip because the bill was $40. However, they lost a good customer, and non of my family and friends, non of my gf's family and friends, and non of her mom's family and friends will go there.
author: Bernard W.

description: If Genki Ramen is any indicator, Japan is filled with flat screen TVs showing football, bright lights, awful music, fruity-looking cocktails, dim sum (what?!?), and of course, Japanese people.  I get the last one.  Not so much the others...
author: Laurence W.

description:
Ok... This placed sucked big fat toe. The only reason I'm giving it two stars is because I LOVE ramen and the decor was cute.
I ordered the kimchee ramen and it was so bleh. I got some kimchee, one slice of chasu. No green onions, no pretty presentation. My friend got the chasu ramen and he didn't even finish his when he's known for being a garbage disposal. I guess garbage disposals need some standards too.
author: Anna S.

description: Good variety of food - ramen, sizzling platters, little appetizer dishes (chicken karaage, gyoza, croquettes). Good place for kids.
author: E F.

description: We just got back from China and lived on ramen since we quickly tired of Chinese food. Our standards were set high coming in and this place surpassed our expectations. So delicious! We ordered the kimchee ramen and the yasai ramen (410) and both were excellent. Our new favorite Ramen spot!!
author: Max G.

description: I like this place. I always get the Chaasu ramen everywhere I go and this place was no exception. It was good and flavorful but may be a tad bit salty. Prices aren't bad either, about 7-8 dollars a bowl. I'm craving it just talking about it. I should really try all the other stuff on the menu, they have a wide selection.
author: Tossama C.

description:
I was looking for a Sunday spot for a late dinner at 10pm in the Inner Richmond, and really hoping this could be my new late night meal place.   I tried a variety of hot dishes (no ramen) and the outcome was...

(-) The gyoza was heavily tenderized (e.g., pink looking but cooked) and the vegetable pan cake, and enoki was too fushion/westernized with mayonnaise/ cream on the top.... which kills any good spices/natural flavors.

(+) The waitresses were quite friendly.. therefore, giving 2 stars.

I won't be coming again...and will continue to hunt for that Sunday late night meal.
author: Hotung T.

description: Ramen is decent here but I still prefer Dojo in San Mateo as my favorite. Service can be a bit slow. We checked in for a free appetizer which was a small tofu thing but it was not very good at all. I might go if I'm in the area but it's not worth the drive and hassle of parking.
author: A. Z.

description:
I actually like the non-traditional ramen here.  Last night, accompanied by 4 other people, we searched out something that would be cheap, quick and easy.  Et voila!  We ended up at Genki.

1st some observations 
-service can be slow
-the place reeks of FISH
-this is more Chinese style ramen (in my opinion)
-there is a large selection of appetizers and also of other non-noodle dishes
-I would like to try it during lunch-time b/c they seem to have good lunch deals/combos on the menu.

Here is what we ordered:

Gyoza (reg & veggie)  9.25
Beef and enoki roll 6.75
Nori Ramen (x2) - 15.50
Chicken Kaarage  4.50
Mushroom Ramen  8.95
Onigiri 3.25
Chicken Curry Katsu Ramen 8.50
3 alcoholic beverages 13.95
Total w/ tax but sans tip = 76.66

WHEW...but the most important part, THE MISO SOUP BASE IS HELLA GOOD.  I ordered the Chicken Curry Katsu, which was delicious.  The curry mixed with the miso soup base (which I ordered specifically, b/c the "original" comes with the pork based soup) with the potatoes and carrots were a delicious combo.  The pork gyoza was also pretty tasty.  

In addition, I learned last night that they are open until 1PM...perfect for the late night munchies :)
author: Hiromi N.

description:
When I say the word "ramen", you think of those bright, crinkly cellophane packages with the pasty block of crimpy noodles nestled inside with a packed of salted "flavor powder".  Don't deny it- I know you do.

That's exactly what my friend Ryan thought when I told him my boyfriend and I were taking him out for ramen for dinner.

This place- Blows. My. Mind.  Yes it does.

1) The soup base is amazing, they use fresh miso.

2) They allow to customize your ramen to a good degree- you can add extra egg, seaweed, meat, and even extra noodles (my favorite)!

3) The ramen noodles are firm!  And you can request the texture of them if you prefer more or less firmness in your noodle!  Personally, I think the noodles are great the way they are!

4) This place is VERY clean!  Yes, that matters.  And decorated with a modern twist, which is really very cool. 

5) The prices are extremely fair, and the portions are very generous as well!

6) They're open until 11:00 PM!

San Francisco tends to get foggy and cold, so this noodle soup is an excellent choice for lunch on those more dreary days!

I've heard the okinomiyaki is crazy delicious, but I can't tear myself away from their ramen yet!

Fact: I've gone to Sapporo Ya for ramen in the past- it's not all that good (I dip my noodles into soy sauce to flavor the soup to the point where I have had friends physically restrain me from doing so from fear that I'll inflict some bad soy-sauce overdose upon myself).  Also, the service bites- I have literally had waitresses there flat-out ignore me!

I went to Genki literally two days ago, and beat my boyfriend there.  I ordered him his favorite (Nori and corn ramen with half a boiled egg added!  Yum!).  The waitress served me tea and I sipped it while waiting for Adam.  He arrived a few minutes later, I waved to him from my seat as he walked in.  The waitress was at our table before he was, with a steaming cup of tea for him!  Wonderful woman!

Ryan was so impressed I thought his eyeballs were going to fall right out of his head.  My friend Cat couldn't stop talking about how good the food was when she and I had lunch there a few days ago.

And lately, I've been going to Genki once every week!

(And yes, I promise, I have never worked for Genki Ramen, and no, they are not paying me to send them cyber love.  I just honestly love their food!)
author: Marisa D.

description:
Gotta say, I was pleasantly surprised.  They deliver!  To my house!  Tasty, albeit not perfect, ramen!  Delivered!  In separate containers so that the noodles don't get soggy. 

Its pretty swell. 

So, if I'm going out it isn't my first choice.  But...  the delivery!
author: Nora B.

description:
Since I'm a fan of Genki Crepes, I was excited to try their ramen.  I was impressed by the sleek & modern look, but after trying it, I'd rather go to other places to eat ramen.  Since I love the kimchi ramen at Santa, I had to order it at Genki so I could compare and I was very disappointed.  
If you like J-pop, you'll love this place because that's all they play on their flat screen tvs.  

On the upside, the drinks were good.  I forgot which drinks we had, but they all have soju in them.  The drinks looked & tasted good in the tall glasses.  & they were only $5 each!
author: Val L.

description:
The first time I went here was probably late last year. The food was good, but shame on me that I didn't write a review back then.

So, I decided to go back tonight. Plus, they had okonomiyaki, which, I have heard so much of, but have yet to try...until tonight.

The husband and I shared 1 sumo okonomiyaki (japanese pizza), 1 order of lamb chop, 1 order of chicken gizzard robayaki, and 1 order of beef and enoki mushroom roll.

First off, the chicken gizzard was a little chewy. Eh, not my favorite, and will probably not order it again from Genki. The lamb chop was very tasty being lightly seasoned, but sort of fatty and pretty tiny to share between 2 people. The beef and enoki mushroom roll was enoki mushrooms rolled up in thin slices of beef and grilled with sauce. With 4 medium sized rolls, the husband and I were able to share the dish with no problem. The beef was very tender and the sauce made the dish divine.

But what probably was our favorite part of the meal was the Sumo Okonomiyaki. It came to us sizzling on a hot plate, with bacon, cheese, the japanese mayo, and okonomiyaki sauce. Wow. What a medley of flavors! It was very filling and almost tasted more like a japanese shepherd's pie. Wow! i highly, highly recommend the okonomiyaki from Genki Ramen! I can't wait to go back and try more flavors/toppings.
author: Jan Z.

description:
I love noodles, as far as I'm concerned they are category of food on their own with a firmly established, somewhat plump, place in my food pyramid.  My soft spot, so to speak, for anything noodle based probably makes me, if anything, too forgiving when it comes to scrutinizing noodley dishes (unless they breach the unpardonable sin of overcooking them) and I have probably been happy with less then spectacular bowls of ramen in the past. 

It speaks volumes then to say I was not content with the ramen I had here, it simply was not overly appealing in flavor or texture.  The ramen was, however, hotter then the service; a whole other aftertaste is left when you can barely get help to deal with an incorrect dish in a nearly empty place.  

I don't think I'll be back, my dealings with Genki will remain with the location on Clement for the occasional egg puff or crepe fix.  Looks like I'll keep roamin' for good ramen.
author: GIR ..

description:
I went here for lunch today, after having dinner a few months ago when it first opened. There is a different lunch menu which took us by surprise, as I was looking forward to the seafood pancake I had last time. Usually I like to wolf down my food, but the seafood pancake was SO good that evening, I found myself savouring every bite....the evening menu is pretty vast for a cafe-type place and was so well illustrated I wanted to take one home so i could salivate over the pictures.... 

Lunch on the otherhand, was a simple affair- the menu is limited to fried noodles, ramen and donburi meals. I had the curry seafood donburi which left me more than satisfied, definetly hit the spot. You can upgrade your ramen noodle to have a side dish of gyoza, pork rice or chicken katsu nuggets for an extra buck- what a feast for around 8 dollars a meal!

The wait staff are attentive- my tea cup was never more than half empty and the TV screens add to this trendy atmosphere, showing lots of eye candy, if you like the J-pop kind of thing. Definetely will be back to try more stuff on the evening menu..... too many choices and distractions!
author: Sushi Y.

description:
Been here twice.  The food is ok, not much different of others.  I was a little irritated when the waitress didn't understand that I didn't want any pork in my ramen and then came back to ask me again because she didnt' understand.  I know some people are not great english speakers but when you work at a restaurant, you should know the basic " I don't want meat" in my dish phrase.  

I did like the watermelon drink.  I don't remember exactly what it was called but it was YUMMY!  I don't think that I would go back for the ramen but I would go for the fruit drinks!
author: Wendy K.

description:
I find the negative reviews interesting here.  However, being a vegetarian, perhaps my impression of the restaurant is different as a result.  I found the menu to be very diverse and ordered quite a few items.  The ramen was tasty and contained more than ample varieties and quantities of properly cooked veggies.  The salads were good, although I'd like to have less dressing on the papaya salad next time.

The decor was a bit too "robot-esque" but at least they had current.tv on the screens.  I'd eat there again.
author: Drew W.

description: Whenever I go here, I get the same thing.  The samurai wing appetizers and the garlic tenderous rib ramen.  It delicious each and every time.  Once we came during happy hour where they have $3 drinks and appetizers, and I tried the matcha smoothie, and if you're a fan of green tea ice cream, you'll love it!
author: Pam S.

description:
Go here to watch TV.  Drink beer...  Maybe

Don't go here to eat food.  Your money would be best spent elsewhere.

They do have nice TVs...
author: Paul J G.

description:
I had the chicken okonomiyaki and gyoza.  My honey had yakisoba.  I didn't care for his dish b/c it looked unappetizing.  Sizzling greasiness.  Yuck.  

As for the gyoza, I like any kind of fried potsticker.  The okonomiyaki was good, but not great.  I still haven't found  okonomiyaki anywhere in the city that I've been wowed by.
author: Jeanne L.

description: low quality tasty food and good prices still, i dont come here because its taste like prepackage stuff but for a snack, its fine
author: B H.

description: I came here when it first opened and the ramen was not up to par. I was disappointed with the broth and the seafood was not fresh. So I came back here just recently for Happy Hour from 3-6pm (the magic words). My friend said they have a good HH menu. I got the sesame chicken wings, gyoza, croquette, and a bowl of ramen. I was full and got to spend time with friends whom I hadn't hung out with in awhile. The restaurant was pretty dead so it was peaceful. The space is simple and there's enough space between tables for some privacy. I liked the gyoza - crispy. The prices are $3 for appetizers and $3 for bottle beer. A decent place to go to for HH if you're in the Richmond area.
author: Candace F.

description:
3.25
This place was better than i expected. They have a bunch of big screen tvs so it was perfect to catch the first part of the giants game. They have a $3 happy hour but its not that great as it consists of various beers from the tap, popcorn chicken, fried squid, croques, and other various unimpressive finger foods. The three dishes we got were the chashu ramen with extra noodles ($1.50), the beef pepper stir fried noodles, and the seafood pancake. I was quite impressed with the seafood pancake as it was quite crispy and came out sizzling on a hot plate. I would definitely recommend it. The beef pepper noodle stir fry was also tasty, but nothing too special about it. I could have probably cooked something similar. The ramen was decent. The broth was above average but the noodles were not that impressive. Not chewy enough and became soggy as I was eating. The broth was pretty good though; not too salty and had good flavor. Overall, the prices are about average,the service was good, and the restaurant was very clean. I wouldn't mind coming back, especially for the seafood pancake.
author: Robert Y.

description: OMG!! I have been to several ramen houses all over the bay area and some in the south bay and Genki Ramen is THE Best I've had so far. If u are craving for some bomb ass ramen, you need to go to Genki. Awesome wait staff and a very nice ambiance. You have to try their tenderous pork ribs ramen. Sooo good and they don't skimp on the meat either like the other ramen places I've been to.
author: Michelle Z.

description:
Finally had a chance to check out this place.  Nice decor, inviting space.  Very "franchise-able" image.  Simple menu, seems to be a ramen house that offers one type of broth with a dozen or so choices of topping.  Some intriguing non-traditional ramen possibilities, some not as much (shrimp tempura ramen?).  Ramen - mouthwatering, shrimp tempura - mouthwatering, served together? mmm not completely sold.  Nice assortment of soju/sake cocktails and draft beer.  

Now to the food....

Nothing to woop about but an average bowl of ramen.  Soup was plain, could not tell if it was soy-sauce or pork broth.  Noodles are definitely store-bought and a little bit soft.  Bamboo tasted straight out of can as the syrup in the bamboo did not mix well with the soup.  Roast pork slices were ok.  Chicken Karaage here is EXCELLENT, i've read reviews here where they say theres a lot of batter.  Not mine, very crispy outside and inside is very tender and WELL seasoned.  Prices are extremely fair, if im fiending for ramen i could find myself coming back as Santa Ramen is not worth the drive/wait.  But Santa does have a superior bowl of ramen.
author: david w.

description: The thing that makes this a 4-star restaurant for me is that it's open late, until 1 on fridays and saturdays. I came here one night after getting home from work late on a friday night, around 9. I was starving, and lately I haven't been wanting to settle for D&A late night food. In search of another late night option, I found Genki on yelp. Whaaaat? I can have Japanese food past 10?? Ramen, you say? I had the curry ramen and the bf had yaki soba. Both were good, not bad. We also shared chicken karaage, which I remembered as being closer to not bad than actually good. Lots of variety in the menu for a place open past 9:30. I would come back again for another late dinner.
author: Jessie C.

description: The food at Genki Ramen is top notch. Their ramen bowls are delicious and their portions are pretty large. The watermelon blended drink was mind blowing! So sweet and frothy. The service there is pretty average. They have all female servers who are relatively attentive. They also have flatscreens all over the restaurant on the daily game which is a huge plus.
author: Eila S.

description: Never get the shrimp tempura ramen! Its so yucky when you dip it in the soup, and leaves a slimey after taste, the chicken karage is on point though
author: Sarah Z.

description:
I came here for dinner with a friend last night. Like a good little Yelper, I looked at their Yelp review page before I left work. From there, I clicked on their website. The first thing that caught my eye on their website wasn't the picture of a delicious-looking bowl of tonkatsu ramen, but a hyperlink labeled "Coupon". I then used the company printer and ink to print out a coupon for free crispy daimaru (deep-fried ring with cheese, spinach, and fish cake) or sesame wings. Woot woot!

Free food makes me happy, and free-food-related happiness makes me more inclined to give a good rating--which may be why Genki Ramen gets 3-stars instead of 2. (Because really, in Yelp words, "Meh. I've experienced better".)

My friend and I chose the CRISPY DAIMARU out of sheer curiousity as to what they were. What we got were 3 crispy deep-fried disc-shaped raviolis filled with cream cheese, spinach, and fish cake. They were served with a sweet chili dipping sauce. Since I like anything with cream cheese in it, I was a fan. Were they amazing? No. Would I normally order this? No, but I'll take any free food I can get =P

From their Happy Hour menu we got the potato croquette and takoyaki for $3 each. The CROQUETTES weren't anything special and were basically greasy mashed potato hash browns that weren't particularly flavourful. (I actually think I prefer McDonald's hash browns...) As for the TAKOYAKI, they were decent but looked like the frozen type you can find at Nijiya. (I'm 94% certain they don't make them in-house.) Even worse, they were soooo stingy with the okonomiyaki sauce (a few squiggles) and there weren't even any bonito flakes!

We then shared a few robata items. At all the other izakayas I've been to robata come in two skewers (or more) per order, so when I saw the prices here I thought they were very reasonable--until I realized you only get one skewer per order. (D'oh!) We got the ox tongue with salt, pork neck with soy sauce, and yaki onigiri (grilled rice ball with diced unagi). The OX TONGUE was horrible. It was tough and chewy--basically the furthest thing from melt-in-your-mouth. I didn't even finish the small skewer because I didn't want to waste calories on non-tasty food. The other two were a lot better. The PORK NECK was tender and fatty and I really liked the unagi in the YAKI ONIGIRI. The only problem was the too-sweet teriyaki sauce they were covered in. We also got an order of their "house specialty" BEEF & ENOKI ROLL. These just looked kinda... well, sad. For $6.75 we got 4 small rolls of sliced beef with enoki mushroom wrapped inside. There wasn't much flavour except for the spicy miso sauce they top the rolls with.

Lastly, we got the CHASHU RAMEN in tonkatsu broth. The pork was tender, the bamboo shoots were tasty, and the boiled egg was marinated well. I wasn't that impressed with the broth though. Sure, it had the creaminess I like in tonkatsu broths but it was just salty more than anything. It didn't make my lips smack and I've definitely had better.

Alas, my search for the best ramen in SF goes on...
author: Steph L.

description:
Always craving a bowl of hot, yummy noodles late in the eve. Maybe because it's colder at night and I'm down for good soup? Who knows but this common nocturnal state of mine lead me and some buddies to Genki Ramen at 10PM on a Wednesday night.

Since we were starving, we ordered:
*Veggie Gyoza, appetizer, 6 pieces
    -Way too oily, stuffing had no flavor and anemic
*Spicy Mussel, appetizer, 4 pieces
    -Melted cheese? Yeah, sounds gross but tastes better than you think
*Beef n' Enoki Roll, appetizer, 4 pieces
    -Holy...I would order 3 more of these if it weren't so expensive
*Spicy Mabo Tofu Ramen
*Chashu Ramen
*Nori Ramen

Food: 3 stars
*Appetizers were too oily, saturating food flavors
*The ramen was goodt, did what it had to do for late-night, starving students.
*Points for having a ton of options on the menu, much more extensive than typical noodle establishments; lots of pickings for vegetarians!
*Having a veggie option for broth gets another point
*My buddy ordered the Spicy Mabo Tofu Ramen with "additional richness" (which is just oil) - it does damage to the tummy so watch out!

Service: 4 stars
*One of our waitresses was nice enough to switch the onions in my Nori Ramen for bamboo for no charge, so point for them!
*Wasn't invasive or awkward

Extra Extra: 4 stars
*Genki Ramen is a hip place, with modern designs
*HUGE TV screens, yes!
*Clean AND visible kitchen

Final Cal:
*Late-night ramen run? Count me in!
author: Chuck N.

description: I've been here once and I ordered the Seafood Ramen with the Chicken Tonkatsu.  The ramen was good and I enjoyed it thoroughly, although I think that the portion was rather small.  The Chicken Tonkatsu on the other hand was a rip off.  It was $1 more on the lunch special menu.  I only got about 3 small pieces of chicken and they didn't taste that impressive at all.
author: Christopher K.

description: Look elsewhere for hype, jacked up prices, and artisinal ingredients like Meyer lemon and King Richard leeks. Come here for damn good ramen, solid service, a good vibe, laid-back crowd, nice beer list, soju cocktails, and great value. Everything I could ask for in a ramen spot.
author: Peter G.

description: Good place for ramen in the area, and they let me change the broth to vegetarian, which is great.
author: Phil J.

description: I tried this place out for the first time after being a regular customer at their Genki Crepes place on Clement. My hubby and I ended up ordering a few appetizers including the pot stickers which weren't as great as we hoped (a little soggy and not really fried enough) but our main dish which was the Seafood Yakisoba noodles were great. I also heard from my friend who ate here with me last time, she really enjoyed the ramen they have, though I still think the ramen here is a bit too over priced for something I can make at home for less than 2 bucks.
author: Petra S.

description: After writing the review for Sapporo-Ya Ramen restaurant it reminds me of the visit i paid to Genki Ramen, we went there when it first opened, i have to say they spend a lot of time decor this place, many flat tvs, nice tables and bars...etc. But after all the quality of the ramen is only ok, the portion is too small for me and it is a bit over priced. In addition the japanese MTV they play is kind of cheesy.
author: William C.

description:
I like ramen.  A couple of friends recommended this place and felt the need to try it last night to satisfy my ramen craving. My girlfriend and I ordered, Chashu, Veggie gyoza, & Chicken Nugget Robatayaki. It was a good amount of food for two. The ramen chashu was delicious. I really enjoyed the noodles and the broth.  

I have decided to rate a place by how quickly it makes me want to come back for more. I mean, a place can be good, but if a place is really good; You will make a point to return soon. I will rate Genki Ramen as a place I will return to in less than 3 weeks. 

If you enjoy ramen and a casual atmosphere, I would definitely find time to try genki.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Mm, every time I'm in town, Genki Ramen always hits the spot. This place was actually the first time I ever had curry ramen. I'm a fan of both the curry tonkatsu and curry chicken katsu ramen.

Too bad we were late to Happy Hour. We missed out on it by 11 minutes. It's okay, though. I ended up getting an interesting cocktail: a Splashy Aloe.

Yes, it's called a Splashy Aloe.

Now, I know it sounds weird since it contains aloe vera, and the first thing that pops up when you hear aloe is lotion, right? How in the world can you drink something that's like lotion?

Contrary to belief, aloe is drinkable, and it's pretty damn good. The Splashy Aloe had a mix of soju, grape soda, and aloe juice with aloe pulp. Yes, aloe pulp. It tasted like grape soju with chunky bits. A bit weird for a mixed drink, but still tasty, nonetheless.

I also tried the So Cool, which had soju and Yakult, and that was pretty tasty as well. Mm, yogurt soju.

Good stuff! I'll be sure to get another Splashy Aloe next time I come back.
author: Mylene A.

description: Seriously- they serve amazing ramen!!! Especially the soup! It's rich, flavorful broth.  The noodles are al dente. Chashu Ramen had the right ingredients and the Tenderous Rib Ramen was deliciouuuss.  The chicken karaage was crispy and savory. Takoyaki was out of this world. Okonomiyake was just right. Side dishes are authentically awesome such as deep fried tofu and endadame   beans.  I don't understand those prior bad reviews.  I've been to Halu (horribly thin broth and the okonomiyake was skimpy - a joke to Osaka's version and a disappointment). Tanpopo's ramen was not impressive at all.  Their ramen is just as good as Katana-Ya's.  This is the perfect ramen place for me - in my neighborhood too.  Delicious warm food when I come home.  Yum!!!
author: Sheue L.

description: My bowl was only half full when they served me.... the broth was way blow the noodle level (kind like dry noodle). i normally don't care about how much noodle i can get as long as there are enough broth... i asked for additional broth for my noodle... the waitress came back with small bowl of soup and give me the dirty look said ' normally we charge for the extra soup'..... WTH....it was not EXTRA.. you guys didn't give me enough at first place.....oh.. and get this.. they charged us 18% for tip.. we got party of 5...
author: zmomoko z.

description:
Downgrading this to 3 stars because the wait staff is not that friendly and understaffed.

Also because I just tried Katana-Ya and realized that it's better, and I gave it 4 stars, so this has to have a lower rating!!
author: James C.

description: Good chasu ramen and fast service.  Otherwise it is overpriced for the location.  Would come back for happy hour and some sports watching on their tvs. You can get cheaper ramen at Hotei.
author: C t.

description: If I had a hankering for some good old Japanese street food, I would definitely come here for their tapas menu.  A friend and I stopped by and ordered seven or eight of their starters to share and I must say the deep-friend soft-shell crab and oysters were the bomb!  will definitely be coming back....maybe tonight!
author: Ben T.

description:
Good food and open late!! Great combo!!! Had the chashu ramen and it was really good!! Especially at midnight after a few drinks!! Service was a little slow and not friendly. Don't think they hated me but I would definitely not try to chat these girls up! 

First time there, but there will definitely be many more!!
author: Robbie W.

description: Dinner here is lovely, yet we left with room for more. The ramen is pretty good, I don't understand the lack of noodles though. There is a lot of meat, but you don't get very many noodles. My tiny friend who eats like a hummingbird had to order an extra egg and eat some fried rice. She never finishes her food. Yet after her entire bowl of ramen and an extra egg, she wanted more. The fried rice was extremely tasty and had a ton of flavor, along with a slight aftertaste that I didn't really like as much. I would go back for ramen, but honestly I would much rather go to Ryowa in Berkeley or Mountain View. Then again, this is across town for me rather than across a bridge or across the entire bay.
author: Lorrie N.

description: Don't really understand the popularity of Genki Ramen. It's ok and would eat here if in the neighborhood. There aren't a lot of good ramen houses to choose from in the richmond and sunset district. To get super delish ramen you'd need to go to sf downtown or the peninsula. But if I don't want to run all the way to either, I'd settle for Genki.
author: Sassy G.

description:
Came for lunch today with a group of 7.  Seated immediately but then waited...and waited...and waited for someone to come take our order.

Finally flagged our waitress down and I ordered the chashu ramen.  They somehow got all 7 of our ramen orders out to our table in under 10 minutes - awesome.  Noodles were perfectly al dente and broth had great flavor.  Chashu was tasty; much better than the negi beef, which I found to be very oily...and not in a good way.

Overall a solid, reasonably priced ramen shop.
author: grace o.

description: My friends love this place - for me, it was ok. I didn't hate it, but I didn't love it. The ramen didn't make me as happy as it made my friends. I tried the seafood ramen (#405).
author: Claudia R.

description: I had their Spicy Mabu Tofu and loved it! I can't say much for anything else sadly. The soup base is good and the ramen is decent.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Good food, but MSG. The ramen is good and some of the appetizers are tasty. Service is usually pretty decent, but i've had one bad experience before.

My GF ordered curry katsu donburri. When they brought out just katsu. So we asked what gives with the curry. her response, "only on the lunch special"

Well why the fuck didn't you tell me it wasn't on there when we ordered. Shit. 

Only one bad experience. Most of the time this place is good and its open late enough.
author: Steven C.

description:
If you are going to have RAMEN as part of your name, then make the broth.  This stuff is from the package. 

The pork has a lot of flavor.  Now, if it were not mushy, it would be very nice.  The noodles are actually al dente, which is good.  This is how I arrive at the two stars.

If there are any native Japanese running this place, and I doubt it, it's time to fall on the ol' sword.  The great part about great, native, Japanese cooking, is in the details.  Take the rice ball for example.  Genki Ramen serves you a bonito flake rice ball... NO soy sauce inside.  And the croquet?  It's priced like you are going to get cream inside and a tasty one... but no.  It has nothing inside and looks like it was made by the Gordon Fisherman.  

Granted, they are trying to do cooky nutty things here, but there are some simple basics to keep one in the realm of quality Japanese food.  Aint happen'n at Genki.  

Bummer... would love to have some great Ramen in this area!
author: Dan M.

description:
This place is.. mediocre. A group of friends and myself stopped by here one evening to get some yummy food.  The atmosphere is really nice (+1 star) and the food didn't make me die (+1 star) but their service is just crazy!  My friend wanted a katsu donburi, not noticing that it was a lunch menu item.  The waiter said he could get it anyway but it would cost more because it was a "special"  Fine.  So four of us get our food, except for my donburi buddy.  I had some yummy curry chicken  katsu with rice, good portion and not too much money (+1).  After about 10 minutes they came over with another chicken curry katsu dish, totally not the donburi special that my friend ordered. 

"That's not what I ordered"
"Yes it is"
"No..."

waiter leaves, brings the dish to a different table (?) and then goes back to where the chef is.  15 minutes later they come back with a bowl with white rice on the bottom and some pieces of chicken on top.  No sauce, no egg, no veggies, not donburi.  At this point my friend is starving, we're all finished eating so he just gives up and takes it.

We asked for separate checks, but he just divided our group in half and gave us two checks, go figure.  We used a debit card, and the original receipt they gave us said the "donburi" was 6.95, then they gave us the second receipt, you know the one you sign, with a "special" costing an extra dollar.  This lead my friend to argue with the waiter and even began explaining what donburi was because they obviously don't know.  

A negative experience, but definitely hilarious to see my friend give a Japanese food lesson to a waiter.
author: Jenn F.

description: My cousin lives down the street from here. I loooooove their butter and corn ramen. Loud funky music and great vibe. Service is on cue. Sometimes their is a wait in the evening but still pretty fast.
author: Madeline W.

description:
Earlier tonight, the six of us decided on some Ramen to warm us up after a hardcore evening of boardgames (yes, we are quite the party animals...aren't we?). 

Now, I'll be quite blunt, Ramen (for me) isn't as good as the Vietnamese soups at Ranch 99 in Berkeley. However, the Ramen dish I ordered was okay, and my friends didn't have any big issues with the Ramen they ordered. 

The staff is polite, this establishment is very clean, and the Ramen is pretty good. If in the neighborhood, and it's cold outside, I recommend some Ramen from this place, try the seafood or the BBQ pork Ramen.
author: Darrel D.

description:
I don't know why all the reviews of this place seem to be negative.  I thought it was pretty good.  I had a vegetarian ramen.  It was packed with veggies and I enjoyed it.  Cheap too.  

Having just been to Japan, I would say that what really makes this place great is that it's very authentic Japanese.  It's very much in the style of fast food places in areas of Tokyo like Shibuya, full of young people, very mod and trendy decor with cheap fast food.  

The staff was kinda spacey and slow and not terribly warm and considering the near emptiness of the place on a Friday night it should've been better.

Service aside though, I like the fact that there's a spot outside of Japantown to get some good CHEAP ramen (i.e. not Hotei) and I'll be trying it again.
author: M M.

description: Great place to get take-out. Not everything on the menu is good, but I'm definitely a fan of the Chahan-- kinda oily pork fried rice but is nutty and delicious with cabbage in it. We always get the gyoza too (pork or veggie- both good).
author: Sandy H.

description:
Sorry to give such a bad review but this place SUCKS! I don't know if it was because they are not use to having such a large party or what but the food and the service was terrible. 

It was my nephews birthday and he loves Ramen so a family member suggested this place . We ordered our drinks have to say very yummy ! but unfortunately only half the table got drinks before our food started coming out which was like 45 min wait . Once the food was out it was super greasy tempura and the beef was more fat than meat ......I mean that was all you tasted ..... a few in our party had the Ramen which was okay ..... Beware extra veg tables means cabbage ! But to top it off two people didn't get their orders until the entire table was already done eating they had ordered the chicken teriyaki. Overall it was all bad ........
author: Mari B.

description: First time eating Kimchi Ramen. I gave only 3 stars because I imagine this could be better. Fairly bland all around, but still very good. Went around 4:30, and they have a happy hour from 3-5. For the amount of food I got for 7.95, I will definitely go back. Quick service, nice decor
author: Anne L.

description:
I love coming to Genki Ramen for lunch and/or dinner. Most of the time I dine here during dinner. The atmosphere is really cool and almost mysterious. Check the website for a monthly coupon, usually valid for a free appetizer during dinner. However, I must dock one star because the service is not up to par. Refilling tea takes forever and most of the time, the servers ignore your table. Exhibit A: I was holding the check for a few minutes before the waiters standing around the bar chatting finally got the note.

I love the tea that's served here. I drink cups and cups of it every time. As for the main entree, I've tried the butter & corn ramen, chashu ramen, shrimp tempura ramen, and chicken kaarage ramen. I think the noodles used to be better quality (thicker) since my chicken kaarage ramen seemed to have finer noodles during lunch today. The chicken kaarage was fried to perfection. I can't wait for my face to breakout, wait, it already is. 

I also opt for the yakisoba entrees when I'm not down for ramen in soup. Now, the yakisoba is smothered in oil so be warned! My friends and I refer to yakisoba as "oily goodness" and it's basically stir-fried ramen with mixed veggies, cabbage, and whatever other ingredient you choose (beef, chashu, kimchi, spicy, etc.) I've tried the kimchi and spicy yakisoba dishes and both are good. The portions aren't fulfilling enough for me, though. This goes for both soup ramen and yakisoba. It might be best to go with an appetizer. During happy hour (3-7pm) many appetizers are $3, but for lunch combinations with soup ramen, an additional $1 will get you either: 2 pcs gyoza (pot stickers), chashu fried rice, or chicken kaarage. Not a bad deal, except maybe the 2 piece gyoza. I've never seen anyone order any rice here but I might try that another time. Genki Ramen is open pretty late but if you around 30 minutes before closing, all orders are forced to be take out. I do recall eating at Genki Ramen after watching movies at AMC Van Ness. It was a great place to chill for a few, actually until closing at 1am and walked all the way to Ocean Beach via Geary Blvd. since no 38 was showing up.
author: Dominic T.

description:
Tasteless food...literally.

The service here is average without any astounding experiences shared, the two times I've been here.  The food though...it's almost bland!  The flavor is lacking--but there must be a reason for this, and I think I might know what it is.  Their interior decor and graphic layout and photography in their menu--although a bit generic modern, based on my opinion as a designer myself--shows off a side of eye candy that their food does not live up to.  In other words, they look better than they taste.  Overall, they are not worth your money.  Go elsewhere for good ramen.
author: Terence K.

description: I like Genki Ramen because it's close to my house and I'm a noodle freak. Each comes in a big portions, I like to order lunch combo with side order of fried chicken (yum). My son loves their kids meal (rice, fries, chicken teriyaki, yogurt drink) while my DH loves their mapo tofu soup. Bathroom clean, servers polite, reasonable price, good food.
author: GreasynCrunchy H.

description:
Feeling a bit weary of the standard chasu tonkotsu ramen, I opted for the spicy mabu tofu with a topping of corn.  The waitress was kind enough to accomodate my request for a mild level of spiciness, which provided a kick without overwhelming the flavor of the broth.

The tonkotsu half of the broth was a bit lighter and watery than what I prefer, while the mabu tofu sauce was quite thick and heavy.  The noodles had a nice silky consistency, though slightly overcooked.  The corn was sweet and buttery and provided a nice counterbalance to the tangy and slightly sour mabu tofu.  Overall, the mix felt a bit jarring and haphazard, though an interesting experiment.

Also ordered a skewer of salted fish, which was flaky, oily, and flavorful.
author: Jeremy C.

description: After being disappointed with Japan Town closing down at 10 and with Ramen on the brain and with a handful of texts to friends to see where we could find a bowl of ramen. Genki was the consensus. Right away we ordered a big tall glass of Sapporo and hot Sake. Its was nice to see the Izakaya type menu with offerings such as Chicken Karage, Nasu Gomaae and Spicy Mussels but after a 35 mile bike ride and 2 hours in a Korean spa I only had one thing in mind the Chasu Ramen. They even give you one of the best candies in my opinion a HiChew!
author: Peter S.

description:
Ok, since the place was called "Genki Ramen" I decided to have the ramen of course. I didn't think I could even tell the difference between different ramens (having been to Santa, Hawarami, Tanpopo etc) but I think I can now differentiate a bit. The broth wasn't as tasty, and the noodles felt a bit. Not bad, but not great.

Service was definitely slow. Had to flag down the staff when i wanted to get anything.

The appetizers were good, gyoza had a surprising tasty ginger flavor to them.

I'll have to try some other other less traditional ramens (ma po, kimchee). Those rice dishes look good. 

Will update when I go back.

Oh yeah, the decor was very nice and definitely very welcoming.
author: Alex C.

description:
I think it's the best tasting ramen in San Francisco. Really really good. 

We were so delighted to have randomly stumbled in here one night. What a hidden gem.
author: Jon N.

description:
I thought the ramen was pretty good here.  Their prices are a little higher than I would like but it's pretty much in line with most noodle houses that try to look "modern".  

But for the price, they give you pretty much.  The bowl is a little misleading.  It looks like there isn't as much as they give you but once you get to the bottom of the bowl, you will probably be pretty stuffed.  

And the broth they make is pretty thick and really tasty.  

FRIDAYS AND SATURDAYS: Open Until 1am

HAPPY HOUR DEETS: (3p-7p Daily)
$3 Drinks & $3 Appetizers
author: Mark W.

description:
Pretty good if you're desperate for ramen and can't get out of the city.

Do yourself a favor and drive down to Santa Ramen. You won't regret it. Get a side of stewed pork if you can get there before they're sold out.
author: Kevin L.

description:
This is more like a 3.5 star review. The extra 1/2 star was for the restaurant's tolerance of our large group, which included 4 loud and messy preschoolers.

If it's a Sunday afternoon, and you're in the mood for ramen, and all your usual J-town haunts are closed...you could come here to get your fix. But, be warned that the ramen noodles are on the soggy side, and don't have that chewy homemade texture that better places have. The broth (chashu) we had was flavorful, though, with fresh meats and veggies. 

I had a chicken okonomiyaki (pan-fried potato pancake with meats and veggies, with special sauce) and it was solid but not mind-blowing. Served piping hot on a heavy skillet, it was on the bland side, but the okonomiyaki sauce on top was quite tasty. The service was attentive though a bit forgetful (we had to ask for our drinks twice). Dishes were served up promptly but the kitchen got my order wrong and I had to wait doubly long for my dish. 

Ambiance: Asian-style casual cafe, with contemporary decor and flat-screen TVs all along the walls. I liked the dark wood floors and custom chairs. 

I'd say this is a good place to go for late-night munchies (open til 1am on weekends). It' also a good lunch or dinner place for groups, and families with small kids.
author: SfMom O.

description:
First visit I had the kimchi ramen soup.  Yummy, with lots of leftovers.  I was a bit disturbed the following day when I pulled the leftovers out of the fridge for lunch and found my soup had become a gelatinous blob that plopped into my bowl.

Second visit I ordered ramen noodles with curry veggies.  Veggies were ok, but the noodles were a stringy pile of glue.  Blech!  My friend ordered some very tasty asparagus wrapped in bacon.  So good and the asparagus wasn't overcooked.

The loungy atmosphere is nice, even when crowded it didn't seem loud and the service was good.  I would like to see the disposable wooden chopsticks replaced by reusable chopsticks.  And be sure to get a table that allows you to sit with your back to the wall of plasma televisions. I can watch tv at home.
author: Amy M.

description:
3.5 stars

Friend recommended Genki Ramen, so decided to stop by last night for dinner with some friends.  The menu offers a great assortment of ramen, okonomiyaki, appetizers and robatayaki.  

I ordered a Garlic Ribs (soft bone) with silky tofu and spicy miso.  Then we shared Takoyaki (octopus balls with sauce and bonito flakes), ox tongue robatayaki  and my friends ordered chashu ramen, spicy sausage and chicken okonomiyaki.  I enjoyed my Garlic Ribs ramen, they had some fried garlic pieces in the meat broth and the ramen was cooked to an al dente texture which I liked.  The other food that I tried from my friends were ok.  The takoyaki was pretty good, very hot and tasty.  The ox tongue unfortunately had no flavor and we had to add salt and pepper.  The spicy sausage okonomiyaki was pretty good (the okonomiyaki in Japantown tastes a lot better).  They served it on a sizzling plate with a cute cutting utensil.

Service really sucked.  They were understaffed with only two servers and one buser.  The girl got our order wrong and I kept thinking she was going to add stinky tofu because that was what she kept repeating.  We had to flag the server so many times for simple thing like getting the bill, paying the bill and just getting simple condiments like salt and pepper.

Atmosphere is nice and clean.  I actually liked the tvs at all angles so there is something to watch.  

I would come back when I feel like ramen closeby and some variety in my menu.
author: Yun W.

description: Had Chasu Ramen.  I lived in Japan for 2 years, I think that although this isn't the best Ramen I ever had the pleasure of having, it was very high quality and extremely well balanced and prepared.  Overall very good experience.
author: John D.

description:
Ive been here several times before and found that i hadn't yelped it yet! :O
I usually come here for the Ramen and they are open late which makes for a good midnight snack if i am in the area.  It doesn't get real busy here but a good amount of ppl flow in and out of this place.  I came here for lunch to treat my co-worker since his bday was last month and we were both busy the whole month. I opted for the Chasu Ramen and he got the Chicken Kaarage Ramen. I also got a Matcha swirl which is a like a green tea smoothie wit whip cream and some powdered Matcha on top. My guess is that there is green tea ice cream in their since i have tired to duplicate this and have made a good one but their is still something that is missing, not sure if i will ever figure out wat that is tho. The Chasu Ramen came with about 4-5 pieces of well seasoned chasu that literally melted in my mouth. I think it was a bit too tender, cuz i didn' t have to chew much. lol.  The noodles are always good and so is the broth.  I also ordered their Karrage which is good but not as meaty as other places. I think Genki Ramen of a place to grab a quick eat or a snack like their sister store. I need to come back here for their 3pm-7pm happy hour, but i have temporarily given up drinking for a while.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
