I love ramen! I really like miso soup based chashu ramen. I get it every time I order ramen. It's sort of like how I always get my Pho Tai at pho places. Hrm, Genki Ramen is a good ramen place. The service is relatively good, they give you seconds on the kimchi pickle thing which is nice. There are tv's everywhere broadcasting various basketball games, which is nice. It seems like the place is trying to go for sort of a sportsbar/clubby atmosphere. I like the TV's, I give a thumbs down for the atmosphere. The music is thumpy and not food music, as if we're in a club. You don't eat ramen in a freakin club. Also, the lighting sucks, it really gives the food an unappetizing hue.

The ramen isn't the best I've had, but I like the texture of the ramen and the soup base. 

I like the croquette cuz it's crispy, but tastes vary since my bro didn't like it at all.
author: Shizuka L.

description: I had a client across the street that I needed to see and after that I decided to check out Genki Ramen.  The waitress recommended the chu-shu ramen and that's what I ordered.  It's was a good bowl of ramen.  Service was good (I went around 2:30 pm so not a busy time).  I know this is not a very descriptive review...it was A-OK.
author: Brent T.

description: Ramen was only ok, service was only ok, which makes the price not ok.
author: daphne w.

description: Decent Ramen out in the Avenues. I'd go for the skewers though. The shishito peppers and scallion wrapped beef were the best.
author: Scott M.

description:
I'd recommend this place.

Food: My friends and I came just in time for happy hour 3-6pm. Ordered a few appetizers: chasu, gyoza, and the tayokaki. All three of these dishes were perfectly flavored. I especially loved the tayokaki for its texture. Yum. I went on and ordered the curry tonkatsu ramen. I was able to eat every bit of what was in the bowl, which was greatly portioned, making it your money's worth even though it was almost $9. The tonkatsu  was crispy just the way I like it. I find some places being too oily, too burned, not crispy enough. The ramen itself was sooo good, which went well with the curry dipping sauce.

Service: Our server was a cute Asian girl. She was attentive, not excellent, but there's no room for complaints.

Atmosphere: This place is really cute. Being in there brings you away. Very pretty shade of green and comfy cute dining chairs and table. The lighting went well with the food, too.
author: Presh J.

description: Super casual atmosphere with friendly service. I got the Chashu ramen - The broth was hearty and tasty. Noodles were cooked well and there was a ton of chashu pork (although sometimes it can be really fatty and/or tough). I also really liked that they serve hard boiled (not soft) eggs. You can add additional toppings for an extra charge. Gyoza was just so so.
author: Maria Y.

description: This is another fake Japanese restaurant owned by Chinese or Korean. None of their food meets the standard to be called Japanese. My friend ordered Noodle with Meat Source, first of all, this is not a Japanese dish. It was disgusting, she had to throw it away. I had Okonomiyaki--this was NOT even close.to real Okonomiyaki. Once again, we had to waste it--it was really nasty, and really all the wrong ingredients to call it Okonomiyaki.  Ramen is not really ramen, either; however, this is probably better than most of dishes served here. I seriously don't understand why people would give this place anything better than 3 stars.
author: Ken S.

description: What I like about this place is that it's opened late even on weekdays. I think my friend and I were hungry at 9:50pm or so and this place happened to be open. Based on the photos on yelp, the food looks delicious but I couldn't tell from my experience because the place was so unbelievably dark. The meal is pretty pricey for the portions. The ramen is pretty good but everything else seems to be lackluster choice. The place is decent and I'll probably come here again in the daylight.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Genki is a little ganky... 

The menu in the window is very appealing. The clean interior is very appealing. The 5 flat screen tv's showing sports is very appealing. However, the food is just mediocre. It was definitely edible but not something stellar enough to return back to.
author: Josephine H.

description:
Good place to go on a cold winter's night when you're feeling sick.  Their spicy mapo tofu broth made me feel tads better.

Open late, especially on Fridays and Saturdays so infinitely better choice to come here for late night snacks then Mel's.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
This place has delicious ramen!!!! The mabo tofu ramen is nice and spicy, prepare to sweat! If you order the side of chicken for a dollar more and place it in the ramen, let it soak then eat it..it's AMAZING!!!!!

The decor of the place is modern and chic. I like it. The bathroom is also nice and clean, that's a plus!

They serve you hot tea, and are friendly and attentive.

I like going to this place for ramen!
author: Chatree T.

description:
The ramen here is okay.  It is not great, not good, just plain okay.  If I craved for ramen, I would not be coming here if I had a choice.  The reason why I say that is that the one thing it does have going for them as far as I am concerned is their location.  They are super close to where I spend most of my time...at work!

Service is okay.  The decor is cool.  But at the end of the day, my first sentence is all that really matters....the ramen here is okay.
author: Stella C.

description:
The bathroom here is indeed very nice and zen. 

I had the Chasu Ramen - noodle soup with house made boiled pork served with half boiled egg, bamboo shoot and green onion.

The BF had the Curry Tonkatsu Ramen - noodle soup with deep fried pork chop coated with curry sauce.

The decor was very stylish and hip, with flat screen tvs.

The food wasn't bad, the service was okay.
author: Helena H.

description:
Either they need a new cook or need to know what Japanese foods are. 
They couldn't even make decent rice for my order, not once but three times. If a Japanese restaurant can't even cook decent rice, better to close down the business. 
Never coming back here.
author: Younjin L.

description:
not too bad. i wish they had udon, though. minimal selection, but still good soup. i ordered agedashi tofu and it was really small. =( but what i am happy about is that they have yam & pumpkin tempura appetizer! like 4pieces of each- my favorite!

i like how they open late of fridays and saturdays!
author: Rosalee C.

description:
Tried this place at my brother's recommendation.   It was pretty good.   We came at 5:30pm just in time for happy hour.   We had the croquettes and the takoyaki.  Both were very good.    

My friends had the chicken salad, and one of the pancakes.  I had the seafood cold ramen with the spicy creamy dressing.   It needed a little more flavor... so I mixed the sauce that came with the croquette and it was just right.   

My friends had a beer and a cocktail that they liked.  I liked the fact that they had a non-alcoholic happy hour drink, too.   I had the maccha swirl which was a blended green milk tea with whipped cream.  That might have been more like dessert.  but oh so yum.....

All in all the food was decent, drinks were good and the restaurant was clean and modern looking.   4 stars!
author: Regi K.

description:
I love their green tea smoothie and seafood ramen. That's awesome because I won't have to drive to Japan Town anymore. The service was fine when my friends and I went there. We went during happy hour. It's a friendly bar set up with TVs that I like. 

We have had a couple of appetizers including Takoyaki that I wouldn't order next time but that's just my personal preference. Chicken Katsu is excellent. 

It was a nice overall experience.
author: MS K.

description:
I went there last week craving for some good ramen.

I usually order the Chasu Ramen. This time I got the garlic tenderous rib ramen. The meat is tender and juicy, just a thad too salty. We also had the Chicken Karragae, fried chicken nuggets and gyoza, which are both very good. The gyoza skin is thin and cripsy while the chicken nuggets are crunch outside but soft and moist inside.
author: Wynne K.

description:
Very nice decor, extremely clean. 

Staff was friendly, but the place was a bit empty (between the lunch and dinner rushes. 

I had the Okonomiaki and it definitely was tasty, if not out of this world. Will need to try the Ramen when I go back. 

I was a bit skeptical with all the time making the place look fancy, but prices were fair and food was good.
author: Christian H.

description:
So I came to this place for the first time after my twin and little wanted something soupy for their sicknesses.  My initial impression of the restaurant could be quoted by my twin's words exactly, "I can't decide whether or not this place is supposed to be fancy or casual."  Haha.  It's got nice quality furniture and bar, but there were like eight tv's in such a small space (all on different channels, btw), the ceiling tile tracks were painted red with no tiles, and disposable chopsticks.  Anyway, my little ordered the chashu ramen and my twin and I both got the curry tonkatsu.

Now, after living in Japan for four months and tasting the most amazing ramen (and other japanese dishes for that matter) ever, I prepared myself for mediocre food.  Which, is not to say that far off.  The ramen was a little undercooked in my opinion (I'm used to super soft noodles), rather chewy... but otherwise tasted pretty good.  The curry tonkatsu was on point but not enough curry for all the rice.  Mmm.  And I love, love, love milk tea... so I ordered one without caramel.  It's the closest thing I've found to my favorite brand back in Nippon.

3 stars for the so-so food, +1 for the wide variety on the menu of nihon tabemono staples (which I will definitely be back to try - i.e. okonomiyaki), -1 for the confusing decor.
author: Stephanie C.

description: I've been meaning to yelp about this place, but haven't had the time. I went to Santa Ramen last night and throughout the meal all I could think about was, Genki Ramen.. This place has a WIDE variety of ramen, as well as appetizers and drinks!!!  Sweet location, although I have to admit parking is a beeotch! I have had the chicken curry and seafood ramen so far and no complaints at ALL. Genki, never again shall I forsake you!
author: Karen A.

description:
awwwwww....yeeeaahhh!!! review 43 is dedicated to AB.

never a sad face at Genki Ramen. Bring an empty belly and your chopsticks, and get ready to ramen-ble.

can't resist the Chashu ramen in the tonkotsu broth. now I get it with veggies (see, Mom?) (about $8.00)

start with the bacon-wrapped asparagus rolls for an amazingly yummy treat for about $2.50.

the gyoza must be hand-made there. the wrappers are so delicate and the filling is delicious. (about $4.50)

all-in-all, super cheap for the quality. NO MSG EVER.
author: Blue R.

description: Decent Ramen, but coming from LA it is just okay. Good for a quick fix but nothing to wow about.
author: Ken Y.

description: Their delivery service is great, their food is decently priced and satisfying, and their menu is vast enough to satisfy most.  The roomies and I order here alot.
author: Clarissa P.

description: Skip the skewers, overpriced for the small portion.  The seafood okono miyaki is good, definitely unique.  Seafood ramen is mediocre.
author: Tracy H.

description: 4 stars for ramen, a 5th star because they deliver to the depths of the Presidio (in a timely fashion and without getting lost to boot)!!! Ramen noodles are good, chasu is tender and broth is tasty. Kudos because noodles and soup are in separate containers and noodles do not get mushy. Love online ordering because orders are transmitted accurately. A new go-to delivery restaurant!
author: Adrienne C.

description:
SF Food Inspection Rating: 88

the ramen is amazing. and they have skewered appetizers called robatayaki which is affordable and delicious. bacon wrapped asparagus is my favorite and you get four skewers (though small) for under $5. 

they have really good cocktails for $5 too and they're quite large. you might be able to share them.

it used to be open til 2am for the late night drinkers at fizees but they changed their hours. 5-11 i believe which isn't so bad.

but don't get the shu mai because it's totally from costco.
author: Kristina C.

description:
Food Genre: Japanese Ramen, Donburi (big rice bowls), Yakisoba (stewed food in a pot), also Asian alcohol bar and desserts

Atmosphere: Hip, chique, very nice interior design.....draws crowds in the evenings.....seems to be Chinese owned(?), Japanese MV playing on 3 different tv screens, reminds me of one of those chique HK fruit and dessert places but just Japanese, I anticipate a few hot chicks there during busy times

Price: Fairly priced...not cheap, not terribly expensive....$10 is enough for a bowl of Ramen and a $1 add-on dish.

Quality: Adequate to pretty good ramen noodles, good enough to keep going back...but not the best out there, broth is good

So, yeah, my older bro and I went here after his doctor appointment in the morning and got there at about 11:30am with only a couple other patrons inside. 2 Asian girls in their 20s were working there at the time....only avg looking tho. I was excited to try another Japanese ramen place...espec since I didnt have to wait 30 min to sit down at this one (Santa Ramen in San Mateo). Price was fair to slightly pricey depending on your view. This was a lunch menu....not sure what they have or how much it costs after 5pm which is the lunch cutoff time.

I ordered the Chashu Ramen which had pork and added $1 for a bowl of Chicken katsu. Service was quick and courteous.

I just love the interior atmosphere and design and the location on Geary @ 4th. So convenient. Next time I go, I intend to try a cocktail...or 2....and maybe split a dessert.
author: Gilbert C.

description:
Their appetizers are really appetizers, because they're TINY!
Service was...decent. They took a while to come over to check on us for our orders. Fried calamari was eh, and so was the ramen.

Genki ramen has nice decor, but it's a little too... in your face. Prices were so so. I wouldn't come back here unless i found myself desperate for bland japanese food.
author: Dan N.

description:
Lately I've become addicted to ramen, and Genki Ramen delivers so that's grand. I have ordered online from grubhub probably a gazillion times in the last two weeks already. D:

The ramen itself is okay, though quite tasty. I like.
author: Ringo M.

description:
While watching the NBA Dunk Contest between Dwight Howard and Nate Robinson on the big screens, I enjoyed a nice hot shrimp tempura ramen on a very very cold day. :)

Yay for Nate Robinson! Yay for Genki Ramen!

I did see the two waitresses that everyone talked about but maybe my group caught them on a good day. The place was pretty packed and we still got our food pretty quickly. Originally we wanted to sit on the bar but they gave some odd reasoning about how we were only 4 and the bar seats 6. Nonetheless, it was fun times and the ramen was yummy.
author: Joanna L.

description: I love it because I cannot get Chicken Curry Cutlet Ramen anywhere else.  Ingenious dish and it's always cooked perfectly when I order it.  I wish I could comment on the other dishes on the menu, but I've actually only ordered this dish every time I go... and I don't think that will change anytime soon!
author: S R.

description: Not bad. Looks a little more upscale than most ramen places I've seen. I got the chicken katsu ramen. It was good, but not amazing. I friend got the Ya-sai (?) ramen and it was delicious. I would suggest adding meat to it since that particular one didn't have any. It was veggie based.
author: Jacqueline N.

description:
So I've never actually stepped foot in this place, but their delivery is fantastic, and actually pretty quick!  Their regular miso is ok, but the spicy Miso is oh so yummy, especially in the seafood ramen with a half egg and bamboo! 

And you absolutely must try their beef and enoki mushroom rolls.  The mayo sauce makes this dish, so if your not a mayo fan, stay away.  Otherwise, enjoy the delicious flavor of PURE HEAVEN.

I'd give it five stars if their delivery.com minimum weren't $20 (hint, hint)

MMmmm, I'm hungry now.
author: Peter T.

description: Good food at good prices, even better, great drinks at GREAT prices, oops, I hope I didn't give it away....Soju based yummy mixed bevs at 6-7 a pop, cheers to that! Miso pork ramen with corn, not too bad, the noodles were plenty and the broth was tasty. Service was excellent, was surprised at the fact that this place wasn't packed on a Friday evening but meh, more room for me and my appetite. I'll have to be back for more.
author: Natasha C.

description: The chashu ramen is not bad, but it satisfies the craving on a cold rainy day =)
author: Erin L.

description:
The food is good.  I would recommended it for that.

Now here's the bad.

I've been to this place 3 times.
First time, they screwed our order up and tried to blame us.
Second time they forgot to cook our food as we were waiting for 30 minutes.
Third time we went 10 minutes before happy hour ended, ordered, but the slow male looking waitress was slow at walking to the computer and it locked him/her out of the happy hour prices.

All this occured even though we were the only ones there all three times.

Three strikes you are out.  Will not return for poor service.
author: Vance K.

description: Love this place! I've tried a couple other Ramen dishes, but I must say the Curry Beef Ramen is hands down my favorite. Although I don't live in the City, I definitely make the trip to SF just for Genki.
author: marisa o.

description: Enjoyed the chicken karaage and spiced pepper beef yakisoba.  Good price and portion size.  Looks like they have some great happy hour specials, but don't think I'll ever make it to this neighborhood between 3-6PM.
author: Josh K.

description:
My mom's been raving about this place and we finally tried it last night. There are many places we go to in SF for Japanese. We are all natives and have our staple places we like. But now that we have a toddler we are some what limited in our selection when it comes to kid friendly places. Well, this place is kid friendly. The menu is very unique and they also have a kids menu too. 
I was not feeling that adventurous last night so I ordered the chicken teriyaki which I thought would be common but it came on a sizzling plate sauteed with mixed vegetables. It was quite yummy! My husband had this pancake dish with chicken that was creamy inside and crunchy on the outside...and it was so good too! The couple sitting next to us had ramen and a chicken kaarage appetizer which looked great! My son actually feel asleep before our food came to the table so we really had a chance to savor our food and enjoy our evening. We will definitely be coming back soon as my mouth is watering just writing this review.
author: Camille S.

description: I like this place but the folks that work there are not from Japan and really make you feel like an ass when you call up and order. I guess that's the bay for yea...! Its like asking about a taco and they are like "what number is that on the menu" wtf...
author: swys -.

description: I drive all the way from the East Bay for this place (as the Chashu ramen is very yummy) but my boyfriend complains that their soba stir fry makes him feel sick. We've tried both the beef and chicken on separate occasions, and both were almost too spicy to eat. Their parking is also very limited, and only one small parking lot exists nearby. Besides that they have good tempura, unique appetizers, and Japanese drinks! Will eat at Genki Ramen again!.
author: Y A.

description:
I knew this was not authentic when I saw "tempura ramen" listed on the menu.  Nonetheless, the curry katsu ramen was delicious.  Most places will serve very thin and rather overdone katsu, but here it was battered up and fried to a juicy crisp.  The noodles have a bite to them and the broth is good.  But again, not authentic by any means.

I wonder how many people order the chicken gristle?
author: Janut B.

description:
You must like to eat chinese food if you eat here, because that is what it is.  Chinese food wearing a kimono.  

The food here is so terrible I almost asked for my money back. Its kind of like sushi rock, nice ambiance, cute enough servers, but soul less cookie cutter chinese food dressed to look japanese.

Save your money !
author: Spanky M.

description:
I just had an all girls dinner there last night! 

I had no problem making reservations for a table of 8. The staff was friendly and didn't throw us the tab to create the feeling for us to leave. We were there for pretty long too.

This is by far the best ambiance for eating ramen in the bay area. Nice, clean, trendy, and even a good restroom. Questionable at those in the hole places, where their food is really good, but their restroom is so ghetto and dirty! 

Now the food, the ramen was okay, not the best like Ryowa or Santa Ramen, but still good.  I prefer the thick curly noodles from Ryowa in Mtn View, vs straight. Most places do serve straight noodles however. 

food item scores

Ramen 3.75 stars
Blue Night Cocktail 1.75 stars
Potato Croquette- 4.25 stars
Chicken Karaage- 3.75 stars
Vegetable Tempera- 4 stars

They have a big list of sake. The blue night cocktaiil I chose was a disappoint. Too sugary. Didn't have a nice balance. I will try some desserts next time. 

Parking was fine- meter parking opens up for 6pm- free. Was not too hard to find at all. 

It's one of my preferred SF dining choices!
author: Connie Y.

description:
If you're craving noodles for around $8-$9 a plate, this place is right for you.

Interior looks pretty good for a restaurant on Geary. There's about 4 TV's along the walls and a lot of places to sit and also a bar just or drinking sake. The food there is alright. I ordered chicken sobayaki and my girl ordered okonomiyaki. We ended up sharing the meals and they made a great combination. Their strawberry mochi makes a great dessert as well. They also have a Japanese yogurt beverage (alcoholic) called "so cool" which seriously tastes like liquid yogurt. 

My only gripe was that we ate there around 4:30PM while nobody else was eating there, and the waitresses STILL were just sitting around, not asking how the food was or anything. I always had to call them over instead of them doing that themselves. 

Other than that, the food was good and I would eat there again; perhaps at a sooner/later time when there's more customers other than myself and my lady.
author: Michael S.

description: Good vegetarian options. Not sure that it was fantastic but it wasn't bad.
author: Leily P.

description: i really wanted to like this place until i found a huge thing of plastic in my food... will not be going back
author: Seaera T.

description: Came here with my friend to have ramen because it was the closes I could find innrichmond. When I order my ramen I asks her can I add pork belly to my noodles. She gave me a weird look and asks what is it ? Seriously pork belly with ramen she never heard of ?  Overall food was ok but definitely will not go back for ramen!!!!!
author: Max C.

description: This place should have 5 stars for sure! I've been there about 8 or 9 times now and have gotten delivery once. Favorites are the seafood ramen, seafood okonomiyaki, takoyaki, and the chicken karaage. The latter two are on a great fried goodness $3 happy hour menu along with $3 beers. The geso ago (fried squid tentacles) are also stellar. Just great Japanese junk food all the way. Service is also spectacular and the chocolate fondue is...ugh...so delicious. I'm never disappointed with this place, there are so many options! I'd recommend it to anyone.
author: Tanya K.

description:
I am not extremely impressed with my Genki Ramen encounter.
I was recommended by a friend who told me their ramen is really good.

I had it for dinner. A pretty nice ramen house, actually more like Japanese tapas restaurant.
Nice ramen, nice broth, but I think it lacks specialty.
Most of their ramen, to me, taste like "supermie," an indonesian instant noodle brand. And for any Indo who is reading this, you know what I mean.

Softshell crab was okay and quite pricey.
I can't remember what else we ordered, but one thing I am sure, ordinary food.

I would say Genki Ramen is comparable to Daikokuya in Little Tokyo, LA.
Or maybe I'd say Daikokuya is slightly better than Genki Ramen.
author: Monic S.

description:
Genki.. Genki.. IM A FAN!!
wHAT can I say

M in LOVE with your curry
M in LOVE with your broth
M in LOVE with your enoki roll with beef
M in LOVE with your bathroom
last but not least,
M in LOVE your Server!! ROFL

with some roommates I came in for the first time on sunday couple hours before closing time. we were greeted by the enthusiastic server with a cute warm smile on her face! boy we felt welcomed already!
since it our first time trying out ramen (we were practically fed up with eating pho an  wonton soup 4 days in a row), we asked her opinions. she, friendly an patiently spent minutes going over almost the entire menu with us. didnt rush us to order immediately.
at first i assumed she was japanese american, she seemed to be fluent in both. talkative. I asked her if she was, an she laughed. apparently she got that a lot an no she isnt japon or chinese or korean, but rather indonesian! dang i dont even really know where that is. talking about geography!
 
ANYWAY lets get down to business!
since we basically clueless on what to order, we ended up letting her order everything she thinks top notch for us.
and here we go, we favored the curry chicken ramen, beef  roll, beef stew an some other stuffs.
I must say that am pleasantly surprised with the beef roll (with mushrooms). the curry was the best ive ever had in muh life (seriously)
i smooch on a friend's dish: the beef stew. that was unbelievably flavorful as well. we got some other stuffs that the names i seem to have forgotten. they have cocktails and happy hours which i have yet to try. 
their bath room is also nice that i thought to myself i have to write about it. yes im a guy an yes im a neat freak. the bathroom is clean cool an doesnt stink of human's urine! thats a major plus!
 
overall, im really impressed by the food an service. it wasnt that hard finding a parking spot since it was almost 10pm. we will definitely be going back. oh an i need to ask for her name.
boy how much i love being straight!
author: Richard K.

description: I came to San Francisco for my honeymoon and tried Genki Ramen. I ordered kabob of smelt and ox tonge, seafood okonomiyaki, and ramen. They are all delicious, best Japanese food I've ever had. The mango cocktail is very balance, really yummy. The lighting can be a little bit brighter, but other than that, I love the food here. Would come here again.
author: Phoebe O.

description: i'm only here when my friends drag me here, usually to satisfy ramen cravings in the late hour that can't be satisfied by katana ya (too far, too small) or suzu (closed).
author: Josie M.

description: Decent ramen and great for kids!  They have a very reasonable kids menu that includes two items, rice, and a Yakuit drink that all comes packaged nicely in a bento box.  It's rare to find a kids menu at a Japanese restaurant, so this has become a standby for us when we eat out.
author: Linda C.

description: I order the Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen with Kimchi on the side. Yummy, melts in your mouth! Comes with a hard boil egg which I like. So far, no complaints about the food. I'd come back for the Garlic Tenderous Rib Ramen especially on a cold day.
author: Men A.

description: Just went here with my fiance and a few friends, and absolutely loved the fact that they were open so late! I was surprised to find cold ramen on the menu, as I usually don't see those anywhere but japantown or LA.. I gave it a try, and we ended up just ordering another bowl of it because it was really good. It wasn't the best I've ever tasted-- (the sesame sauce that you're supposed to mix in was too soy-saucey) but the noodles were a really good texture & they cared to put a lot of vegetables in it. Fiance got the Chashu ramen, which was really delicious.. We finished all of it-- even the soup!
author: Jo S.

description: My first time coming here and my experience was okay. Food was pretty good and it was better than I expected it to be. When I came here, there was only 1 waiter and I don't know if it there is another one or not. But my friend walked in with an umbrella because it was raining outside. When you walked into the door, they had no place for you to place your umbrellas so she brought it to the table and hung it from a chair. The waiter soon walks over with a bucket telling us to put the umbrella into the bucket and then takes paper towel to clean the few drops of water form the umbrella. I felt she was pretty rude about it. Just the way she acted. When I ran out of hot tea, she would see it but wouldn't bother to refill it at all. The service was the main problem. Their cleanliness was also a problem to me. The table would be dirty as if it was wiped without care.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
The best thing about the ramen at Genki is the noodles. They are al dente, cooked to a "t" as they say. I can't stand soggy ramen noodles, but then who can I guess. I got the chicken karaage ramen and liked all the elements. The broth was nice if perhaps a little oily.

I also got the soft shell crab salad which I don't recommend. The batter was too thick and it seemed like I was simply eating batter.

The decor is pretty hipster and typically asian with multiple flat tvs on every wall displaying Japanese programs.
 
This place is pretty new and I'm sure they'll work out the kinks. Hopefully in a month or so I'll be able to bump it up a star.
author: riz n.

description:
The food isn't really "all-that," but it's decent. 

A great place for an inexpensive meal that's also hearty and filling. I'm giving it 2.5 stars.
author: J K.

description:
The ramen here is not good. That's all that matters.

The decor and service and location and hours are all nice and such, but that's just packaging as far as I'm concerned. The product is lacking.

Went here over the weekend and got the tempura ramen. First alarm goes off upon realization that there isn't a choice of bases (i.e. shoyu, miso, salt, etc.). Second alarm went off when I got my order.

The broth was bland at best. I dumped in a LOT of the chili pepper stuff. The noodles were as another reader said, much like instant noodles you eat in college. I've made better ramen from the fresh packets at Nijiya Market. 

The tempura was so overfried that none of us finished our portions. 

The place looks pretty new. I hadn't seen it before or heard much, so maybe they have some kinks to work out and they'll get better. If they ever got around to serving good Ramen, it'd do pretty well especially with a much better decor and service level than other places. 

Unfortunately, given that my primary concern with a ramen restaurant is the ramen, I don't see myself going back anytime soon if at all.
author: Mike C.

description:
The decor there was pretty modern and trendy especially with the numerous flat panel TVs on the walls, but that was pretty much the only nice thing about this restaurant. 

I'd have to say that the service and decent the first time I was there, but the second time our food took 25 - 30 minutes to come out and there weren't many customers so they weren't short staffed. Not to mention that they kept playing the same Japanese pop (Morning Musume if you know JPOP groups) over and over on those TVs which became quite annoying after the 4th or 5th repeat.

I had their chashu ramen which was decent, nothing special. The noodles tasted like they were pre-packaged and the soup wasn't as hearty as Tanpopo's.

All in all, it's a decent place if you prefer decor more than taste.
author: Felix T.

description:
Genki Ramen seems to have all the ramen basics with a millennium flare and great waitstaff. The ramen pairings are a bit odd -- Veggie Curry & ramen, for example -- but it tastes fantastic.

They have a bitchin' happy hour from 3-7 daily, plus they deliver. Their ambiance is cool and they have flatscreen TVs everywhere, so if you get bored with your date -- or you and your date are both into what's on TV -- you can look away.

Oh! And they play pretty good J-pop music.
author: Stephen M.

description:
Genki Ramen, related to Genki crepe, is very clean and has a nice decor.  Lots of flat screens to watch sports center and food network.

Their ramen does the trick. I had the chicken katsu curry which the broth was good.  Just add seven spice if you want some heat.

I've been looking for mabo for a while and they have it here.  I'll let you know how that pans out.
author: Po L.

description: Savory ramen, delicious yaki-soba and one of the best okonomiyaki in the city!
author: Cyndi H.

description: Some great dishes... quite a variety and very authentic - a good beer and sake offering as well! Spacious interior, not too big and yet not packed in or cramped either.
author: Carey C.

description: I have been in search of the perfect bowl of fresh ramen in the city.  You know...complex broth, fresh, perhaps hand made noodles---alas, after eating at Genki Ramen, I am still searching.  The ramen here will suffice, and is satisfying enough if you are in a hurry and not in the mood to drive down the peninsula for a really, really yummy bowl.  The broth is actually pretty good, but could use more complexity;  The texture of the noodles are fair, but I doubt that they were made on the premises.  That said, the noodles were cooked to a good consistency, not over done, not too firm, and the broth was fine.  You will not be disappointed, but you will not be bowled over by the noodles at Genki Ramen.
author: Ovenmittenkitten S.

description: Saturday night 945pm late dinner - SERVICE got a seat right away, but had to WAVE someone down to take our order....no refills on water.....and had to again WAVE someone down for our check....FOOD good, but not the best I've had. We ordered the chicken katsu curry ramen...pretty good....and the chicken okonomiyaki, but ive definitely have had better so not really worth the price. would i go back? well, it wouldn't be my first choice, but i probably would cuz their food is good and filling.
author: Cindy S.

description: Food was yummy, but service was disappointing. The ribs ramen had fall off the bone soft rib meat. I would order it again except the service was so slow and unfriendly, I don't think I'll go back again.
author: Julie P.

description:
The Chashu ramen is to die for!  I've only had this and appetizers.  Also, get it delivered via GrubHub.  That being said, we order it about once a week when it's cold out; every 2 weeks when it's warmer.  
Best ramen in town.
author: Joe J.

description:
My go to ramen place in SF...flavor and noodle texture are better than other places.

I dont have any specific recommendations for you. you are just going to have to experiment yourself, just like i did
author: A W.

description: It was just ok. An appetizer was forgotten, one server seemed grumpy, food was just ok, was told that there's a $8 cake cutting fee even though we only wanted 2 spoons for the kids to eat the individual sized cakes we brought, and they took my daughter's bowl before she was done eating. When I said something and looked over to the server who was holding the bowl, she said nothing (really, not even an apology??) as she had already stacked dirty soy sauce plates into it. Would I go back? The food was ok but being in a busy part of town, no, I wouldn't take the time to go back.
author: Amanda S.

description: Delicious ramen.  Not too oily.  I really like the curry ramen and the chashu, but my favorite has to be the spicy mabu tofu (with ground pork).  so spicy and delicious.    I also like their donburi dishes.
author: Sage S.

description: I've come to this place numerous times. It's seldomly packed. I really enjoy the variety of ramen they got at this place. Their food is always fresh and never disappointing. Will come back again for sure.
author: Ernie P.

description: Excellent Ramen, I'd say best this side of Osaka (nothing beats KinRyu there). Beats all the places I've tried in LA, which were my favorites before.  Had the garlic and "tenderous" beef rib with tonkatsu broth which was really unusual and delicious. The lunch special comes with a side for an extra $1 and mine, Chahan (pork fried rice), was really good.
author: Anthony B.

description: Cannot remember what we ordered, but it consisted of ramen, pancake and noodles  I believe. The food was decent, but not the best I've ever had. I expected a lot more from this place because I heard good things about it.
author: Liz T.

description: Our feast included a shrimp tempura appetizer (which included onion rings, carrot, and potato), kimchi ramen with roast pork, karage ramen, and a very tall beer. The meats were more delicious than the ramen. Unoffensive atmosphere with HD TVs galore.
author: Maximillian M.

description: One of my favorites ramen places in SF. Great broth and love the noodles also great place for kids. I wish they would open one in the mission so I didn't have to drive so far!
author: Peter M.

description: This is the second best chashu ramen I've had and I've been all over searching for good ramen. For me it's the second best to Daikokuya in LA. Nothing really comes close to that place but this would have to be second. I'll try Santa Ramen next. Genki rocks since it's near me and tasty :-)
author: McKay G.

description: So obviously not the best or most authentic ramen out there, but for the price (especially the lunch specials) you get a fair amount of food and tasty broth.  I go here when I'm hungover or just need a quick, cheap bite to eat.  Great during lunch time, and not packed at all.  Recommend if you want something fast, decent tasting, and relatively cheap.
author: Sean S.

description: One of my favorite places for delivery.  Here's what I alwways order: Curry tonkatsu; tofu salad, karaage; sometimes tempura.  Delivery always, always, always on time!
author: Keith K.

description:
Very mediocre Ramen. Yeah, I've experienced the good in Tokyo, but there's a lot of places in the city that are much better. Katana-Ya on Geary blows this place away, and it's not even that great. 

Still, gotta love the Japanese music videos on LCD TVs.
author: Chris M.

description:
After my foot massage, my friend Irv and I decided to get dinner at Genki Ramen. I rarely leave my neighborhood (TL Heights) so coming out to the Inner Richmond was a treat for me, almost like going to another city really.
Genki Ramen was about half full when we arrived, we were quickly seated and had to choose from the numerous choices on the menu. What I quickly discovered is this was not the typical Japanese restaurant that I frequent; Mifune in Japan Town and Kyoto on VanNess. I was in the mood for udon or soba noodle but only saw Ramen. Ok, so that just meant I had to open up my culinary mind and enjoy the culinary ride.

We started with the Chicken Yakisoba which is kind of like a Japanese Crepe only thicker and served hot on a pizza like skillet that comes with a little spatula to serve. For my first time having this dish I have to say it was my least favorite. I thought the dough/batter was too mushy like an undercooked pancake. The chicken was flavorless and the dried seaweed served on top as a garnish made it to "fishy" tasting. I'm glad I tried it but wasn't doing it for me. 
The next item was scallops in butter and garlic. I am not a fan of scallops but Irv and his friend from Germany seemed like them, lets just say none were left behind. I ordered the shitake mushroom served with soy sauce, three good sized mushrooms were served on a wooden pick, nicely cooked al dente'; I definitely like them.
Next we ordered grilled lamb chops served with a mint sauce, not mint jelly, there's a difference. These were grilled perfectly, moist, not gamey tasting and the mint sauce added that extra something special to the chops.
Our final dish and only because I needed some carbs was the Curry Beef Ramen. A healthy portion was brought to us with slices of beef, carrot, green onion, potato in a miso base. It tasted alright but I felt it needed some spice so when I asked our waitress for something to spice it up she brought me a bottle of Sri Racha sauce, anyone who loves spice has a bottle of this in their fridge like I do. Let me just say it did the trick and made this dish even better.
We did not order any drinks and our bill with tax and tip was just under $50 for three people which isn't too bad in my opinion.
I'd definitely come back the next time I venture out to the Inner Richmond.
author: David P.

description:
Perfect food for a cold day, we wandered in here yesterday when we were out running some errands.  We ordered two ramen bowls and a donburi off the lunch menu, which is a really good value considering the mound of food that you get for under $10.
The service was good, the food came out quickly, and it was tasty - will definitely be coming back.
author: Robyn S.

description: Got vegetarian curry over rice.  Thick like gravy.  Pretty filling for pretty cheap.  Demerit for the minimalist techno and crisp decor.  Couldn't stop eating and bobbing my head to the beat.
author: Michael C.

description: My friends frequent this place and I've joined them several times for a good bowl of ramen. SO good. I usually get the curry pork dish ramen bowl but I've also tried the kimchee bowl which was delicious as well. Service is good, food is good, ambiance is good. No complaints here.
author: Maricel B.

description:
Been here four times now - in the past two months. Ramens are solid: noodles just right, broth on the miso-y side rather than overpoweringly soy sauce (it's in there too). Pork slices in the chashumen have good texture and flavor.
The appetizer/small dishes are varied and good: spinach is 'al dente'  (hard to do consistently) Tofu salad had a nice mixture of tastes and textures. Potstickers/Gyoza were just alright - nice crunch, too much onion. Kara-age chicken cooked nicely - as someone else said, maybe too much salt.
The robatayaki side dishes could add up to a meal, my favorite was the beef & green onion rolls: usually this dish is soaked in teriyaki sauce; not here, the meat is tender and the sauce is tasty but muted.
On Sunday evenings they definately need an extra server!
author: Andrew S.

description:
Anyone that wants lunch ends up there with me, and I love the ramen. The broth is delicious, and is a fantastic milky color, and there's a lot of it along with the noodles.

I tend to ket the kaarage (deep fried chicken nuggets), which I let soak in the broth before eating.

Does have a happy hour
author: Kevin R.

description:
Although this place is not as good as Santa Ramen in San Mateo,  but this is still a great ramen restaurant in the Richmond District.  I had the Spicy Mabo Ramen and it was deliciously hot & spicey......loved it.    Great for winter day meals.  Also ordered some yakitori........excellent bacon/asparagus and grilled salmon on a stick.   Another "must" is the Chahan, which is the fried rice.

This place has a very trendy setting.......it makes you feel like in some lounge bar in Tokyo.  Great deals during the happy hour but their desserts are kind of pricey.  The lunch specials are the best deals.
author: Lawrence L.

description: Janki Rawmen is pretty good.  I supposidly had good rawmen in NYC from Ipuddo.  The broth at Ippudo was definitely better than Janki but the noodles weren't as good as janki in my opinion.  The chaseu rawmen is a solid 4 stars.  I would go back if parking ever becomes available.
author: Fatty A.

description: We came here because we didn't want to deal with finding parking at Katana-Ya. Turned out, the food is so-so. My ramen was pretty good actually- I had spicy mabo tofu... and it wasn't bad. But, my hubby's ramen which was chicken katsu curry.. was rather bland. It could have been better though. Overall, it was OK, not too bad... especially the ramen they have is fresh and chewy like ramen should be!
author: Daisy S.

description: Deeeelicious curry vegetarian ramen.  The broth has body and so much flavor, without being overpowering.  It's just a deeply comforting, satisfying dish.  Have a friend who ordered the "tenderous" rib ramen, but they used those disappointing short ribs that are more fat and gristly bone than meat.  Don't get that.  Get the curry vegetarian ramen.  Also the kimchee.
author: L. M.

description:
this is an update thats a must. 

after reading jeff t review, i remembered i have to update this. 

yes. it was bad before. yes they got better. 

and finally, they are pretty decent now. pretty damn decent. 

the last time i came here with a fellow yelper, we couldnt stop mentioning just HOW much better this place has gotten. 

you see, this is my usual, when im completely hungover and dont what to think nor bother with parking ramen spot. for some strange reason, on these early afternoons, i always seem to find parking in front, the place is generally empty and the food comes out fast. 

well as of late. not only this, but the ramen has been getting much better. 

*bumps up to four stars*
author: Euge L.

description: It has many different dishes beside ramen.  Ramen broth is not the best compare to Ramen only restaurant.
author: Charles C.

description:
What does this ABC know about ramen?  Not a whole lot.  I only recently started to like it, since the advent of Yelp.  After growing up on Top Ramen and Maruchan packaged ramen, I never knew what the big deal was.  The package stuff was good for the starving the college kid, but it's not fit for grownups.  Fortunately, I do know what flavors work for me.  I don't like an overly salted broth.  Too much salt and you lose points.  Too much MSG, and I may not be back.  Having sampled Katana-Ya, Halu, and John Hayato's ramen, I can honestly say that Genki's tonkatsu-based broth is delish and ranks up there.  I liked its full flavored velvety broth.  It had like a buttery flavor to it, with not as much MSG (I tasted it afterwards) as Katana-Ya. It was good.  The ramen itself was OK.  It was soft, but didn't have that chewy texture...kind of like having al dente pasta...to it.  The topper was choosing the beef brisket instead of the boiled chasu.  First off, chasu, or Chinese char sui, isn't boiled...it's bbq'd.   I had some of T's charsu ramen, but wasn't that impressed with it.  I was perfectly happy with the slices of brisket that topped my ramen.  The brisket itself had been slow cooked to tender perfection and there was some nice fat marbling in it.  Given this combo, the noodles were forgivable.

Genki Ramen has a pretty decent offering of Izakaya or tapas-like Japanese food.  Since we weren't too hungry, we chose to order the fried squid tentacles.  Usually, when I have fried calamari, I like it with some sort of tomato-based cocktail sauce.  This fried goodness didn't need any of that.  It was perfect on its own and it had me wanting more.

I'm surprised at the mediocre rating of Genki Ramen, as it seems like a really good place for a quick Japanese-style meal.  The décor was modern with warm dark wooden table/chairs and bright flat screen TVs.  The staff was excellent all-around.  They brought me a new set of chopsticks after seeing me drop my original pair.  They were on top of it and everything else.  Perhaps they've improved since they opened.  It's certainly worth a second look, which I will be doing again soon.
author: JeFF T.

description: Genki has stepped up their game. I guess with the rising popularity of ramen and ramen shops, they kinda had to. The menu has been updated and there's even a lunch menu too. But most impressive was that the ramen was much better than it was a few months ago.
author: Kevo M.

description: It's sleek, dark, modern and they have wide screen tv's (perfect for watching the Oscars). Parking is a bit hard as it is on a primo block of Geary.  Anyway, we ordered the seaweed salad, which was tasty. I was craving beef teriyaki and it came on a sizzling plate with a separate bowl of rice. We also had the yam tempura which was good, but not spectacular. The veggie curry noodles looked yummy and there were lots of veggies. I saw a few other tables get bowls of ramen which looked huge!! Definitely wanna come back and check out the ramen. Oh and they have happy hour from 4-7 everyday...
author: Natalie S.

description: Genki Ramen does the job ok in San Francisco.  Felt like eating ramen a few days ago so I came in since it was open.  I frequent genki crepes and i believe that this is a sister store.  It's very clean with modern furnishings and a few flat screen tv's for entertainment.  I got the charsiu ramen with the tonkatsu soup and for an extra dollar i got a few pieces of karage. They do have an extensive sake list for those who want a nice dink with their meal.  i think i'll try the spicy miso combination if i come here again.  the wait staff seemed nice.  i believe the bill came out to around 10 - 11 dollars.  Since it's cold these days, ramen is a good option for a nice hot meal!
author: LittleBird 8.

description:
LOVE the curry chicken katsu ramen here.  I honestly never get anything else.  Curry soup may sound a little weird, but trust me, it's the best.  They use japanese curry, which is pretty dissimilar from indian curry. The kimchi ramen and the garlic tenderous rib ramen are also good. Be warned, it's can be pretty salty, as ramen tends to be.   

Under the robatayak sectioni there's a lot of fried greasy business going on..which i'm not really a fan of...but I don't really know what robatayaki is so maybe that's how it's supposed to be.  

Anyway, great place to eat on fri and sat post drunken debauchery as they open till 1 am or for late night take out (they sepaeate all the ramen components so it doesnt get all mushy)
author: Laurene C.

description: Had the miso ramen, it was pretty good. Not the best I've had. They give Hi-chews after your meal! Service was good!
author: Chistopher T.

description: I am not a big ramen fan generally, but really enjoy Genki Ramen. I like the way they do not give you too much broth. That can really be overwhelming. I love the Shoga Niku ramen- the pork is delicious! I have also gotten Spicy Mabo tofu ramen. This was also yummy, but almost too spicy for me (and I like spicy) after a full bowl. The service is a little brusk though but I'll deal with it for the ramen.
author: Reena P.

description: Hmmm, felt rather trendy and overpriced.  I'm used to having ramen on side streets where dudes make it out of little pickup trucks in Japan.  I want a big ole bowl of noodle and pork loving.  I want ramen like in the movie tampopo.  I guess everything here was ok.  The gyoza was really good though.  Gyoza sauce was mediocre.  It was weird listening to a group that sounded like preteen nasal Japanese girls and the next song be some heavy metal Japanese head banging stuff.  The t.v.s are a nice touch but not everything that's said is subtitled so what's the point.  Especially if all the shows are panel shows where people are talking.  I didn't feel very genki here.
author: John B.

description:
clean cute kind of a modern style of ramen shops.

plays japanese mv while you eat

ramen is pretty good and so is the kaarage

i went in happy and came out happy so overall im happy!
author: phillip w.

description: I love ramen, and this place has some solid noodles and pretty damn tasty sauces.  Not the best in the city, but worth going for sure.  I really like this place though because the staff is super friendly, which makes for a great dining experience :)  Yay ramen!
author: Justin J.

description: Genki Ramen is like trendy sushi -- a little overpriced, not exactly authentic cuisine, and lots of music and other things to distract you from the average food.  The photo menu was a little cheesy and out of place and adds to the inauthenticity of the place.  My chasu ramen was pretty good (on the salty side though), as was the unagi tempura, but all in all, just average.
author: Mitzi C.

description: I only recently discovered that there were places that serve you the yummy ramen that I grew up on - not only that, but they add all the fixings too!  I only have one other place (santaramen) to compare this to, but I must say that, especially in this cold bone chilling weather, this place hits the spot!  I usually go w/ my dude after work, during happy hour and we get 2 of the $3 items on the happy hour menu, along w/ a bowl of ramen each.  It's cool cause there are always games playing on the flat screens hanging on the walls & they usually play the jams.  Whenever we've gone, it was pretty empty and we'd always talk about how this place should get a lot more traffic and business, which they probably do - but we wouldnt know cause we always go at the same time. I'd definitely recommend you folks to check it out if you like soup!
author: Christine T.

description: I went to this place when it was really cold on Sunday night. The Ramen definitely hit the spot. We got the curry Ramen with fried chicken and fried pork, it was delicious and fresh. They had a great happy hour beer selection and flat screen TVs covering the walls showing all the play off games. The portions are huge, so you'll definitely have left overs, or i suggest sharing an appetizer and a bowl of Ramen. Street parking is really convenient and they do offer delivery.
author: Samantha S.

description:
Cute & cozy place.

Baked Scallop - not bad and very buttery
Fried Tofu - YUM and too bad they only served 2 tofus rather than the usual 4
Seafood spring roll - DELICIOUS and MUST ORDER! Didn't care much for their wasabi-mayo, but filling inside was super YUMMY w/soft shell crab :)
Chasu Ramen - alright.  The ramen was cooked perfectly but too bad their soup base was not.  It was missing the countless hours of bold flavor and the chasu was bland.

Will return one or 2 more times to try other items before marking a huge X on this place :)
author: Katy N.

description: I am giving this place a 3.5 star. I've been there three times now, all at different time of day. I found that during 3 pm to 5 pm is when I had the best bowl of ramen...The other two visits were later in the evening, and during lunch rush. And it was just ok. I really think they need to work on consistency. The service was quick and very friendly.
author: L K.

description: Genki Ramen is a good place to come for a decent priced bowl of hot Ramen. My friend and I started out with the shrimp tempura, which was nothing special. Though it was deep fried, so I'm not going to complain too much. I ordered the veggie curry noodle Ramen, at her recommendation. Though the noodles were not homemade (I'm assuming), the broth was tasty- not too salty and the perfect hints of curry. I also enjoyed the carrots, potatoes, and onions mixed in. The portion was more than enough! Service was warm, welcoming, and quick.
author: Laura D.

description: I came here for lunch with my boyfriend because the Genki Crepe was so good that I thought this place should be too and I'm glad I'm not wrong. My boyfriend ordered the Seafood Yakisoba while I got the Sumo Okonomiyaki. Both was delicious but if you don't like oily food, I wouldn't recommend this. The Okonomiyaki takes a longer time to make but it was worth the wait. I also got the Creme Brulee for desert and it was DELICIOUS. I loved it. I ask if I could order it to go but I couldn't. The total for our bill was a little more than $25 which I thought was a good deal considering 2 meals, a drink(Ramune) and desert. The service was pretty good and the designs of the place is nice.
author: Audrey M.

description: It seems like a great concept and setup, but the meal doesn't deliver. I had the seafood ramen. The ramen noodles are real, but the broth screams "I can from a vacuum-packed foil envelope." I actually think I've had better ramen bowls from the japanese market, the ones you just add hot water to. I added the chicken karaage for a $1. Bad investment. They were deep fried hockey pucks, over-fried with no flavor. The decor has a trendy Japanese feel with several plasma TVs. Everything seemed to be specially made for this place. The seats even had "Genki" chisled into the seat back. All in all, this place relies too much on gimmick and not enough on content.
author: Al L.

description: Ordered delivery from here a few nights ago since they're a new addition to delivery.com and was I ever disappointed that I did.  I am by far NOT a picky eater, but I had to throw most of the food away it was so nasty.  The fried tofo was cold, mushy, and horribly flavored, the takoyaki was a greasy soggy deep fried mess (yes, they deep fry the takoyaki), and the "spicy yakisoba" was edible, but nothing worth getting again for sure.  I'll give them credit for being really fast on the delivery and giving you a little tote bag with your order, but the fastest delivery in the world is no good if the food they bring you isn't edible.
author: Joshua W.

description: When you have a place named Genki Ramen, wouldn't you expect the star of the show be the Ramen?!?! I should have known by looking at the menu that the ramen would not be good as they have too many options on the menu.  the noodles and soup base is NG (NO GOOD).  taste like it's prepackaged stuff... if that's the case, i can just buy it at the japanese super market rather than paying 8 bucks a bowl! the gyoza is even worse... the wrapping of it is sloppy and it just falls apart... NG!  I would definitely not go to this place for the ramen... the only good point of this place is the $3 beer during happy hour from 3-7PM.  other than that, this is just another regular chinese owned japanese restaurant that doesn't stand out in my book.
author: Kelly H.

description: Genki Ramen has a pretty big menu. We had ramen and an order of the baked scallops.  I wanted to try something besides my usual basic soba and chicken, so I had Curry Chicken Katsu - deep fried chicken fillet, potato, carrot with curry sauce in tonkatsu base ($8.50). As it turns out, I don't really care for fried battered stuff in my soup. My friend had a much simpler ramen (I can't remember which one now), and I liked it much better, all and all I think Genki Ramen is A-OK.
author: J F.

description:
i would stick to the dessert place (Genki) FOR SURE!

their 10 or so plasma tvs around the restaurant seems to be more appealing to me than the food. i had the shrimp tempura ramen that only came with 2 pieces of tempura. it was just alright, not too thrilling or anything to come back for.
author: mae e.

description: When you have a ramen craving and it's late, you're not sure what's open but you know Genki is, then just go. It's decent and satisfying and they have lots of good nibbles to have with your ramen. I've had much better, but I've also had much worse. Their noodles are cooked just right and the broth isn't bland. Any tips on the best ramen houses in the city are much appreciated!
author: Abby Z.

description: OMG! If you are a vegetarian seriously this place rocks! Ordered the potato croquettes (i mean seriously how can ANYONE not like fried potato perfectly cooked) served with yummy sauce- add a Sapporo to wash it down and u have a winner! I ordered the curry potato ramen in vegetarian broth and added some srircha ( love spicy) and i was on cloud 9. Everything was perfectly cooked, delicious flavor, fried tofu with potatoes and veggies and super fresh ramen! The perfect meal and I will definitely be back. All you vegetarian folks, this place has a TON of options! Next time I'm going to try the vegetarian pancake thing....can't wait to go back..oh btw, we made it for happy hour so the croquettes and beers were $3/each. The service, ambiance and food made this place a WINNER :)
author: sue c.

description:
**my original rating was 4 stars, but after having santa ramen and himawari in san mateo, i see that i was slightly jaded.  Sorry genki, you just got demoted to 3 stars...**


As LA ramen fanatics, my roommate and I have devoted our tastebuds and sensory organs to finding the best ramen in SF (and maybe the woooorrrlllddd).
Maybe it was the extreme withdrawal from LA ramen.  Maybe it was the disatisfaction from other SF ramen.  Whatever the case, Genki ramen answers where other SF ramens have failed to deliver.

While roommates were circling the area looking for parking, I had a good 15 minutes to admire the decor.  First impressions, Genki looks like a chain resturant with customized chairs, chopstick holders and the like.  Naturally, I assumed the food would be typical franchise food, comparable to Ajisen...

The menu is extensive with many ramens i have never seen, including a seafood version (new to me).  As a first timer, I went with the original Chasu ramen...

Dominus Ramenus Points:
+ very modern look, gives it an upscale-y type feel (entire place is newly renovated)
+ great staff was helpful and service was speedy
+ actual ramen noodles were good, not fantastic, but def above par
+ soup base was very tasty and the entire bowl's temperature was perfect (can eat with soup without scalding your mouth)
+ toppings plentiful, more than just 2 slices of chasu
+ chasu had good ratio of fat to meat so that it was tender and delicious and at the same time didnt make you feel like you were an alaskan sucking down whale blubber
+ option of spicy oil to add at own discretion
+ very spacious seating!!!
+ tvs to watch while you wait
+ the kitchen is open to public to view, so we can watch the masters at work
+ the chefs all looked old and japanese (= authenticity in my book!)
+ you get your own pot of tea, to refill at own leisure (plus it came right when i sat down)
+ portions are generous
+ they DELIVER!!!
+ give little japanese dessert hard candies
+ cool sink in the men's bathroom

- parking may be a hassle as that Clement area is...popular...during dinner
- according to another yelper, you must order extra noodle at beginning...
- ramen may be slightly salty and has aura of mass production when compared to a hole in the wall ramen shop

Overall
I will definitely come back when I'm craving some ramen, and am not on an adventure to try out other ramen.  Heck, I'll probably have them deliver tonight!
author: Dominus S.

description:
I don't know how to say this, but I was totally disappointed.  I wasn't expecting Santa Ramen but com'on!!  

We ordered the chicken kaarage ramen with a side of chashu fried rice (extra $1), seafood yakisoba, and spicy sausage okinomiyaki.  The presentation was absolutely lovely on all 3 dishes.  The portions looked so-so for the price.  But it went completely downhill once I took my first bite.  The soup base was blah.  Nothing fancy nothing special nothing to it.  It tasted similar to my ultimate favorite packaged ramen soup base.  The yakisoba tasted blander than the yakisoba prepacked stuff you find in any Asian market!!  The okinomiyaki was the worse.  It was nothing but batter.  I don't think I had more than 8 THIN slices of spicy sausage total.

I would give it 2 stars but the waitress, who was completely by herself, was on top of her service game.  Only until the very very end did it get busy and she forgot about our water refill and check.

We're definitely not going back.

Which ramen place next honey?!
author: Angie C.

description: I didn't expect a nice, modern, clean space with good service, but that's what I got in addition to some very tasty chicken katsu ramen in curry broth.  Generous portion, deeply flavorful broth.  A good value too at $8 tax incl.  They also seem to have some good happy hour deals if that's your thing.  I will be back for sure.
author: Al K.

description:
girlfriend wanted to try this place, so we happy obliged seeing that the interior is new, hip, trendy and reminds me of some gen-Y- targeted restaurants in hong kong. i should have known that its also a recipe for disaster. 
we were the oldest patrons in the restaurant! the others were all high-school-looking kids who probably thought they were so cool to be seen at genki ramen. 
we ordered the agedashi tofu (deep fried tofu) which looked good in the photo menu.. when the actual dish arrived, it was 1/3 the size shown in the photo. the vegetable ramen was bland and consisted more vegetables than soup.
the only dish i actually enjoyed was the seafood okonomiyaki (omlette/pancake) because not that many places serve okonomiyaki and it reminded me of Japan.

**UPDATE** changed from 2-stars to 4-stars. Came here w/ the bf to try their chasu ramen and the soup base was very tasty and flavorful. Therefore I only recommend the chasu ramen and okonomiyaki.
author: Nancie T.

description: Genki Ramen is the best ramen I've ever had.  Admittedly, I haven't gone to Japan nor do I order it at nice Japanese restaurants, so I don't' have much of a comparison point.  I love that the soup base is clean and simple tasting.  If I order the chicken karaage or tempura ramen, I ask to have it on the side (so to not taint the flavor of the soup), and the staff don't look at my funny for my strange request.  The bowl of ramen is plenty to get me full for lunch or dinner.  The venue is sorta ill lit, so it lends itself more to an evening or late night eatery, but it's clean and service is quick.
author: Marie B.

description:
Since I discovered this place (which is about 3 weeks ago), I've paid tribute to them for about 6 times now. Perhaps it's the lack of ramen places in SF, but I simply adore this restaurant! The ramen's great, okonomiyaki rocks, and the price is decent. 

I didn't like their chicken popcorn appetizer (not the karaage). Other than that, tis all gravy. 

Oh oh! I like how they have Sapporo and Sierra on draft.
author: Tracy P.

description:
got here and there was plenty of seating.

got the chasu ramen. pretty solid ramen, nothing too amazing. redeemed the yelp check-in deal for some free edamame. yummy bonus. my only gripe is the service. the place was pretty empty yet we were still rushed. seriously? not okay.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
NUMMY: I had just returned home from the gym and after a 1.25 mi. run, a 1 hour TRX class focusing on chest and quads, and 30 min. on the StairMaster, I was starving.  I planned on cooking but with my kitchen sink broken until the next morning, I opted to order some Japanese food rather than try to make stuffed crab and sauteed kale.  If I'm going to eat a meal outside of my home, my number one priority: dine out somewhere you have never eaten.  Hence, I  had some food delivered from Genki Ramen (GR) via eat24hours.com.  The restaurant has a 15 dollar minimum charge for delivery.  Boo!  However, after selecting what I wanted from the menu, my total was 16 bucks and some change.  Not having to order tomorrow's lunch in order to make the delivery minimum: PRICELESS!  Delivery ETA: 30 minutes to an hour.  Should I have a spoonful of soy peanut butter and jam while I wait - my stomach is giving my liver the hungry eye.  Thank god for my friend Sahar who entertained me until delivery guy rang my door bell in what felt like less than 30 minutes: FABULOUS!  When I go to the door the guy held a cute little reusable GR bag that stated "Got Ramen?"  I signed for the bill and held my hands out expecting him to unload the food in my waiting hands.  When he handed me the reusable bag with my dinner and walked away I was already having premonitions of my future trips to Trader Joe's with my "Got Ramen?" bag.  

Dinner is Served! (with subtitles):

wakame salad (seasoned seaweed salad): not much to botch up here - seaweed and seasonings.  It wasn't the best seaweed salad I've ever had, but I can't even name the best seaweed salad I've ever had and I've had a lot of seaweed salad.  The seaweed was good.  I added some amino acids (great soy sauce substitute - see Rainbow Grocer) and red chili flakes to the salad - SO NECESSARY!  NUMMY!

unagi tempura (deep fried sea eel in tempura batter, served with tempura sauce)  My second priority after finding a restaurant that I have never dined at: try any thing on the menu I have never had in my dining experiences.  I love2love unagi, but I've never had unagi tempura.  The unagi tempura was a bit fishy in taste like fried oysters and I assumed they would barbecue the eel before tempura-ing it.  I assumed wrong.  However, with the tempura sauce and a squeeze of the accompanying lemon wedge: NUMMY!

Grilled Onigiri (charcoal grilled sea-eel rice ball):  I **heart** rice balls!     (Shut it and get my mind outta the gutter!)  Cooking the rice ball on charcoal grill rather than the traditional way (steaming), was inventive.  I actually thought the rice ball was burned until I took a bite, followed by 4 -5 consecutive bites that did a David Blaine on the rice ball in less than 5 minutes.  After the first bite the rice ball fell apart and the eel came tumbling out, so some one at GR needs to re-enroll in rice ball 101.  Despite the aforementioned, the rice ball was bomb and the sweet and salty sauce the rice was soaked in gave the whole rice ball a wonderful flavor that accented its charcoal preparation.

GR - I got your ramen!  Their definitely on my do over list.  I have to try the Ox tongue!
author: Eric J.

description: Not bad, but not Japanese.  I feel like the authenticity of the Ramen and food is not there at Genki.  However, overall the food is not bad.  Especially for the price you pay.  The servers are friendly, but the atmosphere is strange.  They try to get people to go in like a lounge/drink club atmosphere on weekends, but there just aren't enough people or music or ambiance in general to do so.  I'd rather they make it a home style restaurant, something more genuine.  Having said that, my favorite Ramen is actually the ma-po Tofu Ramen, which is Chinese style tofu put into the Ramen broth.  Worth a try if your in the area, but nothing to rave about.
author: Cory C.

description: Came here late night, like 1AM for a late, late dinner. The food was pretty good, maybe because we were starving by that time. But yeah, service was pretty quick, and I loved the ambiance, very modern. I also loved the bathroom, very nice bathroom. And there were several TVs plastered on the walls. Overall, four stars because we were starving and they served us food at a late time and in a quick manner.
author: Audrey T.

description: The only reason i came here, was because i found out they serve takoyaki. Also i was craving for some ramen so this place was an obvious choice to go. I got the seafood ramen, along with takoyaki and the karage chicken. The ramen was ok. It was just blown away by the takoyaki. The chicken was really good too, same for service. The waitress was really nice, i forgot my item there and they held it for me. When i came back to retrieve it....going back 100%
author: Terry S.

description:
this place is cute....I give it a 3-star because I know I have to come back to try more....came here tonight real quick for a quick fix...I just needed a snack and a lil sugar rush....so I got the shumai dumplings & creme brulee (YUMMY i know...separately of course). The waitress was really nice...it was really close to closing time on a Sat night. 

Update to come I'm sure of it once I try more food
author: Dessa R.

description:
we decided to stop by here after many hours at union square. located right on geary street so its not hard to miss. first thing i noticed was the amazing decor. i love the style of vibe of the place. it was fairly crowded but we were able to be seated right away. 

the waitresses were really nice and it actually seemed like they were japanese so that was cool. the food also came out within 10-15 min so that was also a pleasant surprise. 
i tried out the garlic tenerous rib ramen and the noodle with meat sauce for main course. the tonkatsu soup on the ribs ramen was AMAZING i couldnt get enough of it. the noodle with meat sauce was ehh tasted like chinese. it was good but id rather stick with a ramen next time. the unagi tempura was NICE. soo crispy and tasty. the eel tasted very fresh. we also ordered the deep fried oysters which looked sooo goood, BUT my cousins ate them all so i was like whatever haha. i would definately come back for some hot ramen soup on a rainy day
author: Dennis C.

description: Great place for lunch.  Quite possibly the best Ramen in SF.  The ramen combo can be had for less than $10 and is very tasty and filling.  Great value.  I've been eating here quite often.
author: Food N.

description: How interesting..... such a wide arrange of ratings for this place. Well.... I didn't have that great of an experience at this place. The service was not so great... slow and when she finally came to our table, she was so impatient. The soup for the ramen was average, nothing to brag about.
author: carebear l.

description:
when i crave ramen...and want it......and not travel far.......i come hereee. i ate here like twice before, and haven't in a long time. 

so me and my friend decided to come here after a long shopping day. We both ordered some kind of kasu ramen, takoyaki, and samurai wings.
the noodles came before the appetizers. LOL after eating at santa ramen, i realized they didn't give u much...no seaweed, mushrooms...any lil thing.
the noodles are how i like it, not soggy, but the soup base...tasted like...the packaged kind...X___x
but wateverrr, i wanted ramen....the takoyaki was good, wings were okay......
nice atmosphere, really pretty settings, large tvs, but okay food. we ate most of our food cuz we were hungry...but yuppp its an aite place, tried their other stuff, and it was okay too
author: Christine M.

description: If I wanted to have a seizure w/ ramen I'd come here again but, I'd rather just have something that tastes good. Skip it and head to Genki on clement for crepes...
author: Lauren D.

description: One of my favorite ramen spots in SF.  I've had the miso ramen and the katsu curry ramen.  I am originally from japan and am a big fan of katsu curry.  Never have I seen it as part of a ramen dish.  It suprisingly works pretty well.  I'm not saying it's a perfect fit (the katsu has a tendency to get a little soggy) but i would rate it a 8 out of 10.  What really shines here is the okonomiyaki.  The seafood okonomiyaki is excellent and a must have.
author: Tony S.

description: worst service EVER.  we came in late. they made us pay before we were done eating.  they turned off the music, sent the workers home, and stared at us until we left.  and we were only there for less than an hour tops.  their food might have been good and they have good portions with their ramen.  but service was seriously the worst service i've ever had in my life.
author: Angelica T.

description: I've been ordering delivery from them for a long time and with certainty i can say they always 'deliver'. They're ramen's are great but not the best (much better if you eat at the spot and not delivered obviously). I always get the fried rices they're quite dandy (seafood, salmon, pork.) They're robatayaki are good but a bit pricey. Everything else is decent. Overall this place is great for some filling japanese food.
author: Emier A.

description:
There are cheaper ramen houses in the city. They might offer you rubbery Costco gyoza or assembly-line soup with a slab of cold, leathery meat.

Not here. Five or six slices of melt-in-your-mouth pork and solid noodles in a rich tonkotsu broth. High-quality, for about $8-9 per bowl.
author: Shahin S.

description: This place was decent. There was nothing remarkable about it so unless I'm already close-by, I probably won't be back anytime soon. I had the Curry Chicken Katsu which was tasty but not "incredible" or anything like that. I was a little disappointed in the very few tiny pieces of potato. Also, they have these cool TVs all over the place EXCEPT for the bar so I had rubberneck a bit to see the Cal/UCLA game. They could use some little pictures of the food on the menu too.
author: Brian W.

description:
Been hearing about this place for a minute, I actually missed it walking by there, twice. Admittedly I was distracted and always kinda out of it. I went there for lunch

The decor is kinda nice, I'm surprised the staff is Cantonese.. maybe that'd explain the food.. dunno if the owner/kitchen is Japanese

Tried the cha-shu ramen. The egg (whoa so small) was overcooked although it had a nice orange color, I hate bamboo. The noodles are sorta unremarkable and I hate how they slice the meat so thin. It feels so cheap though other ramen houses do that also. What a lame tradition. The bright spot is the broth, actually quite good. Alas, the whole bowl can't really go on broth alone

For an extra $1 you can have either gyozas, chicken kariage or a bowl of fried rice. I tried the chicken on people's recommendation. Just okay but it's nice to have more meat cuz there's really not enough

Total: $11

I'd try the curry pork cutlet ramen next time. Dinner with all the robotayaki items seems to be wassup
author: xo x.

description: Last month I came here for lunch w/ friends and finally tried the pork Okonomiyaki and it was excellent. Now I have to try the other 3 flavors.
author: Johnny H.

description: Yum, nice portion sizes for the prices. We went pretty early on a Sunday evening and it was not crowded yet.  I loved the seafood okonomiyaki.
author: Dale D.

description: I have to give 4 stars just for having a vegetarian based ramen (I always get the curry vegetable ramen).  It's also one of the few places that has salmon fried rice (which my honey likes).  Thank you, Genki, for veggie ramen soup base (and a variety of sake choices)!
author: Vanessa N.

description:
i find the positive reviews of this place very confusing. nothing we ordered was particularly good and it certainly didn't remind me of any ramen shop i've ever been to in japan.

to audition the place, i decided to get the chashu ramen -- that's pretty much the default food at a ramen shop, right? this was nothing like any of the hearty and delicious ramen i've had in the past. the broth was reminsicent of progresso canned soup. it was flat and lacked any sort of body. the noodles were mediocre. the chashu was OK, but how do you screw up delicious fatty pork? even for the US this was mediocre. for japan, it'd be a joke.

my friend got okonmiyaki. i was faintly amused by the idea of cheddar 'n' bacon okonmiyaki and joked that was was burger king okonomiyaki. well, that was sadly true. the ingredients weren't mixed into the pancake, the pancake itself was just undercooked dough. take off the savory toppings (which, to be fair, tasted good) and the okonomiyaki had more to do with aunt jemima than iron chef morimoto.

we also got a couple of robata skewers. i didn't try the corn on the cob (seriously, though, if they screwed that up it would catastrophic.) the asaparagus/bacon was covered in some sort of sauce that obscured the taste of the bacon. why would you put barbecue sauce on bacon?
